column2: LEAD: Riders of the N and R subway lines between Manhattan and Queens will face some trying weekends for the next month and a half as the Transit Authority halts service on sections of those lines for repair work, a spokesman for the agency said yesterday.

LEAD: IT is a meal for our times - providing at once a respite from frenzy even as it affords the opportunity for social tolerance. It is the picnic. And on this Day of Independence, there is perhaps no more appropriate way to celebrate.
LEAD: Snooky Lanson, a singing star of the popular 1950's television show ''Your Hit Parade,'' died on Monday at St. Thomas Hospital here. He was 76 years old.
LEAD: FOR many Americans, today is like a firecracker that fizzled in mid air.

LEAD: Seconds after Sergio Goycochea smothered Italy's last penalty shot, ecstatic Argentines poured into the streets in the capital city today to celebrate Argentina's advance to the World Cup soccer final.
LEAD: Israel's Ambassador to Egypt, Shimon Shamir, resigned today, saying he could not reconcile his political views with those of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's new right-wing Government.
LEAD: International 2-8

LEAD: President Bush's proposal to define NATO's nuclear arms as ''weapons of last resort'' and to make other changes in alliance strategy has stirred considerable concern in some Western European capitals, but no outright opposition.
LEAD: Companies

LEAD: The eagerness shown recently by many bankers to restructure the debt of RJR Nabisco Inc. has put the spotlight on an unusual feature of the leveraged buyout phenomenon: banks that own equity stakes in their borrowers.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3* Audiovox Corp. (AMEX) Qtr to May 31 1990 1989 Sales 82,201,000 75,269,000 Net inc 603,000 30,000 Share earns .07 - 6mo sales 150,433,000 138,234,000 Net inc 688,000 b1,399,000 Share earns .08 - b-Net loss The company said the sales increase in the quarter was a result of increases in cellular and security product sales.
LEAD: ANDREW LLOYD WEBBER says that his marriage to SARAH BRIGHTMAN is over. And that he has a new close friend.
LEAD: With his white jogging shoes padding on the pavement, Fernando Pantigoso loped alongside a slowing car and offered the day's special - the United States dollar at 65,000 intis.

LEAD: Cheryl Quaye, station manager for the Fresh Air Fund, surveyed the swarm of children at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan yesterday morning and decided the time had come. Lifting her bullhorn, she bellowed, ''Are you ready to go?''
LEAD: When James B. Holderman took over as president of the University of South Carolina in 1977, the school was considered by many as a ''good party school'' but very little else.
LEAD: Riddick Bowe, the undefeated heavyweight (17-0, 15 knockouts), will headline his first network television card for CBS on Sunday against Art Tucker in Atlantic City.
LEAD: Bryan Trottier, the last active member of all four of the Islanders' Stanley Cup championship teams, yesterday received his release from Bill Torrey, the team's general manager.

LEAD: The first operational quarter for Donald J. Trump's Taj Mahal Casino Resort, which opened in April, showed a pattern of earnings roughly in line with Atlantic City trends, analysts said yesterday.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from speeches by Yegor K. Ligachev, Vladimir A. Kryuchkov and Eduard A. Shevardnadze today and Aleksandr N. Yakovlev on Monday to the Soviet Communist Party congress, as translated by The New York Times: Yegor K. Ligachev Politbury Member

LEAD: An article in the Sports section on Sunday about the baseball commissioner's investigation of George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, misstated the date of A. Bartlett Giamatti's death. Mr. Giamatti, who preceded Fay Vincent as commissioner, died on Sept. 1, 1989.

LEAD: Any comprehensive tour of the VideoTown Laundrette on the West Side of Manhattan would begin with the copying machine, just to the left of the front door. It's five cents a page. Then come the videotapes, between 6,000 and 7,000 of them. There are Raisinets and Goobers in bins and a popcorn machine on the counter.

LEAD: Dow Jones Information Services and Datatimes have agreed to a joint marketing and service deal to combine their electronic libraries, the two companies anounced on Monday. Datatimes is a subsidiary of the Oklahoma Publishing Company, with a minority share owned by Dow Jones & Company. The arrangement will allow researchers to search electronically through the computerized files of 640 newspapers, magazines, news services and financial data sources.
LEAD: Dr. John Ellis, New Jersey's new Education Commissioner, appealed today to all state residents to help find creative solutions to problems facing the state's troubled urban schools.

LEAD: Perhaps discouraged by the San Diego Padres' slump, in which the team has lost 14 of its last 19 games, Jack McKeon, the club's manager and vice president of baseball operations, said yesterday that he would like to give up his job in the dugout and concentrate on operational duties.

LEAD: The lockout that was the plague and scourge of America during much of the month of March seems to have receded into the mists of history, like the Peloponnesian War. At most, a reference to it is occasionally made.

LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that a final deal may be at hand for the Government to sell 120 of the company's F-18 fighter jets to South Korea. The deal would be worth about $2.7 billion to McDonnell Douglas, which builds the attack fighter for the U.S. Navy and also provides it to several foreign nations.

LEAD: Mortimer H. Gold, a philanthropist who produced variety shows, circuses, carnivals and athletic events to benefit charitable organizations in Queens, died yesterday at Jamaica Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Jamaica Estates. He died after a stroke, his family said.
LEAD: Forty-eight days after the closest such contest in modern history, Ben Nelson, an Omaha lawyer, has been declared the winner of the Democratic primary for governor of Nebraska.

LEAD: One year after the lively song ''Lambada'' and the sensual dance of the same name arrived from Brazil and took first France and then Europe by storm, France's society of composers has ruled that the song is in fact Bolivian.
LEAD: Because of holiday production requirements, The Times is printed today in two sections. The Living Section begins on page 37 and Business Day on page 43.

LEAD: Liberian Rebels Advance Liberian rebels reportedly moved toward the center of the capital in street-to-street fighting against Government troops. Page 3. Unrest Reported in Albania Dozens of Albanians are reported to have taken refuge in foreign embassies, and troops are said to have opened fire to quell disorders.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3* IEH Corp. Year to March 31 1990 1989 Revenue 8,983,544 10,786,436 Net loss b1,515,634 c52,308 Share earns - .02 b-Included a pre-tax charge of $759,167 from write-down of inventories. c-Net income and included a pre-tax charge of $27,000 from settlement of litigation.

LEAD: A primer on Leary's difficult season: 10 losses when the night began, 6 defeats in his last 7 starting assignments and continued nonsupport by his teammates, who totaled 20 runs in his 3 victories but a mere 24 in his losses.

LEAD: Hot lava has gushed from Mount Vesuvius and earthquakes have rattled the city and foreign navies have sailed into the harbor, and now this city will be known throughout Italy for a sporting version of disaster: the defeat of the Italian national soccer team.

LEAD: For the first time, oil companies operating in the United States are spending more to look for oil abroad than at home, and most of their production and reserves are outside the United States, Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm, said yesterday.

LEAD: In a decision that marked the end of an era embodied and romanticized by F. Scott Fitzgerald, the Supreme Court of New Jersey yesterday ordered the last two remaining male-only undergraduate clubs at Princeton University to begin admitting women.

LEAD: A man who went shopping for his wife's birthday last week bought her a shirt covered with stars and stripes - and marveled at social change. Not many years ago, Abbie Hoffman was arrested for wearing a shirt like that. Now the flag's bold graphics turn up everywhere, unchallenged.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3* Patten Corp. (NYSE) Qtr to April 1 1990 1989 Revenue 21,010,000 31,425,000 Net loss 9,832,000 c41,000 Yr rev 101,195,000 136,767,000 Net loss b12,894,000 c8,601,000 Share earns - .50 b-Included an accounting adjustment of $2,500,000, or 14 cents a share, from extinguishment of debt.
LEAD: The Saudi Interior Minister, Prince Nayef, said today that 1,426 Muslim pilgrims died in a stampede in a pedestrian tunnel linking this city with a tent camp for pilgrims.
LEAD: A front-page article on Monday about the economic strength of a unified Germany misidentified an international real estate advisory firm. It is Jones Lang Wootton.
LEAD: A WOMAN whose name means nothing in social circles reports:

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3* Johnson Products Co. Inc. (AMEX) Qtr to May 31 1990 1989 Sales 9,652,000 7,680,000 Net inc b759,000 c121,000 Share earns .19 .03 9mo sales 23,964,000 20,894,000 Net inc b1,387,000 c1,901,000 Share earns .35 .48 b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $277,000, or 7 cents a share for the quarter and $510,000, or 13 cents a share for the 9 months.

LEAD: Zina Garrison, on a diet of disappointment from the start of the year in which she had pegged herself as long overdue for a Grand Slam victory, earned a visit to her second Wimbledon semifinal today by outlasting Monica Seles, the French Open champion, 3-6, 6-3, 9-7.

LEAD: Nelson Mandela expressed optimism today about the prospects of narrowing his differences with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher over economic sanctions against South Africa, and backed off from comments that had suggested that Britain should negotiate with the Irish Republican Army.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3* Metro Airlines Inc. (OTC) Qtr to April 30 1990 1989 Revenue 55,118,000 34,438,000 Net loss 4,231,000 9,151,000 Shares outst 6,098,000 5,931,000 Yr rev 194,562,000 147,452,000 Net loss b19,504,000 c2,735,000 Shares outst 6,095,000 5,844,000
LEAD: Parliament voted overwhelmingly today to replace the Communist state emblem with Hungary's traditional coat of arms.
LEAD: Northwest Airlines is pursuing a possible buyout of Eastern Airlines and is scheduled to hold talks with Eastern union representatives, a union official said yesterday.

LEAD: After five months of fruitless contract talks, union leaders at The Daily News yesterday urged Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to back a state inquiry into their dispute with management, and top state officials said they would meet with both sides tomorrow to consider the idea.

LEAD: The president of a small military contractor based here was sentenced today to three years in prison and a $750,000 fine for his role in a 10-year scheme to avoid testing bolts that the company manufactured for use on military aircraft.

LEAD: After blitzing their way through June with 21 victories in 28 games, the Mets made it two straight in July last night when they hammered the Houston Astros, 12-0. And they did it with a barrage of epic hitting that included four home runs, two of which banked against the scoreboard in remote right field.
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were off slightly for the week ended yesterday. It was the fifth consecutive drop.

LEAD: Dr. Gwendolyn Calvert Baker, elected yesterday as the new president of the New York City Board of Education, is an ardent champion of multicultural education, the idea that children can be taught to appreciate and respect the human coat of many colors. It is a subject that was bred in the bone.

LEAD: A new study in Africa by the World Health Organization has shown that a drug chewed as a wafer boosted the number of immune cells in a small number of AIDS patients whose immune cells had been damaged by the AIDS virus, an official of the international agency said yesterday.
LEAD: It's official. Manchester has been renamed Manchester-by-the-Sea, to distinguish it from the four other New England Manchesters and 18 other Manchesters in the United States.

LEAD: The prosecutor called the shooting a near-perfect crime, the well-planned act of a man obsessed with his neighbor's loud stereo, convinced of racism where there was none and determined to resolve himself what the police, the courts and others would not.

LEAD: Brenda Lansdown, a retired professor of education who introduced new teaching methods in China, died on Sunday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. She was 86 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass. The cause of death was pneumonia, said Harriet Harvey, a friend.

LEAD: THE problem: The earnings gap between those who went to college and those who did not has never been greater. Yet tuition subsidies for all but the poorest students have become scarcer than Taittinger in Teheran. Loans at market-rate interest are generally available to students who need them. But not surprisingly, the children of financially pressed parents are loath to begin their working lives burdened with tens of thousands of dollars in education debts.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: With sales sluggish, the Big Three domestic auto makers recently announced midyear price increases, a move that illustrates the curious economic logic that governs the pricing strategy in Detroit these days.

LEAD: Their swagger has been unmistakable throughout the World Cup. Since the final rounds of the tournament began last month, West Germany's players have talked, acted and performed as if they always knew they would advance at least this far, to the semifinals.

LEAD: FOR years Americans have been popping vitamin pills as if they were lemon drops: a little vitamin A because they don't eat enough yellow vegetables; some vitamin C in place of orange juice in the morning; a vitamin B12 pill for the vegetarian.

LEAD: The problem with being an author who writes in Dutch, as Hugo Claus does, is that parts of the world outside the Netherlands and Belgium may never find out you exist, let alone ever read your books.

LEAD: Col. Thomas H. Johnson, director of the Science Research Laboratory at the United States Military Academy, died on June 26 at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 46 years old and lived in Cornwall-on-Hudson, N.Y. The academy reported that he died of lymphoma.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: Liberian rebel forces were reported to be advancing slowly toward downtown Monrovia from the suburbs of the Liberian capital today in street-to-street fighting against Government forces. A senior Bush Administration official said the Liberian President, Samuel K. Doe, was ''in deep trouble right now.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3* Carolina Freight Corp. (NYSE) Qtr to June 16 1990 1989 Revenue 166,674,312 157,437,908 Net loss 911,571 b2,090,666 Share earns - .31 Shares outst 6,561,789 6,572,576 6mo rev 327,821,718 306,923,356 Net inc 65,624 3,610,798 Share earns - .54 Shares outst 6,560,591 6,577,540

LEAD: Japan today rejected as premature a Soviet proposal to share ownership of Soviet-held islands in the Kurile chain, which Japan claims. The issue is a longstanding sore point that has prevented the Soviet Union and Japan from signing a peace treaty to formally end World War II. Earlier this week, a political commentator, Vsevolod Ovchinnikov, wrote in Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, that the dispute over the islands could be settled if Tokyo and Moscow agreed to place the islands under United Nations trusteeship.

LEAD: The videotape of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. smoking what prosecutors say is crack in a hotel room provides several openings for his lawyers to raise an entrapment defense, lawyers and legal scholars say. But while it may be easy to raise the issue, it will be extremely difficult for Mr. Barry's lawyers to succeed in making their case.

LEAD: The third trial in the Bensonhurst racial killing ended yesterday when jurors acquitted a young white man of intentional murder but could not reach a verdict on a second murder charge and on a riot charge.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3* Western Microwave Inc. (OTC) Qtr to April 1 1990 1989 Sales 2,275,000 2,502,000 Net loss 621,000 225,000 Shares outst 1,405,000 1,431,000 6mo sales 5,059,000 5,178,000 Net loss 311,000 214,000 Shares outst 1,405,000 1,479,000

LEAD: FIREWORKS 9:20 P.M. on the East River. F.D.R. Drive will be closed for viewing from 14th to 42d Street form 7 P.M. until after midnight. NEW YORK Government offices: Federal, state and minicipal offices closed. Post offices: Express mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue.

LEAD: A memorial concert for John Henry Faulk, the Southern humorist and radio personality, is to be held at 5:30 P.M. on Monday at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. In 1962, Mr. Faulk, who had a show on CBS radio, won a libel suit against Aware Inc., which was devoted to alerting broadcasters and advertisers about those in the entertainment industry it felt had ties to the Communist Party.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3* Bassett Furniture Industries Inc. (OTC) Qtr to May 31 1990 1989 Sales 114,474,000 119,109,000 Net inc 5,746,000 5,145,000 Share earns .71 .62 6mo sales 219,930,000 227,791,000 Net loss 969,000 b8,222,000 Share earns - .99

LEAD: Blacks are playing a more prominent role than ever in this year's Independence Day celebration, which comes as blacks seem to be experiencing a growing sense of participating in the nation's rituals and history.

LEAD: Concluding five days on the witness stand in the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., Rasheeda Moore today recanted earlier testimony that she had exceeded some instructions Federal agents gave her before the start of the undercover operation that resulted in the Mayor's arrest on charges of smoking crack.

LEAD: The Western Union Corporation, the financially troubled company that pioneered telegraph and telex services, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its telex, computer mail and computer data transmission services to A.T.&T. for $180 million.

LEAD: There was just one thing wrong with a commemorative cup sold to benefit the city's literacy program: the Mayor's name was misspelled. The cups marked the 10th anniversary celebration of Baltimore's redeveloped waterfront this week. They declared that proceeds would benefit ''the literacy initiative of Baltimore City's Mayor, Kurt L.

LEAD: The chance to compete at the Henley Royal Regatta continues to exert its attraction to American rowers, with the 30 entries from the United States representing the largest foreign contingent from the 17 nations competing at this year's regatta.

LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about the breakdown of safeguards in the savings and loan industry included one accounting firm erroneously in a list of firms that have been sued by the Government over their auditing of failed savings institutions. Coopers & Lybrand has not been sued by the Government.

LEAD: The sale of Stroh's brewery in Memphis to the Adolph Coors Company was made final in a deal under which Coors will make beer outside of Golden for the first time in its 117-year history. The Stroh Companies will continue to operate the 500-employee brewery until Sept. 1, when Coors will assume responsibility for operations.
LEAD: The first-half performance of Saks Fifth Avenue has fallen short of its own projections and those of its new owner, a confidential memorandum shows.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3* Selectronics Inc. Qtr to March 31 1990 1989 Sales 7,319,000 4,427,000 Net loss 2,724,000 2,058,000 Shares outst 36,135,014 35,340,946 Yr sales 32,905,000 21,581,000 Net loss 5,413,000 b45,000 Shares outst 35,473,290 17,423,568

LEAD: The United States is hoping that Moscow will quickly drop its opposition to the membership of a united Germany in NATO if the Western allies agree this week on a plan aimed at making the alliance less threatening to the Soviet Union, a senior Administration official said today.
LEAD: Kevin Tapani scattered seven hits in seven and one-third innings, outdueling Roger Clemens tonight as the Minnesota Twins beat the Boston Red Sox, 7-3.

LEAD: Coming up on Friday: the 50th anniversary of the Berkshire Music Center at the Tanglewood Festival. So it's memory time - memories not only of the beginnings of the Music Center but also of the festival itself.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3* Dataflex Corp. (OTC) Qtr to June 30 1990 1989 Revenue 18,500,000 17,602,000 Net inc 775,000 534,000 Share earns .22 .22 Shares outst 3,500,000 2,448,000
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: After 61 days in captivity in the Colombian jungle, Scott Heimdal has returned to the Illinois city that passed collection plates and held bake sales to raise $60,000 to free him.

LEAD: The conservative pillar of the Politburo, Yegor K. Ligachev, roused delegates to the nationwide congress of the Communist Party today by deploring the five years of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's rule as a period of wavering and ''blind radicalism.''

LEAD: Craig I. Fields, who was removed as director of the Defense Department's long-range research agency in April, will become the No. 2 executive and eventually the head of the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, a computer industry consortium in Austin, Tex.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Gustave Harrow, a lawyer and former assistant New York State Attorney General who was a leader in shaping art legislation, died on Saturday. He was 60 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.
LEAD: A 30-year-old Bronx woman was arrested last night and charged with second-degree murder in the death of her 22-month-old foster child, the police said.
LEAD: American Cheese

LEAD: More than half the nation's cities and towns expect spending to exceed revenue in the current budget year and two-thirds of the municipalities say budget problems are worse than a year ago, according to a survey released Monday.

LEAD: *3*** COMPANY REPORTS ** *3* Valley Industries (NYSE) Qtr to May 31 1990 1989 Sales 20,617,000 19,839,000 Net inc 23,000 bc5,854,000 6mo sales 36,763,000 36,273,000 Net loss 1,240,000 b7,295,000 b-Included a charge of $5,905,000 from writedown of assets.

LEAD: Any doubts about the supremacy of New York as a prime center for Hispanic theater may be swept away with the arrival tomorrow of a new, and second, theater festival dedicated to the art of Spanish-language stagecraft.

LEAD: Both Ivan Lendl and Brad Pearce have declared themselves on a mission to win Wimbledon, but beyond the fact that each recently became the father of a baby daughter, the resemblance between them ends right there.

LEAD: WHILE a microwave oven is great for summer main courses, when you are trying to avoid kitchen heat, it is also a cool way to prepare for one of the easiest, most informal ways of entertaining, the cocktail party. Despite the microwave oven's reputation as being good only for preparing small quantities, it can cook enough for large groups.
LEAD: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday superseded a Bronx school board after it failed to name a superintendent or acting superintendent.

LEAD: Chapman Shaw Root, a former chairman of the country's largest Coca-Cola bottling company, died on Monday at Emory Hospital in Atlanta. He was 65 years old and lived in Ormond Beach. The cause of death was not disclosed. Mr. Root inherited Associated Coca-Cola Bottlers, which had plants in Pennsylvania, Florida, New York and New Jersey, from his grandfather.
LEAD: Amy Ellen Alkoff and Dr. Mitchell Craig Chasin were married last evening at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club by Rabbi Philip M. Weinberger and Cantor David Shiff.

LEAD: While Mike Tyson was losing his heavyweight title to James (Buster) Douglas last February in Tokyo, Donald Trump and Don King, promoter of both fighters, were apparently agreeing that Trump would get the live-site rights to a Douglas-Tyson rematch at Convention Hall, which adjoins Trump Plaza, in Atlantic

LEAD: The Foreign Ministers of Iraq and Iran today held their first direct talks since their 1988 cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war. The talks could open the way to a summit meeting between Presidents Saddam Hussein of Iraq and Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran and the negotiation of a peace treaty to end 10 years of hostility.

LEAD: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 10.00 10.00 11.00 DISCOUNT RATE 7.00 7.00 7.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 8.31 8.34 N.A. 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 7.70 7.73 N.A. 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 7.59 7.60 N.A. 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 8.40 8.43 N.A. 30-YR.
LEAD: * CBS Records, New York, a unit of Sony Corp., named Marvin Cohn president of CBS Music Publishing.

LEAD: CALVIN KLEIN was admitted to New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center last night for observation and treatment of broken ribs and lacerations to the head after he fell from a horse, said MARY CIALONE, night administrator at the hospital. She said the fashion designer suffered the spill in the Hamptons and was flown from Long Island by helicopter.
LEAD: In riots here last week, residents of Mutendere Township, a dusty place of dirt roads and shabby housing, burned the flag of the nation's sole political party.
LEAD: * Intelligy Corp., to Goldberg Moser O'Neill Advertising, San Francisco, for the introduction of Wings, a collection of educational toys, games and activities for small children.

LEAD: It was to have been like thousands of other statues honoring local heroes that stand in public parks across the nation, a monument quickly transformed into a pigeon perch and another source of that eternal question of children: ''Who was that dude?''
LEAD: The lure, and the fear, of 1992 are continuing to drive the pace of mergers and acquisitions in Europe, and more and more they are opening doors that had been closed in the past.

LEAD: Nelson Mandela met with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for three hours today and said afterward that the two ''made progress,'' although they failed to agree on the use of economic sanctions and violence in ending apartheid.
LEAD: Nineteen people were injured tonight when an errant shell from the town's Fourth of July fireworks display shot into a crowd of 5,000 people, the authorities said.
LEAD: ELSIE VAN SAVAGE of Brunswick, Me., has hooked rugs with boats on them, or business logos, or favorite foods or images associated with special trips.

LEAD: An ambitious plan to deliver natural gas from Canada's abundant western reserves to six energy-hungry Northeastern states has pitted neighbor against neighbor and community against community, as well as leading to an uneasy coalition of environmentalists and domestic gas producers against the whole idea.

LEAD: It's called ''Frank, Liza and Sammy: The Ultimate Event.'' Actually, it's a tape of Frank Sinatra, Liza Minnelli and Sammy Davis Jr. in a 1989 concert in Detroit. The show, sponsored by a beer company, was part of a national tour. Ms. Minnelli had replaced Dean Martin in the early rounds. With the recent death of Mr.
LEAD: In the ''war room'' tucked inside a nondescript suite in a high-rise building here, volunteers staff a bank of telephones in front of a wall-size map.

LEAD: East Germans, long deprived of Western rock-and-roll, will get the chance to see the most enduring band of all, the ROLLING STONES. The group, which played to 80,000 people in the Olympic Stadium in West Berlin last month, will return to Germany in August for an extra concert on its world tour, this time in East Berlin.

LEAD: Innovation and unorthodoxy have long ruled at the Kaypro Corporation, reflected in the design of its personal computers and the style of its headquarters, a secluded compound near a beach, where employees munched health food from the company snack bar while they worked.
LEAD: Remembering Wright, 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue; 212-996-1100.
LEAD: Although this year's World Cup soccer champion will not be crowned until Sunday, wrangling has already begun over who will televise the 1994 World Cup tournament in the United States.

LEAD: Here's something we can all root for in the World Cup final on Sunday: the lighting system. If the fuses should happen to blow during a tie breaker at Olympic Stadium on Sunday night, we would all be treated to the spectacle of the biggest tournament in the world being decided by chance.

LEAD: George Washington never slept in Hendrick I. Lott's farmhouse. But after being routed in the Battle of Brooklyn Heights, remnants of his army that were not evacuated to Manhattan were said to have fled across Lott's farm.

LEAD: In the seven years that he was New York City's Parks Commissioner, HENRY J. STERN was noted for talking to trees and protecting the sex life of the dragonfly. Now, he will be a gadfly. The Citizens Union, the New York City watchdog organization that sometimes bites, has elected him its first fulltime president.
LEAD: As a candidate for President in 1988, Carlos Salinas de Gortari promised that he would modernize the Mexican economy and usher in an era of true democracy.
LEAD: Painting a Stone Fireplace Q. We recently purchased a 30-year-old house that has a large stone fireplace probably made of limestone. Is it possible to paint the fireplace front?

LEAD: The virtual evaporation of significant new construction projects in New York City is deeply hurting the architectural profession, forcing firms to lay off employees, cut their fees, diversify their practices and search for work in other cities and countries.
LEAD: The Pentagon is pressing its biggest land-buying drive since World War II, seeking to add nearly 4.5 million acres to its 25 million acres nationwide.

LEAD: An article on the Law page on Friday about efforts to limit certain First Amendment protections incorrectly described the status of a lawsuit over whether panhandling may be prohibited on the New York City subways. The suit is on appeal before the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, not the Supreme Court.

LEAD: AT ''Visions: A New Decade,'' an exhibition of 83 quilts at the Museum of San Diego History, there are quilts that depict trees of the Pacific Northwest and a Mexican celebration of the Day of the Dead. But the newest trend is quilts that look three dimensional. Joyce Marquess Carey of Madison, Wis., created a series of three quilts called ''Glad Rags 5, 6, 7,'' top left, that look as if they are banners waving in the air.

LEAD: Judging by Pennsylvania's experience, the states face substantial costs if hospitals and nursing homes take advantage of a recent Supreme Court decision affirming their right to sue states for higher Medicaid reimbursement rates.

LEAD: Maurice Girodias, a French publisher whose early editions of such books as Vladimir Nabokov's ''Lolita'' and Henry Miller's ''Tropic of Capricorn'' led him into long battles with French censors, died here today at the age of 71, apparently of a heart attack.
LEAD: Dr. Farahe Maloof, a former chief of the thyroid unit of Massachusetts General Hospital, died Monday. Dr. Maloof, a resident of Milton, Mass., was 69 years old.

LEAD: For Mayor Kathryn Whitmire, the Economic Summit of Industrialized Nations, to be held here next week, is ''probably the biggest thing to happen in Houston since the Johnson Space Center came to town.''
LEAD: Bryan Trottier, whom the Islanders released Tuesday, may not be leaving the New York area.
LEAD: After five days of strenuous national debate, a national conference on this island's future concluded today with a call for popular presidential elections.

LEAD: Karl Allison, the director of planning and development for the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. and a former Broadway and Off Broadway producer, died yesterday in a hospital in Perugia, Italy. He was 42 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: TO amuse children strapped into car seats there is the yellow Kiddi Car Phone, which has blue and white buttons and a red antenna that clicks when it is raised. The ''cellular phone,'' made by Fisher-Price, comes with a suction cup to attach to a car window.

LEAD: LILIES have loomed larger in the human imagination for a greater stretch of history than any other flower except roses. One species, the Madonna lily (Lilium candidum), is depicted in frescoes in Crete dating about 1500 B.C. The fairly small flowers of this plant are so dazzling in their whiteness that they have become the stuff of myth and theology.
LEAD: General Assembly AD HOC COMMITTEE ON THE INDIAN OCEAN - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

LEAD: Most of the expectant couples who turned up for the delivery orientation at a hospital in Southern California two years ago were thrilled when an administrator told them, over coffee and doughnuts, that the hospital would offer a discount on their care.
LEAD: To Preserve Choice To the Editor:

LEAD: The thunder that came from the Apollo Theater on Monday night was not an early fireworks celebration honoring the Fourth of July. It was a brilliant pyrotechnical display of tap dancing, presented by Dancing in the Streets as the final event in Rat-a-Tat-Tap, its festival of percussive music and dance.

LEAD: New York's City Council has survived its first major test under the new City Charter. Negotiating with a new Mayor, David Dinkins, and without its old partner, the Board of Estimate, the Council approved a $28 billion budget that deals responsibly with the city's weakening economy.
LEAD: Easy Goer tuned up for his showdown at Arlington Park next month with a contemptuously easy 3 3/4-length victory over De Roche yesterday in the $399,000 Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park.

LEAD: The American Civil Liberties Union filed court papers today arguing that a Federal judge should admit two supporters of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. who had been barred from the Mayor's drug and perjury trial.

LEAD: ''The Fourth of July reminds me that I am an American. Do I need to say anything else?'' - Jack M. Portnoy, a World War II veteran who works as a volunteer at a veterans' home in Queens. [B1:4.]

LEAD: The favorite horse of QUEEN ELIZABETH II, which she rode in 18 Trooping the Color ceremonies, died Tuesday after a stroke. A spokesman for Buckingham Palace said that Burmese, a 28-year-old mare, would be buried in the park at Windsor Castle, which is 22 miles west of London.
LEAD: Not long ago, the Rev. Jonny Ray Youngblood looked around his Brooklyn church and decided he was lonely. ''I was just about the only man there,'' he said.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The marriage of Myra S. Eckstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Eckstein of Great Neck, L.I., to Alon Y. Mogilner, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Mogilner of Brooklyn, took place yesterday. Rabbi Jacob M. Sable officiated at the Great Neck Synagogue. Mrs. Mogilner, 24 years old, graduated cum laude from New York University, where she also received an M.A.

LEAD: Foreign ministers from 24 leading industrial nations agreed today to expand their economic aid program for Poland and Hungary to include the emerging East European democracies of Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Yugoslavia and East Germany.

LEAD: Although the rain stopped, the chill and gale persisted. But the Wimbledon committee, evidently of a mind that their male quarterfinalists could keep a stiff upper lip at this critical stage of the tournament, hustled all four matches onto the nearest available court late this afternoon.

LEAD: Patti Page has maintained her balance in the tricky and treacherous world of pop music for more than 40 years by staying with the kind of simplicity that has enabled Perry Como to have an equally long career. Miss Page opened a three-week engagement at Rainbow and Stars (30 Rockefeller Plaza) on Tuesday singing a program made up mostly of songs that she has been singing for years or that fit the pop and country-western styles of the late 1940's and early 50's when her career developed.
LEAD: A bomb exploded today at the offices of an Afrikaans-language weekly newspaper that reported the existence last month of a right-wing plot to kill President F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela.
LEAD: The U.S. Army spends about $5 million a year to support civilian target shooting - for reasons that no longer make sense.
LEAD: Almost seven months after suffering a severe brain injury in an car accident, the Trail Blazer forward Ramon Ramos left a hospital rehabilitation center in Portland, Ore., on Tuesday.

LEAD: James P. Holland was elected chairman and chief executive of the Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation and the Columbia Gulf Transmission Company this week. He replaces John D. Daly, who will become executive vice president and a director of the Columbia Gas System, the parent of the two companies, which are both based in Charleston, W.

LEAD: Sweltering summer days and school vacations prompt millions of Americans to head for the country or the shore, move to a cabin in the woods or take in the sights in different parts of the country. Most travel by car.
LEAD: Imaginative players sometimes reject an obvious safe lead in favor of a risky one.
LEAD: There will be a unified German team for the Winter and Summer Olympics in 1992, the presidents of the two national Olympic committees announced today.
LEAD: SOME people collect salt and pepper shakers. Joseph Pell Lombardi collects houses.
LEAD: IN the early 1980's, when almost everyone believed that growth was great for a bank, the Jamaica Savings Bank followed a radically different course. It deliberately allowed assets to shrink.
LEAD: Men who live in temperate climates produce significantly less sperm in summer than in winter, researchers report, a finding that partly accounts for fewer births in the spring.
LEAD: For the second time in two nights, a game of soccer turned into a game of chance to decide which of two quality teams would advance to the final of the World Cup.

LEAD: Christopher Janney, a composer who specializes in environmental sound installations, wired up the Fifth Avenue staircase of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Monday afternoon for a three-hour presentation of his ''Soundstair,'' a pedestrian-participation work. The performance, which was part of the Rat-a-Tat-Tap festival of percussive music and dance, was offered as a celebration of the 25th anniversary of the Landmarks Preservation

LEAD: The American League president, Bobby Brown is scheduled to announce today or tomorrow the disposition of the case involving the brawl between Seattle and Milwaukee at the Kingdome last Saturday, but Manager Jim Lefebvre of the Mariners is saying already that he will appeal any suspensions or ''outrageous'' fines against his players.

LEAD: George Steinbrenner finally gets to tell his side today. And what he chooses to say in a hearing before Commissioner Fay Vincent might play an important part in determining the Yankee owner's future in baseball.
LEAD: In London today, NATO, which has lost its original reason for being, is opening its most crucial summit meeting in its existance. Page A8.

LEAD: President Bush wants to reduce NATO's reliance on nuclear arms and on early nuclear first use. But he also wants to preserve a nuclear option for the alliance. He has found a reasonable way to do both by proposing to turn nuclear arms into ''weapons of last resort.''
LEAD: Treatment with human growth hormone can significantly reverse many effects of aging on the body, a new study has found.
LEAD: There was no final ceremony for Donald E. Moore, who retired Saturday after 10 years as president of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.
LEAD: Toxic shock syndrome has declined sharply since 1980, largely because of changes in tampons, the Federal Centers for Disease Control reports.

LEAD: WHEN her stepson was 10 years old, Sally Jo Dady would punish him by sending him to his room. ''A few years later that stopped working because he had magazines, a radio and a TV in there,'' said Mrs. Dady, who lives in Minneapolis. ''He would think being sent to his room was great.''
LEAD: Stock prices closed lower today on the London Stock Exchange, depressed by mounting concern about the strengthening pound.

LEAD: A Federal Court of Appeals ruling has put an end, at least for now, to the drawn-out litigation between Suffolk County and the Long Island Lighting Company over the utility's rate increases while it was building the Shoreham nuclear power plant.
LEAD: A report in the Diner's Journal column of Weekend on Friday misidentified the new chef at 150 Wooster, a restaurant owned by Brian McNally. He is Chris Gesualdi, not Geoffrey

LEAD: CYCLING Fignon Withdraws From Tour Laurent Fignon, who lost on the final day to Greg LeMond in last year's Tour de France, dropped out of the race yesterday in the fifth stage while Steve Bauer of Canada continued to lead. Yesterday's was the longest stage of the three-week race, 187 miles.

LEAD: THE Frank Lloyd Wright rug collection of F. Schumacher & Company has four new designs reinterpreting Wright's designs for a room in the 1902 Arthur Heurtley House in Oak Park, Ill.; two drapery panels for the 1906 Avery Coonley House in Riverside, Ill., and a 1926 cover design for Liberty magazine.

LEAD: Herman Goldfarb, an insurance broker who worked undercover in an inquiry into organized crime in the New York garment industry in the early 70's and who later, while in the Federal witness-protection program, was tried for ordering the murder of a man who had threatened to reveal his identity, died on Sunday in San Diego.

LEAD: Jose Canseco, the top vote-getter among all players, was one of three Oakland Athletics voted by the fans to the American League starting team for the All-Star Game Tuesday night at Wrigley Field. Ryne Sandberg of the hometown Cubs topped the balloting in the National League.

LEAD: The Mets are so immovable these days that they win even when Dwight Gooden pitches on a sweltering night with a blister on his index finger and loses a 4-0 lead in the late innings. And that's precisely what they did last night before a sellout crowd of 48,072 fans in Shea Stadium.

LEAD: The United States, losing faith in the civilian Government, has turned to this country's military to insure stability and combat growing drug trafficking, Western diplomats and Guatemalan officials say.
LEAD: A judge has been asked to order blood tests on 3-year-old twins to determine whether they might be potential bone marrow donors for their half-brother, who is suffering from leukemia.
LEAD: When President Bush appointed a Washington lawyer named Stephen Potts to the Administration's top ethics post two weeks ago, the choice seemed curious at first.

LEAD: SANDING a wood floor to refinish it is not too difficult, but it is dusty, noisy and time consuming. A floor thickly covered with paint should be chemically stripped first, to reduce the amount of sanding necessary.

LEAD: Six Pan American World Airways flights were delayed up to 20 minutes yesterday when a shipment of dummy handguns and hand grenades used for security training was halted at Kennedy International Airport.

LEAD: The chief of President Samuel K. Doe's personal security force deserted today as Liberian rebel forces fired captured artillery and mortars at Government positions and inched closer to the center of Monrovia, the capital, United States officials said.
LEAD: There is a dark side to the stunning fruitfulness of this ancient oasis city that teems so with market produce and some of the most prolific citizenry in the Soviet Union.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Two Christian Scientists were convicted of manslaughter today in the death of their 2-year-old son because they relied on prayer to treat him rather than seeking conventional medical care.

LEAD: Workers for four private agencies serving mentally retarded people and emotionally disturbed children have reached tentative union contract agreements. The workers are to vote on the agreements this week.
LEAD: Stephen Lang is playing another edgy guy.
LEAD: The American Dance Festival's summer season has entered the 1990's with a performance series entitled American Masters Plus.

LEAD: In a move that may foreshadow broad changes in the retail investment market, Fidelity Investments has agreed to market a popular product of John Nuveen & Company to Fidelity's mutual fund and brokerage customers.

LEAD: THE International Business Machines Corporation has decided to put on a happy face. A new corporate advertising campaign for I.B.M., which as the behemoth of the computer world has been unable in recent years to move as quickly into new markets as some of its competitors, creates an image of a revitalized company that cares about its customers and is more than happy to take on all comers.
LEAD: Once the pacesetters for global expansion in the financial industry, American banks are retreating from foreign markets, losing business and stature to competitors from Europe and Japan.

LEAD: Vicki Stein, founder of Victims Assistance Services of Westchester County, a group of professionals formed with state and county money to help victims of domestic violence and other crimes, died on Monday at White Plains Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

LEAD: A man robbed a convenience store in suburban Lakewood on Tuesday, was quickly cornered by the police and then shot himself to death after asking them to kill him, the authorities said. The man was identified today as Darcy Willey, 24 years old, of Tacoma.
LEAD: That Place in Minnesota Changing Lives, Saving Lives By Ed Fitzgerald 237 pages. Viking. $18.95.

LEAD: The Rev. Donald Wildmon of the American Family Association has not been a strong supporter of the free expression that some Americans, on their Independence Day, celebrated as a precious constitutional right.

LEAD: Performances by the Merce Cun-ningham Dance Company, Gunther Schuller conducting Charles Mingus's ''Epitaphs,'' and a Roots of American Music Festival celebrating blues, gospel and folk music are among the highlights of the 20th-anniversary season of Lincoln Center's Out-of-Doors Festival, to run from Aug.
LEAD: * Kathy Harrington, president and chief creative officer of Stern Walters Partners, a Chicago agency, has been named to the additional post of chief executive.

LEAD: The National Chorale has been singing at free concerts of American music in parks around the New York area since 1980. The group began this year's series with a brief historical sampler in Damrosch Park on Tuesday evening. The performance was carried live by WQXR, which is broadcasting concerts from Damrosch Park on

LEAD: With red lights flashing and siren blaring, an ambulance weaved in and out of traffic in upper Manhattan recently, racing to get a woman who had suffered a heart attack to St. Luke's Hospital at Amsterdam Avenue and 114th Street.

LEAD: When readers think of innovation and experimentation in the recent novel, they think of writers like Jorge Luis Borges, Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Mario Vargas Llosa, Carlos Fuentes, Milan Kundera, Thomas Pynchon and Donald Barthelme. They think of the alternatives to naturalism produced by the magical realists from Latin America and Eastern Europe, and by American innovators reacting to the social and political confusions of the 1960's.
LEAD: The Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the London-based advertising conglomerate, said today that it had agreed to sell the Gartner Group, an American consulting firm, for $70 million.

LEAD: At the Swan Club in Roslyn, L.I., Caroline M. Bowers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bill Bowers of Portland, Ore., was married yesterday to Howard M. Hyams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Al Hyams of Baldwin, L.I. Rabbi Charles G. Agin officiated. Mrs. Hyams, 28 years old, graduated from the University of Hawaii and the Fashion Institute of Technology.

LEAD: It may have something to do with the way theater mirrors life, but the disagreement among a group of visiting Russian playwrights brought to New York's theater district a taste of what's going on in larger Soviet stages these days.

LEAD: Moments after Argentina bounced Italy out of the World Cup competition Tuesday night, window shutters flew open at an apartment overlooking Via di San Stefano del Cacco, a narrow street in Rome's historic center.

LEAD: ''ARCHITECTURAL Drawings of the Russian Avant-Garde,'' 150 drawings done from 1917 to 1934, reveals as much fantasy as Socialist Realism. The drawings, at the Museum of Modern Art, include some for projects that were not built, among them a glass pyramid drawn in 1930 that resembles I. M. Pei's addition to the Louvre in Paris; a 1924 proposal for a newspaper building with rotating upper stories.
LEAD: Financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday for the Fourth of July.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that if the troubled Soviet economy failed to begin rebounding in two years, then the Communist leadership of the party would quit ''of its own accord.''

LEAD: Show and Tell, Texas Style In its role as host of the seven-nation economic summit meeting, Houston is proclaiming its own economic rebirth. Page A14. Gorbachev Vow on Economy The Soviet President said that if the economy failed to begin rebounding in two years, the Communist Party leadership would quit.
LEAD: Nike plans to start a $5 million advertising campaign next week in which its spokesmen promote not sneakers but good behavior.

LEAD: Few products looked more promising. When RJR Nabisco introduced a bite-size version of graham crackers last fall, the company was abuzz. In the in-house lingo, the sweet, crispy snack was very ''more-ish'' (you wanted more of it) and had ''high poppability'' (you wanted to pop it in your mouth).
LEAD: Mirko Kontze, a sturdy East Berlin street cleaner, has his own way of measuring the arrival of Western capitalism: it is bringing a lot of garbage to his part of town.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: There was a moment of suspense in the radio studio. Four women waited for the first caller to pierce the intimacy of the soundproof room where Diane Rehm moderates a popular talk show here each weekday morning on WAMU.

LEAD: ''NOW down here is a rental unit, very nice for income. Or when I get old I could put my nurse-companion there. Or if I get rich I could move to the country, rent out the other three floors and keep this as my pied-a-terre.'' I sigh. I have seen photographs of just the kind of simple but elegant city flat I have in mind in a British magazine called World of

LEAD: Pratt & Whitney Inc. has recalled more than three dozen of its newest and largest jet engines because of a compressor problem that if left unchecked could prompt an engine to shut down during a flight.

LEAD: The mass attempt of the Albanians to gain freedom by storming diplomatic missions in Tirana over the last few days was apparently provoked by other similar attempts on a smaller scale in recent months.
LEAD: The party is a corpse. Unless Mikhail Gorbachev at last acknowledges its death, one day he will be buried with it.
LEAD: A wealthy entrepreneur, known here for helping to beautify the town, has been arrested for spray-painting a real-estate sign near his house.
LEAD: A 90-year-old man who often quarreled with others at the retirement home where he lived has been acquitted of thrashing three fellow residents to death with his heavy oak cane.

LEAD: Over the last five centuries Spain has successively expelled Arabs, Jews, Masons and Protestants. In the same period, millions of Spaniards left the country, emigrating first to the New World and more recently to northern Europe, where they found work, sent for their families and became part of local societies.

LEAD: Torn by a desire to limit immigration and uncertainty over how to react to the changes sweeping the Soviet Union, Swedes are agonizing over whether the country should give asylum to about 150 Soviet Jews who arrived over the last year.

LEAD: THE Variety House for Children in Manhattan, one of a handful of residential treatment centers and nurseries for small children handicapped by AIDS, cocaine addiction or other conditions, is cozy and full of whimsical details, like wood cabinets inlaid with animal motifs and floor tiles that form a whale.

LEAD: When the heads of the leading industrial democracies meet in Houston next Monday, President Bush will face a question he has been trying to avoid: what can the West do to help Mikhail Gorbachev?
LEAD: International A2-11

LEAD: Ed McCabe, who made a name for himself and Frank Perdue through his copywriting for the chicken seller, will try to do the same for Mel Coleman, a Colorado rancher. Mr. McCabe's new agency, Beber Silverstein McCabe & Partners, has won the advertising account of Coleman Natural Meats, a Denver producer of beef and lamb.
LEAD: International

LEAD: A small painting by Pierre Auguste Renoir, ''Portrait of a Seated Woman,'' was cut from its frame and stolen in broad daylight from a third-floor gallery at the Louvre Museum today, museum authorities announced.
LEAD: The two leaders of Kenya's unofficial opposition and the most outspoken advocates of a multi-party state were arrested here tonight after weeks of harassment.
LEAD: Forget the fireworks, the tricolored bunting draped over picnic tables and the jostle of the beach crowds.

LEAD: Some celebrated the Fourth of July by gorging themselves on hot dogs and ice cream. Others in the metropolitan area fed the homeless. Almost all tried to escape the withering heat, whether at the beach, in swimming pools or even at an indoor ice-skating rink.
LEAD: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were narrowly higher for the week ended Tuesday.
LEAD: Nelson Mandela and the Rockefeller Foundation have begun to plan the creation of a South African development bank to change the country's white-dominated economy through foreign investment.

LEAD: When President Bush and the 15 other leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization gather in the palace of Lancaster House on Thursday morning, they will begin the most crucial summit meeting since the alliance came into being 41 years ago.

LEAD: * Alliant Computer Systems Corp., Littleton, Mass., a manufacturer of standards-based parallel supercomputers, appointed Ronald H. Gruner vice chairman. He will remain chief executive but be replaced as president by Craig J. Mundie, who also becomes chief operating officer.
LEAD: A man shooting darts through a homemade dart pipe has struck two more women in midtown, making the total of victims 26, the police said.

LEAD: In the last decade, many young, aggressive entrepreneurs have flourished in India by forming ventures with foreign corporations, tapping the subcontinent's vast domestic markets and challenging the traditional power of older, family-held industrial empires.

LEAD: Just when it looked as if the Yankees might salvage the final game of their latest trip through trouble, along came Bo Jackson. The result: another loss. Jackson rubbed out a momentary Yankee lead tonight when he crushed a three-run homer to center field in the seventh inning, a homer that resembled a fiery shooting star.

LEAD: The videotape showing the hotel encounter between Mayor Marion Barry of Washington and an F.B.I. informant, now playing repeatedly at his trial and on television, means many things to many people. To the prosecution it proves cocaine use and perjury in denying using drugs. To the defense it spells entrapment - Government overreaching to nail a troublesome black leader.

LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation's agreement last week to let the Minolta Camera Company of Japan take over the job of marketing Polaroid's most sophisticated instant camera to consumers was not the kind of deal anyone would have embraced around Polaroid's headquarters in Cambridge, Mass., until relatively recently.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Breaking with decades of protectionism, Brazil's new Government has decided to open the nation's economy, the eighth largest in the West, to imports and free trade.

LEAD: Solar power never regained the enormous attention it commanded during the Arab oil embargo of the 1970's, but the General Motors Corporation hopes a race of solar-powered cars it is sponsoring will help persuade students to consider careers in engineering.

LEAD: O Vertigo Dance is a company of fast, hard movers with strong presences and that indefinable French chic, though here on the scruffy side. Or so it seemed from an appearance here by the Canadian dance company on Tuesday night at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, where it performs through Saturday.

LEAD: The General Accounting Office, investigating charges that equipment was stolen from the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in California to buy illegal drugs, says an inventory shows that items worth more than $45 million are missing.

LEAD: JOAN COLLINS is to return to the London stage in September as the sophisticated divorcee in Noel Coward's ''Private Lives.'' The play will be produced by MICHAEL CODRON, who has introduced the playwrights Tom Stoppard, Alan Ayckbourn and Michael Frayn to the West End.

LEAD: A 14-year-old Bengali youth who had come to New York City a few months ago died yesterday, one day after he was hit by metal shards while watching firecrackers being set off at a Fourth of July block party sponsored by the Hell's Angels, the police said.
LEAD: Baseball squeezed in some games between hearings yesterday. But there was lots of action off the field.
LEAD: Paul Wynne, a broadcast journalist whose on-the-air diary about AIDS made television history, died of AIDS today at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center here. He was 47 years old.

LEAD: In what appeared to be a forceful appeal for economic and humanitarian aid from the West, President Hashemi Rafsanjani was quoted today as saying there was a direct tie between foreign aid and improved relations with his Government.
LEAD: No soccer goalkeeper wants to be judged on stopping penalty kicks from only 12 yards.
LEAD: Aaron Pryor will have an eye examination by a New York Athletic Commission doctor today to determine if can resume fighting in the state.

LEAD: The Chilmark Management Corporation has raised its stake in the UJB Financial Corporation to 6.7 percent from 5.2 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Chilmark said the shares had been purchased for investment purposes only. UJB is a Princeton, N.J., banking company that owns United Jersey

LEAD: The day before Independence Day, Rick Brenner was as independent as ever, leaving the group home at dawn to catch the 6:32 train into the city for his clerical job at the American Petroleum Institute. He's been working there 15.8 years, makes $16,883.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: Don Mattingly, who suffered back spasms Monday in Kansas City, Mo., underwent more treatment yesterday at Yankee Stadium and was examined by the team physician, Dr. Stewart Hershon. His condition was listed as day-to-day. The team will decide today whether he will play in tonight's doubleheader against Minnesota.
LEAD: The historic sections of a pair of SoHo streets will take on a purer 19th-century look during the next two years.
LEAD: Four of the six eight-oared crews from the United States entered in the Thames Challenge Cup advanced today at the 151st Henley Royal Regatta.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Merle Haggard has gone political again. More than 20 years after his hit song ''Okie From Muskogee'' made him one of the most outspoken tongue waggers in country music, Mr. Haggard, who is to perform tomorrow night at the Ritz with his 10-piece band, the Strangers, has decided to protest the protesters in a new song called ''Me and Crippled Soldiers.

LEAD: A tax on the sale of securities is among dozens of revenue-raising ideas being discussed in the White House and in Congress, but officials said the odds now seemed to be strongly against such a tax.

LEAD: British and Irish officials said today that the unresolved question of when Dublin would enter proposed talks about returning a large degree of self-rule to Northern Ireland remained an obstacle to setting a date in the fall for beginning negotiations.

LEAD: An Amtrak train collided with a tractor-trailer rig today at a railraod crossing, injuring six people, including the engineer. The New York-bound train, the Crescent, remained upright, and only the engine and the first set of wheels on the second of eight cars derailed. The accident occurred at a crossing off Mississippi Route 11 shortly before 11 A.M.

LEAD: Despite their enormous impact on everyday life, the images that appear in newspapers and magazines remain relatively unexamined. Even the definition of photojournalism is still subject to debate. Does photojournalism have an esthetic and tradition of its own, or is it merely a term for pictures that are reproduced and seen by a large and largely uncritical public?

LEAD: The prosecutor will recommend probation for two Christian Scientists found guilty of manslaughter in their son's death, a spokesman for the prosecutor said today. A lawyer for the parents said the judge has said she will not jail them.

LEAD: At the outset of ''A Silent Thunder,'' Eduardo Ivan Lopez's sentimental romance at the Apple Corps Theater, Kimiyo, an Okinawan teen-ager working in her uncle's tailor shop, takes a man's suit off the rack and dances around the room softly singing Simon and Garfunkel's ''Condor Pasa.'' She is interrupted in this reverie by the arrival of Cpl.

LEAD: The Board of Examiners, which tests New York City's teachers, has been blocked by the Schools Chancellor from giving a test that would have enabled some employees to become supervisors. Page B1.
LEAD: You may find this hard to believe, but President Bush originally wanted to make a day trip out of his visit to London for the meeting of the Atlantic alliance.

LEAD: Gerard Schwarz is to conduct the Waterloo Festival Orchestra in Mussorgsky's ''Night on Bald Mountain,'' David Diamond's Symphony No. 3 and Rachmaninoff's Second Piano Concerto at 8:30 P.M. tomorrow in the opening concert of the Waterloo Festival at Waterloo Village, Stanhope, N.J., at Exit 25 on Route 80.

LEAD: The McMartin Preschool child-molesting case, which produced the longest criminal trial in American history, is expected to go to a jury next week for the second time. Its dimensions have so outgrown its substance that longtime observers now sound like baseball fans: they talk statistics.
LEAD: From the press gallery of the cavernous Kremlin hall where the Communist Party is holding its 28th congress, it is clear that this is not an ordinary political convention.
LEAD: Bob Arum, the boxing promoter who has had a longtime rivalry with Don King, gave testimony yesterday before a Federal Court jury that appeared to support King.

LEAD: The Labor Party's leadership bureau refused to take any position today on Labor's bruising contest for party leadership and left the party leader, Shimon Peres, and his challenger, Yitzhak Rabin, to continue quarreling for three more weeks.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Children were the theme of the International Design Conference in Aspen this year. For a week the participants heard architects, designers, teachers, psychologists and others talk about the needs of children. And all about, their own children played on giant balls, painted, built constructions and generally demonstrated the wonders of youthful imagination.

LEAD: Sidney Fread, an executive in New York for several companies, died last Saturday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Phoenix. He was 74 years old and lived in Phoenix. His family said he had died of lung cancer.

LEAD: MANY stock indexes hit record highs this year, but most money managers earned less in the market in the first six months than they would have earned with Treasury bills, according to CDA Investment Technologies.
LEAD: A police officer eating lunch in the back room of a midtown jewelry store shot and critically wounded one of about eight men who tried to rob the store yesterday, the police said.

LEAD: * Bank of Montreal said it had com-pleted the estimated $23 million (Canadian), or $19.8 million (United States), sale of its 20 percent stake in Banque Transatlantique, a French bank, to the bank's largest shareholder, Credit Industriel et Commercial de Paris.

LEAD: Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks jumped 12.5 percent in late June, surprising analysts and raising hopes among auto executives that the industry had turned a corner after a nine-month slump.

LEAD: Frances Ward Harrington, a retired magazine editor, died on Wednesday at Caleb Hitchcock Medical Center in Bloomfield, Conn. She was 86 years old and lived in Duncaster, a retirement community in Bloomfield.
LEAD: A Federal district judge today rejected a legal foundation's request that he bar the environmental group Earth First from holding its annual meeting in a national forest in Montana next week.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 513 money market mutual funds decreased $2.24 billion, to $382.70 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 161 institutional funds decreased by $222.8 million, to $91.61 billion. The assets of the 250 general-purpose funds were down by $723.9 million, to $133.21 billion.

LEAD: In a sharp policy reversal, Bush Administration regulators said today that enforcement proceedings regarding failed savings and loans would be open to the public. They inaugurated the policy by detailing charges in four pending cases, including the one involving Neil M. Bush, the President's son.

LEAD: Dr. Milton Gabel, a dentist who practiced in Manhattan for more than 50 years, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan at the age of 83. His daughter, Sukhreet, said he died of complications from prostate cancer.

LEAD: The authorities today detained three more prominent Kenyans linked to recent calls for a legalized opposition in this one-party state, including the son of a former vice president and two lawyers.

LEAD: Despite pressure from the White House and Congress to lower interest rates quickly to try to prevent a recession, the Federal Reserve apparently decided at a policy meeting this week to hold rates unchanged for the time being.
LEAD: The putt-putting, pollution-spewing, low-power Trabant automobile has long been the butt of jokes, including bumper stickers that say, ''Zero to 60 in 15 minutes.''
LEAD: James L. Broadhead and Stephen E. Frank, former colleagues at the GTE Corporation, will be working together again at the parent of the Florida Power and Light Company.

LEAD: Soviet Jews could begin to fly to Israel next week from an airport in Finland, the Foreign Minister has said. The operation would make Finland the fourth major route for Jews emigrating from the Soviet Union, along with Hungary, Romania and Poland.

LEAD: In a sweeping mass suspension for an on-the-field brawl, Bobby Brown, the president of the American League, yesterday suspended four Seattle Mariners, four Milwaukee Brewers and Manager Tom Trebelhorn of Milwaukee for their actions in a 28-minute fight between the teams last Saturday night in Seattle.
LEAD: Joseph A. LaPlante, an author and a professor emeritus at the University of Connecticut School of Law, died on Sunday at his home in West Hartford. He was 67 years old.

LEAD: ANNA MAGNANI seems a bit too old, a bit too plump and awfully tired as she begins her role as a commedia dell'arte actress in ''The Golden Coach,'' Jean Renoir's unlikely 1952 film about an 18th-century Italian troupe performing in Peru. Magnani's character, Camilla, has an ingenue's innocence and effortless charm, but she is played by a middle-aged woman who seems uncomfortably stuffed into a funny, harlequin-patterned dress.
LEAD: Vibes and Guitar

LEAD: The saxophonist Dewey Redman presented a relaxed first set at the Village Vanguard on Wednesday night, mixing be-bop, a standard and an original tune. Mr. Redman, who is known for his collaborations with the saxophonist Ornette Coleman, is a spare improviser, and in his hands solos unfold surely, phrase by phrase, pushed along by his slightly grizzled tone and steady logic.

LEAD: The theater panel of the National Endowment for the Arts has denounced the agency's rejection of 4 of 18 grant recommendations and will urge a reconsideration of the decision, the panel's chairman, Philip Arnoult, said yesterday.
LEAD: A composite sketch of the man who is said to be shooting darts at women in Manhattan was released yesterday by the police.

LEAD: Among the modern arts of Africa is film, and eight examples of modern African cinematography will be shown - one film at 4 P.M. and again at 6:30 every Saturday through Aug. 25 - at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street.

LEAD: An article on Wednesday about public access to the beach in Belmar, N.J., referred incorrectly to a former candidate for town office, Roy N. Colin. Mr. Colin ran for commissioner unsuccessfully in an election in which Mayor Maria Hernandez was recalled; Mr. Colin was not recalled.
LEAD: Parliament re-elected Vaclav Havel as President today, completing the first phase of Czechoslovakia's transition from four decades of Communist rule back to a Western-style democracy.

LEAD: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez was handed his first significant setback yesterday when a state judge in Queens declared that the Chancellor may not interfere in the selection of district superintendents by New York City's 32 community school boards.

LEAD: Senator Jim Sasser has detested math since grade school. He says he has no taste for intricate things, unless that means tinkering with the engine of a rust-coated 1967 Jaguar, now sidelined in the Senate garage, that he has been trying to fix up for years.
LEAD: Nancy Wallace walked up to a pair of strangers on a street in downtown Seattle the other day and started talking about the emotional torture brought on by the slow death of her mother.
LEAD: Lending by the World Bank, the biggest source of aid to the third world, has declined in the last 12 months for the first time since 1985, the bank reported today.

LEAD: The Rite Aid Corporation, the drugstore chain that was charged, along with its president, with trying to bribe an Ohio state pharmacy official, was singled out and badgered by state regulators, the company's lawyer asserted before a jury today.

LEAD: George Steinbrenner was the lone witness during a daylong hearing before Fay Vincent yesterday. The baseball commissioner, seeking more information from the Yankees owner about his activities, will hold a second session today.

LEAD: The Government has sold 155 failed savings and loan associations to new owners in the past three months. That's three times what it sold in the preceding seven months. The speedup is a good sign; the Administration is at last getting a grip on this monster task. But it remains under heavy obligation to collar the crooks who made off with the money, and guard the taxpayers' interest.
LEAD: Mitch Snyder, who became a national figure in giving the movement in support of homeless people a public voice and face throughout the 1980's, was found hanged today in an apparent suicide.

LEAD: After considering a variety of ambitious options, the Bush Administration has decided against proposing any major new program or strategy to combat poverty at this time, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Even the most innocuous paraphernalia of a lawyer, it seems, can be the stuff of litigation. Along with burning flags and the right to die, the United States Supreme Court recently ruled on the propriety of a lawyer's letterhead, the latest of several cases it has considered on lawyer advertising.

LEAD: Schoeller Inc.'s plant here will close immediately, putting about 240 people out of work, the Switzerland-based company announced. The company's president, Allen Booth, said from the United States headquarters in Hackensack, N.J., that the decision to close the acrylic yarn-spinning plant had been influenced by low overseas labor costs and recent domestic fashion changes that favor natural fibers.

LEAD: There was a time when Victor H. Palmieri was flying so high he would have balked if clients tried to call the shots. Now, he'd be grateful if they would simply call.

LEAD: Easy Goer's 3 3/4-length victory in the Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park on Wednesday was not just proof that he is back to where he was in his prime last season. It was also the same kind of experience that set him up for the best performance of his career a year ago.

LEAD: For years, it's been difficult to tell who's in charge of New York City's schools: the custodians, who manage day-to-day maintenance of the buildings, or the Board of Education. What is clear is that the custodians have too much power.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Motorists will have to turn on their headlights whenever it rains or snows, under a measure signed into law today by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. The new law, which takes effect on Jan. 1, is intended mostly to help drivers see other cars in bad weather.

LEAD: Squeezed by Government and employer efforts to reduce costs, many hospitals are battling with specialist physicians over the revenues generated by advanced testing equipment and life-support machines. Some of the fights over these lucrative procedures are ending up in court.

LEAD: Heidi Grant is to be the soprano soloist with the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble in Bach's Cantata No. 209 at 9 tonight in the Venetian Theater at Caramoor, on Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y. The all-Bach program also includes the First and Third Orchestral Suites, and the Concerto in D minor for Two Violins.

LEAD: * Yamaha Motor Corporation, to Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/Pacific, for its RIVA motor scooter.

LEAD: President Bush and other Western leaders opened a crucial summit conference today with calls for a reshaped NATO alliance that would both reassure the Soviet Union of the West's peaceful intentions and guard against a possible revival of Soviet expansionism.
LEAD: In a matter of hours yesterday, stocks gave up much of what they had gained in the last five sessions.

LEAD: The new director of the venerable Comedie Francaise is JACQUES LASSALLE, a distinguished actor and stage director who has headed the National Theater of Strasbourg since 1983. He succeeds Antoine Vitez, who died suddenly in May.

LEAD: Visa International and Mastercard International filed a multimillion-dollar fraud lawsuit today contending that a vast telemarketing scheme with nationwide tentacles recruited small companies to launder credit card charges.

LEAD: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman who has been rebuffed in his attempts to get seats on the board of the Koito Manufacturing Company, said on Wednesday that he planned to increase his stake in the Japanese auto parts supplier.

LEAD: For the last three years, visitors to the Storm King Art Center here have been able to look across a broad field studded with giant steel sculptures by Mark di Suvero and see the white silhouette of Alice Aycock's ''Three-Fold Manifestation II.''

LEAD: The defending champion, Steffi Graf, no longer invincible in her own eyes or in those of the players waiting in line to dethrone her, was upset today, 6-3, 3-6, 6-4, by Zina Garrison of Houston in the semifinals at Wimbledon.

LEAD: The surgeon who treated the woman who was raped and beaten in Central Park last year said she was in ''deep shock and barely alive'' when an ambulance crew rushed her to the Metropolitan Hospital Center.
LEAD: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, said today that it had suspended negotiations for a large aircraft purchase at the request of the employee group trying to buy the company.

LEAD: Alan Bond, the Australian financier whose companies have debts of more than $4 billion, has ended his 17-year association with the America's Cup, saying he will not be involved in the 1992 challenge off San Diego.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson announced today that he would run for the office of ''statehood senator'' from the District of Columbia, a new post created by the city government to lobby Congress for statehood.
LEAD: The Falcon Oil and Gas Company, a successful production and exploration company based in Odessa, Tex., said yesterday that it had named Spencer M. Murchison as president and chief executive.
LEAD: How can PRESIDENT BUSH elbow a potential 1992 opponent, MARIO M. CUOMO, while keeping his distance from the very uphill campaign for Governor that PIERRE A. RINFRET is waging against Mr. Cuomo?

LEAD: Democrats and many Republicans believe that President Bush's endorsement of higher taxes will hurt him politically. But they ignore the four major benefits that a successful resolution of the U.S. budget problem would provide.

LEAD: For the last 18 months or so Frederick McCullough has been like Popeye, or Tony the Tiger, or some other cartoon character with hyperbolic energy: shinnying up to the roof to put new concrete around the chimney, washing the aluminum siding around the house, and mowing and re-mowing the lawn.

LEAD: WEST GERMANY has now won its friendly takeover bid of East Germany, gaining not only a lot of real estate and 16 million more Germans, including 10 million workers, but also a host of decrepit factories, rundown roads and other poor public facilities.
LEAD: SPIKE LEE is going into retailing. On July 22, a day before his movie ''Mo' Better Blues'' opens, Spike's Joint will open in a brownstone in Brooklyn.
LEAD: A raging fire today forced residents of a small town to abandon their homes, burned a Coast Guard station and other buildings, and blocked the Alaska Highway, the main road into the state.

LEAD: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the departure of Ralph McA. Ingersoll 2d from the United States newspaper business to run newspapers in Europe misidentifed the paper he operates in Ireland. It is The Irish Press, not The Dublin Press.
LEAD: The Justice Department filed a suit today against the American Institute of Architects contending that the professional group unreasonably restrained price competition.
LEAD: After months of charges that he was waffling on the matter, Mayor Art Agnos has ordered the police to break up a sprawling encampment of homeless people just outside City Hall.
LEAD: * Bank of America, San Francisco, named Barbara L. Rambo, a senior vice president, to manage its Northeast-Southeast institutional group in New York.
LEAD: Zina Garrison's story is one of humble beginnings, painful transitions, and misplaced self-esteem, almost the stuff of soap opera.
