LEAD: Justice Thomas A. Demakos of State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday scheduled Aug. 28 for the retrials of three defendants in the 1986 Howard Beach racial-attack case.
LEAD: The Government ministry that helped engineer Japan's export-fueled economic boom says that in the 1990's Japan must turn inward and set its own house in order.

LEAD: America's music has been forged as much in ghettos and rural backwaters as in the concert hall, and the folklorist Alan Lomax has been bringing it to outsiders since the 1930's. In recent years, he has set out with a video crew, and the results can be seen on ''American Patchwork,'' a PBS series that begins this weekend.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: It took the military government of Myanmar, formerly Burma, over a month to count the votes in the stunning election of May 27, in which the main opposition party won more than 80 percent of the seats.
LEAD: A Federal appeals court today opened the way for two vocal supporters of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. to attend his drug and perjury trial, from which they have been barred by the trial judge.

LEAD: Nothing fades faster than the future, or at least our fanciful notions of what the future ought to be. And ''Jetsons: The Movie,'' a full-length animated version of the 1962 television show that was conceived by William Hanna and Joseph Barbera as ''the flip side of the Flintstones'' (in Mr. Hanna's words), has faded quite a bit.

LEAD: Most of the 140 rural hospitals around the nation that shut down from 1985 through 1988 had been losing money because of high operating costs rather than inadequate government subsidies, according to a report by the General Accounting Office.

LEAD: With health and environmental funds leading the way, mutual stock funds turned in a strong performance in the second quarter of this year. But as a group general equity funds still did not perform as well as the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index.

LEAD: The traffic capacity of an 11-block section of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive will be choked off by one-third or more during roughly three years of repairs beginning later this month, New York State officials said yesterday.

LEAD: BASEBALL COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE - Fined the Yankees $25,000 and ordered them to pay the California Angels $200,000 for violating the tampering rule with Dave Winfield after he was traded to the Angels. LEAD: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival has never seemed quite the right place for the classical ballet, though certainly it has presented some stellar ballet attractions over its 58 seasons. For one thing, the stage of the Ted Shawn Theater here is a little small for bravura ballet dancing. And the festival has a long and vivid modern dance history.

LEAD: Moments after West Germany squeaked past England in Turin, Italy, to advance to the final of the World Cup soccer tournament, people spilled out of pubs and parties throughout England on Wednesday and went on rampages that ended with two deaths and 600 arrests.

LEAD: The report that injections of synthetic human growth hormone seem to reverse some of the effects of aging is much to be welcomed. Previous recipes for stalling age included regular, strenuous exercise and going on a near-starvation diet. But there are a few catches before couch potatoes and epicures can set their hopes high.

LEAD: Whimsy and politics make extremely strange bedfellows, at least in ''The Cassandra Cat.'' This 27-year-old political allegory from Czechoslovakia, opening today at the Public Theater, is the story of a bespectacled cat who brings chaos to a small town when his glasses are removed. Without those blinders, people literally show their true colors.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Sherman Antitrust Act, which this year marks its centennial, has had a long history of both vigorous enforcement and virtual oblivion. In recent years it has not been as widely used by the Government to challenge many kinds of business agreements once viewed as improper.

LEAD: Cameroonian's Makassi Sam Fan Thomas, Kilimanjaro, 531 West 19th Street (627-2333). Sam Fan Thomas, from Cameroon, sings music called makassi that has all of French-speaking Africa dancing, with three chords and a lilting beat that sets hips swaying. The last time Mr. Thomas appeared in New York, he had a Paris-based band that was irresistible; this time, with musicians from Cameroon, he may be even better.

LEAD: Parts of Long Island Sound are so polluted that it faces severe long-term environmental damage, say scientists, government officials and conservation groups.

Bruce F. Allen, a lawyer who was appointed a judge pro tem for the ceremony, officiated.

LEAD: After decades of docile behavior under the old Communist Government, East Germany's trade unions are flexing their muscles this week to make sure that workers' interests are not brushed aside as the nation rushes toward a free-market economy.

LEAD: In big cities many drivers justify the expense of parking in lots or garages by pointing to the security they can provide. Yet it is not uncommon for owners to return for their cars and find dented fenders or scratched finishes. Sometimes, property is missing. And occasionally the car itself is gone - stolen.

LEAD: Yields on bank certificates of deposit rose briefly in May but have slipped gradually since, and rate analysts expect them to move lower through most of 1990. Investors may want to lock in current interest rates. Certificates of deposit are as safe as Treasury securities, while requiring far smaller minimum investments.
LEAD: An illegal strike by offshore oil workers forced the Norwegian state oil company to shut down production again today, although other strikers were back at work.

LEAD: A former New York City schools official who admitted stealing $610,000 from a dropout program was sentenced yesterday to five years' probation as part of a plea agreement requiring him to make full restitution.

LEAD: Until recently, Corpus Christi was like most other cities when it came to the subject of abortion. There were strong feelings on both sides, but other questions, like whether to increase property taxes, seemed more urgent.
LEAD: Andy Hawkins must be wondering what torture he has to endure to squeeze out a victory as a pitcher for the Yankees.

LEAD: Rabbi Byron T. Rubenstein, leader of the congregation at Temple Israel in Westport, Conn., for 23 years before he retired in 1982, died on Thursday at Mediplex of Westport. He was 74 years old and lived in Westport.

LEAD: The driver of a Pepsi-Cola delivery truck was fatally shot yesterday during a holdup in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, the police said. The driver, Hank Fallacaro, 35 years old, of Brooklyn, was shot once in the chest shortly after noon at 630 Central Avenue while making deliveries, said Patrolman Fred Weiner, a police spokesman.

LEAD: During a single night here this week, theatergoers gave a standing ovation to a performance of Chekhov's ''Three Sisters'' performed in Russian, another audience rose to its feet to celebrate the Bolshoi Ballet's return to America, and a long line snaked outside the entrance of a gallery showing five centuries of treasures from Moscow.

LEAD: A decade ago, computer companies trumpeted the arrival of the ''paperless office.'' It would be a workplace where memos and reports would be instantly distributed over electronic networks to be read on computer screens around the world, and where high-capacity memory disks would replace file cabinets.

LEAD: New York City's rent control laws force landlords, tenants and bureaucrats into periodic confrontations: how much rent is fair for what kind of housing? A recent tax law creates a new, solid basis for such discussions - one that turns out to support the landlords' position.
LEAD: Marjorie M. Bitker, a writer and former trustee of Barnard College, died on Tuesday at Columbia Hospital in Milwaukee. She was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: An obituary on Thursday about the French publisher Maurice Girodias omitted his survivors. He was survived by his second wife, Lilla; two daughters from a previous marriage, Valerie and Juliette; two sisters and a brother.
LEAD: After feathering Brett Hull's financial nest, the St. Louis Blues are ready to do the same for Scott Stevens.

LEAD: Rabbi Seymour Baumrind, rabbi emeritus of the Lake Success (L.I.) Jewish Center, died of a heart attack on June 29 while vacationing at St. Agathe, Quebec, his son said. Rabbi Baumrind was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Six weeks before his suicide, Mitch Snyder told a meeting of his co-workers at the Community for Creative Non-Violence that he was being investigated by the Internal Revenue Service in connection with royalties he received from the 1986 television film of his life story, a spokeswoman for the organization said today.

LEAD: Martina Navratilova is known as the golden oldie at Wimbledon, where she is an eight-time singles champion, holds the record for singles victories with 98, and is poised to set another record Saturday if she can use her 11th appearance in the women's singles final to achieve a ninth title.
LEAD: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has ordered the lifting of police roadblocks and imposed curbs on other activities of security forces, to crack down on human rights abuses.
LEAD: Rebel forces attacked the port of Monrovia today and fought a battle less than two miles from the executive mansion where President Samuel K. Doe is trying to stay in power.
LEAD: Consumers' easy access to cable television's wide range of extra programs is being impeded by the inability of cable operators and television manufacturers to agree on standardized equipment.

LEAD: For people worried about overexerting themselves during exercise, two electrical engineers in Aloha, Ore., have invented a wristwatch that they say also provides an accurate reading of heart rates using just a touch of the fingers.

LEAD: One recent day, a 73-year-old man in a suit, tie and hat paced beside an open pit in the desert sands a few hundred yards from the Pacific Ocean and cried out in anguish for the son executed in 1973.
LEAD: A fiery explosion at a petrochemical plant near the Houston Ship Channel killed 17 workers and injured five others, the authorities said today.
LEAD: An 18-month-old fell four stories to his death yesterday in Queens because a window guard had been improperly installed, the police said.

LEAD: Kip Motta says he probably won't be talking basketball anymore with his father, Dick Motta, head coach of the Sacramento Kings. That's because Kip, who was a Washington State University assistant basketball coach for the last three years, was hired on Thursday as an assistant to the Seattle SuperSonics' head coach, K.

LEAD: An article on June 21 about a demonstration by environmentalists against wood cutting in Northern California misstated the increase in logging by the Pacific Lumber Company since its takeover by the Maxxam Group. From 1985 to 1989, logging rose by slightly more than 100 percent.

LEAD: Oliver L. North, the former Reagan White House aide convicted in the Iran-contra affair, on Friday made his fourth appearance before a Federal grand jury investigating the affair. Government officials have said the panel is looking into whether Reagan Administration aides not yet charged helped to deceive Congress about the sale of arms to Iran and covert military aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.
LEAD: I am the Hubble telescope. I was destined to see the outermost edge of the universe. Much big talk accompanied my creation.

LEAD: It was an unlikely band of conspirators, the 13 who gathered, one flight up, in a nondescript building along a lackluster strip of East 49th Street. Unlikely, because they were smiling and chatty even as they were planning new strategies for conquering the streets of New York and telling all to invading out-of-towners.

LEAD: Willliam McCarthy, a former First Deputy Commissioner of the New York Police Department, died on Thursday at the hospice of the Colonial Palms Nursing Home in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 73 years old and lived in Pompano Beach.

LEAD: Waves of speeches roll by, reduced by the translator's monotone to a lulling sea song. It's hard to stay attentive. The Central Committee propaganda wheel who is reading out extracts, remarkably precise and objective at that, looked up and said: ''Oh dear, I've mixed up my papers. It doesn't matter; the speaker's point was that we have to overcome the crisis of socialism,'' and he went on to the next speech.
LEAD: George Steinbrenner may know in two weeks just how his entanglements with Howard Spira and Dave Winfield will affect his future in baseball.

LEAD: Three months after Robert Golub was convicted of the murder of Kelly Ann Tinyes in Valley Stream, her parents have sued his parents, contending that Mr. and Mrs. Golub bear partial responsibility for the girl's death because they had failed to supervise their son properly.

LEAD: A former city employee testified today in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug trial that she sold crack to the Mayor on more than 20 occasions in 1988, sometimes handing it over at her home after he arrived by limousine, other times delivering it to him at hotels and at a city office building.

LEAD: Mack Trucks Inc., an ailing company that still bears the most famous name in American truck making, announced yesterday that it had received a $100 million takeover bid from Renault, the French state-owned maker of autos and trucks.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Control Data Corporation is again seeking buyers for VTC Inc., its 400-employee semiconductor maker in Bloomington. Contol Data reached an agreement in the spring to sell the unit to Seattle Silicon of Bellevue, Wash., for an undisclosed amount, but delays in arranging financing have cost Seattle Silicon its exclusive purchase rights.

LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgage rates averaged 10.06 percent this week, down from 10.15 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.46 percent this week, up from 8.45 percent the week before.

LEAD: More and more vacationers are seeking significant discounts on hotel rooms in the United States through special clubs or coupon books. Those savings can extend, too, to some rental cars and short-term condominium rentals.

LEAD: A judge here handed down a sentence of 10 years' probation today to two Christian Scientists convicted of manslaughter in the death of their 2-year-old son. As a condition of the probation, the parents must take their three other children to a pediatrician for regular examinations.

LEAD: President Bush and the other leaders of NATO today issued a declaration to end four decades of cold war by proposing to act jointly with Moscow and other East Europeans in stating that ''we are no longer adversaries.''
LEAD: Two Israeli researchers this week patented a method for producing an intense red dye for foods and cosmetics from carrot cells grown in petri dishes.

LEAD: By the time the steel gate in the French Embassy wall opened early in the afternoon, the line of Tunisians seeking visas to visit their former colonial power stretched and snaked around a corner and down a street, where Saida Khemeiri let it be known that she had beaten the system.

LEAD: The first bill in the United States requiring warning labels on record albums with potentially offensive lyrics was passed last night by the Louisiana State Senate by a vote of 29 to 9. The bill, an amended version of legislation approved by the state's House of Representatives on May 10, requires warning labels on recordings with themes of rape, murder, suicide, illegal drug use, child abuse or satanic worship.

LEAD: An article on May 25 about a West Virginia man's indictment on Federal charges of racketeering and conspiracy misstated his religious affiliation. A recent letter from a reader pointed out that the man, Keith Ham, was expelled from the Hare Krishna organization in 1987; he leads a splinter group.
LEAD: A 26-year-old police officer was convicted yesterday of shooting an unarmed motorist to death in a burst of anger over a traffic dispute.
LEAD: Describing himself, Pierre A. Rinfret often uses the line, ''what you see is what you get.''

LEAD: More and more lately, young and wayward black bears have been popping up in the leafy outer suburbs of metropolitan New York, providing residents with nervous amusement and testing the wits of the police.

LEAD: Jack Donlan, executive director of the National Football League Management Council, says the Players Association insists it is not a labor union but continues to act like one. So on Thursday in Minneapolis, the council and the league's 28 teams filed an antitrust suit in Federal Court against the Players Association, charging the association with illegally coordinating player-agent activity in negotiations involving rookies and veteran free agents.

LEAD: Jean Dabry, navigator for Jean Mermoz on several of the French pilot's pioneering flights in the 1930's, died on Wednesday. He was 89 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed. On May 12, 1930, Mr. Dabry and Mr. Mermoz completed the first nonstop flight between Africa and South America, crossing the South Atlantic from Senegal to Brazil in 21 hours and 14 minutes.

LEAD: Nathaniel C. Wyeth, a Du Pont engineer who invented the plastic soda bottle, died Wednesday at the Penobscot Bay Medical Center in Glen Cove, Me. He was 78 years old and lived in Tenants Harbor, Me., and Chadds Ford, Pa.
LEAD: Killing Mister Watson By Peter Matthiessen 372 pages. Random House. $21.95.

LEAD: Aaron Pryor won't be able to fight in New York until at least September, when the doctor who examined him yesterday will present his conclusions to the New York Athletic Commission's medical board.
LEAD: Galina Brezhnev, daughter of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the late Soviet leader, has won a lawsuit claiming a variety of valuables confiscated when her husband was sentenced to prison.
LEAD: ''Spectacular!'' said one of President Bush's aides today as the NATO summit conference ended. ''Got everything we wanted!'' said a second senior adviser.
LEAD: British Airways P.L.C. placed an order today for Boeing 747-400 jumbo jets, Rolls-Royce engines and components that could ultimately be worth more than $8 billion.

LEAD: The National Areonautics and Space Administration said today that tests were planned on two coasts starting this weekend to isolate the source of hydrogen leaks that have grounded the nation's fleet of space shuttles.
LEAD: Amid United States pressure to open its rice market, the Japanese Government decided today to cut the price it would pay to rice farmers this year by only 1.5 percent.

LEAD: A Delaware court paved the way for an investor group to proceed in its takeover attempt of National Intergroup Inc., a Pittsburgh-based holding company of metals and pharmaceuticals. Vice Chancellor Maurice Hartnett of the Delaware Chancery Court ruled that Centaur Partners Group might proceed with its appeal to the Delaware Supreme

LEAD: David (Sweeney) Schriner, a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame and of two Stanley Cup teams with the Toronto Maple Leafs in the 1940's, died after a lengthy illness, the National Hockey League announced Thursday. He was 78 years old.
LEAD: Following is the text of the final declaration issued by the NATO summit conference here today:

LEAD: The manager of the Hanford nuclear reservation, who ordered the release of documents showing the worst environmental abuses in the nuclear weapons complex, said yesterday that he was resigning to accept a job in private industry.

LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation will open its annual DEC World computer trade show Monday in Boston with a range of computer hardware and network announcements aimed at strengthening the computer maker's line of proprietary midrange computers.

LEAD: For a minute there this morning, it almost looked as if the United States had come close to agreeing to include surface naval forces in arms-reduction talks with the Soviet Union, something the United States Navy has stoutly resisted for years.

LEAD: Congress may be on the verge of missing a historic opportunity to clean up this country's campaign laws - laws that give near-ironclad protection to incumbents in the House, promote the role of special interests over individual citizens and hide the amount of money that these special interests funnel into national campaigns.

LEAD: Radio and television executives say Federal Communications Commission policies giving special consideration to minority applicants for broadcast licenses have resulted in a modest increase in the diversity of programming.

LEAD: Responding to growing social and political turmoil, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki dismissed the most prominent remaining Communists from his Cabinet today and pledged that Poland would soon hold fully free elections for Parliament and the presidency.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Police Department has taken away the six-member security detail assigned to former Mayor Edward I. Koch since he left office on Dec. 31. The department's action was based on the decision that police protection was ''no longer warranted,'' a police spokeswoman said.

LEAD: Those traditional American rowing rivals, Yale and Harvard, advanced along with Temple today to the quarterfinals of the Thames Challenge Cup at the Henley Royal Regatta.

LEAD: Stocks advanced briskly yesterday, making up most of their sharp selloff the day before. But with many traders taking a long Fourth of July holiday, volume dropped to the lowest level of the year.

LEAD: An inventory that was ordered after the theft of a Renoir painting from the Louvre has disclosed that a dozen pieces of ancient Roman jewelry were also stolen from the museum, officials said today.

LEAD: Stung by criticism that it has moved tentatively and ineffectively to prosecute savings and loan fraud, the Bush Administration has selected 100 savings institutions for priority investigation, Government officials disclosed today.

LEAD: Michel Couturier still chuckles when he recalls the night he and his wife received a phone call at their Greenwich Village apartment from the excited rhythmic gymnastics coach at the United Nations International School on the East Side of Manhattan.

LEAD: The Kyotaru Company, a leading Japanese restaurant chain, has bought Best Western Foods Inc. for $41.5 million. Masakazu Yoda, a Kyotaru spokesman, said the purchase of Best Western Foods, a Los Angeles beef-processing company, was part of a strategy to enter the processed-beef supply field.

LEAD: In 1987 a Government report cited a chemical in pest strips as a probable cause of cancer, and the insect-control devices seemed to disappear from store shelves. Now the Government is preparing a new report that the two American makers of the strips hope will revive their sales.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The following excerpts are from a speech before the Communist Party congress by Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic and a leader of the congress's insurgent minority, as translated by The New York Times.
LEAD: The innings had merged quietly one into the other. The threats, mild menaces at best, had unraveled without much inspiration. It appeared that the Mets' offense was fated to rest.

LEAD: Jurors in the trial of Rafael Rivera Garcia, the Puerto Rican artist and university professor accused of trying to kill his next-door neighbor, told the judge last evening that they are hopelessly deadlocked on most charges.

LEAD: Mark Davis, who won the National League Cy Young Award last year as a relief pitcher with San Diego but has been a major disappointment for Kansas City in the bullpen this year, is going to get a chance at starting.

LEAD: Whitey Herzog resigned as manager of the St. Louis Cardinals today, saying he was embarrassed by the play of a team he had made into one of the best of the 1980's. He accepted blame for the club's poor performance this season.
LEAD: The former co-captains of the Glen Ridge High School football team have pleaded innocent to sexually assaulting a mentally handicapped girl more than a year ago.
LEAD: The British High Court turned down a request by the Greek Government today to halt a sale of Cycladic sculptures scheduled at Sotheby's on Monday.

LEAD: Ivan Lendl's preparation for the 1990 Wimbledon may have been epic, but today, the curtain came down on him one round too early. At the very moment he most needed it, Lendl ran out of his supply of inspired ambition, or zazrany, as they call it back in his discarded homeland of Czechoslovakia.

LEAD: Standards of dress have subtly shifted in midtown Manhattan, and for once the culprit is not an avant-garde French designer or a trend-setting socialite. The mysterious attacker known as the Dart Man is to blame.
LEAD: Because of a transmission error, an article on Sunday about the negotiations over the New York City budget misidentified a City Council member from Staten Island. He is Alfred C. Cerullo 3d.

LEAD: The Exxon Valdez, the tanker that caused the nation's worst oil spill, will be returned to service next month under the name Exxon Mediterranean and will ply the seas half a world away from Alaska, the company that owns the vessel said today.

LEAD: Nine hours after being left for dead in the mud, the woman known as the Central Park jogger lay in a hospital bed, still struggling and kicking as if trying to fight off her assailants, a nurse testified yesterday in a hushed Manhattan courtroom.
LEAD: New Jersey officials should set a goal to recycle 60 percent of the state's garbage by 1995, a task force commissioned by Gov. Jim Florio recommended today.

LEAD: Gov. Buddy Roemer today vetoed a bill that would have outlawed all abortions except those performed to save the life of the pregnant woman, and the State House of Representatives quickly voted to override his veto after a short but emotional debate.

LEAD: The quest for relief from wrinkles, a hallmark of aging, goes on. This week, two medical researchers in Madison, Wis., patented a cream they said embodies a natural process for reclaiming skin damaged by sun and old age.
LEAD: An article on Thursday about immigrants in Spain misidentified the nation that formerly controlled Guinea-Bissau. It is Portugal, not Spain.

LEAD: Jack Morris, retiring the last 25 batters, pitched a one-hitter tonight and Cecil Fielder hit his 28th home run as the Detroit Tigers beat the Kansas City Royals, 4-0.

LEAD: Eight months after the mayoral election, Mayor David N. Dinkins's campaign finances are still being audited by the city, and the costs of the audit are reducing the amount of surplus campaign funds the Mayor will return to the city under the new campaign finance law.

LEAD: President Bush's offer of military aid for Peru's antidrug campaign raises fears that he'll involve the U.S. in another Vietnam. Those fears are unwarranted. A tough military strategy in the Andes, coupled with substantial development aid, is essential to antidrug policy.
LEAD: Two New York City singers, Deborah Voigt and Hans Choi, won top honors today in the voice categories at the ninth Tchaikovsky International Music Competition.

LEAD: Five months after New York City's worst episode of hospital overcrowding in at least a decade, there is an abundance of vacant beds in many parts of town, and hospital experts are debating whether the overcrowding was an aberration or an omen.

LEAD: Wildfires charred about 400 square miles of forests and tundra by today, and still threatened the town of Tok, where firefighters kept up a house-to-house battle against wind-driven flames.

LEAD: Henry Allen Lord Mali, a New York textile executive, died on Thursday at the Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan and Norfolk, Conn. He died of complications from leukemia, his family said.

LEAD: Bragging rights to Wimbledon's Center Court are hard to come by, but Boris Becker and Stefan Edberg, who will play there on Sunday in the men's singles final, have inarguably earned them.

LEAD: In Morristown, N.J., $1.2 million will buy a National Historic Landmark: a Second Empire-style house with 10 bedrooms, four bathrooms, a brass plaque at the door and memories of the illustrator and cartoonist Thomas Nast, who lived there from 1872 until his death in 1902. But it will not buy an oyster ranch - although Mark

Rabbott Jr., was married yesterday to Timothy James Anthony, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Anthony of West Haven, Conn. The Rev. Dennis Murphy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the St. Thomas More Chapel at Yale

LEAD: Cathie J. Martin, a daughter of Robert M. Martin of Lexington, Mo., and Mary T. MacKenzie of Naples, Fla., was married yesterday to James R. Milkey at the home of his parents, Dr. and Mrs. Robert K. Milkey of Granby, Conn. The Rev. Jennifer Phillips performed the Episcopal ceremony.

LEAD: I strongly object to part of ''A Defeat Revives a Dream,'' (The Times, June 15). George Vecsey writes: ''The home-grown players do not develop the knack of scoring. Mussolini once lamented that his nation was a nation of waiters. It is not stretching the truth to say that Italy is currently a nation of midfielders.

LEAD: If there is life on Mars, it may one day be rudely awakened by Ambler, a 12-foot-tall, six-legged walking robot being developed for National Aeronautics and Space Administration by Carnegie-Mellon University's Robotics Institute. With the software ''brains'' and motor skills to explore rugged terrain, Ambler could bring a new dimension to exploration of the solar system, NASA and University officials say.

LEAD: You could say Glenallen Hill of the Toronto Blue Jays got caught in a spider's web. Hill had a lot of explaining to do yesterday. He missed Toronto's 4-2 victory over Seattle because he injured himself Friday night trying to escape imaginary spiders in a nightmare. ''I have a phobia about spiders,'' Hill said.
LEAD: Jack Welsch, a wine distribution executive, died Wednesday. He was 77 years old and lived in San Francisco.
LEAD: STARDUST By Robert B. Parker. 256 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

LEAD: The screenwriter Shane Black went off to his cabin for four months recently and emerged with an original screenplay that he then sold in an auction among the studios for $1.75 million. While the price tag made national news, less noticed was the fact that Mr. Black could have sold it for more but elected to take less - so that he could name the producer he wanted to work with.

LEAD: At 3 1/2 years of age, Peter likes to play with keys and ars and to swing on his swing set. Recently, his foster mother found him emptying onions out of the kitchen vegetable bin. By the time she spotted him, he had peeled every onion and was lying among the skins. Like any other child his age, he has a penchant for getting into mischief.

LEAD: Finally, there's a 2 Live Crew record no one can censor - ''Banned in the U.S.A.,'' released on the Fourth of July. The song's major transgression is grammar that has been bent to fit the rhymes, because the crude sexual boasting and four-letter words that made the 2 Live Crew (in)famous are completely absent.

LEAD: GAMBLING revenues for the 1990 fiscal year, which ended last week, were disappointing, state officials said. But they expressed hope that several changes in the state lottery would increase the state's take this year.

LEAD: Kathryn H. Tunheim liked her job as Honeywell Inc.'s vice president of public relations, but she was hankering for the excitement of running a profit center. Honeywell, meanwhile, wanted to halve the head count in Ms. Tunheim's department.
LEAD: WOMAN OF THE AEROPLANES By Kojo Laing. 196 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $16.95.

LEAD: The man who pioneered the trust-fund program for The Athletics Congress and who was a key executive in long-distance running during the last decade, Alvin Chriss, has announced his resignation from TAC. In addition to his work for the trust fund, designed to help athletes receive money for on-track and off-track activities while retaining their amateur status, the 60-year-old Chriss recently represented TAC in drug-testing appeals.

LEAD: Ariel Sharon is in a typically expansive mood. Midway through a late lunch at the Gush Katif cafe, deep inside one of the Gaza Strip's oldest Jewish settlements, he puts down his spoon, leans back in his chair and stretches his arms toward the panorama outside.

LEAD: THIS city looks better than it did 10 years ago, but not as prosperous as it appears in William Hoffman's painting of it - one of 44 works that are now on view in the Stedman Gallery on the Rutgers-Camden campus.

LEAD: LAST year at this time, concerts were filled with French music, for the French bicentennial. On Saturday, Bastille Day, the French flutist Jean-Pierre Rampal will be among the guest artists at the opening of Summer Music 1990 at Harkness Memorial State Park in Waterford, but the repertory is Bach.

LEAD: THE Untermyer Performing Arts Festival, held amid the magnificent formal gardens and fountains of Untermyer Park in Yonkers, overlooking the Hudson, has brought the county first-rate artists in various disciplines for a dozen years now.
LEAD: ''NOISES OFF'' by Michael Frayn is about a provincial English touring troupe doing a tacky sex comedy ('' 'Nothing On' by Robin Housemonger'') - and doing it abominably.

LEAD: The distance the United States soccer program must travel before the next World Cup in 1994, America's first turn at being host to the world's largest sporting event, is formidable. Without the opportunity to look back and see how far the sport has progressed in such a short time, America's task might seem insurmountable.

LEAD: Q.Q. Some years ago, we replaced our sun deck flooring with cedar. Although I originally intended to apply several coats of varnish to this decking, I followed the advice of an ''expert'' and painted the flooring instead. The paint soon peeled, and the deck has been repainted several times since. Each time, all peeling paint was scraped off.

LEAD: Imelda Marcos had the shoes; now she has walked. In a case that began four years ago, Mrs. Marcos, the widow of former Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos, was acquitted by a Federal court jury in Manhattan last week of helping her husband loot $200 million from the Philippine treasury and then investing the proceeds in art, jewelry and prime New York City real estate.
LEAD: Len Dykstra. Is there another ballplayer who brings a bigger grin to the face of any real baseball fan?
LEAD: REBUILDING THE HOUSE By Laurie Graham. 174 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

LEAD: In a flurry of last-minute activity during the final days of its 213th Session, the New York State Legislature approved measures to create a children's health insurance program, to cap the fees that doctors may charge the elderly and to pump $420 million into New York's hospital system.

LEAD: The camera focuses in on a stand of timber, trees in a quiet wood. The day has a look of fall to it, arcs of sunlight cutting through the spare foliage, the ground blanketed with leaves turned brown and bone dry. A breath of wind sends the leaves scuttling and, suddenly, a black fedora sails gently into the frame.
LEAD: Contemporary pop is so overrun by commercial formulas these days that marketing considerations exert a powerful influence on the way a record company presents a new singer to the public.
LEAD: Like battered Gucci loafers and scuffed Vuitton steamer trunks, wilted little Pucci numbers from the 1960's carry a certain cachet that could make the sleek 1990 updates seem a bit obvious.
LEAD: Re: ''The Builders Are Trying to Undercut Us'' (May 27).

LEAD: To the Editor: I recently returned from five weeks' travel in South America (Chile, Bolivia and Ecuador) and have been reading about the hooliganism in Moscow and State Department warnings regarding travel in Lithuania and other countries.

Although I originally intended to apply several coats of varnish to this decking, I followed the advice of an ''expert'' and painted the flooring instead. The paint soon peeled, and the deck has been repainted several times since. Each time, all peeling paint was scraped off.

LEAD: WRESTLING WITH THE ANGEL A Memoir of My Triumph Over Illness. By Max Lerner. 210 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95. TAKING HEART By A. C. Greene. 222 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.
LEAD: THERE is more to ponder at the Caramoor Music Festival this summer than music's relationship to nature, or the stoicism of a wind player with a fly buzzing about his mouthpiece.

LEAD: Some of the Boston jurors were in tears last week when they returned a verdict after a two-month trial, convicting two Christian Scientists, David and Ginger Twitchell, of manslaughter in the death of their 2-year-old son. Following the precepts of their religion, the Twitchells relied on prayer instead of seeking conventional medical care to treat their son, Robyn, who died in 1986 of a bowel obstruction.

LEAD: Hieu Dam is to the ordinary woman in Los Angeles what Jean-Paul Gaultier is to Madonna. Like Mr. Gaultier, she designs bustiers. In the last year, the 22-year-old designer, who lives in Los Angeles, has specialized in bustiers and bras - all lavishly ornamented with sequins, pearls, lace or safety pins.

LEAD: President Bush told Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan today that the Administration would not oppose Japanese plans to resume its multibillion-dollar program of aid to China. But he urged Mr. Kaifu to slow down the aid plan and limit its scope.

LEAD: The Louisiana State Senate today upheld the Governor's veto of a bill that would have created the strictest anti-abortion law of any state, all but killing any chances that the bill would become law.

LEAD: TO date, the most sensible attempt to capture the elusive mystique of the great Billie Holiday in theatrical terms is ''Lady Day at Emerson's Bar and Grill,'' Lanie Robertson's ''drama in the form of a cabaret act,'' as the playwright has described it.

LEAD: One billion people - a fifth of Earth's population - will watch the final game of the World Cup soccer championship on television today, according to utterly unreliable estimates of the contest's popularity. Even if that's an exaggeration, it doesn't diminish the fact that soccer has more fans than any other sport on this planet.

Then, as the green flag drops, there's the thunder of 44
LEAD: New studies continue to raise the troubling possibility that even the low levels of radiation emitted by most computer monitors have the potential to cause health problems.

LEAD: In New York recently, Dominique Aurientis wore huge elephant-head earrings, half a dozen lapel pins, a scarf dangling golden charms, and two armloads of bracelets with gilded trimming. Of course, the jewelry was all of her own design, and marked by a soupcon of wit and a large dose of sophistication.

LEAD: They have been teammates on the Indy-car circuit for a year and a half, but for Mario Andretti and his son Michael, that could end if there is substance to the speculation that Michael, 27 years old, will drive on the international Formula One circuit next year.
LEAD: The nation's largest teachers' union issued a report today calling for a gradual end to the tracking policy of grouping students according to past performance.

LEAD: Secretary of State James Baker says the United States won't stand in the way of allies who want to offer aid to the Soviet Union. And the Bush Administration is prepared to send technical assistance, but not to extend credits.

LEAD: Golf Aching Archer Takes Senior Lead: George Archer took a two-stroke lead yesterday in the second round of the Northville Long Island Classic despite a flareup of chronic back problems. Archer said he felt the back pain increase after last weekend's United States Senior Open in Paramus, N.J., where he tied for 13th.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Jose C. Roska of Bloomsburg, Pa., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Carolyn Kangleon Roska and Erik Helge Weiner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Erik Weiner of Falkoping, Sweden.

LEAD: They are the masterpieces on the museum walls, the unvarying stars in our artistic firmament, the van Goghs and Goyas and Rembrandts and van der Weydens. In our youth, we stood before them, notebook in hand, feverishly analyzing them for art-history classes. Later, as we revisited them through the years, they became dear friends.

LEAD: When the Berlin wall opened last fall, one recurring image of a society where technology had stood still for 40 years was the little East German Trabant automobile, with its noisy two-stroke engine spewing pollutants and fumes. Westerners are more accustomed to two-strokes in lawnmowers than in cars.

LEAD: WHEN Robert M. Hoffman purchased a home on Main Street in Farmington in 1944, he had no idea he was buying into one of the most dramatic episodes in American history.

LEAD: It's the bigness that first inspires fear. Then, having to make what seem like endless decisions. Never mind the financial investment or the shopping time involved. Even the sanest of folks can find buying a sofa a daunting experience. For starters, consumers will usually be bombarded with questions from a pleasantly inquiring salesperson: what size and shape will fit the space?

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Robert G. Maddern, an investor in Killingworth, Conn., knows the Fidelity Municipal Bond Fund is doing well. But how well? He got different answers from the three newspapers and magazines in his mailbox recently. Because they arrived so close together, the discrepancy caught his eye.

LEAD: After considering a recent letter to President Bush from Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, Administration officials have concluded that another attempt to organize Israeli-Palestinian talks may be justified.

LEAD: The legacy of the 1980's is quick-change, recombinant rock - music that jumps from style to style without worrying about transitions or fusions. A wave of bands is knocking together rock, rap, funk, reggae and hard core, simultaneously honoring and defying pop's fragmentation.

LEAD: Housing advocates have long complained that affordable-housing projects in New York City could not receive aid from the city or the state unless they were built on city-owned land to keep development costs to a minimum.

LEAD: One day last week a young woman about to take a very long plane trip packed herself a kind of CARE package. There was cheese, prosciutto, bread, a tomato and a mango because she distrusts airline food. Two newly purchased shirts and a sweater because she is wary of air-conditioning. And three books, also newly purchased, in case the flight attendant ran out of magazines before she got to her seat.

LEAD: Betsy Ellen Painter and Roger Army Kline were married yesterday at the Anabel Taylor Chapel at Cornell University. The Rev. Jack Lewis, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

LEAD: The idea is appealingly Soap Box Derbyesque - a bunch of young people competing with their homemade cars. Of course, the scale is slightly inflated. Tomorrow morning, student teams from 32 colleges and universities will begin an 11-day, 1,700-mile race through eight states - from Walt Disney World in Florida to the General Motors Technical Center in Warren, Mich.
LEAD: Long known for its free-spirited environment, Bennington College is trying to shake off the image that, in the words of one administrator, ''anything goes here.''

LEAD: When the advances of technology outstrip the quickening of ethical and moral values in a society, why then do we turn to the law for solutions? The ''right to die'' bill in in the New Jersey Legislature (''Bill to Allow Living Wills Draws Criticism,'' May 20) is yet another symptom of our dependence on government to make more and more of life's decisions.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Philip N. Whittaker of North Falmouth, Mass., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Nancy Crosby Whittaker and Neil Davin Charney, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Evan Charney of Boylston, Mass.

LEAD: After calling George Steinbrenner to account for charges brought by a self-described gambler, after ordering the Yankees to pay $200,000 in compensation and $25,000 in fines for tampering, Fay Vincent was asked if baseball had been damaged during the unpleasant week that was.

LEAD: Clothes for a summer weekend: shorts, shirts, sweaters, easy jackets and, of course, pants. It's all very simple. Whether your weekends are spent in town or in the country, the formula is essentially the same.

LEAD: Jeff Innis, crouched and cringing at the base of the mound, never took his hands off his knees, never sneaked a desperate peek over his shoulder. Innis had seen his pitch leap off Jim Presley's bat and understood instinctively that there was no need to look for it again.

LEAD: To the delight of serious collectors, older recordings of outstanding musical merit are constantly being reissued on CD. Yet the process of transfer to the new digital format led to a sad discovery. Many priceless master tapes of yesteryear had deteriorated, seemingly beyond hope of restoration.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. David Lafayette French of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Elizabeth Druecker French, and Kenneth Andrew Toudouze, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Paul Toudouze of San Antonio.

LEAD: In referring to biological research on mental illness, Janna Malamud Smith states: ''Schizophrenia is no longer understood only as the product of a mother's intrusive and smothering behavior. (She may be a player, but hardly alone on the stage.)''
LEAD: He has already given one gift to his daughters in this soccer season: a wedding.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev brought his unruly Communist Party congress under control, heading off a threat to his leadership team. Page 4.

LEAD: To the Editor: After reading about the man who had his wallet stolen or rifled four times on three continents (''An Easy Mark to Pickpockets of 3 Continents,'' Travel, May 20), I would like to offer my own experience on a trip to Sicily.

LEAD: EACH week, after Robert Marshall completes his clerical duties for Metro-North, he returns to his home here, sheds his coat and tie, picks up his block and tackle and a couple of giant pry bars, and goes out to do his other work. Mr. Marshall, 54 years old, is a trail blazer. He has just designed and completed, with the help of volunteers from the Mohican Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club, a new eight-mile looped hiking trail on the east bank of the Hudson, just a few miles north of the Bear Mountain Bridge.

LEAD: To the Editor: In his engrossing account of ''Hiking With History in the Pyrenees'' (Travel, May 20), Mark C. Hansen related that he crossed by train from Spain to Latour-de-Carol in France, from which point he trekked to the Canigou Masif.

LEAD: Sometimes anger serves a social purpose. That was clearly true in the case of Mitch Snyder, who died last week at the age of 46. His anger about the condition of the homeless in America fueled a national cause.

LEAD: Watching soccer on television in the United States is like watching a great party going on across the street from your house.

LEAD: Janna Malamud Smith's article ''Mothers: Tired of Taking the Rap'' (June 10) certainly hit home. The 1980's saw anti-momism as a growth business. Look at the dialogue in popular television programs like ''Thirtysomething'': ''My mother is coming for a visit.'' Nudge, nudge, wink, wink. Lots of eye rolling and in-joking among the cast.

LEAD: This year, for the third year in a row, owners of Acura automobiles ranked them the most satisfying in America in the prestigious J. D. Power Customer Satisfaction Index survey of product quality and dealer service.

LEAD: On sultry summer days, when a child's toughest decision may be whether to sell lemonade or draw with crayons, the Brooklyn Children's Museum ranks as one of the more sophisticated - and fun - places to learn something.

LEAD: It started with a casual conversation between a swimming coach and a fisherman. Now the resulting project - preserving the environmental quality of streams in eastern Pennsylvania -has grown to involve students from a half-dozen schools.
LEAD: WHEN the glass blowers light their furnaces at the Allaire Craft Fair on Saturday, the fiery glow will echo flames that lighted a bog-iron forge at the same site nearly 200 years ago.

LEAD: While growing up in Augusta, Ga., 40 years ago, Charlie Watson could always step outside his front door and find grass, trees, flowers and shrubs. This summer his children will leave their inner-city home to explore nature while fishing, boating and hiking.
