LEAD: For This Week: Do not delay applying fertilizer to woody plants, which need the summer months to ripen (harden) new growth. Spray fruit trees again to keep them insect-disease free for the summer-fall harvest. Protect rosebushes from fungus diseases. Last call to control woolly adelgids on hemlocks.

LEAD: It's no news to most of us that life can be, and very often is, ornery. What's given with one hand is taken away with the other. Nice things happen at inopportune times (there's no opportune time for bad things), perfect plans are marred by the unexpected, sure things turn out to be not so sure, and small gambles that are almost certainties backfire.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Q. Our family plans to visit Australia in October. We are interested in visiting an aborigine family. - Barbara Johnson, Brooklyn
LEAD: The official Iranian press agency reported today that a Western hostage held in Lebanon, probably a European, was expected to be released shortly.

LEAD: In baseball, at least, possessions can cry out for new owners. In recent years, much wailing has been heard from the New York Yankees, whose principal owner, George Steinbrenner, faced league disciplinary action on two fronts last week amid persistent speculation that he just might be thrown out of the game.
LEAD: Psst! Have you heard? It seems Garry Trudeau is, just maybe, a secret stamp fancier.

LEAD: I was disappointed to read the article concerning the Ireland-Romania soccer match (''Ireland Tops Romania, Ending 0-0 Game on Final Penalty Kick,'' The Times, June 26). Instead of quoting the Irish coach's remarks on tactics you quoted his remarks on drinking. The article had many other slurs and subtle insults.

LEAD: Her workout aboard Howling Success was just that, Julie Krone said yesterday at Monmouth Park, where the jockey took the first step back toward her return to competitive riding. After riding the horse a half-mile, Krone declared herself ready to resume racing. Krone fractured a forearm Nov. 24 in a spill at the Meadowlands and had surgery twice.

LEAD: WHEN Cafe du Bec Fin opened more than 10 years ago, it merited an Excellent rating for its exquisite nouvelle-cuisine cooking and presentation. Later, a change of ownership, from the original chef to his sous-chef, and a coarsening of the fare brought a revised appraisal in this column to Good.

LEAD: In late September of this year, Congress will have a splendid opportunity to honor itself and the name of the United States - and correct a great wrong done to a monk who leads a nation from exile.
LEAD: The official Vatican newspaper today assailed right-to-die legislation, alluding to a bill passed by the New York State Legislature this month.
LEAD: When it comes to pure skills, the best man in baseball is Jose Canseco. We have a modern Babe Ruth on our hands.
LEAD: About 300 Haitians chanted and marched peacefully Saturday outside a shopping center where police had violently broken up a demonstration two days earlier.

LEAD: Flotillas of speedy little watercraft piloted by individual riders, some of them hardly old enough to ride a bicycle, are swarming the shores, lakes and rivers of the Northeast and are generating the kind of excitement and controversy that first accompanied snowmobiles and dirt bikes.

LEAD: Kevin Appier, a rookie, pitched a one-hitter and Kurt Stillwell keyed a three-run third-inning attack tonight as the Kansas City Royals beat Detroit, 4-0, repaying the Tigers for Jack Morris's one-hitter Friday night.

LEAD: It is not a question of fixing blame or exonerating from blame, but of understanding the centrality of the early relationship between parent and child. The infant makes of its world what the world presents to it, mediated by the mother. In this sense, the mother is central and powerful. We know the mother has environmental limits to her power; the baby does not.

LEAD: As the historical story goes, when Jacques Cartier, the French explorer, stepped ashore in 1535 at the rapids near what was to become Quebec City, he confronted a band of curious natives. Looking around at the pristine countryside, he asked them in French and sign language what they called that place.

LEAD: After a grand month of play, along with hooligans, penalty kicks, Italian flags and young men's faces painted in their national colors, the 1990 World Cup ends Sunday with a championship match in which West Germany is favored to defeat the team it lost to in the 1986 final, Argentina.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Manville Trust was meant to compensate tens of thousands of workers dying or diseased from exposure to asbestos. But the two-year-old trust is already out of cash, because of higher than expected payments to early claimants and large attorneys' fees. Many victims will have to wait until 2015 to get any payments.
LEAD: Rickey Henderson. He is at or near the top in nine offensive categories. He also closes the outfield gaps as effectively as any left fielder in baseball.

LEAD: Bupleurum is the genus name for Hare's Ear, a plant marked by a single, earlike leaf that sheathes the top of its stem. It is a member of the order Umbelliferae, which also includes carrots, parsley, dill, lovage and hemlock. In the 19th century a new species of Hare's Ear was identified by one Professor Fenzl, who, following the custom of naming rare plants for distinguished botanists, called his discovery Bupleurum Koechelii.

LEAD: A Federal law intended to stop states from locking up runaway juveniles has succeeded in keeping tens of thousands of them free, but the National Coalition for the Homeless says nine states are still violating the law.
LEAD: After a flurry of union agitation at universities around the nation, graduate teaching assistants have made significant gains in their campaigns for better pay, benefits and working conditions.
LEAD: MY LIFE AS A DOG By Reidar Jonsson. Translated by Eivor Martinus. 220 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

LEAD: FURORS DIE. By William Hoffman. (Louisiana State University, $18.95.) William Hoffman's 10th novel is an ambitious, well-written book. Its great theme is that the believer, the person of conscience and religious faith, is destined for destruction in our dissolute culture. Amos (Pinky) Cody is the son of a poor, alcoholic father and a mother who appears to be a religious fanatic.

LEAD: Mary Alison Curtis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Allen James Curtis of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif., was married yesterday to John Charles Ulin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Irwin Ulin of New York. Judge Frank Baffa of Los Angeles County Superior Court officiated at the home of the bride's parents.
LEAD: ''THE COCKTAIL HOUR'' is A. R. Gurney's portrait of a middle-aged playwright who has written a play about his upper middle-class WASP family and called it ''The Cocktail Hour.''
LEAD: WHEN the earth trembled in late June and swallowed part of northwestern Iran, the world responded quickly.

LEAD: It's getting scrappy out there in the T-shirt market. Producers' capacity was stretched last year, as sales exploded by nearly 30 percent. To avoid getting shorted this season, many wholesalers double-ordered the shirts, the sort on which decals and slogans are printed.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Opponents of a Massachusetts law protecting homosexuals from discrimination cannot try to repeal it through a referendum, the state's Supreme Judicial Court has ruled.

LEAD: Police officers here have been authorized to use stun guns as an alternative to nightsticks, but there is a catch: any officer who wants to use the device must be stunned by it first to know what it feels like.

LEAD: In recent days the trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has sprawled far beyond the courtroom, becoming a painful morality play that has transfixed this city and generated extraordinary soul-searching among its citizens.

LEAD: Many of the books that come my way from publishing houses for possible review deal with presumably better ways to outwit some species of fish or game animal, or describe in detail the twists and turns of foot trails that lead one through forest and mountain in various regions of this country.

LEAD: In ''And Maradona Was Waiting,'' (The Times, June 25) about the contest between Argentina and Brazil, George Vecsey opened with the following statement: ''He (Diego Maradona of victorious Argentina) wore the fabled yellow jersey of Brazil like a trophy from a primitive war. He waved it at the stands as if brandishing the pelt of a vanquished enemy.

LEAD: Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I., was the setting last evening for the wedding of Dana Irene Spector, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Spector of Kings Point, L.I., and Scott Lauren Kimmel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kimmel of Buffalo. Rabbi Jerome Davidson officiated.

LEAD: Technically, Cape May, N.J., is a beach resort. But the rather uninspiring stretch of sand there, packed though it may be on summer afternoons, is not the main point of this exuberantly Victorian town at the southeastern tip of New Jersey. Cape May, a National Historic Landmark, is made for strolling, for porch-sitting, for steeping oneself in the atmosphere of another era.

LEAD: DRESSED in a beaded gold velvet costume so tight she had to be sewn into it, with stacks of golden bracelets encircling her wrists, silk flowers in her hair and her face and lips painted, Somaly Hay looked nothing like a boy. But she was wearing the costume of a young prince, in accordance with the traditions of
LEAD: Mike Kingery hit a two-run single in the ninth inning and Gary Carter went 5 for 5 as the San Francisco Giants defeated the Chicago Cubs today, 10-9.

LEAD: The Yankees got another uninspiring pitching effort from Jimmy Jones yesterday, but one of three rookies in the lineup delivered a big home run and the Yanks scored a 5-4 triumph in 12 innings over the Minnesota Twins.

LEAD: Growing up on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, Wilbert Murdock was interested in the martial arts and in contact sports like boxing. He was a good student, especially in math and science, and today he gives talks in schools to encourage minority youngsters to pursue careers in technical fields, often showing the relationship of science and sports.

LEAD: To the Editor: During a recent trip to Spain as a guest at the Macarena Sol Hotel in Seville, my cameras were stolen. This took place under the nose of my wife who only looked down to address a postcard. I think that you should warn travelers to Spain, especially in light of the 1992 Olympics and Columbus celebrations, that they should hold on to their valuables, even in the lobby of a four-star hotel.

LEAD: MONDAY: The economic summit of industrialized nations begins in Houston. Through Wednesday. A 1,700-mile, 10-day race among 32 solar-powered cars begins in Orlando, Fla. Consumer credit for May. TUESDAY: Wholesale trade for May. PC World Forum/Moscow, through Sunday. WEDNESDAY: The Senate Banking Committee considers jurisdictional disputes between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

LEAD: The Kansas City Chiefs have put Ron Jaworski, the quarterback, on waivers and that means the 16-year pro, who led the Philadelphia Eagles to the 1981 Super Bowl, might have to call it a career. He's 39 years old and had signed as a Plan B free agent with the Chiefs last season, but appeared in only six games before suffering a sprained knee and spent the rest of the season on injured reserve.(

LEAD: Why all this fuss about Belgian chocolates, one wonders, as more and more of them appear on the grander avenues of the grander cities. Their current prominence seems to be due to the newly sophisticated marketing of the Belgian bonbon, and to the growing chocolate consciousness of the Western world.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Tony Gwynn, because he has done it all: hit, field and throw, run, and win longer and better and more consistently than anyone else.

LEAD: Laura Ann Kirby, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Kirby of Amelia Island, Jacksonville, Fla., was married yesterday in Woodstock, Vt., to David Francis Melbourne Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melbourne of Darien, Conn. The Rev. William P. Gallagher and the Rev. Henry A. Albeke officiated at Our Lady of the Snows Roman Catholic Church.

LEAD: It is only in the frantic final days of the legislative session, when dozens of new laws may be created in a single hour, that the New York State Legislature really seems to accomplish anything substantial.

LEAD: Rachel Carole Countryman, the daughter of Joan C. Countryman of Philadelphia and Peter Countryman of West Lafayette, Ind., was married yesterday to John Wescott Bracker, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Earl F. Bracker of Concord, Mass., at the Germantown Monthly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends in
LEAD: Ryne Sandberg. The Gold Glove second baseman does it all, and does it whether the Cubs are good or poor.

LEAD: Dr. Martha Dandridge Bowers, a daughter of Mrs. Michael J. Higgins of Palm Beach, Fla., and Sampson Pendleton Bowers of St. Helena, Calif., was married yesterday to Dr. James A. Falcone, a son of Josephine Falcone of Gilroy, Calif., and the late John Falcone. The Rev. Joseph Asturias, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Mission of San Juan Batista in San Juan Batista, Calif.

LEAD: At first glance, it seems like old times. In a warren of cubicles within a modern office building in the San Fernando Valley, teams of young, casually dressed animators labor furiously to supply their daily quota of raw cartoonage. Production schedules and colored pencils litter the desks and drawing boards; walls and bulletin boards are festooned with sketches of familiar-looking ducks, rabbits and road runners.

LEAD: When a Nebraska judge last month found Elizabeth Irene Richardson guilty of making a false accusation of rape, he handed down a sentence for which even he knew of no precedent: he ordered her to apologize in half-page advertisements in four newspapers and 10 spot announcements on two radio stations.
LEAD: Clarence D. O'Connor, superintendent emeritus of the Lexington School for the Deaf in Jackson Heights, Queens, died on June 29 at New York Hospital. He was 92 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THIS is an extraordinary summer in international affairs, a summer when the leaders of the West are trying to keep the mighty steed of change from galloping away from them, trying to tame it and guide it.

LEAD: A NEW approach to Westchester's costly homeless problem that emphasizes control and assessment rather than placement of the 4,500 residents in need of housing has been proposed by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, to cautious praise and some misgivings.
LEAD: FOR years, this sandy, mile-square Ocean County municipality and the sprawling Naval Air Engineering Center here have enjoyed a harmonious, almost symbiotic relationship.

LEAD: Our 60-year farm-policy civil war is increasingly devastating to American competitiveness. The Department of Agriculture will reward farmers for keeping idle almost 60 million acres this year - equivalent to shutting down all the crop land in California, Colorado, Kentucky, Louisiana, Montana and Wisconsin.
LEAD: The variety of mushrooms in specialty stores now is dazzling and, while they cost as much as or more than a rack of lamb or lobster, to my mind they are equally as sumptuous.

LEAD: Elizabeth Emma Mayer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Mayer of New York, was married yesterday in Laurel Hollow, L.I., to Michael William Keohane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Keohane of Livingston, N.J. The Rev. Burton Davison, a Methodist minister, conducted the nondenominational ceremony at the home of Mr.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Gant of New Vernon, N.J., have announced plans for an August wedding for their daughter Sarah Ross Gant and Michael Anthony Mandanis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Mandanis of San Rafael, Calif.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about a program in which low- and moderate-income families earn equity in cooperatives by helping in the buildings' renovations misstated the amount to be paid by residents of a building in Torrington. Depending on their income, it is $250 to $525 a month including mortgage, utilities, property taxes and insurance.

LEAD: The milestone race that Darrell Waltrip thought he would be in yesterday went off without him, just as the races over the next two months will probably do. Only hours after eating a piece of cake to celebrate what would have been the 500th Nascar race of his career, Waltrip wound up in a hospital on Friday night with serious injuries from a seven-car crash he was involved in at Daytona International Speedway in a practice run for yesterday's
LEAD: Jean Paris, a former vice president and director of design for Cartier Inc. of New York, died on Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.
LEAD: THEN AND NOW How the World Has Changed Since WWII. By Tad Szulc. 515 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

LEAD: Nora Patricia FitzGerald, the associate editor of Connecticut magazine, and Peter Finn, a reporter, were married yesterday at St. Augustine Roman Catholic Church in North Branford, Conn., by the Rev. Daniel F. McSheffrey. The bride, who will keep her name, is 29 years old and a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.

LEAD: Having been quoted by James Traub in his article, I would like to clarify the context of my remarks. As I noted, the chancellor's first steps have been to increase the system's central command position, as part of a strategy aimed at producing greater school-based autonomy and accountability. The fact that this move has not yet changed the climate of our schools is not, however, a criticism.

LEAD: AS technology spawns the production of higher-quality, less expensive computer, video and audio products, an increasing number of new tools are being made available to the blind and visually impaired that greatly widen their academic and career opportunities, experts say.
LEAD: NATURE CENTER OPEN
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Sarah Pearson Von Culin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Von Culin of Pottersville, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher Mark Treanor, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William J. Treanor of Convent Station, N.J. The Rev. Mark R. Summer, a Lutheran minister, assisted by the Rev. Boniface J. Treanor, a Roman Catholic priest and the bridegroom's uncle, performed the Lutheran ceremony at Zion Lutheran Church in Oldwick, N

LEAD: James Traub depicts well the problems of corruption and inertia Joseph Fernandez faces as chancellor of the New York City schools system (''Fernandez Takes Charge,'' June 17). But his article overlooks one ironic aspect of the situation, namely that Stanley S. Litow and Robin Willner, the powers who installed Fernandez, were themselves rewarded with posh jobs as his top lieutenants.

LEAD: One of the first development-rights transfers in Westchester County has been concluded, setting the stage for a two-tower, half-million-square-foot commercial project in White Plains that would draw one-fifth of its bulk from the little country Gothic church beside which it would rise.
LEAD: Yosemite National Park is celebrating its centennial this year. Marika Somogyi has produced a medal that depicts the Half Dome, one of the park's most famous attractions.

LEAD: The military strategy outlined by NATO leaders for adapting to the end of the cold war marks a break with 40 years of military planning and deployment. But the new concepts - including multinational units and smaller and more mobile forces - will pose a challenge to those who must put them into action.
LEAD: COW By Beat Sterchi. Translated by Michael Hofmann. 353 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95.

LEAD: Harvard advanced two of its boats today to Sunday's finals of the 151st Henley Royal Regatta, and those two will be the only United States representatives still competing from the 30 entered this year.

LEAD: Harold S. Hirsch, founder of the White Stag Manufacturing Company, a leading maker of casual sportswear, died of cancer at his home here Wednesday. He was 82 years old. Mr. Hirsch, who became one of Portland's most prominent civic leaders, was a pioneer in the manufacture of outdoor clothing.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lincoln Jewett of Darien, Conn., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Laura Jewett and Abner Oakes 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abner Oakes 3d of Hamden, Conn.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Kirby Puckett. Who else can lead the league in hitting, drive in 100 runs, steal you a base and win the Gold Glove in one of the most active positions in the game?

LEAD: Q. Some years ago, we replaced our sun deck flooring with cedar. Although I originally intended to apply several coats of varnish to this decking, I followed the advice of an ''expert'' and painted the flooring instead. The paint soon peeled, and the deck has been repainted several times since. Each time, all peeling paint was scraped off.

LEAD: The well-known English indifference to fashion does not apply to plants. A visit to the halls in Westminster in London where the Royal Horticultural Society stages 12 shows each year reveals that black pansies and hellebores (the claret colored ones above all) are now in favor. And ''geraniums are making a comeback, you know,'' one frowzily dressed English matron excitedly assures her friend as they look over a display of pelargoniums.

LEAD: On paper, Stanford University looks flush. As it turns 100 in the fall, this college of lush greenery and rust-tiled roofs is blessed with prestige, a $2 billion endowment and generous alumni who have raised nearly $1.1 billion in a fund drive.
LEAD: One worker to another: ''How come I didn't see you at the last party congress?''

LEAD: Kelly Ann Healey, a public relations representative, and Peter James Albano, a vice president and bond trader, both at Salomon Brothers in New York, are planning an October wedding, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Healey of Barrington, Ill., have announced.

LEAD: Rafael Rivera Garcia, a highly regarded Puerto Rican art professor who said the police, courts and city agencies left him defenseless against the terrifying harassment of a biased white neighbor, was acquitted yesterday of trying to murder the man.

LEAD: One cannot be totally disappointed with the United States team's performance in the World Cup tournament, although the United States team has a few weaknesses. The first was poor ball-controlling techniques, and the second was the long passing of the ball. The improvement in these areas would require good coaching and playing many matches with international teams in the next four years to be exposed to the international standard of play.

LEAD: SUNDAY Three weeks after almost being released, Andy Hawkins pitches a no-hitter in Chicago and loses, 4-0. The Yankees commit three errors in the eighth inning to allow the runs. Hawkins becomes the first pitcher in 23 years to lose a complete-game no-hitter, the first in modern baseball history to pitch an eight-inning complete-game no hitter.
LEAD: CLASSICAL

LEAD: The word that leaps from Felice Michetti's lips as she seeks to articulate the special stamp that the administration of David N. Dinkins will put on city-assisted housing programs is affordability.

LEAD: Tonight's opening concert of the Tanglewood season had the air of a class reunion. The festival's educational adjunct -the Tanglewood Music Center - is 50 years old this summer, and there were distinguished alumni in every size, shape and form trundling on and off the stage of the Shed.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: ''It'' began when we responded to an ad in the newspaper that read ''Second Wives/Stepmothers support group forming. . .contact. . .''

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Wyndham R. White 3d of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Allison Stuart White, and Stephen Douglas Twente, a son of Patricia A. Twente and Dr. Elmer W. Twente of Brooklyn.

LEAD: Karah Henry, a daughter of Frances McDonald Henry of Durham, N.C., and John F. Henry of Mattydale, N.Y., was married yesterday in Amsterdam to Marc C. van Gelder, a son of Mieke J. and Bob F. van Gelder-van Teeseling of Bussum, the Netherlands. The Rev. E. E. van Steenis, a minister of the Dutch Remonstrant Protestant Church, performed the ceremony at St.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev brought his unruly party congress under control today, heading off a series of up-or-down votes on his leadership team that had threatened to become a vote of confidence on Mr. Gorbachev's programs.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Suttenberg of Syosset, N.Y., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Jill Dara Suttenberg and David Matthew Altshuler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan A. Altshuler of Belmont, Mass. Miss Suttenberg, 24 years old, graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University. An associate at Corporate Decisions, a Boston management consulting firm, she is also a saxophonist and the director of the Sunday Jazz Band at Harvard.

LEAD: At the First Congregational Church in Williamstown, Mass., Tina Maureen Webster and Thomas Maxwell Loose, both 23 years old and graduates of Williams College, were married yesterday by the Rev. David Williams.

LEAD: THE steady rush of the Still River, which winds past the old grist mill in Brookfield, offers those who visit the Brookfield Craft Center one of many glimpses of the past. During the 1800's, the main building in the community housed the Brookfield Mills and general store, where townspeople came to gossip and to barter food, ironware, furniture and other goods.

LEAD: I think of Bursa as the most Eastern city in the west of Turkey - it lies not far from the Sea of Marmara, along the foothills of one of the tallest mountains in Turkey. The mountain, Ulu Dag, now a ski resort, was once called Mount Olympus. It rises at the beginning of the great high plains of Anatolia.

LEAD: On Wednesday, 475 guests of R. H. Macy's chief executive, Edward S. Finkelstein, were treated to an unobstructed view of Macy's annual Fourth of July pyrotechnics display over the East River. They included Macy's executives, their families and guests from the worlds of fashion and theater. They boarded the Dutchess of New York yacht for a leisurely dinner cruise around the harbor, docking on the Long Island

LEAD: AS Connecticut's political faithful prepare to gather in Hartford for the state party conventions, the spotlights and headlines will focus on the candidates seeking the nominations for governor. But the tops of the tickets will probably be determined without much drama.

LEAD: Frequent visitors to Singapore know that amid the city's wonders there are occasional flies in the Tiger Balm. Forty-eight-hour deliveries are frequent from Singapore's 24-hour tailors. Happy hour comestibles in the city's bars and lounges are far below Western standards in quantity and variety if not in quality.

LEAD: Some days, when Paris gets just too speedy, I prefer sweet-scented conifers to chestnuts in bloom, a tranquil, narrow path to a vibrant, wide avenue. Though it's rush hour, I can actually hear birdsong, and only very distantly a faint susurrus of traffic. Far from the melee of tourist buses, I relax in the peace and quiet of the Montparnasse Cemetery.

LEAD: The new Fiorello Festival of dance got off to a model - and often exhilarating - start on Friday night with a program of work by Beverly Blossom, Janis Brenner and Jeanette Stoner. The evening was a tribute in its way to the Hanya Holm-Alwin Nikolais-Murray Louis tradition of modern dance to which the three belong.
LEAD: EVERY SPY A PRINCE The Complete History of Israel's Intelligence Community. By Dan Raviv and Yossi Melman. Illustrated. 466 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: In Hollywood, money talks. What it has been saying recently is revolutionary.

LEAD: A FANTASY of many buyers of resort condominiums is that when they are not using them their units will be rented by contented, careful vacationers. The upbeat sales literature for the resorts often encourages such expectations.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: When it opens on Tuesday at the New York State Theater, the Bolshoi Ballet will not look too different from the way it did on recent visits. During the two-week engagement, the company will present a familiar quota of full-evening classics and spectacles - from ''Swan Lake'' and ''Romeo and Juliet'' to ''Ivan the Terrible,'' a modern-day signature work by Yuri Grigorovich, director and chief choreographer of the

LEAD: An executive of the second largest company that processes claims for New Jersey's pool for high-risk drivers was arrested today on charges of accepting bribes to allow body shops and appraisal companies to inflate repair bills, law-enforcement officials said.

LEAD: An Arizona insurance executive with a history of legal and regulatory problems was allowed to buy 15 insolvent Texas savings and loan associations with borrowed money in 1988 and was promised $1.85 billion in Federal subsidies. Congressional investigators call the arrangement the worst abuse found in the Federal bailout program.

LEAD: Etienne Chatiliez is the big noise these days in popular French cinema. In 1988, after directing some 70 television commercials notable both for their humor and their against-the-techno-glitz-grain narrative qualities, he made a resounding leap into feature film with ''Life Is a Long Quiet River,'' which opens in New York on Friday at the Paris Theater.

LEAD: About 20 years ago, Connecticut politicians tried tinkering with the state's tax system and brought on a political clampdown. They created and passed an income tax for the first time, but within weeks the law was repealed under a storm of public outrage. Tax reformers went underground, and a new generation of income-tax hard-liners within the state's majority

LEAD: IT had rained the night before, and all the plants were washed clean. They looked fresh and green. There was also a fragrance in the yard, but it was not apparent where it was coming from. Only a few plants were in bloom, as it was a between time, past the glories of spring, but not quite ready for the opulence of annuals.

LEAD: There are at least 120,000 Thais living in the greater Los Angeles area today - more than in any other region outside Thailand itself. What has drawn them to the city? Prakas Yenbamroong, a Thai banker-turned-restaurateur who has himself been an L.A. resident since 1979, suspects that it has something to do with the area's climate, which he considers not unlike that of Thailand- and, he adds unexpectedly, with the city's profusion of Chinese and Mexican restaurants.

LEAD: Dripping Air-Conditioner Question: We live in a very old building in Manhattan. Since tenants above us installed a very powerful air-conditioner in their window water constantly drips and often pours from it down to our ledge and window sill. When their air-conditioner is on we cannot leave our windows open.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Donna Marie Soares, the daughter of Dr. Anthony T. and Dr. Louise M. Soares of Trumbull, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Walton Kemp, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Kemp of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. M. Joseph Joaquin officiated at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Trumbull.
LEAD: Let's stop blaming mothers and turn our attention toward making the world a better place in which to raise children.
LEAD: Attitude cannot be taught. Gregg Jefferies has my vote.
LEAD: Rebel forces continued their siege of Monrovia today, preventing food, water and fuel from entering the encircled Government stronghold in the city's densely populated center.

LEAD: Being tired of reading George Bush's lips, I was reading some of my old newspaper clips the other day, and there in the middle of The Times's Op-Ed page of May 2, 1979, was a big headline: ''George Bush for President?''

LEAD: NEW YORK 1913: The Armory Show and the Paterson Strike Pageant, by Martin Green. (Collier/Macmillan, $14.95.) In 1913, just about the time that the famous show at the 69th Regiment Armory on Lexington Avenue was introducing New Yorkers to the likes of Picasso and Duchamp, Big Bill Haywood and the Wobblies were organizing a different kind of insurrection: a march up Fifth Avenue by 1,200 New Jersey millworkers striking for an eight-hour day.

LEAD: NINA SKLANSKY moved into her new apartment on West 55th Street last August and, boy, was she pleased with it. Then, on her first night there, through the windows and out of the walls came the BANG! and the CRASH! and the CLANNNGG! from the hotel being built across the street. ''It was like dinosaurs fighting out there,'' she said.
LEAD: The Bush Administration has decided to allow American commercial satellites to be launched on Soviet rockets for the first time, Government and industry officials say.

LEAD: I grew up thinking cheese was something a little smaller than a breadbox, about the color of finger-painted pumpkins and as perishable as powdered milk. The only time I ever tasted the real thing was when my father was feeling flush enough to invest in a round of Colby longhorn to ration out in thin slices on saltines as a late-night snack.

LEAD: The history of the game is replete with accidents of various kinds. The first occurred in 1929 when Ely Culbertson took his foursome to Paris following a victory in London. The scoring was French-style ''plafond'' with which the Americans were not familiar and the host country had a small lead throughout.

LEAD: As I read your article ''Community Hospitals Adapt to Changes'' (May 27), I found it to be quite enjoyable and unfortunately accurate in describing the financial plight of most of New York States' community hospitals. There is a real financial crisis in the hospital industry due to reimbursement patterns of Medicaid,
LEAD: LYING TOGETHER By D. M. Thomas. 247 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

LEAD: To the Editor: This letter is in response to Sylvia Steinbrock's complaint (Letters on Travel, May 6) about the 900 number of the French Government Tourist Office. As a tour operator specializing in travel, to France only, I feel that the 900 number is an excellent initiative to help travelers get the information they seek to arrange their trip to France.

LEAD: In his pursuit of fashion novelty, Franco Moschino of Italy might well have thumbed through the Frederick's of Hollywood catalogue. So might Thierry Mugler of France, Katharine Hamnett of Britain or, for that matter, any number of world-class style provocateurs in search of new ideas. Leggy body stockings, lacy lingerie, slick bustiers - the venerable catalogue is rife with items that have influenced designers on both sides of the Atlantic.
LEAD: I enjoyed reading the article ''Suffolk Wrestling With Fate of Estates'' (May 13), which focused on the fate of several historic homes on the island.

LEAD: For those planning a trip to England this summer, the news in recent weeks has not been so good. Since the beginning of June, the pound has risen by 10.5 cents, to $1.7865, from $1.6810. This is a 6 percent increase - or, put another way, a 6 percent cut in the budget for American travelers. And four cents of the pound's rise came in the last week.

LEAD: To the Editor: I would like to warn prospective travelers in Portugal of the possible theft of their luggage from a van or station wagon. I remember vividly my shock and disbelief when five suitcases were stolen from our locked Ford while it was parked in a deluxe hotel parking lot. The remaining 10 days of our stay were largely devoted to replacement of my husband's prescription medicines, some clothing and other necessities.

LEAD: October wedding plans for Deborah Ann Firsty and Wayne Joseph Zuckerman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Zuckerman of Hillside, N.J., have been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Firsty of Santurce, P.R.
LEAD: It is refreshing to see a man like Joseph Fernandez take charge.

LEAD: After three weeks of bitter negotiations that often lasted late into the night, the Massachusetts Legislature today sent a $1.6 billion tax package to the desk of Governor Michael S. Dukakis. The Governor's press secretary said Mr. Dukakis would sign the bill early next week.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The brash new City Council, opting for a utopian antidote to Communism, has voted to take the city's entire apartment housing stock from the state's control and give it away free to millions of hard-suffering tenants.

This is a 6 percent increase - or, put another way, a 6 percent cut in the budget for American travelers. And four cents of the pound's rise came in the last week.

LEAD: To the Editor: I would like to warn prospective travelers in Portugal of the possible theft of their luggage from a van or station wagon. I remember vividly my shock and disbelief when five suitcases were stolen from our locked Ford while it was parked in a deluxe hotel parking lot. The remaining 10 days of our stay were largely devoted to replacement of my husband's prescription medicines, some clothing and other necessities.

LEAD: THE RED-HAIRED WOMAN: And Other Stories. By Sigerson Clifford. (Mercier Press/Dufour Editions, Paper, $9.95.) LEAD: TOWARD WHAT BRIGHT GLORY? By Allen Drury. (Morrow, $22.95.) LEAD: The history of classical-music performance since the time of Bach has been, in large part, a history of scale. Not musical scales, but scale in terms of size. As audiences and ensembles have grown, so have the spaces in which performances were to take place. That, in turn, meant brighter, louder instruments along with augmented performing forces.

LEAD: We are four of us, men in our early 30's, squatting on crude stools on a sidewalk in Da Nang, a perpetually sunny city on the central coast of Vietnam. LEAD: At the game's start, the thermometer read 99 degrees. An hour later, it had climbed to 102. Franco, just a couple of outs away from the cool of the clubhouse and the relaxation of the All-Star Game break, stood on the lonely rise of baked clay, upset at a rut in the mound, concerned about the 2-1 lead over the Braves he had been charged with preserving and incensed with himself for having issued consecutive walks.

LEAD: Debra Lynn Rosenstock, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Rosenstock of Plainview, L.I., , was married yesterday to Michael V. Goetz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael S. Goetz of Philadelphia. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster officiated at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I.

LEAD: Greece's new Conservative Government and the United States signed an eight-year agreement here today providing Greece with more than $1 billion worth of arms in return for the continued operation of American military bases in this country.

LEAD: Chile, one of the lowest-tariff countries in Latin America, will open negotiations with Washington this week about establishing a free trade zone with the United States, Finance Minister Alejandro Foxley said Friday.

LEAD: Having today become perhaps the ultimate achiever in the history of his sport, Franz Beckenbauer has the luxury of choosing whether to take on a new challenge or to drift off into the hazy limelight enjoyed by very wealthy retired superstars.

LEAD: Bonnie Honig, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Honig of Montreal, was married there yesterday to Michael Dennis Whinston, the son of Dr. George J. Whinston of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Joan Aronson Whinston. Rabbi Sidney Shoham performed the ceremony at the Queen Elizabeth Hotel.
LEAD: The South African police announced today that nine white men with known right-wing sympathies have been arrested in connection with a series of bombings in the last three months.
LEAD: If the American people don't holler fast, the crooks who looted the nation's savings and loans are going to get off very cheaply.

LEAD: When ANTHONY J. F. O'REILLY became the chief executive of the H. J. Heinz Company 10 years ago, the company was smaller and less profitable. If success is measured by one's peers, Mr. O'Reilly has been successful indeed, since he was chosen as Chief Executive of the Year from more than 1,400 others.

LEAD: The Group of Four went to the rodeo tonight, where they saw armadillo races, bull riding, barrel racing, calf scrambling, the Grand Ole Opry, an Old West village, cowboys and Indians, oil rigs, square dancing, a sheriff with silver spurs, Styrofoam cacti, a model of the space shuttle, horseshoe contests, 1,250 gallons of barbecue sauce and jalapenos, 500 pounds of onions, 5,000 servings of cobbler and carrot cake, and 650 gallons of lemonade and iced tea.

LEAD: Analysts and money managers say that the bond market rally that began in late spring has been sidetracked for the time being, but that it has not been derailed. Consequently, yield levels, which had been inching lower, are likely to have an upward bias over the next few weeks at least.

LEAD: Henry J. Kuss Jr., an international military consultant who was the Defense Department's chief arms salesman in the 1960's, died of cancer Friday at Fairfax Hospital in Falls Church, Va., a family spokesman said. He was 67 years old and lived in McLean, Va.
LEAD: The weather table for U.S. cities on Friday incorrectly reported the high temperature for Thursday in Washington. It was 99 degrees, not 113.
LEAD: The Milwaukee Brewers, who trailed by 7-0 in the third inning, scored 20 unanswered runs today and beat the California Angels, 20-7.
LEAD: A prominent Kenyan lawyer, who has been in the forefront of the push for a multiparty democracy, has sought refuge in the United States Embassy in Nairobi, the American Ambassador said today.

LEAD: A smoky house fire, accidentally started by a child playing with a cigarette lighter, took the lives of a 43-year-old Bronx woman and her 4-year-old son yesterday in the Williamsbridge section, the authorities reported. A police spokesman, Sgt. Edward J. Burns, said the fire broke out about 4:15 P.M.
LEAD: While scholars debate what books should be taught in college, there is no debate about those that students are reading outside the classroom.

LEAD: In the ultimate capitalist test, Soviet publications are gingerly making their way on to American newsstands in a market already saturated with foreign policy journals and glossy travel magazines.

LEAD: Revolution is sweeping Latin America and Washington, sensibly, wants to encourage it. LEAD: The good news for the Yankees is that their next contact with a baseball won't be until Thursday. They are so desperate to get away from the game that Manager Stump Merrill canceled a Wednesday workout.

LEAD: Suzanne Kaufman, the daughter of Esther F. Kaufman of Brooklyn and the late Joseph A. Kaufman, was married yesterday to Lee McClure Come, a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Arnold B. Come of Larkspur, Calif. Rabbi Ari L. Fridkis performed the ceremony at CAMI Hall in New York.

LEAD: After the discovery of masses of human bones in secret graves in caves here and nearby over the last two weeks, a series of witnesses have come forward to report seeing large-scale shootings 45 years ago, painting a grisly picture of mass murder by the Communist Partisans led by Marshal Tito.

LEAD: Charon scored an overpowering nine-length victory yesterday in the $287,500 Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park, and only one thing could have made her handlers happier: they almost wished that Go for Wand had been in the race.
LEAD: Jack Armstrong of the Cincinnati Reds will start for the National League in Tuesday night's All-Star Game, Roger Craig, the league's manager, announced today.
LEAD: PRODUCERS from two of the five series CBS will broadcast this summer call what they are doing ''guerrilla'' television.

LEAD: Senator Nunn has recently offered a plan to enlist the Pentagon's aid in saving the planet. Though the chairman of the Armed Services Committee's new interests may not be entirely unconnected to his old interest in safeguarding military spending, his ideas are worth considering on their merits. They open up potentially important areas for cooperation, and set off a number of alarm bells.

LEAD: The editor of The Financial Times recently sent his journalists a brisk memorandum urging them to cut costs. Among the measures he suggested were avoiding expensive restaurants, canceling some foreign trips, using public transportation rather than taxis to Heathrow Airport and sharply curtailing the practice of ''F.T.

LEAD: Julie Kuberka stood on the edge of the Hudson River here, pulling in a laundry line cord with a white plastic tile at its end. Her assistant, Jennifer Curnow, sealed the tile in a plastic freezer bag, ready to be sent back to a laboratory for analysis.
LEAD: Page Group Publishing Inc. has purchased a pair of reader-written magazines in Beverly Hills and Brentwood.
LEAD: FOUR years ago, analysts expected E-Systems Inc., which makes highly sophisticated military electronics, to elude likely cutbacks in Pentagon spending and prosper.

LEAD: As Eastern Europe struggles toward democracy, it must also grapple with a ravaged environment. Corrosive soot has fouled water and soil, and in blackened industrial cities the air is laced with heavy metals and chemicals. In a world ruled by production targets, there was no pressure to clean up.
LEAD: A young man was stopped last night as he was trying to reach his home. It was dark, and long past Monrovia's dusk-to-dawn curfew.
LEAD: Physicians must act more aggressively when women find lumps in their breasts, a study of malpractice claims and lawsuits indicates.

LEAD: Brick and steel, bit by bit, the 90-year-old piers built here by German steamship lines to last for ages are reluctantly coming down, opening this Hudson River waterfront to a future filled with uncertainty.

LEAD: In international education tests among industrial nations, American students usually come close to the bottom in math and science; the Japanese are always on top. More than 90 percent of Japanese children graduate from high school; close to 30 percent of Americans drop out. If a nation depends on the quality of its people, American children should be worried about their future competitors.

LEAD: The Acura luxury car division of the Honda Motor Company of Japan has topped the J. D. Power & Associates list of cars most satisfying to owners for the fourth year in a row, the marketing company said last week.
LEAD: An exhibition that was staged by the Nazis to vilify artists like Picasso, Wassily Kandinsky and Paul Klee will be presented in Los Angeles next year, but under very different auspices.
LEAD: Seldom has there been a more blatant case of blaming the victim than those pious American demands, during Nelson Mandela's visit here, that he renounce violence as a political instrument.

LEAD: PHIL LOMBARDI and Greg Olson are starring in this season's poor man's version of the Wally Pipp and Lou Gehrig story.

LEAD: President Bush plans to tell the United States' six main industrial allies this week that he is prepared to send teams of experts to the Soviet Union to help it rebuild rail and communications networks, grain storage sites, food distribution systems and other essential services, senior White House officials said today.

LEAD: To be a woman, 40 and unmarried in a farming village of rural Pakistan is virtually to count for nothing. About all the attention a single woman can attract is negative: social ostracism and sometimes physical abuse. But here in Shah Jewna, nobody fools with Jivni.

LEAD: Treasury financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, an offering tomorrow of 30-year bonds by the Resolution Funding Corporation to finance the bailout of savings institutions and Wednesday's auction of seven-year notes.

LEAD: Sophie Kochaney sat in the ninth pew at St. Bridget Catholic Church today clutching a rosary as she has every Sunday for 51 years. But this time she went through a fistful of tissues and received communion with tears in her eyes.

LEAD: Jamie Lauren Columbus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Columbus of Rochester, and Richard Allan Glaser, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Glaser of New York, were married yesterday by Rabbi Shamai Kanter in a garden near the bride's home in Rochester.

LEAD: George T. Eggleston, a cartoonist, yachtsman, author, editor and isolationist who became embroiled in a national controversy in the 1940's, died Saturday in a nursing home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: George Burditt of Santa Barbara, Calif., won $1 million recently by being the first person to punch in, using the buttons on his telephone, the correct numerical answers to seven questions. He was the first winner of a new national contest that people enter by dialing a ''900'' telephone number, paying $2.99 for the call.

LEAD: DOG SHOW World Champion Crowned: A dog whose ancestors came from the sacred city of Lhasa, Tibet, is the champion of the canine world. He is Ch. Chakpori's Mao, a golden Lhasa Apso owned and handled by Bianca Saasen of Eindhoven, the Netherlands. Mao triumphed yesterday at the world show in Brno, Czechoslovakia.

LEAD: How slowly does traffic move in New York City on hot summer afternoons? LEAD: For 38 years, the McCarran-Walter Immigration Act has allowed the U.S. to bar foreign visitors whose ideas the Government finds offensive. The number of visitors kept out each year varies, but the Government maintains a list of more than 350,000 people to be excluded. LEAD: Americans took out $3.9 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in May, 10 times the amount incurred only a month earlier, the Government said today.
LEAD: The Supreme Court by a vote of 7 to 2 today rejected a request to free a Texas television reporter serving a six-month jail term for refusing to reveal the name of a confidential source.
LEAD: Mario Lemieux will have back surgery Wednesday but there is a 90-percent chance he will be ready for the start of the Pittsburgh Penguins' season, the team doctor said today.

LEAD: The General Instrument Corporation disclosed that it had been approached by an unidentified financial concern seeking information about the New York-based electronics company. The disclosure came as Forstmann Little & Company formally began its friendly $1.6 billion tender offer for the company.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: John C. Carroll, retired executive vice president of the Communications Workers of America, died Saturday at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 68 years old and lived in Forestville, Md.

LEAD: The leaders of the seven major industrialized nations may arrive at decisions in Houston this week that can make or break the present Uruguay Round of multinational trade talks. If they listen to food exporting countries, especially in the third world, they will hear this: Open up markets, or forget about new trade rules on services and intellectual property.

LEAD: CYCLING Italian Takes 9th Stage Massimo Ghirotto of Italy won the ninth stage of the Tour de France yesterday while Steve Bauer of Canada held onto the overall lead for the ninth day. Ghirotto broke away with Eduardo Chozas of Spain in the first of the mountain passes as the race crossed into Switzerland on a 122-mile leg from Besancon to Geneva.

LEAD: Fashion is almost always in a state of flux, so it is curious that hemlines on the runways have remained stable for about three years. With surprising unanimity, leading designers in Europe and America have shown suits, dresses and, for fall, coats that are no more than fingertip length. An occasional below-the-knees style is seen on the runway and immediately dubbed dowdy.

LEAD: ANALYSTS say there are at least 40 million personal computers in use worldwide, and millions of new PC's will be added this year. To Alex Randall, that means there are at least 40 million used computers out there that will eventually need a new home.

Partners & Shevack is already the agency for Anacin-3.

LEAD: A Swiss investor has agreed to settle Federal charges that he bought shares of Rorer Group Inc. while possessing nonpublic information about a pending merger between Rorer and Rhone-Poulenc S.A.
LEAD: A woman who falsely accused a man of raping her appealed today to the Nebraska Supreme Court her perjury sentence, which requires her to pay for advertisements apologizing to the man.

LEAD: Space agency officials said today that a primary seal in a large pipe that carries liquid hydrogen fuel to the space shuttle is the ''prime suspect'' for causing leaks that have grounded all three of the spacecraft.

LEAD: Tens of thousands of flag-waving fans greeted West Germany's World Cup champions here today in a peaceful show of pride that was a stark contrast to Sunday night when four people were killed and hundreds injured after street celebrations turned violent.

LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, priced a $600 million issue yesterday in its regular monthy sale. The Government-sponsored public corporation usually sells short-term floating-rate notes on the Monday before the second Thursday of each month, The notes, due Jan. 10, 1991, were priced at par to yield 25 basis points more than the bond-equivalent yield of the 91-day Treasury bill and are expected to begin trading today.

LEAD: Mobil Oil has agreed to spend what is expected to be tens of millions of dollars to clean up a vast and hazardous pool of oil that has been seeping under the streets of Brooklyn for more than 40 years.

LEAD: Annoucing that it would open its first American outpost in Trump Tower in Manhattan, Galeries Lafayette, France's largest department store, said it would specialize in women's clothes made in Europe in an effort to succeed in a neighborhood that contains some of the world's most fashionable retailers.

LEAD: One month before a deadline for financing a $4.38 billion acquisition of the UAL Corporation, the employee buyout group has enlisted the tentative financial support of five major banks, according to United's unions and bank officials. But none of the banks have signed agreements to provide loans, and several obstacles remain to be overcome before the Aug.
LEAD: Bernard Perricone, the youngest of the world's first documented male quadruplets to survive, died Sunday at a Nederland hospital. He was 60 years old.

LEAD: Federal regulators are considering filing a $200 million lawsuit against Neil Bush, the President's son, and other directors and officers of the defunct Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver, seeking to recover some of the $1 billion in losses from speculative lending and insider transactions, officials said today.

LEAD: Molly Yard, president of the National Organization for Women, predicts ''the feminization of power'' as more women win public office. Women politicians talk enthusiastically about the ''decade of the woman.'' Dianne Feinstein, the Democratic nominee for governor of California, says that a woman official can protect abortion rights more reliably than a man.
LEAD: Eric M. Warburg, an international banker and a member of the German banking family, died on Monday at his home in Hamburg, West Germany. He was 90 years old.

LEAD: With the financial futures industry fearing for its future, and some parts of the securities industry warning of a financial crisis unless there is reform, pressure is building for Congress to control just how much risk speculators can take when they use the futures market to bet on whether stock prices will rise or fall.

Proulx, who resigned from those positions in June, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Hiller, 50 years old, has been vice president of finance of the Atlanta-based razor and lighter company since 1986.

LEAD: Alain Chapel, regarded as one of the finest chefs in France, died yesterday while visiting friends in Avignon, France. He was 53 years old.
LEAD: New York State's highest court today widely expanded the rights of unwed fathers, ruling that a state law restricting their ability to intervene in adoption proceedings was unconstitutional.

LEAD: Prices rose an average of 25 percent at grocery stores today as the Czechoslovak Government ended subsidies on farm products and fresh and processed food. There was some grumbling, but on the whole there appeared to be widespread acceptance of the increases.
LEAD: A boy and a girl playing on their front lawn in Rosedale, Queens, were struck and killed last night by a car that ran through a stop sign, apparently out of control, the police said.

LEAD: A. Donald MacKinnon, a lawyer with Milbank, Tweed, Hadley, & McCloy for nearly 50 years, died on June 21 at the Seabrook Health Center in Hilton Head Island, S.C. He was 94 years old and moved to Hilton Head recently from Summit, N.J.

LEAD: The school board has dismissed the Superintendent here, citing a lack of ''mutual trust and cooperation.''

LEAD: Sandra M. Schor, a poet, novelist and associate professor of English at Queens College, died on Monday at the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. She was 58 years old and lived in Locust Valley, L.I., and in Manhattan. Her family said she died of cancer.

LEAD: United Banks of Colorado, the largest banking company in the state, said yesterday that it was discussing a possible merger with the Norwest Corporation, the largest banking company in Minnesota. With $6 billion of assets, United Banks is about a fourth the size of Norwest. The two companies, which have been the focus of merger rumors, said no agreement had been reached.

LEAD: CERTAIN lean, meaty fish, like halibut, swordfish and marlin, require utmost care in preparation to prevent dryness. If you barbecue or broil them, frequent basting is necessary. Sauteeing is less risky, but you must check frequently to avoid even the slightest overcooking. In this recipe for halibut with lemon sauce, I take the safest route, poaching.
LEAD: Dr. David Owen turned 52 years old a few days ago, a month after the failure of his decadelong attempt to create a European-style Social Democratic Party outside the British Labor movement.

LEAD: * Ketchum Communications, working through the Advertising Council, has prepared an ad campaign for the State Department. The effort, which advises Americans on how to travel abroad safely, begins next month.

LEAD: The Illinois Supreme Court cleared the way today for a stroke victim's guardian to seek withdrawal of the food and water that is keeping the patient alive.

LEAD: The unemployment rate in the European Community has remained steady at 8.6 percent for the first five months of the year, the European Community statistical office reported on Monday. Unemployment ranged from 1.7 percent in Luxembourg to 16.6 percent in Ireland.
LEAD: An All-Star Game in Wrigley Field with two runs scored?
LEAD: Ronan Pensec celebrated his 27th birthday today with as pretty a present as the Tour de France can offer: he received the yellow jersey of the overall leader.

LEAD: The law we learned in Physics 101 that two bodies cannot occupy the same space at the same time is getting its annual hot weather test on the sidewalks of New York. Back in January and February, streetwise walkers used the west side of the avenues in the morning and the east side in the afternoon, absorbing whatever warmth they could from the winter sun.

LEAD: Mackey Sasser, the Mets' catcher who was injured in Sunday's game in Atlanta in a collision at home plate with Jim Presley, was examined by the Mets' team physician, Fiske Warren, yesterday and was reported to be suffering from a sprained right ankle.
LEAD: When Mona el-Rifai returned from a spell in Saudi Arabia eight years ago, she had become used to wearing Islamic dress and thought others might like to do so as well, so she opened a store.

LEAD: TENNIS Wilander Comes Back Mats Wilander, playing competitively for the first time in five months, defeated Johan Anderson, 6-0, 6-3, yesterday in the Swedish Open in Bastad. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD Burrell Stays Unbeaten Leroy Burrell of the United States remained unbeaten at 100 meters in the Nikaia Grand Prix meet last night at Nice, France.

LEAD: Political and labor leaders called today for a general strike on Wednesday to protest the return from exile of the former leader of the brutal paramilitary force built by the Duvalier family to maintain its 30-year dictatorship.
LEAD: Former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. was sentenced by a Federal district judge today to 5 years and 10 months in prison and a $170,000 fine for a variety of corrupt acts both in and out of office.

LEAD: English soccer clubs were readmitted to European tournaments today without special conditions, ending a five-season ban imposed after the Heysel Stadium riot in Brussels in which 39 persons died.

LEAD: Bidding that starts at the one-level is usually very accurate, like the operation of a watch. But if the opponents begin with a pre-empt, it is like throwing sand in the watch. Some good guessing is needed to be accurate, complicated by the fact that bad breaks are now more likely.

LEAD: City residents today rejected by 12 votes a waterfront redevelopment plan with the Port Authority that municipal officials said would be a financial boon but that opponents charged would overwhelm the small Hudson River community. The vote was 4,418 against and 4,406 in favor of the plan, according to figures from the City Clerk's office.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Galeries Lafayette's plan to open a store on 57th Street misstated the location of Henri Bendel. That store is at 10 West 57th Street, just west of the Galeries Lafayette site. The article also misstated the location of Saks Fifth Avenue in some editions.

LEAD: Using torture, murder and mass arrests, governments trampled the human rights of tens of thousands of people in 1989 to suppress conflicts stemming from ethnic or nationalist tensions, Amnesty International says.
LEAD: The American Red Cross has delayed reporting or has failed to report to the Federal Government hundreds of errors it has made in handling contaminated blood, a Federal inspector reports.
LEAD: A Sikh leader who helped fashion a brief truce between the Indian Government and Sikh militants was assassinated today in the capital of Punjab.

LEAD: Near the beginning of ''Father Was a Peculiar Man,'' an exhilarating evening of environmental street theater presented by En Garde Arts, an actor from the company of more than 60 performers approaches the audience and excitedly offers his theory of the significance of Madonna. By suggesting that sex is possible in the age of AIDS, he says, she is ''trying to become a Christ - she will link us together.
LEAD: The donation by the media of time and space for public service campaigns dropped by 15 percent last year, to $1.04 billion, from $1.23 billion in 1988, the Advertising Council said yesterday.

LEAD: Hundreds of striking Sandinista workers and students stood aside and offered little resistance today as riot police officers and army bulldozer crews knocked down barricades that the protesters had built to stop traffic in a nationwide protest that began here Monday morning.
LEAD: Stock prices sank yesterday in waves of computer-driven program selling that swept through the market most of the day.

LEAD: At last it seems possible to get younger. Growth-hormone injections have done the trick for a test group of men aged 61 to 81, according to last week's science news. Practically all of them perked up noticeably, regaining scientifically measurable amounts of the mustard commonly associated with younger men.

LEAD: IN Bo Jackson's latest commercial for Nike Inc., there does not seem to be anything the versatile sports celebrity cannot do. LEAD: Louis P. Singer, an investment banker and a retired senior partner in Troster, Singer & Company, an over-the-counter securities concern, died on Monday at University Hospital in Denver. He was 84 years old and lived in Hewlett Harbor, L.I.
LEAD: The State Department advised American citizens today to defer all nonessential travel to Kenya because of anti-Government strife there.

LEAD: STEVEN RUBIN, who founded a large oil brokerage firm, flees his life several times a year for the Maharishi Ayur-Veda Health Center in Lancaster, Mass., a serene and elegant retreat where the emphasis is on integrating the mind and the body.

LEAD: The economic world focused on the business of the seven leading industrial powers here, but Houston's food community has been obsessed since April with the politics of culinary summitry. LEAD: Mitch Snyder's memorial service was held here today with all the trademarks that had characterized the homeless advocate's life: Hollywood celebrities mingled with homeless men and women and 37 people were arrested at City Hall in a protest after the service.

LEAD: American Airlines, reacting to what it calls ''excessive charges'' imposed by five airports, plans to add ticket surcharges of $1 to $4 beginning next week for its flights from those airports.

LEAD: The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it had created a form of diamond with an enhanced ability to transmit heat and light. Company spokesmen said it could lead to important advances in microchip design and new applications for lasers.

LEAD: Archbishop Eugene Marino, the first black to be appointed a Roman Catholic Archbishop in the United States, resigned today as head of the Atlanta Archdiocese, citing a need for ''spiritual renewal, psychological therapy and medical supervision.''

LEAD: Like many parents who cannot afford health insurance for their children, Edith M. Harris has known the guilt of delaying her sons' vaccinations and treating their fevers with compresses rather than antibiotics.
LEAD: The person most likely to be entertained by ''The Adventures of Ford Fairlane'' need not be made aware of the film's existence. He's already on the screen.
LEAD: JERK-STYLE Jamaican barbecue is more prevalent than McDonald's along East 233d Street in the Bronx, and Allan Vernon is known there as Vernon, the King of Jerk.

LEAD: When they get off the plane in Moscow today, 50 young American musicians from all over the country will have just two days before they meet and start rehearsals with 50 of their Soviet counterparts for a joint concert at the Moscow Youth Palace on July 19.
LEAD: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

LEAD: Shaquille O'Neal sat on a bench outside his dormitory, shifting his weight in a futile effort to find a pocket of cool air on this hot, humid Minnesota night. LEAD: The Houston summit conference was a successful holding operation. In the face of conflicts over aid to the Soviet Union, the elimination of agricultural subsidies and actions to deal with environmental pollution and global warming, the leaders of the seven major industrial countries preserved their civility and produced a set of compromises that will enable them to go on working together a while longer.

LEAD: English is the lingua franca of summitry. At NATO summit meetings, France's representatives still make a point of speaking French in plenary sessions, but in the corridors they converse informally in English. At economic summit meetings, some leaders still rely on translators, but the sherpas who accompany them to the summit do their communique drafting in English.

LEAD: One of the tasks of the art of the last 10 years has been to reconstruct the notion of natural beauty in the face of a seemingly endless onslaught against nature. Mankind's alteration of previously pristine spaces, from tropical rain forests to the very air we breathe, poses a challenge that is not only environmental, but also esthetic: can art reflect what is happening to the natural world while retaining its traditional attachment to the sublime?

LEAD: Unnerved by the rising public outrage over the nation's savings and loan scandal, the Republican Party opened an orchestrated effort today to blame the Democrats before the Democrats succeed in their effort to blame the Republicans.

''What kind of clown are you?'' a bank guard snarls at a man in a circus costume, who has wedged one giant red shoe in the door at closing time. Beneath his painted smile, Bill Murray assumes the most serious, sincere expression and answers sweetly, ''The crying-on-the-inside kind, I guess.'' After Mr. Murray's character, Grimm, robs the bank and takes some hostages, the police chief bargains on the phone for their release. ''At least give me the women,'' the chief pleads, and Grimm yelps, ''Get your own women!''

LEAD: Walk along a weedy roadside or an unmowed field, especially toward the end of a heavy summer day, and suddenly you are surrounded by surprising flowery smells from a couple of commonplace plants. The bright, heady scent is from honeysuckle, an aggressive and unwelcome vine that climbs everywhere. The musky scent comes from the gawky milkweed, whose clustered flowers summon up the poet's perfumes of Araby.

LEAD: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said this week that it had affirmed Time Warner Inc.'s BB-rated long-term debt and B-plus subordinated debt and preferred stock ratings. The securities were removed from S.&P.'s Creditwatch, where they had been placed for possible downgrading. Roughly $1.5 billion of long-term debt and $5.6 billion of preferred stock are affected.

LEAD: In today's perilous marketplace, one might think it imprudent to tinker with a winning formula. Yet Richard Lavin, the affable and savvy restaurateur who owns Sofi on lower Fifth Avenue and Lavin's on West 39th Street, has done just that. He has taken the popular Sofi, which served inventive American food for three years, and made it northern Italian - a move that seems akin to converting the New York Mets to a soccer team.

LEAD: A Federal district judge today ordered that the man who has become the focus of an investigation into two fatal bombings in the Southeast last December be held without bail after his indictment earlier this week on unrelated charges of perjury and obstruction of justice.

LEAD: Michael Tilson Thomas, the principal conductor of the London Symphony Orchestra, had his arms tightly folded and his face twisted in a mild scowl the other day as he sat in a recital hall in the back woods of Hokkaido, Japan's northern-most island. ''The percussion must be much, much more after the third bar,'' he said emphatically, as his comments rippled in translation through a newly assembled orchestra of young music students from the Korean countryside, the west coast of South America and the urban tangle of Tokyo.

LEAD: The Mets, conceding that they ran the enormous risk of losing their marquee player and facing a severe public backlash next fall, said today that they had broken off contract negotiations with Darryl Strawberry because of a ''huge gulf'' and would not resume them until the end of the season.

LEAD: A scientific expert from the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified yesterday that a DNA analysis of semen found in the jogger in Central Park did not match any defendants charged with her rape and attempted murder.

LEAD: O'Connor and Rome There was a great deal of speculation last month when John Cardinal O'Connor abruptly left a spiritual retreat in California and got on a plane for Rome. He had arrived in California just the day before from New York in anticipation of spending a week with other bishops from around the nation.

LEAD: From the season's start, Frank Viola has insisted that he doesn't focus on his statistics, being, among other things, suspicious that he might get dizzy from any high opinion of himself that might result. Tonight, his numbers weren't anything to get dizzy about.

LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl will fly to Moscow late Saturday for some personal diplomacy with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, hoping to convince the Soviet leader to drop his remaining objections to German unification within NATO, West German officials said today.
LEAD: Recharging a dead automobile battery can now be as easy as flipping a switch.

LEAD: Lucy Gaspe gazed up St.-Michel Street, past a crowd of reporters and television crews, past knots of police officers with pump-action shotguns crouching behind a wall of sandbags, to a barricade of upturned police cars and a front-end loader at the crest of the hill.

LEAD: Pressed by widespread public anger over steep rate increases for cable television service, Congress is close to imposing modest controls over prices. But disputes over proposals aimed at fostering competition could derail the legislation and leave the industry a winner by default.

LEAD: Jacques Demers, who guided the Detroit Red Wings to the playoffs for three consecutive seasons before the team missed out last season with a 28-38-14 record, was dismissed as head coach yesterday. He was replaced by the former coach of the Washington Capitals, Bryan Murray, who will also be general manager.

LEAD: Johnny Newman, the Knick small forward, signed a free-agent offer sheet with the Charlotte Hornets yesterday.

LEAD: Helped by strong demand for light trucks from General Motors and Ford, sales of American-built vehicles rose 2.5 percent in early July, the industry's second consecutive 10-day period of healthy sales gains.

LEAD: Robert B. McKay, a former dean of the New York University Law School who led the New York State commission that investigated the 1971 Attica prison uprising, died yesterday morning in Reno, where he was to address the National Judicial College. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: A biotechnology company in New Jersey won a patent this week for a method of preventing fruits and vegetables from spoiling by using genetic engineering to enhance their natural defenses against fungus.

LEAD: Luther Henry Tindal, who is 45 years old and looks 60, and his wife, Linda, 34, rest on a dust-caked couch outside their $125-a-month cinderblock shack here, smoking discount cigarettes and drinking discount beer.

LEAD: In a break from past policy of shunning the Cambodian Government, the Bush Administration announced today that it had accepted an offer by Phnom Penh to cooperate in examining what could be the remains of Americans missing in action from the Vietnam War.

LEAD: Tattered, penniless and weary, but jubilant just the same, thousands of Albanian refugees sailed today into Western Europe and, they were certain, to a better life.

LEAD: Any complaints that the United States Women's Open was being played under conditions that were too easy came to an abrupt halt today as the field sloshed around a waterlogged golf course in the midst of waiting out three rain delays.

LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev remains hopeful that the Communist Party, still the only nationwide political force, provides the best vehicle for reforming the Soviet Union. Boris Yeltsin, arguing that hard-liners who still dominate party ranks are unreformable, now abandons the party to take a different path to radical change.
LEAD: ''Worse in the near term, better in the long term.''

LEAD: The stock of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation moved higher today amid rumors and speculation about the struggling military contractor's future. McDonnell Douglas's shares rose $1.25 each, to $44.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

LEAD: Thirty-nine Haitians fleeing their impoverished Caribbean island drowned when their sailboat capsized and sank in choppy seas while being towed by Bahamian authorities, Government officials said.

LEAD: The staff of the state's utility regulating board recommended today that a rate increase sought by New York Telephone be denied and the company be forced to cut its rates instead.

LEAD: In the 20 months since the United States Supreme Court outlawed racial quotas that favored white applicants to the huge Starrett City housing complex in Brooklyn, the black and Hispanic families who had sought apartments for years have remained stuck on a long waiting list.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that illegal profits of at least $1 million were obtained from a sophisticated insider trading scheme in the stock and options of the Contel Corporation shortly before the company announced Thursday that it would be bought by the GTE Corporation.
LEAD: Robert Nelson Timmins, a New York investment banker, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60 years old.

LEAD: At least 40 correction officers and 47 inmates were injured on Rikers Island yesterday when 48 Muslim prisoners seeking revenge for the slashing of their religious leader stormed the cell of his attacker, correction officials said.

LEAD: The Communist Party suffered additional major defections today as the Moscow and Leningrad City Council leaders quit the party and insurgent forces began moving slowly toward forming a national opposition coalition.

LEAD: Prof. John F. Middlemiss, a lawyer in Brooklyn and a retired law professor, died on Thursday at the home of a daughter, Nancy Palmer, in Fairfield, Conn., where he celebrated his 91st birthday on Sunday.

LEAD: Automobile experts warn that if your car is not properly maintained in summer, a vacation could come to an unexpected stop. Make sure that lights, brakes and wipers are in good condition.
