LEAD: Hundreds of counterfeit car-inspection stickers are turning up on cars in suburban New York counties in what motor-vehicle officials say is the largest such scheme they have seen.

LEAD: A woman who has engaged in a protest for the last two years by camping in front of the motel where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. died was ordered by a judge today to get out of the way of workers building a museum there.

LEAD: Disposable diapers have become a symbol of a throwaway society. They squander resources and clog scarce landfills. To be environmentally responsible, parents should use cloth diapers, which can be washed and re-used many times. Or should they? A study of the comprehensive environmental impact of both kinds of diapers, conducted for Procter & Gamble by a prominent consulting company, suggests that neither has a strong advantage.

LEAD: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it expects a sharp decline in second-quarter earnings because its Allstate Insurance group's catastrophe-related losses exceeded expectations and sales by the merchandise group were disappointing.

LEAD: The former head of the Hooker Corporation, the collapsed retailing concern, and his wife have declared bankruptcy, citing debts of nearly $400 million. George and Sheila Herscu filed debtors' petitions in the Federal court at Melbourne on Monday, which the court accepted. The Hooker Corporation was placed in receivership a year ago with debts of about $1.6 billion.

LEAD: The Rev. Manley Beasley, a prominent Southern Baptist evangelist who did not allow a longtime kidney ailment to keep him away from the pulpit, died of kidney disease on Monday in a hospital in Dallas. He was 58 years old.
LEAD: Bruce K. is a pilot who flies Boeing 727 jetliners for a major airline. He is also a recovering alcoholic.
LEAD: * Bancorp Hawaii Inc., Honolulu, said it would acquire FirstFed America Inc., Honolulu, a savings and loan holding company, and its units.

LEAD: A co-star of the television comedy ''Cheers,'' KELSEY GRAMMER, has been ordered to stand trial in Van Nuys, Calif., on a cocaine possession charge after failing to enter a drug-treatment program.

LEAD: Fang Lizhi, China's most prominent dissident, said today that he planned to study in the United States for at least six months beginning in January. He also said that while he was there he would meet with exiled Chinese dissidents and speak out against his country's Government.

LEAD: The Arizona Supreme Court has unanimously ruled that former Gov. Evan Mecham can run for governor this fall despite his being impeached and removed from the office in 1988.

LEAD: In a decision that would remove France's leading independent book publishing company from family control, Francoise Gallimard has agreed to sell her 12.5 percent stake in Editions Gallimard to the Banque Nationale de Paris.
LEAD: The Senate today completed Congressional action on a far-reaching bill to bar discrimination against people with physical and mental disabilities.

LEAD: The shares of the General Instrument Corporation rose today on the expectation that a new offer might arise to top the friendly bid of $1.6 billion made earlier this month by Forstmann Little & Company.

LEAD: Steve Sax got a couple of hits: a double and a single. Steve Balboni got a couple of hits: a single and his eighth home run of the season, a bases-empty shot in the fourth inning. Nobody on the White Sox got more than one hit, but that didn't stop Chicago from beating the Yankees, 3-2, at Yankee Stadium last night.

LEAD: Joseph F. Cullman 3d, a leading organizer of women's professional tennis events, and Jan Kodes, one of the leading men's singles players of the early 1970's, will be inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame in Newport, R.I., today.

LEAD: The growing use of personal emergency-alert systems, devices of potential benefit to millions of older people, is giving unscrupulous businesses a chance to prey on some of the nation's most vulnerable consumers.

LEAD: Democratic leaders pounded the Republicans over the savings and loan scandal today. But the attempt to compel the Attorney General to consider appointing an independent prosecutor in the case of Neil Bush appeared to founder as Republican leaders threatened to retaliate by seeking an outside prosecutor to look into the actions of former Democratic leaders.

LEAD: This is a tough summer for the French. Bad enough that a reunited Germany will put an end to French aspirations to the leadership of Europe. Bad enough that the English are buying up half the Normandy and Brittany coasts as summer homes. But now, the truly inconceivable has happened: Citroen has announced that, after 43 years, the last Deux Chevaux will roll off the final remaining production line, in Portugal, at the end of the month.

LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York stepped up their criticism of the Census Bureau today, charging that the accuracy of the 1990 census was imperiled by the agency's reluctance to correct its tally to make up for millions of uncounted Americans.
LEAD: The Superintendent of Schools here announced Thursday that he would resign at the end of the next school year.

LEAD: An article on Monday about an exhibition of art labeled ''degenerate'' by the Nazis misstated the dates. LEAD: Proposals aimed at reducing the threat of airborne asbestos in buildings have set off a furious debate in New York City, which already has some of the toughest asbestos regulations in the country.

LEAD: Mary B. Joy, a former official with the American Association of University Women who was also active in many other civic organizations, died on Wednesday at her home in Morris Township, N.J. She was 82 years old and died of congestive heart failure, her husband, Homer, said.
LEAD: Joey Browner, a strong safety for the Minnesota Vikings who has played in the last five Pro Bowls, has signed three one-year contracts.

LEAD: Eddie Pizzaro grew up poor in Spanish Harlem. His father abused drugs, went to jail every so often and beat his precious mother in front of him. Out on the ragged streets, friend after friend seemed to fall inexorably into similar dismal traps.

LEAD: Vice President Dan Quayle sought to reassure a nervous group of Republican leaders today that President Bush did not simply kick away one of their best campaign issues when he acknowledged last month that tax increases would be needed to reduce the Federal budget deficit.
LEAD: Just as a resolution appeared at hand in a bitter patent battle over a promising laser technology to correct near-sightedness and far-sightedness, a new complication arose this week.

LEAD: A black man convicted of murder 12 years ago read a statement denouncing the death penalty as racist and then was strapped into Alabama's electric chair and executed early today.

LEAD: When a personal doctor retires or dies, long-term patients confront two problems: finding another doctor and obtaining medical records.

LEAD: A terrible thing is happening to President Bush's youngest son, Neil. He is in danger of being turned into a sound bite.

LEAD: In the first Congressional action on the 1991 military budget, a Senate committee today approved a plan to cut $18 billion from the Bush Administration's proposal, and called for sharp troop reductions in Europe and cuts in the ''Star Wars'' anti-missile program.

LEAD: Ten years ago, a Queens restaurant owner named Jimmy Yu was shot and killed by a young holdup man who fled the eating place in Rego Park. Within weeks the police identified a 17-year-old resident alien from Italy, Anthony Sciacca of Queens, as the gunman.
LEAD: Lucien Paye, head of the O.E.C.D., which groups 24 industrialized countries, was asked what worried him most on the horizon. U.S. budget and trade deficits? Protectionism? Recession?

LEAD: Representatives of the clergy and the laity of the Greek Orthodox Church in the Western hemisphere have recommended that the church allow married priests to become bishops. The proposal, which would alter 1,300 years of Eastern Orthodox practice, would require an unusual consensus among Orthodox Christian bishops.
LEAD: Earl Stewart, who won two events on the PGA Tour and coached golf for 13 years at Southern Methodist University, died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

LEAD: A lawyer for a Bronx man accused of blowing homemade darts at women said yesterday that the evidence against his client is flimsy and the charges motivated by the publicity surrounding the attacks.

LEAD: Gov. William A. O'Neill, making his final address at a state convention as Connecticut's chief executive, spoke tonight of Democrats' past glories but offered no detailed guidance to a party that he conceded is now badly fractured.
LEAD: American Dental Laser Inc. of Birmingham, Mich., obtained a patent this week on a laser system to remove tooth and gum decay without the need for drills, scrapers or even Novocain.
LEAD: Helped by strong department store sales, overall retail sales rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Government reported today. It was the first increase since January.

LEAD: Lyudmila Semenyaka, the best known of the Bolshoi Ballet's current crop of visiting ballerinas, can do better than the ''Swan Lake'' she proffered with alternating casualness and intensity on Thursday night at the New York State Theater.
LEAD: Zewdu Sahelu, a 55-year-old Ethiopian Jew who has never been to school and can neither read nor write, arrived in the capital here two months ago from his farm, expecting to go to Israel.

LEAD: The New York City Board of Education, which until this month absorbed the full cost of substitute-teacher applications and most costs for prospective full-time teachers, has begun charging all applicants $104 in fees.

LEAD: Lured by the pop-star glamour of Roland Gift, an unusually youthful theater audience swarmed through the Staller Center for the Arts at the State University here this evening for the first of five performances of Shakespeare's ''Romeo and Juliet.''
LEAD: Beach Towel rallied midway through the stretch tonight and captured the $1,153,500 Meadowlands Pace by a nose over Jake and Elwood.
LEAD: After 19 days of testimony from 22 witnesses, the prosecution in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug and perjury trial announced today that it had almost completed its case.

LEAD: Esther Lucile Brown, an author, educator and social anthropologist whose contributions led to major changes in nursing education and practice, died July 6 at Pacific Presbyterian Medical Center in San Francisco. She was 92 years old and lived in San Francisco.
LEAD: Paul Laurent, a senior official of the French Communist Party, died of cancer on Sunday. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: New York City's school system is at a critical point of transition. Mr. Fernandez has made an impressive start in his first seven months on the job.

LEAD: Genentech Inc. today reported sharply lower earnings for the second quarter because of expenses related to its planned merger with Roche Holdings Inc. It also told of a weakening in sales of its heart-attack drug, tissue plasminogen activator, possibly because of mounting competition.

LEAD: R. J. Reynolds's two-run single broke an eighth-inning tie and Barry Bonds hit a homer today as the surging Pittsburgh Pirates continued to dominate San Diego by beating the Padres, 8-4. Pittsburgh has won 10 of 11 games against the Padres this season, including all 5 at Three Rivers Stadium, after losing 9 of 12 to them last season.

LEAD: It has taken a decade for the message to sink in, but the advertising industry has come to accept the fact that consumers do not receive information only from the usual sources - network television, newspapers and magazines. LEAD: WHEN 17-month-old Ari Winkleman toddles around his Hastings-on-Hudson backyard, his parents worry about the spills and falls he will take as he exercises his new-found motor skills. What they don't worry about is his exposure to pesticides on their property.

LEAD: INSIDE TRACK: My Professional Life in Amateur Track and Field. By Carl Lewis with Jeffrey Marx. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Carl Lewis, the track and field superstar who has won six Olympic gold medals, is one of the world's greatest athletes. In his autobiography, ''Inside Track,'' Mr. Lewis focuses not on his athletic prowess but on the reasons why he has been unable to cash in on his celebrity.
LEAD: Steinbrenner may be meddlesome and idiotic, but it is his constitutional right. He should stay unless found guilty in the Spira hearing.

LEAD: Computers are getting faster, more powerful and more reliable, and so too are modems, the devices that allow two or more computers to share information over regular telephone lines. Fairly bristling with advanced circuitry, the new modems achieve their performance by taking over a lot of processing done by computer-based software communications protocols.
LEAD: LISTENING to fine music in beautiful surroundings can add immeasurably to the delight, and this week there are several opportunities to enjoy concerts in esthetically pleasing settings.

LEAD: EVERYONE makes fun of the word mulch. It does sound strange, yet it is fun to say. Those who are serious members of the trowel and hoe fraternity know well what the word mulch means, however, and they are good practitioners of its use.

LEAD: Salt is something associated with health - too little can cause fainting in hot weather and too much can raise blood pressure. The word salary, for example, comes from the Latin salarium, which was the money paid to Roman soldiers to buy salt.

LEAD: One of the popular Wall Street parlor games these days is buying closed-end funds at a discount. The rules are simple. Check the price of a closed-end fund, a fund whose shares trade publicly like common stock. Check the per-share market value of the fund's portfolio. If the fund's price is a lot lower than its net asset value, consider it a bargain.

LEAD: A LOT TO MAKE UP FOR. By John Buell. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) Marino resigned last week as head of the Atlanta archidiocese, colleagues said he had been under ''a great deal of stress'' in a growing archdiocese with a shortage of priests. The 56-year-old Archbishop had temporarily relinquished his duties in May, when he entered a retreat after suffering chest pains brought on, his doctors said, by ''physical and psychological stresses possibly relating to cardiovascular functions.

LEAD: Karen Sydney Greenberg, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney S. Greenberg of New York, was married last evening in New York to Richard David Rudman, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Rudman of Milwaukee. Rabbi Miriam Shapero performed the ceremony at the Mark Hotel.

LEAD: MONDAY: Business inventories for May. TUESDAY: Merchandise trade for May. Industrial capacity and utilization for June. WEDNESDAY: Housing starts and consumer prices for June. Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan appears before the Senate Banking Committee. The United Auto Workers begin contract talks with General Motors.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: I say, bravo, Bryant. He runs a terrific show. It took guts for him to write that memo, and I happen to agree with his assessment of Willard Scott.

LEAD: If the modern watch industry had a theme song, it would probably be Peter Allen's ''Everything Old Is New Again.'' Mechanical watches, which all but ceded the market to quartz movements more than a decade ago, are best-sellers again. Analog faces, the ones with big hands and little hands, have recaptured a chunk of the market from digital displays.
LEAD: COBBLERS are enjoying a renaissance. Most often they are deep-dish fruit desserts with some kind of pastry topping.
LEAD: In response to Pete Dunne's ''In the Natural State'' column, ''In Trying to Kill the Gypsy Moth, Are We Going Too Far?'':
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: By the Air to the Beach

LEAD: The differences between men and women are slowly disappearing, at least in the hair salon. First, men ventured into unisex parlors for hair cuts. Then they tried perms. Now, more are getting color: highlights so locks look sun-touched, or dark streaks to emphasize the pepper rather than the salt.
LEAD: EAST HAMPTON'S Laundry Restaurant is celebrating its 10th anniversary. Although that is not a monumental milestone for most Long Island restaurants, for an East Ender, it is an accomplishment.

LEAD: Q. We have a bad mildew problem on the outside of our house, especially on the north side. We have tried the usual measures, including scrubbing with bleach, but nothing has helped. We are now planning to cover these eaves with aluminum or vinyl siding. Must the mildew be washed off before the new siding is installed over it?

LEAD: If there were an Oscar for the best architecture criticism in a movie, ''Gremlins 2: The New Batch'' would win hands down. Who could put Donald Trump in his place more deftly than Joe Dante, the director whose movie takes as its target a horrifyingly sleek and impersonal glass skyscraper built by a horrifyingly sleek and impersonal developer named Daniel Clamp?

LEAD: Joe DiMaggio's 56-game hitting streak came to an end in Cleveland on July 17, 1941. Most serious fans know that DiMaggio was stopped by the clutch pitching of the Indians' starter, Al Smith (12 victories, 13 losses that year), and the reliever Jim Bagby Jr. (9-15) and by two great fielding plays by the third baseman, Ken

LEAD: Dr. Laura Helene Kahn, a staff resident in internal medicine at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, and David Nathaniel Spergel, an assistant professor of astrophysical sciences at Princeton University, are planning an August wedding.

LEAD: Approval of Gov. Jim Florio's job performance has plummeted among New Jerseyans over the last three months, as they have reacted negatively to the multitude of tax increases he introduced in his first months in office, a new poll has found.

LEAD: For the miners, rubber planters and colonial officers who made Malaya their main chance in the late 19th century, the sweltering lowlands must have seemed a trial, to be endured then just as now by repeatedly dousing the body with cold water.
LEAD: FOR some prominent chefs from New York City, restaurants and food shops on the Island are providing safe harbors in the economic storm.

LEAD: When Elverda Commings introduced her 5-year-old son to swimming in 1979, her ambitions were confined to the local Boys Club in Blackjack, Mo. She paid the $5 membership fee and later, when her son began racing, she paid a modest meet fee of 75 cents per event.

LEAD: Connecticut's Democrats split over the choice of a candidate for governor at their state convention here today, forcing the first gubernatorial primary in 12 years. But the break was far less rancorous than many delegates had feared.

LEAD: AWAY FROM HOME: A Novel in Ten Episodes. By Penelope Farmer. (Victor Gollancz/Trafalgar Square/David & Charles, $19.95.) When it is pointed out to Elinor, the central character in the British writer Penelope Farmer's third novel for adults, that she is letting her feelings run away with her, she rails against the notion that people ought to have a sense of humor, a belief that she equates with not taking oneself seriously.
LEAD: From time to time, Italian cookbooks and restaurants come up with some combination of pasta and potatoes - the carbohydrate-loader's dream.
LEAD: The Professional Golfers' Association intends to consider the membership policies of a potential host club before selecting the site of the PGA Championship, the organization said today.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Herman Plotnik of Westwood, N.J., have announced March wedding plans for their daughter, Michele Beth Plotnik, and Lee Warren Brooks, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Selig Brooks of Fair Lawn, N.J.

LEAD: Cynthia E. Barber, the daughter of Hortense L. Howell-Barber of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Eric R. Mingo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Mingo of New York. The Rev. David D. Cockcroft performed the ceremony at the Riverdale Presbyterian Church.
LEAD: Should honorable, decent men who personify Yankee Tradition (Yogi Berra and Dick Howser) have suffered the indignity and humiliation of being dismissed?
LEAD: SUMMER-STOCK theaters are those places in which young hopefuls in the industry can gain experience and where more-experienced hopefuls can hone their craft while waiting for that big break.

LEAD: August wedding plans for Susan Scott Parrish and Bruce Cordiner Judge have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, T. Kirkpatrick Parrish 3d of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. Lawrence A. Bianchi of Boston. Mr. Judge is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard D. Judge of Ann Arbor, Mich.

LEAD: It may have been bravado; it may have been naivete; it may have been her way of collecting her allotted 15 minutes of fame. But for Linda Kean, allowing herself to be photographed for a magazine article on AIDS has led to an attempt by the police to have her charged with attempted murder.
LEAD: A HISTORY OF SOUTH AFRICA By Leonard Thompson. Illustrated. 288 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $29.95.

LEAD: The sale of a vacation home has never been blessed with the tax advantages that normally help to reduce or postpone indefinitely the capital gains tax due on the sale of a principal residence. This is a problem for the seven million households that the American Resort and Residential Development Association estimates now own second homes.
LEAD: ''Funny, you don't look Jewish.''

LEAD: FATHERS and sons, mothers and daughters, mothers and sons, fathers and daughters: the continuity of family businesses depends on the willingness of younger family members to join the family firm and, sometimes, to take it in new directions.
LEAD: WORKING IN HOLLYWOOD By Alexandra Brouwer and Thomas Lee Wright. 546 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $24.95.

LEAD: A long-neglected stretch of parkland along the Hudson River in northern Manhattan will be the site of a 127-slip marina and 60-seat restaurant if a plan by the New York City Parks Department is approved.
LEAD: NEW JERSEY residents are recycling more trash than anyone had expected, according to a new report that has already begun to intensify the incinerators vs. recycling debate.
LEAD: THREE years after Connecticut developed a comprehensive environmental plan setting out goals for the year 2000, a state environmental panel has reported little progress toward meeting them.

LEAD: WHEN Virginia Woolf wrote about a room of one's own, she didn't specify which room. She didn't rule out the attic, for instance. Woolf, claiming for women writers the physical space in which to explore spiritual space, left self-image issues to later generations of feminists.
LEAD: AMERICAN APOCALYPSE The Great Fire and the Myth of Chicago. By Ross Miller. Illustrated. 287 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $24.95.
LEAD: A ROMANCE OF THE EQUATOR The Best Fantasy Stories of Brian W. Aldiss. 345 pp. New York: Atheneum. $18.95.

LEAD: In what may lead to a larger battle over New York City's property tax system, the City Council has approved tax rates for the current fiscal year that hold down increases for the owners of cooperatives, condominiums and rental apartments.

LEAD: If you're over 60 and still on Wall Street, you might as well be dead. So goes the cutthroat business credo in Annette Meyers's TENDER DEATH (Bantam, $17.95), which causes the heroine, Leslie Wetzon, no end of distress. Not only is the headhunter-sleuth having problems placing her veteran clients (''The older broker had become a dinosaur''), but the mysterious death of a 78-year-old woman with vast stock holdings has her wondering whether there might be some plot afoot to boot all the old-timers off the Street and into the grave.
LEAD: Armed with honors, degrees and noble ambitions, 25 of the nation's brightest scholars are going to battle for better education in some of the neediest schools in this state's rural areas.
LEAD: I have known about Amy ever since she ran into a tree. She is 23 years old, a restaurant manager on Long Island, and a friend of my son's. She also knows more about air bags than most of us.
LEAD: A fire that destroyed a large section of the historic downtown here in May has left the question of when and how to rebuild.

LEAD: The name of Alberto Salazar first blazed across the world distance-running scene in 1980, when Salazar won the first of three straight New York City Marathons and snapped Bill Rodgers's string of four. Now almost eight years after his last victory in that 26-mile-385-yard event, the 32-year-old Salazar is planning to return to running in the Big Apple after several years of injuries and operations.

LEAD: Just two days after he signed a two-year contract to remain head basketball coach at Cleveland State, Kevin Mackey was arrested Friday night on a charge of driving while intoxicated as he left a suspected drug house, the police said. The school immediately suspended him without pay until more is learned about the case.

LEAD: The solution to NBC's ''Today'' problem is so obvious that it appears no one can see it. When a show is so clearly dominated, both in style and content, as ''Today'' is by Bryant Gumbel, there is no real way to ''fix'' the sliding ratings without also doing something about Gumbel.

LEAD: Hartford, Conn. $500,000 226 Palm Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 90-year-old colonial; dining room, pantry, fireplace, 1 acre; taxes $1,186. Simsbury, Conn. $155,000 Walnut Hill Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 31-year-old Cape Cod; formal dining room, bedroom skylights, large country kitchen; taxes $1,515.

LEAD: October wedding plans for Priscilla Singer and James Halper have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Singer of Harrison, N.Y. Mr. Halper is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Halper of Washington.

LEAD: The engagement of Jamie Naomi Kolodkin to Michael Howard Carus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Carus of Merrick, L.I., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Kolodkin of Stamford, Conn. A December wedding is planned.
LEAD: Definitely, without a doubt, Steinbrenner should be suspended. Unlawful activities should not be tolerated along with the downfall of such a once-respected baseball franchise.

LEAD: Two years ago, Reggie Vokes had an odor problem. When hot, sultry air settled over the garbage landfill he manages in West Palm Beach, Fla., nearby residents complained about the sour smells wafting their way.

LEAD: After several years of rapid construction in the resort areas along Lake Erie, little waterfront property remains for additional development. As a result, attention is turning to a tiny cluster of islands off the shore here.

LEAD: Fay Vincent's commissionership is relatively young. Yet, as he begins his deliberations on the fate of the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner, he does so equipped with the knowledge of 70 years of precedent-setting acts by commissioners past.
LEAD: If horse racing is the sport of kings, stamp-collecting may be the hobby of kings.

LEAD: Students in the Soviet Union will be able to earn a degree that epitomizes capitalism, a master's in business administration, under a program that Clemson University is setting up in Moscow, the university announced today.
LEAD: PLAYS IN THE MAKING
LEAD: When it comes to the news, a survey indicates that Americans are both broadly interested and quite uninformed.
LEAD: When it comes time to figure out the Andretti family legacy, one item in the inheritance will be a front-row starting spot at the Meadowlands Indy-car race.

LEAD: Carolyn Talbot Seely, a counsel to Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, and Malcolm Hewitt Wiener, the founder and chairman of the Millburn Corporation and Comminvest, New York investment management companies, were married June 8. Iris McCleery, a justice of the peace in Ridgefield, Conn., officiated at the bridegroom's home there.

LEAD: GLADYS HUSTED OWEN stood next to an antique table dotted with five- and six-pound Revolutionary War cannonballs and gazed proudly at a watercolor of the Marquis de Lafayette. ''This was our most illustrious guest,'' said Mrs. Owen, her silver-and-white-flecked hair tucked neatly into a bun. ''We had a ball for him right here in this house.
LEAD: Great rivers cause anglers to fall in love.

LEAD: By the second inning yesterday, everything had fallen into place as it always does. The Chicago White Sox had seven runs, the Yankees had none, the afternoon at the Stadium was overcast and dreary, and people were booing, from the box seats to the bleachers.

LEAD: There are some things about a live operatic performance that a studio-made recording just can't duplicate. All the possibilities - inspiration, subtlety, revelation of a composer's work, seizure of a great moment, athleticism with its risk of disaster, simple music-making - are in play before an audience of flesh and blood, in one particular moment.

LEAD: Just the other day it happened again: I was sifting through a rack of charming but inflationary baby clothes together with my friend Susan when she said, sotto voce: ''I talked to my cousin yesterday. She saw 'Pretty Woman.' She said she loved it, too.'' Although I doubt Susan's cousin loves the movie as much as does Susan, who's seen it three times, the list of suspects keeps growing.

LEAD: In a move opposed by Mayor David N. Dinkins, the Transit Authority plans to make a concerted effort tonight to eject vagrants sleeping on the A train who prevent employees from cleaning subway cars.

LEAD: In the midst of a meterological Maelstrom, Patty Sheehan completed the two best opening rounds in the history of the United States Women's Open today to take a six-shot lead into what officials hope will be a 36-hole finale Sunday.

LEAD: A recent Midwestern drive presented more than expected sights like the Gateway Arch, Sears Tower and Blue Water Bridge. The roads between scheduled stops revealed a four-decade evolution in American motoring. The Interstate highways enter the 1990's, like many of us who travel them, pushing middle age.
LEAD: SOVIET DISUNION A History of the Nationalities Problem in the USSR. By Bohdan Nahaylo and Victor Swoboda. Illustrated. 432 pp. New York: The Free Press. $29.95.
LEAD: Before he put on a Yankee uniform for what he agreed would probably be the last time, Phil Rizzuto was finishing another cup of coffee.

LEAD: Uncritical presentation of a controversial medical procedure, thermography (''Diagnoses by Photographing Body Heat,'' New Jersey Q & A, June 17), is both poor journalism and a disservice to readers, patients, the medical profession and the legal system, to name a few.
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Hiroshi Nakachi of Tokyo have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Mari Nakachi and Daniel A. Simkowitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Simkowitz of Bloomington, Ind.

LEAD: The Mostly Mozart Festival will open a series of pre-concert Meet-the-Artist ''Tastings'' tomorrow at Avery Fisher Hall.
LEAD: A jury today sentenced to death a man who confessed to torturing and strangling one boy and stabbing to death two young brothers he found riding their bikes in a park here.

LEAD: Hawthorne $180,000 165 Hillcrest Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 36-year-old, custom-built ranch; h/w floors, natural woodwork; taxes $3,722. Howell$154,900 443 Casino Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old ranch; enclosed porch, den, family room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,443.

LEAD: Has black been banished? Probably not, but it has been pushed aside for the moment. These photos, taken at recent social events in New York, clearly show that vibrant colors have overtaken black as the sophisticate's choice. And it's not just the obvious shades, like red, that are being chosen, but juicier ones like orange and pistachio.

LEAD: For libraries around the world, the enemy is time. Since the 1850's, when all-rag paper became prohibitively expensive, printing has been done on wood-pulp paper. But alum, a component in that paper, reacts with atmospheric moisture to form an acid that dissolves the wood fibers: books become discolored and brittle.

LEAD: Originally, I regarded the Gumbel memo as a strange (and failed) attempt on the part of the network to add spice to the ''Today'' show by injecting controversy into it. Now it seems the memo is being used as a scapegoat for the poor decisions made by executives on the show.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN a bookstore in Rockaway Township recently, a customer stood in front of an overstuffed rack looking for magazines about New Jersey. An assistant manager pulled five from the shelf. ''We used to carry only New Jersey Monthly,'' she said. ''These others are new to me.''
LEAD: Taking Tea in London

LEAD: The melee in which 66 officers and inmates were injured Friday on Rikers Island was termed ''particularly distressing and ominous'' yesterday by the chairman of the New York City Board of Correction, because it indicates a failure to control the jail even when it is not overcrowded.

LEAD: For This Week: Snap old flowers off geraniums and cut them off pansies, petunias, snapdragons and other annuals to keep the plants blooming; formation of seed pods will stop flowering. If bloom is finished, cut stalks off astilbes, foxgloves, phlox, lilies, heucheras, delphiniums and other perennials to prevent seed pods.
LEAD: Joe Falcon captured the Dream Mile, Carl Lewis won a close 100 meters and Jan Zelezny of Czechoslovakia broke the world record in the javelin tonight at the Bislett Games.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I have always loved rivers. I learned I could feel the rhythms of a river in a canoe. But I hoped that, in a whitewater kayak, I could become part of the river. So I ventured in May to Sundance Expeditions on the Rogue River in southwest Oregon for a nine-day kayaking course.

LEAD: August wedding plans for Elizabeth Lawrence Hiser and Charles Park Hoban, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Hoban of Lake Forest, Ill., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harold R. Hiser Jr. of Short Hills, N.J.

LEAD: The Elwha River comes bouncing out of the high-country heart of this million-acre park, a surge of clean water that used to provide passage for some of the world's biggest salmon, the giant chinooks.

LEAD: Just an hour from Manhattan, there is a place of peace and beauty in Nassau County where the only reminder of civilization is the occasional sound of a car on Route 106. In the Muttontown Preserve, birds, wild animals, forests and fields coexist, quietly recalling the Long Island of two centuries ago.

LEAD: Last week, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, took the foreign exchange market by surprise, announcing Thursday that the central bank might ease interest rates because of dwindling credit from commercial banks and then, on Friday, actually pushing rates down slightly. The dollar fell sharply after his remarks but recovered some on Friday, partly because the June increase in producer prices was disappointingly high.

LEAD: Janette Sadik-Khan was married yesterday to Mark Geistfeld at the home of her father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. Orhan I. Sadik-Khan, in Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Thomas L. Stiers, a Congregational minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

LEAD: Keenen Ivory Wayans, Executive Producer, Writer and star of Fox Broadcasting Company's ''In Living Color,'' had a problem. He and Tamara Rawitt, one of the show's producers, had developed a sketch that would push the Fox network's cutting-edge humor policy to its limit. Or break it.
LEAD: TO ''HERLAND'' AND BEYOND The Life and Work of Charlotte Perkins Gilman. By Ann J. Lane. Illustrated. 413 pages. New York: Pantheon Books. $29.95.

LEAD: When the leaders of the Group of Seven industrialized nations met last week in Houston, the three main issues of contention were trade policy, aid to the Soviet Union and the environment. Here, by David E. Rosenbaum, a New York Times correspondent who covered the Houston event, is a look at the issues, what the summit meeting produced and the outlook.
LEAD: A REGIONAL health-planning agency recently took a hard look at health-care issues in the lower Hudson Valley and concluded that there were eight priority issues urgently requiring attention.

LEAD: When Twyla Tharp is presented with the annual Samuel H. Scripps-American Dance Festival Award today for lifetime achievement in modern dance, she will not - as is customary - accept it in a theater. The annual $25,000 award was established by the festival 10 years ago specifically to honor modern dance and its creative personalities.

LEAD: JACK GANCE, by Ward Just. (Ivy, $4.95.) A young pollster with connections to the Chicago political machine becomes a White House aide and then a senator. Last year our reviewer, Judith Martin, said Ward Just ''is not only the most literary chronicler of the daily lives and moral dilemmas of contemporary politicians, bureaucrats, intelligence agents, military officers, diplomats, lawyers and journalists, but one of the few novelists even interested in depicting such people realistically.

LEAD: In West Virginia politics, they do take prisoners. Last week former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. was sentenced to become one, joining nearly a dozen state legislators, lobbyists and government workers who have been convicted on corruption charges in the last couple of years. Mr. Moore, who served two terms as Governor in the 1970's and one term in the late 1980's, pleaded guilty to Federal charges of extortion, mail fraud, tax fraud and attempting to obstruct the grand jury that indicted him.

Ward Hallman, a minister of the Unity Church, officiated.

LEAD: Bill Carter's article about the ''Today'' show anchor Bryant Gumbel - and the contretemps swirling about him - was refreshingly evenhanded and temperate (''Forecast for 'Today': Cloudy,'' June 10). But could any of us measure up to the kind of intense scrutiny Gumbel has received?
LEAD: I'd just like to point out that no region of our nation is immune to ecological catastrophe. Ohio is, at the moment, underwater.

LEAD: A white roar disturbs the canyon quiet. Roabie Johnson pulls a pair of pliers from the holster on her belt and draws a diagram in the sand: two parallel lines to show the course of the river, three or four circles to indicate rocks, and a series of peaks that stand for tail waves. ''These pliers are your boat,'' she says as she threads the tool through the circles and aims it directly at the peaks.

LEAD: TRUMPET fanfares will introduce the 50th anniversary gala of the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival in Norfolk this afternoon at 3, followed by opera arias and vocal duets, short instrumental works of Bartok and Schumann, a Mozart String Quartet and other compositions. The performers, all members of the Norfolk faculty, include the trumpeters Allan Dean and Robert Nagel, the pianists Donald Currier, Ward Davenny and Joan Panetti, the oboist Ronald Roseman, the Tokyo Quartet and others.

LEAD: Later this month New Yorker Video will release four titles from its library of 400 foreign films. One, ''Sand and Blood,'' is in French. Two others are in Spanish and German. The fourth, ''Dragon Chow'' (set in a Chinese restaurant) is in German, Urdu and Mandarin. Along with other recent releases, the four films may be indicative of what some hope is a growing interest in foreign movies in this country, not to mention a developing tolerance for something many
LEAD: Students at Carnegie-Mellon University will soon be protected by a new campus security officer - the bicycle patroller.

Sands of Dallas, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. R. Leonard Allen of Lebanon, N.J. Ms. Allen, 29 years old, graduated from Yale University and earned an M.B.A.

LEAD: So far in 1990, antiques enthusiasts have paid premium prices at auctions for the finest period objects. This comes at a time when there are indications in the market that the decade-old antiques boom may be on the wane.

LEAD: AT 7 A.M. in the restaurant at the New Woodlands in Madras, more than 10 people are already waiting in line for breakfast. The scent of coconut drifts through the air as barefoot waiters race past bearing trays loaded with steaming white patties and large, fragrant pancakes. Madrasis and visitors pore over their morning papers, washing down patties and pancakes with small cups of sweet, milky coffee.

LEAD: The rhythm was fluid, the location precise, the fastball flat-out fierce, all of which made the analysis in his own mind indisputable. David Cone, the right-hander for the Mets with the ability to turn an encouraging roll into a long run of brilliance, is gathering momentum.

LEAD: Lois Moran Young, a star of Hollywood's silent films and Broadway musicals who began charming audiences as a dancer at the Paris Opera at the age of 13, died Friday at the Kachina Point Health Center, a nursing home in Sedona, Ariz., near Flagstaff. She was 81 years old and lived in Sedona.

LEAD: August wedding plans for Judith Gibson Allen and Paul Francis Mulkerrin, a son of Margaret Mulkerrin of Somerville, Mass., and the late Michael Mulkerrin, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon E. Allen of Osterville, Mass.

LEAD: When the nation's greatest and most troubled exercise in counting finally comes to an end - when the last form flicks through the machines, when the last enumerator turns in the last Questionnaire Misdelivery Record Nonresponse Follow-up, when the last lawsuit is filed - the 1990 census seems certain to stand as a bleak landmark in the annals of arithmetic.
LEAD: With all the brouhaha about index funds these days, something important is slipping by. Tracking Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is not the only way to go - or perhaps the best.

LEAD: Hidden by surrounding buildings, the 1929 Morrisania Hospital complex in the Highbridge section of the Bronx comes on you by surprise. It's a full-block derelict, closed since 1976, but all the more surprising because it is such a tidy derelict, with its windows neatly removed.

LEAD: Carnegie-Mellon University has always marched to the beat of a different instrument. Bagpipers lead the school's kiltie band onto the football field, and they lead the graduating classes in their commencement processions.

LEAD: Mount Holyoke College and the city of Holyoke, Mass., will open a new public middle school this fall that is intended to be a model for fighting rising dropout rates among urban youngsters, especially Hispanic students.

LEAD: I was surprised that there was virtually no mention in your article of John Palmer, who was one of the big plusses of ''Today.'' Although we were all sad to see Jane Pauley leave the show, there are many of us who were sorry to see this highly respected, veteran news professional downgraded to second-string status.

LEAD: In northeast Greenwich, 26 stately pleasure domes have been built at Conyers Farm, a 1,500-acre enclave resembling a contemporary Xanadu. Maintaining its private, pastoral quality is a set of covenants under which no more than 60 families may live on minimum lots of 10 acres, protected in perpetuity by deed restrictions.

LEAD: THERE is a surprising harmony among some plastic baskets, Op Art quilts and the 154-year-old converted gristmill where they are now on display at the Hunterdon Art Center. Both the center and the work in the ''Fiber as Art'' exhibition bear witness to their more mundane beginnings.
LEAD: Mark Twain considered reports of his death exaggerated. Likewise, the widely proclaimed demise of big-dish antennas (to receive satellite television) also turned out to be grossly overstated.

LEAD: At age 14 in her first year as a pro, Jennifer Capriati has already influenced women's tennis. Acknowledging her presence in the ranks among the top 20 players in the world, the Women's International Professional Tennis Council has revised its eligibility rules to allow the talented Floridian to qualify for the season-ending Virginia Slims Championships on Nov.

LEAD: William F. Weigel, a New York City lawyer and the former chairman of the Westchester County Republican Party, died on Friday morning at New York Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

LEAD: The Fresh Air Fund builds bridges between the woods of upstate camps and farms and the children of city streets and housing projects. And the fund builds other bridges, between the children and those who help the fund in ways large and small.

LEAD: The Komodo Dragon, an endangered 10-foot lizard that preys on small wild pigs, is not ordinarily much in the news. But in December 1984, a former organized crime figure named Charles Cantino, a k a Vincent A. Teresa, was charged with smuggling this and other exotic species into the United States.

LEAD: Rock-and-roll, with its unbookish culture, seems an unlikely candidate to adopt a literary figure. But there is no longer any doubt that the perennial iconoclast-author William Burroughs has been given a lifetime pass to the rock-and-roll circus. The bassist and songwriter Bill Laswell, leading a loose assemblage of players he calls Material, recently drafted the writer to read excerpts from his latest novel, ''The Western Lands,'' as part of the album ''Seven Souls'' (Virgin 91360; CD and cassette).

LEAD: BUYING lumber can be confusing. For example, any piece of lumber that is less than two inches thick and eight inches wide is called a strip; any piece less than two inches thick but more than eight inches wide is called a board.

LEAD: The Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival has a distinctively paradisiacal air these days. There is a sense that every inch of the newly landscaped, refurbished festival complex in the Berkshire woods has been happily taken over by dance, from the rustic benches and woodland ponds that offer performers and dancers in training moments of private meditation to studios brimming with classes and informal events that are open to theatergoers' casual inspection.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: The Communist Party significantly revamped its Politburo today, carrying out Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to separate the party hierarchy from the Government.

LEAD: UNTIL this year, about 225 4- and 5-years-olds were routinely given a developmental screening to test their readiness to enter the Katonah-Lewisboro school system kindergartens. But for this fall's kindergarten class, the test will be voluntary, as the appropriateness and the reliability of the standardized test has been increasingly called into question.

LEAD: As the unofficially designated ''first dropout'' of Hampshire College (1971-72), I would like to describe my impression of the tumultuous first days there (''What's New at Frisbee U.'' by Chip Brown, June 10). Like many applicants, I was mesmerized by the promise of the truly ''progressive'' education described in the college's catalogue.

LEAD: First came the villagers, then the weekenders, then growing numbers of resident commuters who ride the Upper Harlem Line and, finally, the office campuses with crew-cut lawns that have muscled their way in among the apple orchards and dairy farms of Putnam County.

LEAD: The engagement of Jennie Van Pelt McAvoy to Bart Lawrence Landenberger, the son of Jane Hamilton Landenberger of Bedford, N.Y., and the late John Landenberger, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. McAvoy of Tappan, N.Y. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Eckman of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Heidi Kim Eckman, to Barry Philip Silverstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Silverstein of West Newton, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: Merely to suspend Steinbrenner would be a tragedy. Nothing less than a forced sale of the ball club will rescue the legions of still-loyal Yankee fans and the team from the darkness and disgrace that this egomaniacal man has inflicted on us.

LEAD: KENT has art galleries like cities have bars. The number has gone from zero to seven in less than seven years - roughly one per 350 inhabitants. With its vintage railroad station and a Main Street rich in clapboard buildings, the hamlet could never have been an eyesore, but there's no doubt that it has been overtaken by gentrification, gilded store signs and all.
LEAD: The road from Lucena, the capital of Quezon Province, bogs down in mud miles from this fishing village at the base of the Bondoc peninsula.
LEAD: DAVID MAMET'S plays are populated for the most part by characters who are unable to establish meaningful relationships.

LEAD: Q. We have a bad mildew problem on the outside of our house, especially on the north side. We have tried the usual measures, including scrubbing with bleach, but nothing has helped. We are now planning to cover these eaves with aluminum or vinyl siding. Must the mildew be washed off before the new siding is installed over it?

LEAD: Yes, there are those of us who ''failed'' at experimental education, who caught the bus back to requirements and midterms and cumulative grade-point averages. And I don't think we are necessarily less self-reliant or less willing to take chances than the students who stayed.
LEAD: ''We take food very seriously here and we are great carnivores,'' said my hostess proudly, opening her refrigerator-sized freezer.

LEAD: Forgive my lack of modesty, but I am the most experienced and the best regular caddie at the Old Course at St. Andrews. I have caddied there at least four times a week for the last 44 years, since I was 14 years old. Of course, it has been my great privilege to carry Arnold Palmer's bag there in three British Opens, as well as the 25 others he has played in.
LEAD: Concerto for Piano and Guns
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: I read that a former newspaper colleague of mine is so depressed by the way things are in the United States these days that he says it reminds him of Romania.

LEAD: Mark Gastineau's debut in the Canadian Football League was just as provocative as the sack dance that used to set off opponents in the National Football League. Doug Flutie's was just as spectacular as his college career.

LEAD: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 WHILE MY PRETTY ONE SLEEPS, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Pocket, $5.95.) The murder of a gossip writer in New York. 2 8 THE JOY LUCK CLUB, by Amy Tan. (Ivy, $5.95.) Chinese-American women and their mothers.

LEAD: Although the Annadale neighborhood is flat, the district manager of Community Board 3 refers to it as ''the Beverly Hills of Staten Island.'' Situated on 1.8 square miles of the island's south shore, the community is one of the wealthiest in New York City. Some say Annadale owes its cachet to its lack of sewers.

LEAD: Dartmouth College is reviewing its procedures for dealing with sexual assault and harassment following two cases involving the editor of the college newspaper, who has been suspended over accusations that he sexually abused a woman student.

LEAD: Quick Call, who usually saves his best races for Saratoga, found a wet Belmont track to his liking yesterday and scored a front-running four-length upset victory over Sewickley in the $87,800 Tom Fool Stakes.

LEAD: More than half the nation's 9.8 million black children under 18 years old and nearly a third of the seven million Hispanic children lived with only one parent in 1989, according to a Census Bureau report.

LEAD: Those who need further evidence that nowadays no manner of alchemy can separate the art world from the world of politics might consider the following incident, which illuminates what is becoming a quagmire for American museums.
LEAD: THE RED KING'S REBELLION Racial Politics in New England, 1675-1678. By Russell Bourne. Illustrated. 273 pp. New York: Atheneum. $22.95.

LEAD: The summer months tend to dull City Hall's conscience on the homeless problem: with no one likely to freeze to death, the lack of decent shelter seems less urgent. But warm weather also means the homeless are far more visible - a sad, glaring reminder of official neglect.

LEAD: The Better Homes Foundation, a nonprofit organization serving homeless families, has been in contact with more than 1,000 programs that deal with issues regarding the homeless. Many of these programs find ''substance abuse'' a growing problem. However, this does not mean that substance abuse causes family homelessness.

LEAD: Two years ago, internal dissension threatened to destroy the Shanti Project, the San Francisco nonprofit group that is one of the world's largest providers of care for people with AIDS. Its founder had stepped aside and Douglas P. Holloway, a member of Shanti's board, ran the group on a day-to-day basis for eight months while holding down a full-time job as an executive vice president of Wells Fargo &

LEAD: It was a lucrative week for Mario Gabelli, the New York investor who has long been predicting a wave of takeovers in the independent telephone market. Mr. Gabelli owns 8 million shares of Contel, whose stock leaped $7.125 a share Thursday on the news of its merger with the GTE Corporation. That deal meant a paper profit for Mr.

LEAD: August wedding plans for Jeanne Edelen and Felix Bizaoui, the son of Ida Bizaoui of Southfield, Mich., and the late Eli Bizaoui, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William M. Edelen of Newtown, Conn. Miss Edelen, 26 years old, graduated from the Madeira School and the Muscular Therapy Institute in Cambridge, Mass.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about Japan's efforts to turn economic power into political influence gave an incomplete name and affiliation for a NATO seminar participant. He is Masashi Nishihara, a professor at the National Defense Academy.

LEAD: American tourists have always had a way of seeking out offbeat places. This summer they may roam even farther afield than before, as Eastern Europe seems increasingly congenial to visitors. So chances are that vacationers abroad may find themselves at some point a long way from the nearest newsstand that carries English-language papers.
LEAD: AN AMERICAN LOOKS AT BRITAIN By Richard Critchfield. 496 pp. New York: Doubleday. $22.95.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A picture caption on page 39 of The Times Magazine today, with the Fashion column, reverses the identities of two women in some copies.

LEAD: After a tedious decision-making process that resulted in his becoming the No. 1 selection in the college draft, after signing a six-year, $15 million contract to play in his hometown for the Indianapolis Colts and after practicing at the Colts' training center for the last month, Jeff George took a vacation in

LEAD: President Bush's next summit meeting might well be a cozy little chat in the Oval Office with a handful of environmental leaders. There's much common ground between them. But one would never know that from the poisonous and sometimes silly rhetoric that filled the air during last week's economic summit meeting in

LEAD: To the Editor: In the article ''New Phone Line Advises Travelers About Vaccines'' (Practical Traveler, May 13), Rosamond R. Dewart of the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta was quoted as recommending allowing six weeks prior to travel for getting information on vaccinations. I suggest that travelers allow at least eight weeks.
LEAD: Tamil rebels stopped three buses and shot to death at least 35 Muslim passengers in eastern Sri Lanka, Defense Ministry officials said today.

LEAD: When you give up a rook for a minor piece - a bishop or a knight - the process is called an exchange sacrifice to indicate that even though each player has exchanged one unit, the value of the respective units is unequal. Yet, although a rook is formally worth approximately one and a half pawns more than a minor piece, the transaction is frequently a gain of material because the opponent must lose several pawns along with his bishop or knight.

LEAD: David R. Peterson, the man found innocent by reason of insanity in the 1989 slaying of a 9-year-old girl at a busy street fair, has been committed to the state's only maximum-security mental hospital. The State's Psychiatric Security Review Board on Friday found that Mr. Peterson was a danger to the public and should remain at Whiting Forensic Institute in Middletown, a board official said.

LEAD: A TWO-MONTH disagreement between Yonkers and the builder of the first 142 of 200 units of court-ordered desegregated housing in the city was resolved last week, clearing the way for construction of the low-income units to begin next month.

LEAD: As the audience meets Magaly and Pa in ''Jersey City,'' Wendy Hammond's jarring new play at the Second Stage Theater, they are finishing their evening meal with a game of baseball trivia. Magaly, still tomboy enough at age 15 to prefer a catcher's mitt to a new dress for a present, knows what year Willie Mays and Mickey Mantle broke in as rookies, then stumps her dad with a question about what outfielder is named after a fruit (until she starts chanting ''Dar-ryl'' to give him a clue).

LEAD: In its zeal to enact the nation's stiffest anti-abortion law, the Louisiana Legislature has passed a bill that Gov. Buddy Roemer must veto if he holds to his own standards. A politician with a pro-life record, Mr. Roemer asked his Legislature to exempt victims of rape and incest from any new law.

LEAD: On Tuesday, 600 guests turned out for a black-tie dinner-dance at the Promenade of the New York State Theater, proving that even the summer heat can't keep the benefit crowd down. Its purpose was to raise funds for the general benefit of the New York City Opera, which is providing a home for two weeks for the Bolshoi

LEAD: Q. We have a bad mildew problem on the outside of our house, especially on the north side. We have tried the usual measures, including scrubbing with bleach, but nothing has helped. We are now planning to cover these eaves with aluminum or vinyl siding. Must the mildew be washed off before the new siding is installed over it?

LEAD: When my family and I first traveled to England in 1965, we carried an engraved-letterhead note from our bank in New York that would have done credit to Edith Wharton. It introduced us to a bank in the City of London that would cash one of our New York checks, in case we ran through our $10 ''tip pack'' of British currency and our traveler's checks.

LEAD: ''COME sailing with us,'' said our friends last week. ''Just bring a bathing suit and a book and relax. We'll do the rest.'' We found out that nothing is as relaxing as a midsummer sail, unless you count childbirth.
LEAD: Summer showers may suggest lighthearted frolic, but if they fall on a work day, serious protection is in order. Happily, new fibers and styling have produced coats that can do the job all year.

LEAD: In the nearly 90 years that Gray Ranch was managed as a working cattle ranch, it was able to preserve, as your article states, ''more separate species and subspecies of mammals . . . than any existing national wildlife refuge or national park in the continental United States.''
LEAD: THE WORLD OF NAGARAJ By R. K. Narayan. 186 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

LEAD: WE first encountered Clyde's Mexican Grille and Bar (then Clyde's Mexican Cafe) late in 1988, ensconced in tiny quarters in a fitness club in Stamford. Now it is in a free-standing building (formerly occupied by the Gaslight and several other restaurants) on Route 1 in Old Greenwich.
LEAD: To The Editor:
LEAD: The first Top Dog World Championship Prairie Dog Shoot competition got under way today with more than 100 participants, despite protests by about two dozen supporters of animal rights.

LEAD: Amid the bluegrass of Lexington, Ky., this week and the breezes of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., next month, tuxedoed auctioneers will sell nearly a thousand sleek and blue-blooded yearlings for more than $200 million to dreamers and speculators searching for the next Secretariat.
LEAD: Albanian refugees who fled their homeland said today that they hoped their daring would encourage more of their compatriots to resist Albania's hard-line Communist Government.

LEAD: Fenton Johnson's article ''Aftershock in San Francisco'' (June 17) left the mistaken impression that San Francisco's disaster planning is rooted in denial. Nothing could be further from the truth.

LEAD: When thousands of Zambians rushed onto the streets of Lusaka last month to celebrate what they thought was a successful overthrow of their longtime President, Kenneth D. Kaunda, they were expressing what citizens in many parts of Africa have been saying more and more: Africa's original big men have been around too long.

LEAD: When Rick Mears leaves his hotel this morning for the five-minute ride to the Meadowlands Sports Complex in East Rutherford, N.J., where he will be driving in the Marlboro Grand Prix, you can bet he will allow a little extra time. Two hours, perhaps.
LEAD: A businessman has dropped plans to kill 30,000 South African seals after protests by international animal rights advocates, the Government said today.

LEAD: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 5 THE BURDEN OF PROOF, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) An attorney tries to unravel the mystery of his wife's death while defending his wheeler-dealer brother-in-law.

LEAD: Having long pursued an independent military policy, the French Government is for the first time facing domestic pressure to reduce its arms spending in response to the changes sweeping the Warsaw Pact and NATO.
LEAD: Baseball

LEAD: Calling visitors to Cape May ''shoobes'' because they bring all their needs to the shore in a shoebox is certainly colorful (Cape May Journal, ''Facing the Tourist Season With Mixed Feelings'' but is at variance with the etymology or folk wisdom on Long Beach Island.

LEAD: In the matter of the great city of Berlin, which is now in such a state of ebullition, I have a mental image that many people find perverse. My private Berlin has nothing of the pompous, bombastic, self-satisfied Berlin, all tuba and trombone and bass drum, that was the natural backdrop for the outbreak of World War I.

LEAD: There were a lot of things Barbara Weiser didn't know. ''It never dawned on me,'' she recalls. ''Like most apartment dwellers, I didn't know that faucets didn't come on sinks or that pipes don't last forever.'' But as an owner of Charivari, the Manhattan clothing chain, she has a sure eye. For years, every time she passed this house she knew it had charm, even though she had never been inside it.
LEAD: The secret-police captain convicted in the 1984 killing of a pro-Solidarity priest has raised new questions about whether more senior officials in the Interior Ministry were involved.

LEAD: ''Knits are the summer's answer to cashmere because they're soft and movable, and they feel good against the body,'' said Donna Karan, the fashion designer. ''They're thoroughly modern for the hot days of summer.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Carolyn Hoyt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Hoyt of Glen Cove, L.I., was married last evening to Rabbi Marc L. Disick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Disick of West Hempstead, L.I. Rabbi Charles A. Kroloff and Cantor Martha T. Novick officiated at Temple Emanu-El in Westfield, N.J.

LEAD: August wedding plans for Laura Sack and David Evan Lewis, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Lewis of the Bronx, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Barnet Sack of West Hempstead, L.I. Ms. Sack, 23 years old, is a law student and an editor of the Journal of Law and Feminism at Yale University, where her fiance is studying for a master's degree in public and private management.

LEAD: INTERNATIIONAL The Best Little Summit in Texas A summit conference meant to celebrate the triumph of free-market economics became a demonstration of laissez-faire diplomacy as well. For every country and cause, the final communique had a clause. As the conference in Houston ended, West Germany came away with the right to unilaterally aid the Soviet Union, Japan the right to aid China.

LEAD: Concerned about the growing sophistication of Iraq's military, the Pentagon is leading a last-minute effort to prevent Baghdad from importing industrial furnaces that some experts say could be used to make components for missiles and atomic weapons.
LEAD: William James Burrud, a television producer and narrator of nature shows and travelogues, died Thursday at his home in Sunset Beach, Calif., after a heart attack. He was 65 years old.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:

LEAD: Within 24 hours of arriving in New York City, Ecumenical Patriarch Dimitrios I of Constantinople, spiritual leader of the world's Eastern Orthodox Christians, presided over two services aimed at healing centuries-old divisions among Eastern and Western Christians as well as more recent divisions in his own flock.

LEAD: The New Music Seminar started as a conspiracy in 1980. It was a gathering, in one rehearsal studio, of 200 people from the margins of the music business, outsiders plotting to get their music heard. Ten years later, the New Music Seminar is the biggest music-business convention in the United States.
LEAD: To anyone who had known Moscow when secrecy was an obsession and the Communist Party was almighty, the action last week in the Kremlin's cavernous Palace of Congresses was wondrous to behold.

LEAD: Underscoring a search for new relations between the North Atlantic alliance and the Kremlin, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today received the leader of NATO and agreed to visit and address the alliance at its headquarters in Brussels.

LEAD: 50 affordable two-family town houses nearing completion in the Crotona Park section of the Bronx, offered to pay the mortgage points for the first 25 buyers. A point is 1 percent of a mortgage, and most lenders charge two or three as an origination fee for a home loan.

LEAD: If baseball officials would avoid charges of being as imperious and mercurial as Steinbrenner himself, they will ask themselves this perhaps troublesome question before imposing any penalty: What would we mete out under identical circumstances to one of the more ''likable'' of baseball owners, such as Gene Autry or the late Tom Yawkey, Connie Mack or Walter Briggs?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Gerson Smith of Margate, N.J., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Renee Smith and Allan Jeffrey Borkow, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen E. Borkow of Hewlett Harbor, L.I. Ms. Smith, 27 years old, is a painter and print maker in New York. She is a graduate of Carnegie-Mellon University and earned a master's degree in fine arts at Columbia University.

LEAD: The horses and riders tread softly through the peat bog at the top of a windswept Connemara mountain. Manes and tails wave like the tall russet-tipped grasses of the bog. In the near distance are granite boulders and small pastures enclosed by serpentine lace walls, so called for the holes left for the wind.

LEAD: What's going on in Tokyo? Why are some small stocks soaring and the lesser-known stock indexes at record highs? With the closely watched Nikkei 225 Index still floundering around 32,600, how can some forecasters still expect it to hit 40,000 - a new high - by the end of the year? And has Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, given a boost to market hopes with his surprising promise to lower

LEAD: Ellen Ann Bauerle and David Stone Potter plan to marry in August. Ms. Bauerle is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bauerle of Delaware, Ohio; her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. David Potter of New York.

LEAD: Seventeen months after a cargo door blew off a United Airlines Boeing 747 south of Hawaii, sweeping nine passengers to their deaths, an effort to retrieve the door from an ocean depth of more than 14,000 feet is scheduled to begin late this week.

LEAD: Before Americans can celebrate the decline of Communism, we should ponder why a Japanese eighth grader typically knows more mathematics than an American with an M.B.A., and whether our own decline can be far behind the Soviet Union's. I believe we can avoid that fate, but we need to make a number of fundamental changes in business, government and education if we are to continue to prosper.

LEAD: ''HEDDA GABLER'' is 100 years old, but the tantalizing title character in Ibsen's classic of demented psychology remains a puzzlement. The prevailing perception of Hedda as predator, ''a hopeless specimen of degeneracy'' or merely ''mean'' was epitomized by Brooks Atkinson's pronouncement in 1936: ''In cold fact, she is the most hateful woman in dramatic literature.
LEAD: BOHIN MANOR By Tadeusz Konwicki. Translated by Richard Lourie. 240 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.

LEAD: REBUTTING criticism of the 1913 Armory Show, one of the participants, Oscar Bluemner, contended that art was still ''largely misunderstood'' in America. Art is not meant ''to amuse or instruct,'' he said, nor is it to be taken as ''imitation of nature.'' Its purpose, rather, is to elevate and liberate by making ''articulate the life of its time.
LEAD: Prime Minister V. P. Singh offered his resignation on Saturday to his party's leader, who said later that he had rejected it.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Adrianne Craig Benton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Benton of Evanston, Ill., was married yesterday to Robert French Furniss, a son of Susan W. Furniss of Fort Collins, Colo., and the late Norman Furniss. The Rev. George Conway, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the home of the bride's parents.
LEAD: An attempt to claim a historic trophy for the fastest time under power across the Atlantic Ocean has produced a controversy that seeks to separate commerce from sport.

LEAD: Barbara Buchanan Hope, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Deane Gordon Hope of Hilton Head Island, S.C., was married yesterday to Anthony Louis Gentile Jr., a son of Mrs. Gentile of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Gentile.
