LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: SEPARATE HOURS By Jonathan Baumbach. 204 pp. Boulder, Colo.: Fiction Collective Two. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $8.95.

LEAD: Japan's Education Ministry, long criticized for sanitizing school textbooks that try to detail Japanese wartime atrocities and the nation's domination of much of Asia, has embarked on a new task: toning down accounts of recent political scandals.

LEAD: It was Sir William Schwenck Gilbert - better known as the Gilbert of Gilbert and Sullivan - who had the good sense to observe (in his lyrics for Act II of ''The Pirates of Penzance''), ''A policeman's lot is not a happy one!''
LEAD: A student militant at Wesleyan University who was once considered one of the university's most promising minority scholars was killed during a drug deal, a police affidavit says.

LEAD: Laura Ruth Shapiro, a lawyer, was married yesterday at the Water Club in New York to Acting Justice Richard Lee Price of State Supreme Court in the Bronx. Harry W. Davis, a retired acting justice of State Supreme Court, officiated.

LEAD: Ilene Podgur, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Podgur of Brookline, Mass., was married last evening in Boston to Thomas Vogel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gunter Vogel of Heilbronn, West Germany. Rabbi Benjamin Rudavsky officiated at the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Vogel, 28 years old and a graduate of Syracuse University, is the leasing manager at the Mutual of America Life Insurance Company in New York.

LEAD: A determined group of younger musicians, mostly women, is scrambling to find ways to bring the harp into the late 20th century. For an instrument that numbers diminutive angels and a Marx brother among its best-known virtuosos, that is no easy or straightforward task. Some harpists are following the Swiss star Andreas Vollenweider into New Age washes.
LEAD: LION IN THE LOBBY Clarence Mitchell, Jr.'s Struggle for the Passage of Civil Rights Laws. By Denton L. Watson. Illustrated. 846 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $24.95.
LEAD: His round, jovial face and twinkling eyes belie it, but James E. Preston is getting annoyed.

LEAD: The traditional big month of weddings is now behind us, which means nothing because fall is another major wedding season. And then, of course, there are all kinds of weddings in winter, spring and the middle of summer. So when you get right down to it, there isn't a time of the year when great numbers of people aren't getting married.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: NASSAU FOLK FESTIVAL
LEAD: Faculty and staff members at the University of Georgia are opposed to a new state law requiring all applicants for state employment to submit to drug testing.

LEAD: Nancy Fairchild Sachs, a partner in the law firm of Wilson, Elser, Moskowitz, Edelman & Dicker in New York, and Dr. Paul Bennett Wiener, a nephrologist with the Norwalk (Conn.) Medical Group, plan to marry in August. Ms. Sachs is the daughter of Gloria Sachs of New York and Irwin Sachs of Rye, N.Y.

LEAD: The danger peaks near dawn, said a man named Jenkins, when Government soldiers, sometimes wearing masks, stalk the gates in front of the makeshift refugee camp within the walls of the American Cooperative School.
LEAD: If guilty, yes. If innocent, he should be allowed to return to his fraternity of selfish and arrogant owners, overpaid ballplayers, agents, and be forced to watch a Yankee game every day.
LEAD: Bob Welch won his major league-leading 14th game today and Jose Canseco hit his 24th home run to lead the Oakland Athletics past the Milwaukee Brewers, 3-1.
LEAD: THE DARK ROMANCE OF DIAN FOSSEY By Harold T. P. Hayes. Illustrated. 351 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.
LEAD: Laugh - love, commingled seemed to be the traditional remedy that Janet Pomeranz, in her bittersweet article found completely inadequate to cheer her out of her melancholia (May 27).

LEAD: Cabot Barber Paley, a clinical social worker, and Dr. Donald Paul Thaler, a dentist, both in New York, were married yesterday. Judge Edward Horne of East Hampton Town Court officiated at Gardiners Marina in East Hampton, L.I.

LEAD: On the steps of a church in Greenwich Village in Manhattan, a small crowd waits expectantly for a wedding to begin. Suddenly the bride appears and dashes inside. ''Don't look at the bride!'' her bridesmaids scream. ''It's bad luck.'' But everybody ignores them, for they have paid admission to attend.

LEAD: In the recent interesting article about an exhibition of dinosaurs at the Monmouth Museum (''Don't Pet the Dinosaurs, Museum Hit Show Asks''), it was pointed out that in the first three weeks the exhibition drew 29,000 children and adults, illustrating the fascination that dinosaurs have for people of all ages.

LEAD: The seemingly harmless addition of Deborah Norville to the ''Today'' show to ''give Jane a jolt'' is every working woman's worst nightmare. Who would, after more than 13 years on the job, like to come to work and, without warning, find someone new at one's desk?

LEAD: The Mets' Mike Marshall, one day after engaging in an angry clubhouse quarrel with Manager Bud Harrelson over lack of playing time, checked into a hospital here today for what was initially described as a stomach disorder and feared to be a bleeding ulcer. Marshall, a first baseman, was scheduled to remain at Christ

LEAD: Family Business 1989. RCA/Columbia. 1:53. LD, $34.95. CC. R. Sean Connery (Jessie), who begat Dustin Hoffman (Vito), who begat Matthew Broderick (Adam), is the charming and roguish patriarch in Sidney Lumet's film about a family that develops togetherness after a bungled theft at a Long Island research lab.
LEAD: In an effort to crack down on what they said was an increase in under-age drinking, the East Lansing police have confiscated more than 700 fake driver's licenses from students.
LEAD: The Army has announced that it will close its Reserve Officer Training Corps program at 50 colleges and universities at the end of the next academic year.

LEAD: Bryant Gumbel's prescription for ''Today'' may be responsible for the decline in the show's ratings, but that's what can happen when network executives mistake a star interviewer-newsman for a market researcher.

LEAD: Nancy Carlson and Timothy J. Berners-Lee were married yesterday at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield, Conn., by the Rev. George C. Bland. Mrs. Berners-Lee is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. D. Bret Carlson of Fairfield. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Conway Berners-Lee of London.

LEAD: When the avant-garde theater director Anne Bogart and the Trinity Repertory Company came to the last act of their drama in May and parted company, it was more than a dispute over budget cuts. The fact that after less than a year the 38-year-old director and one of the nation's leading regional companies did not live happily ever after is an example of the challenge now confronting a number of the nation's not-for-profit theaters: how to secure the next generation of artistic directors while maintaining a faithful subscriber audience (the key to a sound operating budget) and at the same time

LEAD: JANET MURPHY of West Hartford stood in line at the checkout counter of the Cheese and Stuff supermarket in Hartford and handed the cashier a wrinkled brown grocery bag and a green-and-white card. As she watched, the cashier punched the card. When all the holes in the card are punched, Mrs. Murphy will receive one dollar off on a purchase.

LEAD: Q. We have a bad mildew problem on the outside of our house, especially on the north side. We have tried the usual measures, including scrubbing with bleach, but nothing has helped. We are now planning to cover these eaves with aluminum or vinyl siding. Must the mildew be washed off before the new siding is installed over it?
LEAD: Connemara is that wild hinterland on the west coast of Ireland, bounded on the north by Clew Bay, on the south by Galway Bay and on the east by Lough Corrib and Lough Mask.

LEAD: One of the big surprises of the American Dance Festival is the annual program by the Young Choreographers and Composers in Residence. Each summer, three choreographers collaborate on new works with three composers. It is impossible to predict what the results will be, and it is always fascinating to discover what young dancers and musicians have on their creative minds.

LEAD: Grand Canyon, headed for last May's Kentucky Derby until sidelined by injury, was humanely destroyed today after contracting laminitis, a frequently fatal disease of the hoof, Overbrook Farm said.
LEAD: Bush Administration officials say the Soviet Union has floated the outlines of a proposal that could lead to a settlement of the 12-year war in Afghanistan.

LEAD: In June I went to a friend's wedding. Like most weddings these days, this one featured a cast that included not only a bride, bridegroom and assorted attendants, but also a wedding photographer and a member of that newest of aspiring occupations, a videographer.
LEAD: THE BODY AND ITS DANGERS And Other Stories. By Allen Barnett. 181 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $15.95.
LEAD: Normally I enjoy reading Pete Dunne's ''In the Natural State,'' but he is dead wrong in his recent piece on the gypsy moth.
LEAD: Animal-rights supporters plan to challenge a state decision allowing the use of a powerful class of steroids on race horses. They say the drugs pose a danger to both horses and jockeys.

LEAD: There is no doubt in anyone's mind in London, Paris or Bonn that the Western leader who dominates the international agenda these days is not Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain or President Bush of the United States, but Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany.
LEAD: To the untrained eye, it seems a mystery. Flights to and from New York airports have increased less than 5 percent over the past year, but delays have in some cases more than doubled.

LEAD: In a tacit challenge to the African National Congress, Chief Mangosuthu Gatsha Buthelezi, the principal Zulu leader, moved today to convert his movement into a multiracial political party and said that it must be reckoned with in future negotiations that the Government convenes on the nation's future.

It was correctly reported that I voted for the proposed 24,000-square-foot terminal - which also went down to defeat during our June 25 meeting.
LEAD: Read my lips: No more savings and loan crisis.

LEAD: Midway in a cabaret act that is as musically sophisticated as it is verbally acute, Amy Ziff, the self-proclaimed diva of the female pop trio Betty, adopts the personality of a generic B-movie character named Kat.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation had Lee Iacocca; New York University had John Brademas. Not that the university was on the verge of extinction when Dr. Brademas took over as president in 1981, but it was looking to grow and looking for a leader who knew where to look for money. Dr. Brademas did. He came to the university with 11 terms in Congress behind him and quickly became a familiar figure in the New York financial community.

LEAD: On what is now an expanse of rice paddies and dilapidated buldings, China has begun a massive project to build an Asian financial capital and prove to the world that it is still open for business.

LEAD: CLOWN PRINCE OF HOLLYWOOD: The Antic Life and Times of Jack L. Warner. By Bob Thomas. (McGraw-Hill, $19.95.) ''Moguls? Don't like the word,'' Jack Leonard Warner once said. ''It reminds me of some bad Turkish cigarettes I used to smoke.'' Yet for more than 25 years there was perhaps no better word to describe him as he helped run Hollywood and dictate the cinematic tastes of the American public.

Giniger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Giniger of Rock Hill, N.Y. Rabbi Joseph Potasnick officiated at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Mrs. Giniger, 27 years old, is a sales representative at Vidi Vici, a fashion showroom in New York.
LEAD: Bulgarians like Stefan Dankov are having a hard time deciding if these will be the ''good old days.''

LEAD: FOR the first production of his last season as artistic director of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival, Paul Barry has hauled out an inauspicious ''Romeo and Juliet.''

LEAD: A Federal grand jury is preparing to file criminal charges against Eastern Airlines, accusing it of faulty maintenance practices at La Guardia and Kennedy International Airports in New York and Hartsfield International in Atlanta, lawyers involved in the investigation said yesterday.

LEAD: BEN. By Max Schott. (North Point, $17.95.) '' 'Mom has a tumor in her brain. It's growing,' I said, brightly. To have a tumor in your brain - like a ship in a bottle - would be novelty enough alone, but to have one growing was nearly a miracle.'' Max, the young boy who narrates this novel by the author of ''Murphy's Romance,'' is naive enough to be fascinated and hopeful about desperate situations, yet he is honest and real enough that the reader never tires of him.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: THOSE who enjoy lively, thriving professional summer theater in Connecticut can hold onto a few signs of stability in an otherwise changing, shrinking - and Shakespeare-less - summer season.

LEAD: A Federal district judge here says he will probably impose a $43 million penalty against a Japanese shipping company for keeping double books to avoid paying a crew of 21 Filipinos most of the wages called for under industry-union agreements.

LEAD: To the Editor: On a recent trip to Europe, I discovered just how ''helpful'' the American Express office can be to American tourists. Since I had planned to meet friends in different cities, we relied on the various American Express offices as a means of leaving and retrieving messages.

LEAD: LANGUAGE MAVEN STRIKES AGAIN. By William Safire. (Doubleday, $22.95.) What is a maven, anyway, and how is it different from a pundit or a boffin? How formal is semiformal? Which is worse, going bananas or going ballistic? When did anxiety turn into stress? William Safire's sixth compilation from his weekly column On Language in The New York Times Magazine - augmented with contributions from friends and readers, the Lexicographic Irregulars - addresses these and many, many other pertinent issues raised in the course of reading, writing, talking and listening in America.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. William N. Martin of West Hartford, Conn., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Cynthia Morris Martin and David Noah Brown, the son of Murton L. Brown of New York and Carol Z. Brown of Boston.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's closest Cabinet ally resigned today on the third day of a controversy over an interview in which he denounced European monetary union as ''a German racket designed to take over the whole of Europe.''
LEAD: MARS BECKONS The Mysteries, the Challenges, the Expectations of Our Next Great Adventure in Space. By John Noble Wilford. Illustrated. 244 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

LEAD: The fight between Congress and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney over the fate of the Osprey, the tilt-rotor aircraft that ascends like a helicopter and flies like a plane, has heated up with the release of a study commissioned by the Pentagon at Congress's request.

LEAD: Meredith Rainey often tells the story of how she walked into the Harvard track office in 1986, in the fall of her freshman year, and asked Fred Haggerty if she could go out for the sport. She was unaware at the time that Haggerty, coach of the men's and women's teams, had vowed not to allow any more walk-ons.

LEAD: Southern Methodist University has begun giving money to students and faculty and staff members whose proposals can help the school save money.

Although he grew up in the Milona workrooms on Seveth Avenue, he decided to veer slightly off the well-worn track. He set his sights on designing leather and suede ready-to-wear items.

LEAD: A SCARSDALE police officer who said he had been shot in the line of duty has resigned from the police force and faces criminal charges because forensic evidence did not match his version of the incident, Robert A. Neary, an assistant county district attorney, has announced.
LEAD: Barely a month has gone by since his dismissal, but Bucky Dent looked refreshed and ready yesterday. He smiled a lot, he shook hands with old friends and he talked about coming back.

LEAD: Brown quotes one Hampshire student who found students at the University of Massachusetts overly distracted with test scores (''It was like a big high school''). It is likely that this attitude is due less to a lack of talent and creativity among students at the state-run university than to a desire to one day find a good job.

LEAD: Nothing is harder to kill than a good myth. Beat on it with hard facts, and it will hardly notice. Chop off its head, and it will grow another one by nightfall. Nothing, it seems, can put an end to a myth but its replacement by another myth.

LEAD: Passing Along Costs Question: I own an occupied, rent-stabilized apartment in Riverdale. Recently, new windows were installed throughout the building and I have started paying an assessment that will last for the next year to cover the costs of that project as well as other scheduled improvements.

LEAD: When Nicaraguans awoke last week to bitter street fighting, the most important news was not who joined the fracas, but who stayed away.

For the first time, the season is devoted to a single composer: Stravinsky, appropriate to the setting. LEAD: Not missing a beat, American designers are picking up on pretty shadings and continuing them for fall. It gets really interesting when two or more colors are combined. Here are a few of the new looks that should soon be arriving in stores.

LEAD: In your article on the homeless, a Department of Housing and Urban Development official comments, ''We can't have socialism for the poor and capitalism for the wealthy.'' In fact, just the opposite is true. President Bush proposes to spend $700 million on housing programs for the poor, while the cost to taxpayers of bailing out the savings and loan industry is estimated at anywhere from $325 billion to more than $1 trillion.

LEAD: Mailing privileges for Vermont lawmakers will be suspended through Jan. 1, 1991 as part of a cost-cutting effort. The Legislative Council, eight lawmakers who oversee internal business, this week notified the other 172 members of the House and Senate of several cost-savings measures. The changes included suspension of stenographic services, stationery and postage.

LEAD: Everybody expected the Tour de France to get off to a new beginning today, and it did as Erik Breukink and Greg LeMond went on a long breakaway and made up nearly five minutes of their deficit on the man in the yellow jersey, Claudio Chiappucci.

LEAD: The engagement of Jennifer Rae Gierke to James Alfred Mitchell, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul L. Mitchell of Melville, L.I., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Bradford M. Gierke of Tacoma, Wash., and Janet Rae McKay of Bellevue, Wash. A November wedding is planned.

LEAD: ''We are concerned about out-of-sequence and vanity addresses. They're really proliferating. It's hard even for old-timers - but particularly for newcomers - to find their way around town.'' -Marla G. Simpson, director of land-use planning in the office of the Manhattan Borough President.

LEAD: With every passing day, disclosures from secret files of the former Communist governments in Eastern Europe show more clearly that well into the 1980's, they gave sanctuary to Middle Eastern and Western European terrorist groups that were attacking Western targets, despite official denials at the time.
LEAD: ''Where you stand depends upon where you sit'' is one of the oldest saws in politics. On no issue does this hold more than on the issue of free speech.

LEAD: Conditions for children in New York City have deteriorated significantly in the last 15 years, with marked increases in infant mortality, reports of child abuse and the number of children living in poverty, according to an index tabulated by social scientists at Fordham University.

LEAD: P. T. Barnum, who mockingly announced there was a sucker born every minute, has a new and aggressive student in Richard Amper. Unfortunately for the rest of us, Mr. Amper looks to sucker the taxpayer and in his essay, ''The Builders Are Trying to Undercut Us'' (May 28), he shows just how adept he is at his scam.

LEAD: SINCE 1986, more than 200 families and five churches have moved several miles from the five-square-mile center of this town of 1,700 people. They moved because the town sits on a salt dome where 43 percent of the liquid natural gas in Texas is stored and where a dangerous leak was discovered in 1980.

LEAD: Although tuberculosis can affect almost any organ, by far the most common form involves the lungs. Its symptoms include a cough, fevers, drenching night sweats, fatigue, weight loss and blood-tinged sputum. They can vary in severity. Some patients dismiss their symptoms as a smoker's cough while others have a serious pneumonia.

The problem is that the labor participation rate, as it is called, was the same 66.4 percent a year ago.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The covered arcades of Paris, wrought with iron and surmounted by sparkling ceilings of glass, have been among that city's most celebrated architectural features since the 19th century. But for Susan Buck-Morss, an associate professor of government at Cornell University, the arcades have been the focus of a lengthy task of scholarly detective work, an attempt to decipher a massive, mysterious, unfinished tome by a renowned critic and philosopher who has been dead for 50 years.
LEAD: Four men who appeared to be homeless and were sleeping in their seats on an IND A train were ejected without incident last night by transit police so that employees could clean the subway cars.

LEAD: Gail Cynthia Seibel and Roger Alan Stern were married yesterday at Dowling College in Oakdale, L.I., by Rabbi Laurence A. Kotok. Mrs. Stern is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Seibel of Seaford, L.I. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter H. Stern of Roslyn Harbor, L.I.

LEAD: ''A Day in the Death of America'' is not an elegant piece of work, with its lurid photography, haunted-house music and hyped-up re-enactments. Yet the idea behind it, a recounting of some of the 61 deaths by gun that occurred in the United States on July 16, 1989, is powerful enough to hold you to your set.

LEAD: DURING running, the feet absorb a great amount of shock and transmit signals of distress to the legs, the back and other parts of the body. Now the growing field of reflexology offers runners a chance to use their feet as a source of comfort, healing and even runner's high.

LEAD: Reachable only after hours of paddling and portaging through the northern Adirondack wilderness, Bessie and Nellie Ponds look like a fisherman's paradise. The waters are still and deep, and the woods are so quiet that a loon's call seems almost startling. But there is a problem: The fishing is lousy.

LEAD: Andres Galarraga hit a three-run home run in the sixth inning and drove in the tie-breaking run with a ninth-inning single today as the Montreal Expos took advantage of poor Atlanta fielding for a 16-14 victory.

LEAD: The national economy has become so sluggish that 16 states, with more than a third of the nation's population, are in a recession or close to one, an analysis of employment data shows. And throughout the country, people are talking of stagnant wages, falling real estate prices, deeply indebted corporations and jobs that are getting harder to find.

LEAD: WOMEN who go to sea on powerboats tend to go along for the ride. Although a vast majority of the 15 million recreational boats in the United States are powerboats, it is not the women of America in charge of driving.

LEAD: Nancy Campbell Walworth, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. James C. Walworth of Freeport, L.I., was married there yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration to Robert James Chant, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Richard Chant of Bayport, L.I. The Rev. Daniel S. Harris 3d performed the ceremony, assisted by the bride's father.

LEAD: Under pressure from the federal Government and burdened by economic problems, the newly elected leaders in the Yugoslav republic of Slovenia are pressing to forge a sovereign state and recast Slovenia's relationship with the country's five other republics.

LEAD: The cautious process of rebuilding the strained relations between the Soviet Union and China have taken another modest step forward with a report here today that the first Chinese-Soviet joint venture in China will soon be established.

LEAD: EVEN though it was late afternoon when Vic Pomiecko of Claremont, N.H., and I reached Chapin Pond, the heat was oppressive. It was not ideal trout-fishing weather. The surface temperature of the pond was 72 degrees, too hot for trout, which begin to languish when the water gets much above 65 degrees.

LEAD: A British newspaper reported today that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher convoked a daylong seminar of historians and German experts in March that discussed positive and negative aspects of the Germans.
LEAD: Bobby Thigpen, the Chicago White Sox relief pitcher, is not exactly a phenomenon, although it is somewhat phenomenal that he is suddenly the best late-inning closer in baseball.
LEAD: All-Star Sluggers

LEAD: Brooke Elizabeth Hillary and William Elwood Schmearer 4th were married yesterday at the Bedford (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Paul D. Alcorn. Mrs. Hillary-Schmearer is the daughter of Grace Harvey Fuller of Lindenhurst, L.I., and Norman Sheresky of New York. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs.

LEAD: In ''Die Hard 2,'' the new film that is less a sequel to than a remake of the 1988 hit ''Die Hard,'' Bruce Willis uses an icicle to stab a man in the brain via the eye socket. Later, another unfortunate man is sucked into a 747's jet engine and comes out the other end looking like borscht.

LEAD: A scuba diver in Miami has developed a pouch that allows divers to drink fluids under water. The device comes with a collapsible bag that feeds beverages through a port in a specially designed mouthpiece.
LEAD: * Bobbi Blair has been promoted to senior vice president for media at Buena Vista Pictures Marketing.

LEAD: THE newspaper story out of Cincinnati yesterday reported that Mike Marshall of the Mets had checked into a hospital ''for what was initially described as a stomach disorder and feared to be a bleeding ulcer.''

LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins has appointed a new city sheriff to head what amounts to an expanded central municipal collection agency that will seek to recover some of the more than $4 billion owed over the years to the city. About $2 billion is owed by motorists who have ignored parking fines and penalties.

LEAD: Smiling and bantering like old friends, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that they expected major progress in their talks on lifting the last obstacles to German unity.

LEAD: After three months of spirited exchanges between Jerusalem and Paris that required the personal intervention of Prime Minister MICHEL ROCARD, and the Minister of Culture JACK LANG, both of France, and the Director General of French Museums, OLIVIER CHEVRILLON, word came that ''formalities connected with the export'' of 103 works by MARC CHAGA
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about negotiations between the Big Three auto companies and the United Automobile Workers referred incorrectly to the union membership of workers at United States plants owned wholly or partly by Japanese car makers. At some plants, hourly workers are indeed represented by the United Automobile Workers. LEAD: Contract negotiations between the Big Three auto makers and the United Automobile Workers union, which have historically been fractious, show signs of being much tamer this year. But the apparent calm may be deceiving.

LEAD: Marie Blood regaled a standing-room-only crowd of several hundred here tonight with childhood reminiscences of her famous uncle, Harry Houdini, jumping off bridges, escaping from handcuffs and tickling her without using his hands.

LEAD: ''We began putting nuts in our mouth and testing them on our teeth, and I must say our teeth are strong. We'll crack them.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev, after meeting withChancellor Helmut Kohlon German unification. [A6:5.]

LEAD: Leonard Bernstein, suffering from what his doctors and managers said was exhaustion, is cutting short a three-week tour for a new music festival in this country and is returning to the United States for medical treatment.
LEAD: KENNETH H. OLSEN, the founder and president of the Digital Equipment Corporation, has always been a rugged individualist who has studiously avoided fads and fashions in the computer industry.

LEAD: Many publishers were irate three weeks ago after Dell Publishing agreed to pay $12.3 million for Ken Follett's next two novels. Now, having had time to think it over, they are even angrier, in part because HarperCollins quickly bought three books by Jeffery Archer, for what the British author said was more than $20 million.

LEAD: Joseph Blumenthal, a publisher and typographer who printed special editions of Robert Frost's poems for more than 30 years, died on Wednesday at his home in West Cornwall, Conn. He was 92 years old.

LEAD: Gen. George L. Mabry Jr., who won the Medal of Honor in World War II and later commanded American forces in the Panama Canal Zone, died Friday at Richland Memorial Hospital in Columbia, S.C. He was 72 years old and lived in Columbia.

LEAD: After waiting nearly five years in vain for a proper house, Calvin Mukondeli spent his savings of nearly $190 as a down payment on a prefabricated shack of wood and metal that he built for his wife and three children.

LEAD: The 12th Olympic Festival ended this evening with solid reviews for a job well done, but also with a nagging question that has remained unanswered for the last five years: What does it all mean?

LEAD: Midway through a 12-hour shift in which he had driven from one end of the Bronx to the other for $9.50 and to points in between for lesser fares, Joe DeMaio parked outside the Thruway Private Taxi Company and explained why the killings of 19 cabdrivers this year have not frightened him.
LEAD: With virtually no advance publicity, Jupiter, a sprightly looking astrology magazine, appeared last winter on newsstands across the country. A second issue followed months later.

LEAD: As a result of a recent Supreme Court decision, courts around the country are dismantling state and local programs that set aside contracts for companies whose owners are members of minority groups.

LEAD: After finding a safe berth for the Contel Corporation, with the proposed merger of Contel into the GTE Corporation, some might expect Charles Wohlstetter to feel that his work is complete and think about retirement.
LEAD: Kevin Cook and Roddy Marino each scored four goals today to lead the United States to a rain-splattered 19-15 victory over Canada in the Lacrosse World Series championship game.
LEAD: The first major study of the world's poor in a decade says that poverty is likely to decline by the year 2000, except in sub-Saharan Africa.
LEAD: When international trade talks reconvene in Geneva on July 23, the negotiators will resume their long-stalled discussions of agriculture subsidies.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ordered today that the state broadcast monopoly be drastically revamped to allow a more democratic and competitive variety of broadcast outlets that might further shrink the Communist Party's power over national life.

LEAD: Near the end of a debate on Saturday between the five Democratic contenders for governor, former Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta said he wanted to sum up what distinguished him from his opponents.

LEAD: Suppose you wander into a strange club in another country and sit down behind one of the players. He holds the West cards shown in the diagram, and you wonder whether or not he is an expert. You are mildly surprised that he chooses to open one spade rather than one no-trump: It is obvious that he employs four-card major openings, and you suspect that he favors the weak no-trump opening.
LEAD: Brig. Gen. Alejandro Galido, a figure in the events of last December, when dissidents in the Philippine military failed in a coup attempt, died today of liver cancer, officials said. He was 54.
LEAD: When it comes to criticizing the British press, nobody here beats an American, Bob Borzello.

LEAD: When Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson of Federal District Court here learned that he had been selected to preside over the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., he said he had two immediate thoughts: It was going to be an exciting episode in his judicial career, and he would have to sequester the jury.
LEAD: The communications industry will soon aim anti-drug advertising at children 6 to 8 years old, using as its medium not broadcasting or billboards, but bedtime stories.

LEAD: Tennis Titles for Sampras and Sabatini: Pete Sampras of the United States recorded 10 aces in winning the men's singles title, and Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina took the women's title yesterday in the Gunze world tournament in Tokyo. Sampras, ranked 18th in the world, scored an easy 6-1, 6-4 victory over 46th-ranked Jaime Yzaga of Peru.

LEAD: Like Zubin Mehta, Seiji Ozawa seems eager to expand his operatic activities. Perhaps partly for that reason, he has taken to offering semi-staged operatic productions every summer with the Boston Symphony at its Tanglewood festival in the Berkshires. This year's installment was tonight's ''Pique Dame,'' and despite some reservations it turned out to be a genuinely effective realization of one of Tchaikovsky's masterpieces.
LEAD: BRITISH OPENS are unavoidably memorable when they are held at the Old Course in St. Andrews, Scotland.

LEAD: The Marlboro Grand Prix was the kind of Indy-car race in which Arie Luyendyk could finish fourth after driving his car toward the Lincoln Tunnel, Teo Fabi could finish third without brakes or a clutch, and Michael Andretti could win while keeping an eye on his fuel gauge.

LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of July 16: MONDAY Dana Corp Eastern Utils Goodrich B.F. Co Lilly Eli & Co Oxford Inds Russ Togs Southern Co TUESDAY AAR Corp Amer. Cap. Mgmt & Resh Cincinnati Milacron Federal Natl Mtg Assn Hawaiian Elec Inds Honeywell ICM Ppty Invs Inc K Mart Corp Mellon Bank Corp Natl.

LEAD: Education officials here have finished projecting the impact of lost state aid under Gov. Jim Florio's new school financing formula. They say the figures pose nightmarish years ahead for the town's children and taxpayers.

LEAD: Suddenly it's open season for savings and loan politics. Some House Democrats have been pressing for an independent counsel to investigate President Bush's son Neil. A clutch of Democratic and Republican Representatives feel the scandal's heat in their races for re-election. And both houses are rushing bills to beef up the pursuit of S & L crooks.
LEAD: The Federal Express Corporation said last week that its profits rose 5.1 percent in its fourth quarter but slumped for the year in large part because of the acquisition of Tiger International.

LEAD: With a mixture of fanfare and skepticism, Los Angeles this week opens the first leg of a multibillion-dollar, 150-mile commuter rail line intended to help save this car-choked city from a future of paralyzed roads and unbreathable air.
LEAD: The Government said on Saturday that it was helping about 190,000 refugees return to the south, where they had fled famine and civil war.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation, the MCI Communications Corporation and officials at a group of Michigan universities have quietly begun discussions with the Federal Government about creating a nonprofit company that would operate a high-speed computer network that could one day reach every home in the country.

LEAD: ''My socks, my socks!'' the panicky Iranian woman said, throwing off her shoes and hurriedly trying to pull socks over her bare feet as the officer approached the taxi. Noticing that the young woman was accompanied by a Western visitor and apparently wanting to avoid an incident, the officer waved the car on without inspection.
LEAD: Indians locked in a land dispute with the Canadian authorities reversed themselves today and kept up their blockade of a bridge into Montreal.

LEAD: Ed Rollins, the able and usually unflappable Republican strategist, sounded defensive and more than a little panicky at his party's Chicago meeting last week. He was trying to claim that it was the Democrats who had ''sold out the taxpayers'' in the colossal savings and loan scandal.
LEAD: Perhaps the surest sign that Communism is crumbling is that the price of its pieces is falling.
LEAD: William James Burrud, a television producer and narrator of nature shows and travelogues, died Thursday at his home in Sunset Beach, Calif., after a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: Public television's ''American Masters'' has been dedicating the first three weeks of its new season to film directors. So far there have been documentaries about Preston Sturges and John Cassavetes. Tonight at 9 on Channel 13, there's ''Martin Scorsese Directs,'' an hourlong biography produced and directed by Joel Sucher and Steven Fischler, former film students of Mr.

LEAD: Maria Kollaris, a 70-year-old widow dressed completely in black, wept as His Holiness Dimitrios I, Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, entered the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity on East 74th Street.

LEAD: After spending three rainy days shooting two of the best rounds ever played in a United States Women's Open, Patty Sheehan undid it all with two terrible rounds in one sun-drenched Sunday to lose the championship to Betsy King.

LEAD: Two final decisions on pivotal land-use questions face the Board of Estimate before it ceases to exist under terms of the new City Charter. One decision appears easy; the other, difficult. They will be remembered as a test of wisdom and courage as the board closes its 90-year run.

LEAD: THE sound stages are being re-activated here this week as production begins on the fall season's television series. And the large majority of those stages will be filled with people telling jokes.

LEAD: THE sound stages are being re-activated here this week as production begins on the fall season's television series. And the large majority of those stages will be filled with people telling jokes.

LEAD: Sister Mary Rose McGeady's priorities are very clear. She told an interviewer she's not aware of any more important job in America than ''taking care of our troubled young people.'' Fortunately for thousands of troubled young people, she's earned the chance to do just that, as the new director of Covenant
LEAD: Twenty-three gray whale carcasses have washed up on two remote islands in the Gulf of Alaska, and scientists plan a study to determine why they died.
LEAD: Harvey Gantt is telling the Harvey Gantt story, spinning it into a rich tapestry of the American Dream.
LEAD: Kenneth G. Zalkin, a lawyer, died on Saturday at the Ritz Tower in Manhattan. He was 46 years old.
LEAD: Computers, printers and copiers have become so sophisticated that United States currency and other securities can be counterfeited with remarkable accuracy, the Treasury Department said Friday.

LEAD: Dr. George Wythe, a former Latin American specialist and section chief in the Department of Commerce, died on June 23 at a hospital in Vienna, where he had lived in retirement. He was 96 years old.

LEAD: THERE is a touch of ceremony in the way traditional yachtsmen run their races. But the routine was interrupted during one of the first races of the Liberty Cup Regatta two weeks ago in New York Harbor. The marine division of the New Jersey State Police became part of the act, much to the chagrin of the race committee.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The bond market, which has so far this summer received help from both the President of the United States and the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, may have a more difficult time finding new friends in the weeks ahead. But without further assistance, credit market analysts said, interest rates were not likely to decline much from current levels, and might even rise.
LEAD: Debt
LEAD: Gerald Perry led an 18-hit attack with a single, double and three stolen bases as the Kansas City Royals scored three runs to break a sixth-inning tie today and beat the Boston Red Sox, 13-4.

LEAD: Jennifer Lynn Gentin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Gentin of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday at Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn., to Mark Steven Lieblein, the son of Joan Lieblein and Dr. Jerome Lieblein, both of San Diego. Rabbi Hillel Silverman officiated.

LEAD: The ball settled into Carlton Fisk's glove, and then the boos fell around Don Mattingly like rain. They followed him from home plate to the dugout, where he sat on the bench and listened to the growing frustration.
LEAD: BBC/Lionheart Television International Inc., the distributor in the United States for the British Broadcasting Corporation's programming, has named Sarah Frank president and chief executive.

LEAD: Two years ago, the road to China was a winding, almost secret path for South Korean business executives, but one that was illuminated with hope. After a number of bitter encounters, that hope has given way to disappointment and frustration.

LEAD: World Poverty and Africa Poverty is likely to decline by the year 2000, except in sub-Saharan Africa, according to the first major study of the world's poor in a decade, by the World Bank. Page A3. The Law Seeks Longer Arms State prosecutors hope to obtain the broad powers exercised by their Federal counterparts to seize the property of drug traffickers.
LEAD: Having started an overhaul of the economy and a striking removal of trade barriers, the Government of Brazil is now looking to the international financial community for support.
LEAD: Joseph P. Dougherty, a retired executive vice president of Capital Cities/ ABC, died on Saturday in Point Pleasant Hospital in Point Pleasant, N.J. He was 66 years old.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 The Soviet state broadcast monopoly was ordered to be revamped to allow a more democratic and competitive variety of broadcast outlets that might further shrink the Communist Party's power over national life. Page A1
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The District of Columbia spent $859 per person in 1988 for police protection, the courts, jails and other criminal and civil justice services, higher by far than any state and four times the national average, the Justice Department said in a report released today.

LEAD: Concerned over recent troubles with the Hubble telescope and the space shuttle, the White House has been holding discussions on how to shore up support for the nation's space program, Bush Administration officials said today.
LEAD: CHARLES KURALT has turned down a request by a group of archaeologists to dig up the front lawn of his Connecticut vacation house.

LEAD: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation said last night that it would begin its $6.9 billion refinancing program today, buying back some of its high-yield ''junk bonds'' in the open market, receiving additional equity and securing new bank loans.

LEAD: Ellen Fran Gleimer, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sol E. Gleimer of Brooklyn, was married yesterday at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., to Richard Earl Hustead, a son of Mrs. Frank Driskill of Glendale, Calif. Rabbi Jack Bemporad and Cantor Howard Stahl officiated.

LEAD: While Czechoslovakia's Foreign Minister argues for a new political architecture in Europe and Poland's Foreign Minister concentrates on safeguarding his nation's postwar borders, Romania's new Foreign Minister, Adrian Nastase, has a different focus: helping his nation join the family of Europe.

LEAD: Dr. Theresa Felicia Pearse, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Pearse of New York, was married yesterday to Kurt Alexander Eichenwald, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Heinz F. Eichenwald of Dallas. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Dr. Richard J. Petranek Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic

LEAD: The Cummins Engine Company yesterday announced a series of transactions that would give it an immediate infusion of $250 million in fresh capital in return for surrendering a 27 percent stake to the Ford Motor Company, Tenneco Inc. and Kubota Ltd. of Japan.

LEAD: An armed gang, its members impersonating plainclothes police officers and drug agents right down to their bulletproof vests and the red bubble on their car's dashboard, robbed and ransacked two multifamily houses in the Bronx on Saturday, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: When the Oakland Athletics placed Carney Lansford on the 15-day disabled list today and called up two minor leaguers, they also released the pitcher Mike Norris, who was attempting a comeback after a six-year absence from the major leagues.

LEAD: On the same day recently that the New York Civil Liberties Union was criticizing the Police Department's ability to police itself, a police sergeant in Brooklyn was suspended after two officers accused him of brutality. Investigators are struggling to corroborate the allegation. Everybody agrees, though, that its source was unusual.
LEAD: Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss an-nounced Friday that it had resigned the Haagen-Dazs Company account.
LEAD: Little but the seasons have changed in front of the Korean-owned Family Red Apple grocery store in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
LEAD: Mildred Falk Loew, a former editor and part owner of The American Mercury magazine, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 79 years old.

LEAD: The prospects are still good for a bumper grain harvest in the Soviet Union this year, the Agriculture Department said last week. Total grain production is estimated at 215 million metric tons, up from 211.1 million in 1989, the department said in a report. That would be the largest since a record 237.4 million tons in 1978.

LEAD: The final standing of the 1990 lacrosse world championships may read four losses in a row for the Iroquois Nationals, but team officials are calling the Native Americans' return to international competition after a century's banishment a major success.

LEAD: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Wednesday misstated the type of magazine to be included quarterly with People magazine. It will be a version of In Health, a three-year-old magazine published by Time Warner and Hippocrates Partners; it will not be a new magazine.

LEAD: Benjamin P. Schoenfein, a retired New York City banker, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old.

LEAD: Whether or not the contractual dispute between Don King, the promoter, and James (Buster) Douglas, the heavyweight champion, is settled out of court, Steve Wynn still has problems.

Jeanette Champsaur, star saleswoman at Lick Your Chops, was up front finishing a high-protein, high-fiber order for a new customer, Wizzy Wig.

LEAD: TO the ancient Greeks, the word ''parasite'' meant one who eats at the table of another. But far from having the decency to sit down for dinner, most parasites in nature suck the blood, sip at the gastric juices of the intestines, pierce into the nourishing warmth of muscle tissue and otherwise leech rudely off the fluids and labors of their unwilling hosts.

LEAD: A spurt in automobile production and a heat wave that increased utility output pushed industrial production up four-tenths of a percent in June, the Federal Reserve reported today.

LEAD: The gloom was pretty much unrelieved on Friday night at the handsome theater at the Fiorello H. La Guardia High School of Music and the Arts when the new Fiorello Festival presented the second of three programs of new and recent dance. Each choreographer represented - Zvi Gotheiner, Elisa King and James Sewell - had a sense of craft.

LEAD: Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of the New Jersey Supreme Court, who was appointed by former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne in 1979, is a former State Assemblyman and the son of the late David T. Wilentz, the former Attorney General who prosecuted Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh's son.

LEAD: DIMITRIOS I, Patriarch of Eastern Orthodox Christians, made an unscheduled stop on Monday on his tour of New York City. The Patriarch, 75 years old, consulted DR. ARIADNA PAPAGEORGE, an otolaryngologist, at Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital. His car, with its ''Hellenic 1'' license plate, and a phalanx of bodyguards and police officers were not exactly inconspicuous.

LEAD: President Bush sought today to dispel any suggestion that Germany and the Soviet Union had reached an independent agreement on German unification, saying the United States ''has been in the forefront'' on the issue since before the Berlin wall was opened.
LEAD: Japan will stop drift-net fishing in the South Pacific this season, a year before the date set by a United Nations resolution, the Japanese Embassy said today.

LEAD: Magazine advertising revenues for the first half of 1990 rose a slim 1.6 percent, to $3.28 billion, compared with the period a year earlier, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. Advertising pages fell 3.3 percent.

LEAD: Though it seemed as if the mix-and-match pop music esthetic that began in the early 1980's might lumber to a stop in the 1990's, it hasn't. African, American and European pop music all greedily suck in cultures, easily available by travel and record collections. The result is a party where the old mingles with the new, where a sense of cultural movement, always exciting, momentarily blinds an audience to its differences, uniting it.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about the savings and loan crisis misstated the percentage of respondents in a Gallup poll who believed that neither the Republicans nor the Democrats were to blame. LEAD: Corning Inc. agreed to sell most of its 33.4 percent stake in the Iwaki Glass Company, a Tokyo-based manufacturer of industrial, consumer and laboratory products, to its partner in the concern, the Asahi Glass Company. Corning would not disclose the amount, but said the deal would result in a one-time gain after taxes of $18 million against its third-quarter earnings.

LEAD: The Quedlinburg Treasure, slowly surfacing in Texas, is the stuff of a Dashiell Hammett novel. Like the Maltese Falcon, it provokes enormous greed. What it doesn't appear to provoke is a sense of shame among those delaying its return to its proper owner, a German church.

LEAD: If the Old Course continues to take the kind of par pounding that was administered by the field today in the first round of the 119th British Open, the knobby moonscape fairways may look like a parking lot with a couple of speed bumps by the end of the championship.

LEAD: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Joseph Fernandez, has long promoted the idea that principals, teachers and parents in individual schools ought to share power. Now 117 of the city's 984 schools are ready to take up the challenge. In a system that already divides authority between a central board and 32 community boards, giving more power to individual schools is the ultimate decentralization plan, and it's off to a reasonable start.

LEAD: Six years after a 750-acre area of Patchogue Bay was found too polluted for shellfishing, the state has declared the clams clean and reopened the waters. The pollution had stemmed from Patchogue's sewage plant, which was upgraded in 1985. The town of Brookhaven and Suffolk County tested the water and the shellfish for three years, and the State Environmental Conservation Department said Wednesday that shellfishing could resume.

LEAD: Lorna Simpson's Conceptual-based art, which is currently the subject of a ''Projects'' exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, has a double theme: the oppression of blacks and of women. LEAD: Because of a production error, a chronology yesterday about events of the last 15 years in Cambodia omitted an entry in some copies. LEAD: TENNIS Rostagno Stops McEnroe Again Derrick Rostagno yesterday defeated John McEnroe for the second time in a month, duplicating his Wimbledon upset with a 6-3, 1-6, 6-1 victory in the third round of the Sovran Bank Classic in Washington. Rostagno, ranked 113th in the world, lost his serve only twice - when he dropped the second set - and charged through the third set by breaking McEnroe twice.

LEAD: Just as the savings and loan scandal awakens the public to the costs of fraud, some members of Congress propose undercutting the country's most sweeping civil fraud law. The 1970 law is called ''Civil RICO,'' short for Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations. It enables private citizens as well as government to seek triple damages for all kinds of commercial fraud.

LEAD: Now that the dog days are here, the subject of heat and photography is never far from my mind. To tell the truth, when it's really hot outside the idea of carrying around a black, five-pound hunk of electronic and optical technology does not seem that appealing. I'd rather be carrying one of those tiny, battery-operated fans than having a thick camera strap bite into my sweaty neck.

LEAD: Randall Walrath Hoffmann, a professor of English who had been an administrator at several colleges, died on Tuesday at St. Luke's Hospital in Tryon, N.C. He was 77 years old and had recently moved to Tryon from Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. He died of heart failure, his wife said. Mr. Hoffmann was the dean of students at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., from 1951 to 1966.

LEAD: After years of sitting on the sidelines because of soaring housing costs and high interest rates, first-time home buyers in the New York region are finally getting a break. The relief, say bankers, brokers and the buyers themselves, is in lower prices, cost-cutting incentives offered by both builders and individual sellers and more flexible loan policies of mortgage lenders and insurers.

LEAD: For This Week: Keep after insect-disease problems before they overwhelm the plants. Transplanting and dividing continues. Finish pruning, especially spring-flowering species. Last call to apply fertilizer to ornamentals so the new growth has time to develop and harden before cold weather. Keep up fruit tree spray and rose spray as protective measures against disease problems.
LEAD: WINNING the Indianapolis 500 brings a driver fame and fortune, but not immunity from the rules of racing as the 1990 Indy winner, Arie Luyendyk, has just learned.
LEAD: WITH the wealthiest generation of elderly people in the country's history reaching the end of their lives, economists are trying to predict what will happen to their money.

LEAD: Saving and rehabilitating old buildings has become so common in the last few years that it is tempting to think of the whole process as easy - after all, if no one is clamoring any longer to tear a landmark down, hasn't the hardest battle been won? Not necessarily: roughly 15 years passed between the departure of the New York City Police Department from its old headquarters at 240 Centre Street in Manhattan and that building's reopening last year as a strikingly elegant cooperative apartment building; an even longer period elapsed between the abandonment of the old Association

LEAD: THE Bush Administration's policy shift on Cambodia last week is the latest evidence of how the thaw in American-Soviet relations is transforming both superpowers' approach to regional conflicts.

LEAD: The 61-year-old Drake Tower in Center City is undergoing an interior renovation in a conversion from its primary use as a dormitory to an apartment house. It will be ''a New York-style apartment building, with a concierge, at Philadelphia prices,'' said Milton Cross, a spokesman for the development group.

LEAD: For more than three decades Lenore Tawney has been a revolutionary figure in fiber art. In the 1950's she was credited with freeing weaving from the confines of the loom. She was one of the first to juxtapose areas of plain weave with areas of unwoven warp, to incorporate knots, braids, shells and feathers into her pieces and to create weavings intended to be hung away from a wall, adding a sculptural dimension to what traditionally had been a flat art.

LEAD: ''Near the heart, on top of the head, the right shoulder, other places, too,'' says Joel Ghivelder, listing the damaged regions on the mountaintop statue of Jesus that is perhaps Rio de Janeiro's most famous landmark. Ghivelder, an architect, is overseeing the restoration of the statue and the public space around its foundation, a project that began last March.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. George A. Vaughn of Princeton, N.J., and Warwick, Bermuda, have announced the engagement of their daughter Phoebe Hinman Vaughn to Andrew Willard Outerbridge, a son of Mrs. John Hollis Kaufmann of Somerset, Bermuda, and Colebrook, N.H., and Yeaton Outerbridge of Smith's parish, Bermuda, and Jamestown, R.I.

LEAD: A NEW generation of nuclear power plants - smaller, simpler and probably safer - is taking shape on the drawing boards. But rethinking the nuclear reactor is raising difficult issues for manufacturers and critics alike.

LEAD: As the Jets' training camp opens, there are new players, a new head coach, new assistants and new front-office people. But whether the club has managed to turn over a new leaf after last season's dismal 4-12 record remains to be seen.

LEAD: HE has caught more passes (534) for more yards (10,352) and more touchdowns (67) than anyone else in the history of the New England Patriots franchise, but the way the Patriots figured it when they released him this year, after 13 arduous seasons and at the age of 35, Stanley Morgan had simply outlived his usefulness as a wide receiver.

LEAD: President Bush began discussions today on a successor to Justice William J. Brennan Jr., while liberals and conservatives immediately began organizing for what many predicted would be a bruising battle over the shape of the Supreme Court in the 1990's and the constitutional right to abortion.

LEAD: THE sign on the telephone pole near the Long Island Shore in Mamaroneck warns: ''Closed area. Taking clams and other shellfish from this uncertified area is prohibited. Violations are punishable by a fine, a jail sentence or both.''

LEAD: Next to lunching on goat cheese and gelignite, one of the more dangerous things you can do in London is to mess with the National Gallery. Not only is it, inch for inch, as great a picture gallery as the world can show; it is midmost, inmost England. Gloriously situated at the north end of Trafalgar Square, it is the sanctuary of a specific sensibility and the stronghold for 150 years of a heroic view of art.

LEAD: Siegfried Matthus counts as East Germany's most successful opera composer, with his works performed throughout Eastern Europe and, increasingly, West Germany. Up to now, however, apart from the ministrations of a few champions of his orchestral music, he has remained largely unknown in the United States.

LEAD: Late August wedding plans for Maria-Flora Miller and Anthony Michael Smoller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Smoller of Larchmont, N.Y., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Ava Mohas of Mill Neck, L.I., and Leverett Saltonstall Miller of Fairfield, Fla.

LEAD: It seems that the Bush Administration doesn't consider Orlando Bosch that bad a guy, after all. Dr. Bosch, an anti-Castro Cuban who American officials say is responsible for dozens of bombings, including that of a Cuban airliner in Chile in 1976, last week was granted limited parole by the Justice Department, which had detained him in Florida for two years as an undesirable alien.
LEAD: Dumpling dough must be beaten until it talks to the bowl, my mother used to advise as the thickening, sticky mass hit the side with a thwop.

LEAD: Regulatory authorities are receiving a growing number of complaints from buyers and sellers about the way they are treated by real estate brokers. New York State, for example, received some 3,000 complaints in 1989, up from 2,200 in 1987. This is resulting in a rewriting of regulations to better protect and educate buyers.

LEAD: A Bronx man who told the police he wrested a gun away from an armed robber and then fatally shot his assailant was arrested yesterday on murder charges, although a police spokesman said investigators thought the man had acted in self-defense.

LEAD: Japanese who have settled in the New York suburbs, whether for a temporary business assignment or for good, are starting to feel a backlash from their growing presence and the rising economic tensions between Japan and the United States.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. George W. Howey of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne Kristen Howey to Robert T. Carson, the son of Mrs. James Weatherstone of Summit and Benjamin R. Carson of Warminster, Pa. A December wedding is planned.

LEAD: Chess is neither the oldest board game in the world nor the most difficult to master. For 14 centuries, however, judging from the wealth of innovative sets that survive, it has challenged designers and artisans on four continents.
LEAD: Two landlords and their University of Maryland student tenants have teamed up to challenge a Prince George's County law restricting student housing.

LEAD: More than 48,000 residents of Eastern Europe have inquired about immigrating to South Africa this year, the Government-run radio said today. A total of 375 immigrants from Poland, Yugoslavia, Hungary and the Soviet Union arrived in the first five months of 1990, the South African Broadcasting Corporation said.

LEAD: It may be an exaggeration, but not by much, to say that everyone has one. And there's at least one good thing to be said for this thing: it's the place to go whenever whatever you are looking for can't be found anywhere else. On the other hand, if you do look there, and even if you find what you want, more often than not it's a mess.

LEAD: AS farming vanishes from Connecticut, the popularity of country fairs, with events from jam judging to oxen pulls, is booming. But as the larger fairs draw ever-growing crowds and ever-growing traffic problems, and as all the fairs confront a shrinking pool of volunteers, some people see problems ahead for these events.

LEAD: Twenty-eight people were injured yesterday when a city bus skidded out of control on a rain-slicked roadway and slammed into an elevated train stanchion as the bus was exiting the Williamsburg Bridge, the authorities said.

LEAD: Bohemia $202,000 1025 Locust Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, custom-built 12-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, family room w/fireplace, 1 acre, 2-car garage; taxes $4,600. Levittown $144,000 30 Haymaker Lane 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 35- year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,800.

LEAD: A space squeeze in its Wayne, N.J., building is prompting the Calvin Klein Cosmetics Company, which makes and distributes the Obsession and Eternity fragrance lines, to spread out and move west. The company will lease a new 142,500-square-foot warehouse and distribution center that is being built for it in the International Trade Center in Mount Olive.

LEAD: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 6 THE BURDEN OF PROOF, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) An attorney tries to unravel the mystery of his wife's death while defending his wheeler-dealer brother-in-law.

LEAD: It wasn't close. Greg LeMond sped away from Claudio Chiappucci of Italy in the showdown time trial in the Tour de France today and donned the yellow jersey of the overall leader for the first time in the three-week race.

LEAD: April wedding plans for Ellyn J. Polishook and David H. Wander, a son of Arlene Wander and Philip Wander, both of New York, have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Polishook of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

LEAD: TRIAL BY JURY. By Steven Brill and the editors and reporters of The American Lawyer. (American Lawyer/Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $12.95.) ''Trial by Jury'' is to litigation what sportswriting is to playing ball. It is a collection of articles, originally published in The American Lawyer, about 17 celebrated lawsuits of the 1980's.

LEAD: Less than six months ago, preparing for a night out at one of East Berlin's theaters was a nerve-racking experience for the Western visitor: tickets had to be reserved well in advance through an East German Government agency and crossing from West Berlin involved standing in long lines at one of the two border crossings open to foreigners, Friedrichstrasse and Checkpoint Charlie.

LEAD: There will be a Gielgud at Lincoln Center this week, but this particular Gielgud will not be delivering stirring soliloquies from Shakespeare or taking to the stage in any physical way, except perhaps for a final curtain call.

LEAD: A picture caption on the film page of the Arts and Leisure section today misstates the title of a film starring Kiefer Sutherland and Emily Lloyd.

LEAD: Commissioner Fay Vincent, forced by the George Steinbrenner case to learn quickly the history of baseball disciplinary proceedings, arrived at a conclusion: ''In situations where owners have been investigated by the commissioner, routinely they go to Federal court,'' Vincent said. ''Routinely they lose in Federal court.

LEAD: When nature leaves no stone unturned, you get a smooth, sandy beach. When chess strategists leave no stone unturned, you get a whole series of jagged edges, White and Black taking turns at sharp victories.

LEAD: Herbert Nelson, an actor whose repertory ranged from Shakespeare to Broadway comedy to television drama and soap operas, died on Thursday at the Actors Fund of America Nursing Home in Englewood, N.J. He was 76 years old. A former resident of Leonia, N.J., he had lived in Venice, Calif., until last year.

LEAD: An article on May 27 about Christie's and Sotheby's auction houses characterized Sotheby's incorrectly. It was founded by Samuel Baker, not by his nephew John Sotheby. A reader's letter pointed out the error several weeks after it occurred, and The Times inadvertently delayed a correction.

LEAD: Nick Faldo kept up the fastest pace ever set in a British Open today, one that even the hottest golfers could not catch and one that all but left Greg Norman buried in one of the claustrophobic bunkers of the Old Course.

LEAD: THREE of the American theater's most popular recent plays are included in this summer's repertory at the Westport Country Playhouse: ''The Cocktail Hour,'' which was seen early this month; ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' now playing, and ''Steel Magnolias,'' coming up on July 31.

Must we brace for a confirmation fight that could dwarf the Senate's 1987 brawl over Robert

LEAD: Sergei Paradzhanov, an Armenian film director, has died after a long illness, the official press agency Tass said today. He was 66 years old.

Newton of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Patrick Sean Scobie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Scobie of Chippewa Falls, Wis. The Rev. David S. LEAD: PICNICS are fun for the host because there are no last-minute pressures. All the food is prepared beforehand. Ideally, I like to have a simple central dish such as cold roast chicken, ham or pork loin or even a poached salmon - around which various salads can be organized. These are chosen to provide contrasting textures and flavors.
LEAD: TED TURNER is a notorious film colorizer from way back. He is also responsible for those soporific Atlanta Braves broadcasts into defenseless homes and taverns all over this land.

LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

LEAD: Almost every stamp issued by the United States seems to point topical collectors in a new direction. The latest was occasioned by the issuance of a block of four stamps in March to honor great movies of 1939.

LEAD: E.O. Wilson doesn't make a lot of headway hiking through the Panamanian rain forest. Invertebrates distract him. He stops to poke. A wasp is acting strangely - he must see why. A bee clamps its mandibles onto his hand - no problem. He'll just observe it for a while. He snaps off epiphytes - plants that grow in the lower forest canopy - looking for nesting ants.

LEAD: French families receive generous welfare and tax incentives to have more children, but to no avail. Mothers in France are no longer averaging the 2.1 children needed to insure a natural replacement of the country's population.

LEAD: SINCE its Viennese premiere in 1905, the Franz Lehar operetta ''The Merry Widow'' has been a high-spirited staple of the world's musical stages in innumerable translations and adaptations - not to mention filmed, danced, recorded and even ice-skated versions.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE line dividing publicity from criticism is not as clear as it used to be. These days, dealers and museum personnel quite often get right to the point by asking reviewers to ''generate'' interest in a show and, upon encountering resistance, will invoke the popularity of the art, as if they are helpless in the face of public opinion.

LEAD: A dispute over a plaque put up to commemorate the Rev. Jozef Tiso, a Roman Catholic priest who headed Slovakia's pro-fascist independence government during World War II, has led many Czechoslovaks to ask where their new-found freedom is leading them.

LEAD: THE STATIONS OF SOLITUDE. By Alice Koller. (Morrow, $19.95.) In this account of her struggles with self-imposed solitude, the essayist Alice Koller discloses her most intimate secrets with startling nonchalance. She can get away with this because she stands as far away from us as possible and because her voice is strong and carries, not only from the New England and Virginia country houses where she has spent the past 28 years, but from the place just beyond the pale of human contact where she lives.

LEAD: President Samuel K. Doe of Liberia expelled the United States military attache today, accusing him of providing support to the advancing rebels, as support for Mr. Doe diminished further within his own Government.
LEAD: MONDAY: Treasury Department's budget deficit report for June. Negotiators from 105 countries take part in trade talks in Geneva, through Friday.

LEAD: International 3-13 East Germany's economic problems are beginning to reflect its transition to a market economy. Joblessness, officially unknown a year ago, is growing. Page 1 Solidarity's continuing rift has had a disillusioning effect on Henryk Wujec, a leader of the Solidarity caucus in Parliament.

LEAD: An article on June 24 about travelers' safety in Athens referred incorrectly to a Greek restriction on visitors. Only passengers on charter flights from Europe are required to show proof of prepaid accommodation; the requirement has not been applied to Americans.

LEAD: Like the Music Center at Tanglewood some 40 miles to the north, the Norfolk Chamber Music Festival in northwestern Connecticut is celebrating a half-century of summer schooling for young musicians.

LEAD: A Dartmouth College student found guilty of sexual abuse last spring by the college's discipline committee and suspended until January will file a lawsuit against the college this week seeking to nullify the actions, his lawyer says.

LEAD: While planning a recent solo trip to Europe, I received warnings from friends about the dangers of a woman traveling alone in Italy. My experience there confirmed that, in general, women are valued only as mothers or else seen as sex objects. However, I never had any problems because I refused to be intimidated.

LEAD: Dave Mora of Bloomington, Ind., an unofficial member of the United States team, became the first track and field gold medalist of the 1990 Goodwill Games today, winning the men's marathon.
LEAD: A picture caption on July 8 about the reclaimed Aberglasney garden in Wales misidentified a structure. It was a stable block, not a cloister and terrace walks.

LEAD: AS the popularity of cats continues to soar - at 58 million, they now outnumber dogs as household pets by about seven million - so does the market for feline-related products. Some are strictly for cats. But many others court the needs, whims and fancies of cat owners.

LEAD: Angier Biddle Duke announced his retirement yesterday as chancellor of Long Island University's Southampton campus, ending a long career in international diplomacy and academia.

LEAD: The Mets are prepared to make Darryl Strawberry an incredibly wealthy young man with a reported salary of $3 million to $4 million per year. If they choose to delay contract negotiations until after the season to avoid a distracting media circus, they are totally within their rights to do so.

The wood squares are still firm and sticking solidly. Would it be possible to leave the wood flooring in place as insulation and then lay the tiles directly over this?

LEAD: The recent fuss over canned music at live concerts assumes there's a con going on. The argument, put forth by rock critics and legislators, holds that real music must have real live musicians playing it. Anything else is aural Naugahyde.

LEAD: IT did not start out as a contest. The catbird was just singing from a branch of the pine tree with a long happy series of chortles, trills and burbles that made up a happy tune. The song sounded very much like the endless cheer of the purple finch, until the catbird was spotted from below.

Gorbachev gave his imprimatur to German unity, he was following a compulsion with deep roots in Russian history, and his gaze ranged far beyond Germany.

LEAD: STATE-CONTROLLED French companies are breaking the mold. Rather than tending to their home market, they are aggressively buying abroad, both in Europe and the United States. Some, like Renault, are positioning themselves for the economic union of Europe in 1992; others, like Rhone-Poulenc, are pursuing the grander goal of a top ranking in their industry, worldwide.

LEAD: Nearly seven decades after his death, Enrico Caruso remains this century's most famous tenor, vividly present in 246 surviving recordings that trace the trajectory of his career and technique and attest to his influence on the art of singing. Although desirable for these reasons - and because of his crucial role in the history of recording - a good ''complete Caruso'' remained, in several LP projects, an elusive ideal.

LEAD: The Japanese Government, good to its word, sent the World Bank a check for $7,706,000 last week in final payment on a highway loan. Japan? Borrowing? To build roads? Yes. Back in the 1950's and 1960's, when Japan was hardly an economic powerhouse, it borrowed $863 million from the bank for projects to rebuild its economy.
LEAD: A music listing in the Arts and Leisure Guide today misstates the date for ''Turandot'' by the New York Grand Opera in Central Park. It will be performed on Thursday night, not Tuesday.

LEAD: ''My mother would never have consented to my making my first appearance in a public room, so to Mrs. Morton's we went,'' the novelist Edith Wharton wrote, as she recalled coming out into society in 1879. ''Mrs. Morton's'' was a sturdy brick dwelling, with handsome arched windows, at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

LEAD: The rebel army controlling most of the northern Ethiopian province of Eritrea is blocking desperately needed famine relief supplies, members of the United States Congress and officials of the United Nations say.

LEAD: The San Diego Padres have executed one of the better magic tricks of recent seasons. They have gone from contenders to rebuilders right before their very eyes.

LEAD: IT used to be that programmers, engineers and marketers were the centerpiece of the computer industry. Now lawyers are taking center stage. Dozens of computer companies are wrangling over copyright and patent issues, and some analysts fear that legal code, rather than software code, is emerging as the factor that will determine which companies and products will dominate the 1990's.

LEAD: She walked into the courtroom, which was an accomplishment all by itself. ''She looked great,'' said one observer, ''for a person who's been beaten to death.'' By the time she testified, wearing a purple suit and assorted scars, it had become almost fitting that the only thing we did not know about her was her name.
LEAD: Haiti has become the first United Nations member to request that its elections be monitored by the organization to insure that they are free and fair.

LEAD: In ''Healthy Indulgence'' (Food, June 24), Jacques Pepin does an admirable job of delivering savory and attractive low-fat fare. However, in the future, I hope Pepin's nutritional profiles for servings will be expressed in whole numbers, rather than counts extended to two decimal places. (One recipe, for example, estimated a lime cookie's calories at 59.63.) At best, a recipe analysis is an estimate of nutrient content, with considerable margin for error in either direction.

LEAD: THE market got news last week of two new pending issues of LYONS, one of the trademarked borrowing gimmicks from Merrill Lynch. A LYON, or Liquid Yield Option Note, is Merrill's zero-coupon twist on the old-fashioned convertible bond. Issued at a big discount from its value at maturity, a corporation's LYON gives the buyer the right to convert the bond into a fixed number of the company's shares, or an equal sum of cash, at the company's option.

LEAD: Richard Kessel's article (''Power Authority Is Necessary to Oversee Lilco,'' June 24) emphasizes the $5.5 billion cost of Shoreham. Let us examine the facts: Both Federal and State governments actively encouraged the building of a nuclear plant at Shoreham. After construction was well along, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission began to order hundreds of changes in design, and many completed and started structures had to be destroyed and new ones installed, beginning from scratch.
