LEAD: The Cable Act of 1984 freed cable television companies to gouge customers. And gouge is just what many of them did - with wretched service and unconscionable rates. One company had to be forced by law just to answer telephone calls from an army of irate customers. In the cable business, one Congressman gibed, ''customer service is an oxymoron.
LEAD: THE Los Angeles Dodger infielders Alfredo Griffin and Juan Samuel were arrested on assault charges early yesterday after an early-morning fight involving a bartender at a Pittsburgh nightclub.

LEAD: Marian Ball Thayer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sydney Thayer 3d of Coatesville, Pa., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Kenneth Edwin Gemes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl E. Gemes of Atlanta. The Rev. Timothy Pickering, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Until June, much of what four young pianists from the Juilliard School knew about pianos was how to coax music from the keyboard. But by early this month they had also learned how to dismantle, pack, reassemble and tune the instrument.

LEAD: Of all the ancient rock dreadnoughts supplying audiences with a vestige of the 1960's and early 1970's, Robert Plant has survived the best. Having shed the worst of his Led Zepplin mannerisms and left them to countless heavy metal bands, he's instead tried to work out a balance between the hippie experimentalism of Led

LEAD: For six centuries, through Poland's wars and vacillating fortunes, the faithful have walked days, often the last distance on their knees, to revere the Black Madonna of Czestochowa. Painted on wood - legend has it by the brush of St. Luke - the doleful four-foot-high icon is the focus of the nation's spiritual life.

LEAD: There were no victory parades here when the cold war ended. Instead, warriors began slipping away, tanks were lined up neatly on parking lots for storage, and the civilians who live around this huge Army base started feeling as though they were the losers.
LEAD: New York City has 8,100 sidewalk pay phones. That should be plenty, if they all worked, and if long-winded talkers didn't monopolize the ones that do.

LEAD: Judge and Mrs. William A. Dreier of Warren, N.J., have announced December wedding plans for their daughter, Susan Alice Dreier, and David Charles Wishnow, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Wishnow of Bridgewater, N.J.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A picture caption in some copies yesterday misstated the date of William H. Rehnquist's appointment to the Supreme Court. He was named to the Court in 1972 by President Richard M. Nixon and elevated to Chief Justice in 1986 by President Ronald Reagan.

LEAD: AT TRW Inc. and the United Technologies Corporation, the title is ''vice president of science and technology.'' At Merrill Lynch & Company, it's ''executive vice president for operations systems and telecommunications.'' Chemical Bank sticks with the plain-vanilla ''chief technology officer.''

LEAD: BOTH houses of Congress did some cleaning last week. A House panel voted to punish a Democrat who did wrong for a lover and a Senate committee voted to sanction a Republican who did wrong for cash.

LEAD: I understand that traveling alone in India can be an uncomfortable experience for a woman (Hers: ''Ladies' Compartment,'' by Martha Stevenson, July 1). But it is unfair to condemn Indian men on the basis of a problem that hasn't been solved at home. Stevenson should travel across the United States in a bus and see that gender relations are mired in medieval times, no matter where you are.

LEAD: THE exhibition ''New Jersey Painting Today'' is the first juried annual to be staged at Phyllis Rothman, the still newish gallery on Fairleigh Dickinson's Florham-Madison campus. The judge was Zoltan Buki, curator at the State Museum in Trenton, and from about 200 entrants he culled 31.

LEAD: At the opening of ''The Magicians of the Earth,'' the gigantic exhibition of contemporary art in Paris last summer, I mentioned to another American art critic that I found the selection of Western artists troublesome. I also said that some of the non-Western artists were not very good.
LEAD: THE earnings released last week by aluminum producers were, in a word, grim. But the companies appeared unfazed and said profits would start climbing soon.

LEAD: Seven years after my father's death, I have begun wearing his ring. Not always. I wear it, talismanically, to weddings, funerals and other solemnities, on long drives toward meaningful destinations. I slip it on, I will sheepishly admit, for its powers.

LEAD: It seemed odd. When Nolan Ryan of the Texas Rangers hobbled out of the trainer's room in Arlington Stadium on Friday night with an ice bag taped around his right ankle and was met by a group of mostly local reporters, all of them asked about his back.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Just when everyone knew the program traders were going to bail them out by buying stocks, they didn't. That may be the simplest summary of a week when the Dow Jones industrial average first failed to close over 3,000 by the smallest margin possible, and then saw prices crumble in the final moments Friday.

LEAD: Adrienne Willets Brodeur, a legislative aide at the San Diego Board of Supervisors, and Bartlett Christmas Brewster, the captain of the lifeguard services division of the San Diego Park and Recreation Department, were married yesterday in Orleans, Mass. The Rev. Valjeanne Paxton, a United Church of Christ minister and the bride's aunt, performed the ceremony at the summer home of the bride's mother, Mrs.

LEAD: ON the gouged, crumbling road from Phnom Penh to the southern Cambodian port of Kampot, a man weaves a bicycle awkwardly among the potholes. He is pedaling with one foot; the stump of the other is swaddled in a kramar, or cotton scarf, slung from the handlebar.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs Stephen Ehrlich of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Anne Ehrlich, to Emanuel Robert Pearlman, a son of Leonard D. Pearlman and Roberta C. Pearlman, both of New York. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: In pictures and from the air, the Bulgarian Black Sea coast looks like a vacationer's paradise. The rolling hills of the coast meet the blue and green Black Sea along beaches of golden sand that seem made for swimming and sun bathing. Picturesque villages where each house is wreathed in grape vines, roses and house plants sprouting from oil cans and jars and old tires dot the coastal roads.
LEAD: Thousands of protesters clashed with the riot police today after a huge anti-Government rally drew together South Korea's splintered opposition and attracted about 300,000 people.
LEAD: Thousands of protesters clashed with the riot police today after a huge anti-Government rally drew together South Korea's splintered opposition and attracted about 300,000 people.
LEAD: Shiite Muslim factions fought another round of ferocious battles in southern Lebanon today, in which 30 people were killed and 45 were wounded, the police said.

LEAD: The ''reverse commute'' and the suburban-to-suburban commute have become the most serious ground transportation problems in the country. The June 3 article ''Ranks of Reverse Commuters Expected to Grow'' touched the surface of the employee commuting problems during and after a company relocation.
LEAD: RESEARCHERS at the Batelle Institute's Pacific Northwest Laboratory in Richland, Wash., have developed a way to inhibit the growth of plant roots for as long as 100 years.
LEAD: Jean Marie McDonough and William Ross Mattson were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Timothy M. Johnson performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A SEAT on a board of directors has always been one of the ultimate signs of achievement. Increasingly, the doors to the boardrooms of major corporations and foundations have been swinging open to admit women.

LEAD: The Arizona businessman who secured $1.85 billion in Federal savings and loan subsidies with lobbying help from a former aide to President Bush was also able to buy an insolvent Oklahoma bank at a favorable price despite his failure to meet Federal standards for such purchases.

LEAD: The one-traffic-light village of Red Hook sits inconspicuously in the northwest corner of Dutchess County, near the Hudson River, off the beaten track of the tourist trail that takes thousands of visitors each year to more popular attractions in Rhinebeck and Hyde Park to the south.

LEAD: Doug Dascenzo scored the tying run in the eighth inning on a balk by a reliever, Jeff Brantley, and Marvell Wynne raced home from second on Jose Uribe's error at shortstop as the Chicago Cubs defeated the San Francisco Giants today, 3-2.

LEAD: Q. Our den has a cement slab floor that is covered with squares of wood parquet flooring. This floor has no insulation and is cold in the winter. I would like to cover it with ceramic tiles. The wood squares are still firm and sticking solidly. Would it be possible to leave the wood flooring in place as insulation and then lay the tiles directly over this?

LEAD: A Federal judge in Cincinnati said he saw two people in front of him last week: Pete Rose the living legend and Pete Rose the tax cheat. He sent them both to jail for five months. Rose, who batted his way on to base more times than anybody else in baseball, pleaded guilty to two felony counts of filing false income tax returns.

LEAD: William Beckett, a former president of the Beckett Paper Company of Hamilton, Ohio, died Thursday at his home in Hamilton at the age of 81. The company said he had been in declining health for two years.

LEAD: A century ago, on the advice of his brother, Theo, and the painter Pissarro, Vincent van Gogh traveled from Paris to Auvers, a small village along the banks of the River Oise, where a certain Dr. Gachet awaited to treat him. Just 20 miles north of the capital, Auvers is ''far enough from Paris to be real country,'' wrote van Gogh in the first of many letters to Theo describing his new surroundings.
LEAD: Air Fares Cut In California Price War

LEAD: The article ''Effort on Affordable Housing Is Falling Short of Goal'' (May 27) provided an excellent update on the status of affordable housing in New Jersey. With due respect to the tireless efforts of many builders, nonprofit organizations, the Council on Affordable Housing and the State Division of Housing Development, I would like to point out the following.

LEAD: Behind the iron gates of Budapest, in courtyards buried within unassuming apartment buildings, offices and universities, a traveler can find forgotten treasures of art and architecture, and footprints of the wars and revolutions that have marched across Hungary for the last millennium.

LEAD: Home Builders' Lament: Fewer New Houses, Fewer New Buyers Everyone's favorite leveraged investment is going sour. Housing starts have fallen five months in a row, the Commerce Department reported last week - down 15.7 percent in a year to an annual rate of 1.18 million in June. Home builders blame their old friends, the savings institutions, who are now unwilling or unable to back them.
LEAD: On Monday, A.T.&T. and the National Coalition of 100 Black Women held their 8th annual Candace Awards dinner at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Lamkin of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Melissa Warren Lamkin to William Baldwin Kuesel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Kuesel of Darien. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: The Mazda Motor Corporation on Friday recalled 102,548 of its 1985 and 1986 model 626 cars because of potentially faulty ignition switches. The company said the switch could wear out after extended use and affect the operation of the windshield wipers and washers, engine cooling fan, heater blower and air-conditioner compressor.
LEAD: The Mets' front office have let talent like Kevin Mitchell and Len Dykstra slip from their fingers. Now it would seem that Darryl Strawberry is next.

LEAD: A SIMPLE premise lies behind the Re-entry Program of the Middlesex County Chamber of Commerce: people who have been out of the work force a long time need training that prepares them for available jobs. Since its inception in 1986, the program has trained 400 people, placed more than 90 percent of them in jobs and earned the trust of employers in Middletown and neighboring communities in Middlesex County.
LEAD: An American philanthropy plans to spend millions of dollars to bring scholars and industrial leaders together in projects to restore the nation's competitive edge in manufacturing and trade.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Halan of New Caanan, Conn., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter, Ann Elizabeth Halan, and L. Crawford Brickley Jr., the son of Dawn J. Doyle of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Mr. Brickley of Greenville, Tenn. The prospective bride and bridegroom are associates at the New York law firm of Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts.

LEAD: Always playing, the violinist in his gold-embroidered blue tunic strolls to the table where a couple are halfway through their roast duck dinner and asks for their selection. As something is murmured, the fiddler strikes up the plangent opening bars of ''There Is Only One Girl in the World.''

LEAD: What is quotable? To quote, or what to quote, that is the question. Should I dress up in taffeta phrases or stick to russet yeas and honest kersey noes? (What is kersey, anyway?) Will a dab of Shakespeare daintily perfume my wit or just sound like the literary belching of a compulsive nerd? But that is not the question.

LEAD: THE journey through Trail Wood, the Edwin Way Teale memorial sanctuary in Hampton, begins at a break in a stone wall opening into Firefly Meadow. Here a path bordered by wildflowers and furrowed grasses leads to the bridge over Stepping Stone Brook, where largemouth bass meander among the water weeds.

LEAD: PATRIOTISM may be the last refuge of scoundrels, but it is often the first choice of companies seeking the ear of the investing public. Consider the case of American Spirit Corporation of Beverly Hills, Calif.

LEAD: LAST month, when he was named emeritus university librarian, Phillip Rosenstein was honored at a champagne bash for 250 people at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. But he still doesn't know what he will do later this month, when he actually leaves the Newark-based library, taking a big chunk of his pension money with him.

LEAD: During the freewheeling 80's, when almost any company was fair game for raiders and other businesses willingly sold themselves, many American hi-fi manufacturers were gobbled up by foreign investors. What happened in the case of Analog and Digital Systems, better known to audio fans as a/d/s/, is all the more remarkable.

LEAD: A Congressional report has criticized the nation's ''Star Wars'' program, saying the recent addition of a new weapon concept has complicated and delayed the process of deciding whether the system is feasible.

LEAD: BEHIND THE MASK: My Double Life in Baseball. By Dave Pallone with Alan Steinberg. (Viking, $18.95.) Every baseball umpire dons a mask to work behind home plate, but the former National League umpire Dave Pallone wore one off the field as well. The reason, Mr. Pallone reveals in his emotional memoir, written with the freelance writer Alan Steinberg, is that he is gay.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Erica Gail Rubinstein and Jay Leon are planning an October wedding. The engagement was announced by the bride's mother, Ricki Rubinstein of Riverdale, the Bronx.
LEAD: A Federal grand jury's investigation into the possibility of vast corruption in the South Carolina Legislature appears to be expanding rapidly and has left this capital city shaken.

LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is facing a decision on whether to raise the minimum amount of automobile liability insurance that New Yorkers must carry. If he does so, lawyers say, bigger damage awards would result. But insurers warn that an increase could also mean more lawsuits that would drive up the cost of motorists' premiums.
LEAD: Orthodox politicians are trying to outlaw pork, the most unkosher of foods.

LEAD: THE City Council approved a proposal last week to spend $167 million to upgrade the 74-acre Seattle Center, which comprises 26 of the buildings that housed the 1962 World's Fair, among them the 605-foot Space Needle.

LEAD: Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, the Vietnamese Communist commander, is certainly a man of deep commitment, and Stanley Karnow's fascination with his erudition and style is understandable (''Giap Remembers,'' June 24). But before we grant Giap an eminent place in the ''pantheon of military leaders,'' we ought to remember one thing.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Drayton of Villanova, Pa., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Constance Cameron Drayton and Jonathan Whitehead Old 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Old Jr. of Greenwich, Conn.

LEAD: In 1956, when John Wayne played his greatest role in John Ford's film ''The Searchers,'' he appeared as a lonely, embittered, deeply prejudiced figure, a mean-spirited warrior estranged from home and family. By the end of the film, Mr. Wayne's Indian fighter Ethan Edwards was able, quite literally, to close the door on those antisocial feelings and embrace his loved ones and a peaceful, quieter life.
LEAD: AFTER months of quiescence in American politics, the two parties are finally stirring, lurching into the 1990's and the uncharted political terrain beyond Reaganism.

LEAD: Though golfers are accustomed to the idea of handicapping, it is a novel concept for tournament bridge players. A Handicap Knockout Team Championship was on the schedule of the Greater New York Bridge Association's Summer Regional in Manhattan a week ago. It provided for almost all participants a first taste of this type of contest.

LEAD: Arthur Tremain Hertig, whose pioneering studies on human embryology contributed to the development by others of the contraceptive pill and in vitro fertilization, died Friday at Falmouth Hospital in Falmouth, Mass. He was 86 years old.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Dr. Barbara Stricker, a resident at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, and Dr. Michael Friedman, a resident at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, plan to marry next fall. Dr. Stricker's parents are Mrs. Norman Kaufman of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Dr. Howard Stricker of Fort Lee, N.J. Dr. Friedman is the son of Lois Klaristenfeld of Fort Lee and Joseph Friedman of Oceanside, L.I.

LEAD: When I moved to Portugal last year after covering guerrilla wars in Ethiopia, Iraq and Afghanistan, I assumed I was putting the dangerous part of my life behind me. I couldn't have been more wrong.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: RECENT Supreme Court decisions have once again turned the spotlight on child abuse, that most disturbing of family crimes. Last year, 4,600 cases of child abuse were reported in the county, a number that has climbed steadily in recent years, said Efrain Centeno, executive director of the Exchange Club Child-Abuse Prevention Center of New York.

LEAD: Prince Norodom Ranariddh, son of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and the commander of his army, says the American shift of policy on Cambodia offers Vietnam an opportunity that he fears Hanoi will not seize, thus risking an intensification of the war in Cambodia.
LEAD: SEXUAL PERSONAE Art and Decadence From Nefertiti to Emily Dickinson. By Camille Paglia. Illustrated. 718 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35.

LEAD: Sailors worldwide are closing in on a speed barrier that is to sailing what the four-minute mile was to running. The wall they are confronting is at 50 knots, or about 58 miles an hour. At the rate records are toppling, the magic number is within sight, say speed-sailing experts.

LEAD: The Department of Energy has agreed not to burn waste containing plutonium and hazardous chemicals at the last two operable incinerators at its Rocky Flats weapons plant near Denver, unless it can win permission from the Colorado Department of Health or the United States Environmental Protection Agency.

LEAD: September wedding plans for Gretchen Ann Snow Johnson and Michael Francis Bigham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Bigham of Annapolis, Md., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James L. Johnson of Pottersville, N.J.
LEAD: Cara Ivy Somach and J. Robert Londin, lawyers in New York, plan to marry in October.

LEAD: The Mets should have learned from the Milwaukee Brewers, with Robin Yount, and continue their talks with Strawberry. Once he wins the National League's most valuable player award and becomes a free agent, his value will inevitably increase. KENNETH C. SIEGEL Bridgeport, Conn.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: THE MAGIC LANTERN The Revolution of '89 Witnessed in Warsaw, Budapest, Berlin, and Prague. By Timothy Garton Ash. 156 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

LEAD: Your article on the Poppers suggests that they would allow Indians to live on the Buffalo Commons. Do they assume that these Indians are going to ''go native'' and cheerfully pose for photos as the deer and the antelope play for the amusement of the eco-chic on chartered covered-wagon tours?
LEAD: Almost everybody already knows who did the whodunit, so who'll buy a ticket to the movie? For ''Presumed Innocent,'' such is the cinematic paradox of literary success.

LEAD: Remember the scene from ''Where's Poppa?'' in which the shy, mother-dominated lawyer played by George Segal tries to seduce the ethereal nurse played by Trish Van Devere while the two are standing upright on a bed that offers them no support at all?

LEAD: Is it possible that a decade has passed since Liz Thompson became artistic director of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival? At summer's end, Ms. Thompson, now the Pillow's executive producer, departs to head the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. She leaves the Pillow, a small but internationally known festival in Becket, Mass., a very different place from the one she found several years after the death of its founder, Ted Shawn.

LEAD: Tennis Agassi Routs Chang: Top-seeded Andre Agassi overpowered Michael Chang, 6-3, 6-1, last night to join Jim Grabb in the finals of the Sovran Bank Classic tournament in Washington. Agassi jumped on Chang's serve and used a strong baseline game to beat the him for the fourth time without a defeat in matches between the two young American stars.

LEAD: A whole world of modern dance lies beyond this country's borders. The American Dance Festival is to be congratulated, therefore, for establishing the International Choreographers Workshop, which, with financing from the United States Information Agency and the Rockefeller Foundation, enables choreographers from overseas to gather each summer on the campus of Duke University to take classes, observe festival performances and exchange ideas.

LEAD: Although commercial development has slowed to a snail's pace in much of the Northeast, a partnership of American and British builders thinks it has the right opportunity in an unlikely corner of the region: 10 miles west of Atlantic City, where ground has been broken for a 40-acre office project.They have named the complex Harbor Creek Office

LEAD: The attention given to the challenge of unreasonable speeds and irrational driving behavior in the article ''Chasing Speeders on the Sprain Brook'' [July 1] , is encouraging; the details are more appalling and dismaying than expected. My fear of driving approaches others' fear of flying, and it depresses me to learn how justified is that fear.

LEAD: Kyle-Beth Basson and Steven Martin Hilfer were married last evening at Temple Sinai in Roslyn, L.I., by Rabbi Aaron Petuchowski. Mrs. Hilfer is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin E. Basson of Upper Brookville, L.I. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Hilfer of Jamaica Estates, Queens.

LEAD: Robert P. DeVecchi of New York and Florence Sloan DeVecch of Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Lincoln DeVecchi to Peter Johnstone Smith, the son of Mrs. Albert Oliver Smith of Milton, Mass., and the late Mr. Smith. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: ''Herein lies the tragedy of all the age: not that men are poor - all men know something of poverty; not that men are wicked - who is good? Not that men are ignorant - what is truth? Nay, but that men know so little of men.'' - W. E. B. DuBois.
LEAD: This city's government wants the state to buy 13.9 acres of oceanfront land with an asking price of $6 million. The catch is that the state recently handed over its title to a developer.

LEAD: Frank and Deborah Popper's plan for a Buffalo Commons in the Great Plains has great romantic appeal (''The Poppers and the Plains,'' by Anne Matthews, June 24). As a lawyer and conservationist, I spent considerable time several years ago on a similar proposal for eastern Montana - the Big Open - researching the practicalities of implementing such a scheme.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Just when Iran's sickly economy seemed incapable of sustaining another blow, it was dealt a tremendous one by the earthquake in June.
LEAD: The possibility that the National Football League's Raiders might move back to Oakland from Los Angeles is inching closer to resolution.

LEAD: The Jets signed one of their No. 1 picks today when Rob Moore, the wide receiver from Syracuse taken in the supplemental draft earlier this month, agreed to terms on the eve of the opening day of training camp.
LEAD: Gary Redus hit a grand slam, the light-hitting Rafael Belliard had a three-run double and Pittsburgh turned five walks into runs to rally for an 11-6 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today.

LEAD: Robert McCune seemed uneasy as he walked up Main Street here, especially for a man who had just won $25,350 in a Nebraska Supreme Court case that may give him and his hometown of 780 people a place in legal history.

LEAD: Dr. Howard S. Grob, a professor of biology at Adelphi University whose laboratory work helped clear the way for in vitro fertilization, died on Friday on a research trip to Phoenix. He was 58 years old and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

LEAD: The Central Intelligence Agency, which has prided itself on its knowledge of the inner workings of the Soviet Union, has come under criticism from some lawmakers and economists who say it greatly overestimated the strength of the Soviet economy.

LEAD: The city's second-largest sewage treatment plant shut down for several hours yesterday after an electrical fire, spewing untreated waste into the East, Harlem and Hudson Rivers, a city environmental-protection official said.

LEAD: George Steinbrenner will be largely powerless to appeal whatever sanctions may be meted to him by the baseball commissioner, Fay Vincent, unless, authorities on sports law say, he can prove that Vincent acted either capriciously or maliciously.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY Congress is considering ways to assess foreign ownership and its impact on the economy, mirroring concern about the rise in foreign investment in the United States in the last decade. [D1.] American companies are rushing to issue new shares with an eagerness not seen since before the October 1987 stock market crash.

LEAD: Owen D. Cox, a retired Federal district judge who in the 1970's ordered the busing of thousands of Corpus Christi students in the interest of desegregation, died Saturday at a nursing home here. He was 80 years old.

LEAD: Sixteen years afterward, the year 1974 flickers like a dim dot in a vast night sky. At this time in 1974, President Richard M. Nixon had yet to resign. ''Jaws'' was a runaway best seller for beach reading. Streaking was a fad. ''The Sting'' had won the Oscar for Best Picture.

LEAD: Chile has barred Erich Honecker, the deposed East German Communist leader, from entering the country after West Germany said that allowing him in would be an ''especially unfriendly occurrence,'' the newspaper Welt am Sonntag said today.

LEAD: The Tandy Corporation will introduce a home computer today that the company said would be less expensive than the model introduced by the International Business Machines Corporation last month. I.B.M. introduced the PCjr in late 1983, but withdrew the product in 1985 after disappointing sales. Tandy, which was one of the first personal computer makers, has continued to sell to the home market and is now considered the leading maker of home computers by market researchers.

The Tesco supermarket chain began selling Wholemeal Highgrove yesterday for $1.07 a loaf in its stores in southeastern England.

LEAD: In a case that is being watched closely by aviation experts and safety groups, three former Northwest Airlines pilots accused of flying a commercial jet while under the influence of alcohol go on trial in Federal District Court in Minneapolis today. LEAD: A half-brother to Summer Squall, the 1990 Preakness Stakes winner, brought a top price of $2.9 million yesterday at the Keeneland July Selected Yearling Sale at Lexington, Ky. The bay colt by Seattle Slew out of Weekend Surprise was purchased by BBA (Ireland) for Tomonori Tsurumaki of Japan. The colt, consigned by Lane's End Farm near Versailles, will stay in America to race, said Noel O'Callaghan, a BBA director who signed for the colt.

LEAD: Members of the Actors' Equity Association failed to decide yesterday whether the union would permit the English actor Jonathan Pryce to repeat his performance as a Eurasian when the hit musical ''Miss Saigon'' moves to Broadway from London.
LEAD: The trial of Peter MacDonald, the suspended chairman of the Navajo Tribe, was delayed again today after the Navajo Supreme Court ordered a review of his legal representation.

LEAD: The Unisys Corporation will offer new versions of its A Series and 1100/ 2200 mainframe systems. The new A16 model is currently available and priced between $1.75 million and $5.9 million depending on configuration, the company said. The new A12 model is also available and priced between $495,000 and $2.4 million.

LEAD: The machinery is deafening, the floors are messy, and the pungent air is thick with flies on a summer day inside the Plastics Again polystyrene recycling plant here, an hour's drive west of Boston. But the scene is enough to delight a plastic manufacturer.

LEAD: Charles Schwab & Company, the discount brokerage firm, said on Monday that a hearing panel of the New York Stock Exchange had approved a settlement resolving a review of unauthorized trading of customer shares by Schwab's reorganization department. LEAD: Today is the first anniversary of the death of 45-year-old Steve Rubell, that loquacious scamp who made his mark by being in the right place at the right time in a town where that is often all that matters.
LEAD: In the marketplace found in the slim newspaper columns of classified advertising, a 43-year-old man has become as hot a ticket as New Kids on the Block.
LEAD: A company that distributed wristwatches decorated with a logo resembling that of Batman has been ordered to pay more than $40,000 to the caped crusader's copyright owners.

LEAD: Harold (Red) Grange, the legendary Galloping Ghost of football, has been diagnosed as having Parkinson's disease but should be returning to his home in Lake Wales, Fla., after a few more weeks at an extended-care center, according to his wife. ''He won't be going dancing,'' said Muggs Grange, his wife of more than 49 years.

LEAD: In his seven years as an Associate Justice of the New Hampshire Supreme Court, David H. Souter wrote opinions in a wide variety of legal cases. Two months ago, he became a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston, but has not yet written any opinions for that court.

LEAD: Facing mounting pressure to conclude a budget deal before Congress adjourns for its August recess, President Bush and top Congressional leaders agreed today to cool their political oratory in hopes of spurring stalled negotiations on a $50 billion deficit-cutting package.
LEAD: Using a metal strainer, a pipe and a vat of salty water to simulate a human body, an independent expert has tested Florida's electric chair and declared that it works effectively.

LEAD: Earnings for the Martin Marietta Corporation, a leading aerospace and military contractor, increased in the second quarter because of the success of several space programs, the company said today.

LEAD: CHICKEN livers are not only among the most inexpensive meats, but they also are one of the most versatile. They can be used in stuffings, sauces, pates, terrines, in rice dishes and in scores of main courses. One of my favorite preparations calls for simply dipping the livers in seasoned flour and then cooking them in oil until crisp and browned.
LEAD: American Airlines Inc. today withdrew plans to add surcharges of $1 to $4 at five airports that the carrier said were charging ''exorbitant and intolerable'' landing fees.

LEAD: The Interpublic Group of Companies said second-quarter earnings rose 9 percent, to $30.9 million, or 92 cents a share, from $28.3 million, or 84 cents a share, in the period last year. Revenues rose 8 percent, to $342.4 million.
LEAD: Dave Winfield and his relationship with Howard Spira will not be the subject of any further inquiry after Commissioner Fay Vincent wraps up his investigation of George Steinbrenner.

LEAD: I.B.M. will not broadcast television advertisements during the P.G.A. Championship next month because of racial exclusion at Shoal Creek Country Club, site of the golf tournament. A spokeswoman, Gina Chew-Holman, said today that when the corporation learned of the racial issue, ''we decided it would not be an appropriate vehicle for our advertising.

LEAD: WHEN McDonald's, Burger King and Wendy's announced in recent days that they would fry their potatoes in all vegetable oil instead of a mixture of beef tallow and vegetable oil, it was just one more sign that fast-food chains have learned a lesson: to survive in today's health-conscious society, they must provide more nutritious alternatives to double cheeseburgers and fried chicken.
LEAD: The Thruway Authority announced today that it had begun a $4.6 million two-year study of erosion under its bridges.

LEAD: A Los Angeles business professor and a Soviet economist have announced that they are introducing the nuts and bolts of capitalism to the inhabitants of the remote Russian island of Sakhalin, north of Japan, in one of the latest free-market experiments in the Soviet Union.

LEAD: In the 1970's, during the heyday of the Joint Stock Company and other politically inclined theatrical organizations, English playwrights like Caryl Churchill, David Hare and Howard Brenton often reacted immediately to public issues. Faced with urgent political questions, the writers reached for their quill cudgels.

LEAD: One year after suffering a torn muscle behind the right shoulder, Dwight Gooden acknowledged tonight that he had been pitching for the last couple of weeks with some stiffness behind the shoulder.

LEAD: In a defiant challenge to the authority of the Financial Accounting Standards Board to set accounting policy, the leading professional group of accountants has alerted the board that it plans to consult the board's experts less often and that it may issue its own rules, even when the board staunchly opposes them.

LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts continued to slide during the week that ended yesterday. It was the eighth consecutive week of decline, and reflected a flight to quality caused in large part by a weak stock market.

LEAD: Facing opposition from Ethiopian rebels, the United Nations abandoned efforts today to reopen an Ethiopian port through which it hoped to ferry food for about 4 million people at risk of starvation.

LEAD: The Navy has developed such skill in recovering objects lost on the ocean floor that this week it embarked on a remarkably difficult search. It is seeking a cargo door that blew off a United Airlines jumbo jet en route from Honolulu to New Zealand.
LEAD: Three men were injured, one seriously, in an explosion and fire last night at the Marian Motel in Seaside Heights, N.J., the police said.

LEAD: LAYING bricks with plain sand instead of mortar is an easy way to pave areas like patios, walks and driveways. Bricks are arranged close together on a bed of packed sand surrounded by a border. After they are in place, more sand is swept into the crevices between them to prevent shifting.

The Indian, Timothy Jacobs, received a six-year prison sentence in June 1989 after pleading guilty to second-degree kidnapping. Mr. Jacobs and another Indian, Eddie Hatcher, took over the The Robesonian on Feb.

LEAD: Feeling the effects of a changing computer industry, the Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday reported the first quarterly loss in its 25-year history as a public company and declared a $400 million charge for retraining staff, closing operations and reducing total employment by 5,000 to 6,000.
LEAD: * Mary Conrad, Bill Daily, Steve Seyferth and Martin Sherrod have been promoted to senior vice president in the account management department of Bayer Bess Vanderwarker, Chicago.

LEAD: Yutaka Hasegawa, who has moved several times in the last six years, hopes the new job he began yesterday as the senior executive officer of the Mitsubishi Bank's North American headquarters and general manager of the New York branch will lead to a bit of permanence.
LEAD: * Caesars World Inc., Los Angeles, said it had started its $22-a-share tender offer for the 2,175,945 outstandinng shares of Caesars New Jersey Inc. common stock it does not own.

LEAD: ''If there is a smudge on the Seal of the United States Senate, or on the Star of the North, as we like to call our state, I will work my hardest to polish both back to brightness.'' - Senator Dave Durenberger of Minnesota. [A1:3.]

LEAD: A SCRATCHED Art Nouveau Lalique plaque with a nymph face is in need of repair and a chipped chandelier prism needs grinding. Then there is the Baccarat lion with a severed tail, the cordial glass with a broken stem and the Steuben eagle with a broken wing. ''After it is polished, it will look like it was never damaged,'' said Augustine Jochec (pronounced JOE-check).
LEAD: Nelson Mandela suggested today that the African National Congress might consider compromises to achieve progress in formal negotiations with the Government on the country's future.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Morgan Grenfell Group P.L.C. of London said yesterday that it was joining Eric Gleacher, former head of mergers and acquisitions at Morgan Stanley & Company, to form a firm to be called Gleacher Morgan Grenfell Inc. that will do merger and acquisition work in the United States and abroad.

LEAD: A teen-ager who had danced on Broadway was killed in the Bronx early Tuesday morning when a sniper with a machine gun fired on his car and riddled it with bullets. The shots came from an apartment-building roof where young drug-gang members regularly shoot weapons for thrills, the police said yesterday.
LEAD: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation offered $150 million in senior 20-year notes through an underwriting syndicate led by the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.

LEAD: Gov. Buddy Roemer vetoed a bill today that would have required warning stickers on record albums with potentially offensive lyrics. The bill was the first in the United States ordering the use of warning labels on albums.
LEAD: 40 Strong, Ward-Nasse Gallery, 178 Prince Street (Sullivan Street); (212) 925-6951.
LEAD: A newly repaired unmanned rocket blasted into space today with a satellite that will use chemicals to transform the lines of Earth's invisible magnetic field into brilliant bursts of color.

LEAD: House Sustains Veto Of Family Leave Bill The House failed by 53 votes to override President Bush's veto of a bill that would have required employers to grant workers as much as three months of unpaid leave for births, adoptions or family emergencies.

LEAD: Airbus Industrie will pay Rohr Industries $1 billion to supply 800 jets with engine nacelle systems, the aerodynamic structures that surround jet engines. In 1984, Rohr made a similar deal with the European consortium, involving 200 Airbus A320's.

LEAD: JOHN DENVER, the singer and environmentalist, is joining forces with representatives of the Amway Corporation, the United Nations Environment Programs and the space agency to establish the Aspen Institute on Global Change. The institute will seek to enlist leading scientists to exchange ideas at summer seminars in Aspen, Colo.

LEAD: An armed robber was shot to death early Tuesday after he burst into a motel room unaware that seven armed officers were inside setting up a drug trap, the authorities said. The officers were in adjoining rooms when Darnell Madison, 37 years old, brandishing a revolver, and Jacqueline Lynn Simmons, 21, entered.

LEAD: AFTER six years of financial turmoil, including two close calls with filing for bankruptcy, a drastically smaller Western Union Corporation may be on the verge of emerging as a company that can meet its obligations.

LEAD: In Maina Gielgud's production of ''Giselle'' for the Australian Ballet, the wilis (ghosts of jilted maidens) are seen for the first time as shrouded white figures, faces covered by huge bridal veils. They rise up from a horizon of mist, not from the usual stage wings, and surge toward the audience.
LEAD: Lie to Me By David Martin 269 pages. Random House. $18.95. Nemesis By Rosamond Smith 276 pages. A William Abrahams Book/ E. P. Dutton. $18.95.
LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc., in a direct challenge to personal computer manufacturers, announced today that it would sell its engineering work stations through computer retailers.
LEAD: The dinner menu, once again, was to be United States Department of Agriculture canned pork, canned corn and rice at a homeless shelter here for 50 single men and women with children.

LEAD: It costs $5,000 to restore one horse on the antique carousel in Prospect Park and HILDY SIMMONS and ANITA NAGER are celebrating their 40th birthdays. Those numbers add up to a party tonight at the Prospect Park Picnic House, where Ms. Nager, the grants administrator for the Fund for the City of New York, and Ms.
LEAD: To The Home Section:
LEAD: Yields on tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report continued to decline in the week ended yesterday. The declines, however, were not significant.

LEAD: Buoyed by strong initial sales of its new Windows 3.0 product, the Microsoft Corporation today reported a 76.2 percent rise in net income for its fourth fiscal quarter, on a 53 percent gain in revenue. The Redmond, Wash., company also became the first personal computer software company to exceed $1 billion in annual revenues.

LEAD: Donald C. Carter, the brash confidant to a generation of takeover artists, was sentenced yesterday to 16 months to four years in state prison. In March he pleaded guilty to one count of larceny and one count of tax fraud.
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would close a Canadian plant and consolidate all of its Jeep production at its Toledo, Ohio, complex.

LEAD: In an effort to raise badly needly foreign currency for its beleaguered economy, the Soviet Union has agreed to sell its uncut diamonds through the international diamond cartel controlled by De Beers of South Africa.

LEAD: Dull Counter Top Q.The finish on the plastic counter top in my kitchen is practically gone. Is it possible to paint this plastic, and if so, what preparation is needed and what kind of paint should I use? A.You can paint the counter top, but I'm not sure it would be a good idea. You risk scratching the paint when you cut or prepare food, and that could mean toxic particles mixed in with the food.

LEAD: The House of Representatives today failed by 53 votes to override President Bush's veto of a bill requiring employers to grant workers time off without pay for births, adoptions or emergencies in the family.

LEAD: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the Electronic Data Systems Corporation posted solid second-quarter earnings gains, but profits slipped 21.3 percent at the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation, which includes Hughes Aircraft and Delco Electronics.

LEAD: Charles Shackleford, a center-forward with the Nets who appears to have been shut out of playing time with the drafting of Derrick Coleman from Syracuse and the return of Roy Hinson from the injury list, will spend next season with S.C. Juventus of Caserta in the Italian League, Shackleford's agent confirmed yesterday.
LEAD: What is the one thing everybody wants to know about Judge David Souter of Weare, N.H.?

LEAD: A 61-year-old livery-cab driver was shot in the head and killed in a robbery in the Bronx early yesterday, the police said. He was the 19th livery-cab driver and 20th cabdriver of any kind killed in New York City so far this year. The driver, George Fitzgerald, who worked for the Bessie Cab Company, was shot once in the head in front of 1155 Cromwell Avenue in the Highbridge section at 1:45 A.M.

LEAD: In a starkly decorated house on Long Island, a collection of china teapots shaped like English cottages seems out of place, a little pool of charm. The modernist who collects them (with some embarrassment) cannot fathom her passion for them. But Grant McCracken can.
LEAD: Ammirati & Puris, the agency whose ads for BMW's ''Ultimate Driving Machine,'' Club Med and Waterford crystal helped establish the 1980's as the ''Me Decade,'' is doing an about-face.
LEAD: A new study suggests that contrary to popular belief, menopause does not cause stress or depression in most healthy women, and it may even improve mental health for some.

LEAD: Carl Lewis extended one of the most remarkable streaks in track and field history tonight, winning the men's long-jump competition at the Goodwill Games for his 64th consecutive victory in the event.

LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. is seeking an agreement with Outbound Systems Inc., a small Colorado computer company, that would allow Apple's key chips to be used in Outbound's machines, according to industry officials.
LEAD: A former Passaic Housing Authority official admitted today that he lied to Congress during a Federal investigation of mismanagement in the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

LEAD: TENNIS 4 Seeded Players Eliminated Brad Gilbert, seeded second at the Player's Limited International in Toronto, was upset yesterday, 7-5, 4-6, 6-2, by 65th-ranked Todd Witsken in the second round of play. The tournament lost three other seeded players yesterday: Derrick Rostagno beat Jean Fleurian, Jakob Hlasek beat Michael Korda, and Jim Grabb retired in the first set against Jimmy

LEAD: All he has to do to attract attention is to walk down the runway. Yves Saint Laurent did that Wednesday morning, looking fit and proud in a natty beige wool suit, after his successful couture opening at the Hotel Inter-Continental. He was followed along the route by thunderous applause and was immediately besieged by photographers.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today unanimously approved a one-year trial of a New York Stock Exchange rule that would curtail a type of computerized trading on days when the stock market swings widely up or down.
LEAD: When right-wing whites tried to blow up the newspaper office of Vrye Weekblad early this month, they paid the small Afrikaans-language weekly a sincere if terrifying compliment.

LEAD: The people had come for a party, and Nolan Ryan was prepared to be the honored guest. He had talked about earning his 300th major league victory in style, of hoping to pitch a complete game if his recent back trouble did not persist. He spoke of his hope for his best game of the year. Instead, Ryan was left with his worst.
LEAD: Bob Engel, the suspended National League umpire, pleaded no contest today to stealing baseball cards, then announced he was retiring from baseball.

LEAD: The Conair Corporation, a marketer of personal products and consumer appliances based in Edison, N.J., announced yesterday that it had purchased the Faberge Salon division of Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. for an undisclosed price. Chesebrough-Pond's, a maker of personal products, is based in Greenwich, Conn.

LEAD: A 45-YEAR-OLD woman, noticing that her mother seemed depressed, asked her if the trouble was sexual problems. When her mother admitted to the daughter that that was the case, the daughter referred her to places where her parents might get help. And she gave her mother specific suggestions on how to make herself more sexually attractive.

LEAD: Douglas E. Ebert, who left the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in the spring after 22 years, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Miami-based Southeast Bank N.A. and is scheduled to become the bank's next chief executive.
LEAD: Vapors of a cleaning solvent leaking from equipment used to mix chemicals led to the deadly explosions and fire that rocked a chemical plant last week, a fire investigator says.

LEAD: A North Carolinian has passed the halfway mark in an attempt to become the first blind man to walk the 2,143-mile Appalachian Trail. Since he left Georgia on March 9, Bill Irwin has hiked more than 1,200 miles over some of the roughest terrain in the East. The 49-year-old hiker, who is accompanated by his guide dog Orient, hopes to reach Mount Katahdin in Maine, the northern end of the trail, by October.
LEAD: The Coast Guard today suspended the captain's license of Joseph Hazelwood for nine months for his actions as the skipper of the Exxon Valdez when she ran aground off Alaska in March 1989.
LEAD: Despite his self-confidence and his apparent lead in public opinion polls, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo arguably cannot afford to debate his Republican opponent, Pierre A. Rinfret.
LEAD: Pat Leahy took a good bit of good-natured kidding about his age yesterday after the Jets' new head coach, Bruce Coslet, was asked to evaluate the performance of the rookies in training camp.

LEAD: The Coast Guard today suspended the captain's license of Joseph Hazelwood for nine months for his actions as the skipper of the Exxon Valdez when she ran aground off Alaska in March 1989.
LEAD: Two defense witnesses in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s trial on drug and perjury charges today called into question earlier testimony that Mr. Barry used drugs on a 1986 cruise off St. Thomas.
LEAD: Scientists have devised an experimental treatment that dramatically stops scarring from a kidney disease in animals and holds promise for preventing the same problem in humans.

LEAD: EVEN at first sight, it seemed clear that there must be a story behind the huge, handsome, round table and the graceful mismatched chairs that surround it. ''It was made for a sea captain's family in Biddeford, Me., in 1820,'' said Morgan Rank, an antiques dealer in East Hampton, L.I., whose shop is dominated by the 7-feet-8-inch diameter table.

LEAD: A record store owner who refused to stop selling a 2 Live Crew album pleaded not guilty Tuesday to a charge of promoting obscene material. David Risher, owner of Hog Wild Records and Tapes, was released on a personal recognizance bond after a hearing before Judge Tony Jimenez 3d of Bexar County Court.

LEAD: A decade into death, Vladimir Vysotsky's bardic voice was heard at his graveside today, carrying in throaty scraps from the portable tape recorders of some of the tens of thousands of devotees who trooped past to honor his continuing lyrical power over the nation.
LEAD: A homeless woman involved in a lovers' quarrel set fire to a shack under the West Side Highway yesterday morning, setting off a blaze that reduced a shantytown to rubble, fire officials said.

LEAD: EXECUTIVES of indebted companies and battered investors in high-yield ''junk bonds'' may push companies close to the brink as they battle over their competing interests. A piece of the troubled empire of Alan Bond, the Australian entrepreneur, now appears headed for liquidation.

LEAD: Lincoln Center's plan to program every one of Mozart's 626 opus numbers next season to commemorate the 200th anniversary of his death is both noble and dangerously overweening. If anything could make the miracle of Mozart into humdrum, it would be this kind of gather-all, which might appeal more to the stamp collector and statistician than to the music listener.

LEAD: In spite of attempts to seal off leaks, hydrogen fuel seeped from the space shuttle Atlantis in tests today, and the craft will be removed from its Florida launching pad for more extensive repairs, space agency officials said.

LEAD: The Justice Department is investigating charges that the Federal Bureau of Investigation's top agent for South Carolina avoided a drunken-driving arrest with the help of the state's chief highway patrolman.
