LEAD: Gerald Hedley, described by the National Gallery here as one of the world's leading experts in art restoration, died on Saturday in a mountaineering accident in the French Alps. He was 41 years old.
LEAD: The Anheuser-Busch Companies today reported record profits and sales for the second quarter as new brands aided growth at the world's largest brewer.

LEAD: Christian Brando, 32-year-old son of the actor Marlon Brando, has been ordered to stand trial for murder in the fatal shooting of his half-sister's boyfriend and is being held on unusually high bail of $10 million.

LEAD: Judge David H. Souter, President Bush's choice for the Supreme Court, visited the Senate's Democratic and Republican leaders today in a relaxed atmosphere that reflected the absence of active opposition to his nomination so far.

LEAD: Three decades ago, when the enemy in much of rural Japan was poverty combined with brutal working conditions, this riverside farming town became a symbol of self-improvement by encouraging the local farmers to break their dependence on rice and experiment with cash crops, principally plums and chestnuts.

LEAD: O. Gene Gabbard, chairman and chief executive of Telecom USA, will become executive vice president and chief financial officer of the MCI Communications Corporation after the completion of MCI's acquisition of Telecom, MCI said yesterday. Mr. Gabbard, 50 years old, has led Telecom USA, based in Atlanta, since its formation in 1988 through the merger of his former company, SouthernNet, and the Teleconnect Company.

LEAD: Warning of a looming ''disaster'' as the nation's bumper farm crop goes unharvested, Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian republic, sought today to offer an incentive coupon plan to channel scarce consumer goods to workers who help bring in the crops.

LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation said today that its net income rose 24.3 percent in the second quarter, to $104.3 million, or $1.18 a share, from $83.9 million, or 98 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago.
LEAD: The new advertising campaign for No Excuses jeans, starring Marla Maples, is unlikely to appear on any of the three major television networks, having run afoul of their standards.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: An article last Friday about Pennsylvania companies' rejection of the state's takeover protection misidentified the nation's largest pension fund.

LEAD: Cities and towns across the New York metropolitan region are reducing services, sometimes drastically, under pressure from the slowing economy, declining state aid and a populace tired of ever-rising property taxes.

LEAD: As some of the big names got off to poor starts, Chris Johnson, a nonwinner since 1987, shot a four-under-par 67 today and took a two-stroke lead in the richest event on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, the $1 million Mazda L.P.G.A. Classic.

LEAD: President F. W. de Klerk met with Nelson Mandela tonight for what the authorities said were urgent talks on police assertions that members of the African National Congress and South African Communist Party had prepared a plot to overthrow the Government.

LEAD: The CSX Corporation, a Richmond transportation holding company, offered $250 million worth of 10-year notes yesterday through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation. The 9 1/2 percent notes, which are noncallable for life, mature on Aug. 1, 2000. They were priced at 99.62 to yield 9.56 percent, 1.08 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes.

LEAD: According to the standards by which deranged, joy-riding killers are measured, Georgina Grayson and Ricky Allen, an English showgirl and an American G.I. who teamed up in London in 1944, weren't much. Their spree took the life of only one victim, a taxi driver who gave the so-called cleft-chin murder its nickname.
LEAD: The Walt Disney Company today reported record sales and profits for the third quarter based on the continued strong performance of all of its three operating segments.
LEAD: The Quedlinburg treasures will be stored at the Dallas Museum of Art but not displayed there until a lawsuit contesting their ownership is settled, the museum announced yesterday.

LEAD: The General Electric Company, which was convicted in a jury trial in February of overcharging the Army for a battlefield computer system, agreed yesterday to pay one of the largest fines ever assessed for defrauding the Defense Department.
LEAD: Brent Mydland, the keyboardist for the rock band Grateful Dead since 1979, died yesterday at his home in Lafayette, Calif. He was 37 years old.
LEAD: WHEN Randy Weston and Max Roach join forces on Sunday afternoon for a concert in the Brooklyn Museum's sculpture garden, they will be celebrating their roots in more ways than one.

LEAD: Having taken more than a decade to get virtually nowhere - stirring terrific controversy in the process - a plan to build an enormous marketplace in the vaulted chambers beneath the Queensboro Bridge now appears close to collapse.

LEAD: Three administrative law judges of the New York Public Service Commission ruled yesterday to allow the release of some of the documents that the New York Telephone Company had sought to label as trade secrets in its request for a $1.4 billion rate increase.

LEAD: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation agreed to buy Knoll International Inc., a privately held maker of office furniture based in New York that has about 2,800 employees. The acquisition would make Westinghouse one of the three largest makers of office furniture. No terms were announced.

LEAD: The current baseball commissioner, a former commissioner, a district attorney, a hefty assortment of lawyers and investigators, Howard Cosell and a Bronx letter carrier were among 48 people whose names George Steinbrenner's attorneys presented as possible witnesses in his hearing before Fay Vincent.

LEAD: EXPULSION 1861: John B. Clark, Democrat of Missouri, for support of rebellion. 1861: Henry C. Burnett, Democrat of Kentucky, for support of rebellion. 1861: John W. Reid, Democrat of Missouri, for support of rebellion. 1861: Michael (Ozzie) Myers, Democrat of Pennsylvania, for corruption in connection with the ''Abscam'' scandal.

LEAD: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries moved closer today to an agreement that would set a ceiling on its 13 members' production of 22.5 million barrels a day and raise oil prices to at least $20 a barrel.
LEAD: The Norwest Corporation, a Minneapolis-based banking company, said it had agreed to acquire United Banks of Colorado Inc., Denver, for about $440 million.

LEAD: A 3-year-old Brooklyn boy was killed yesterday when gunmen fired more than 18 rounds from semiautomatic pistols through a steel-covered door as he slept in his family's apartment. He was the third child killed in New York City this week by bullets apparently intended for someone else.
LEAD: FRIDAY LITERATURE SPOKEN HERE

LEAD: * American Express Bank Ltd., New York, a unit of American Express Co., appointed Suzan T. Picariello senior vice president and head of the Latin American and Caribbean region of the firm's consumer financial services group.
LEAD: rrIt has been widely reported that Soviet officials were not amused when a hockey player jumped to the Detroit Red Wings while he was supposed to be playing in the Goodwill Games this week.

LEAD: A House committee voted today to grant the ''junk bond'' financier Michael R. Milken and Ivan F. Boesky, the convicted stock speculator, immunity from additional prosecution in order to get them to testify before Congress.

LEAD: Federal health officials yesterday reported evidence suggesting that for the first time a health professional with AIDS had transmitted the virus that causes the disease to a patient during a medical procedure.

LEAD: Jerry Zaks, the Tony Award-winning director, has resigned as director in residence at the Lincoln Center Theater to accept a salaried, untitled position with Jujamcyn Theaters to develop plays and musicals for the company's five Broadway theaters.

LEAD: The New York City municipal hospital system announced yesterday that it would encourage all of its adult patients to be tested for the AIDS virus, a shift aimed at helping tens of thousands of people who need treatment.

LEAD: Samuel H. Armacost, who ran the BankAmerica Corporation as it fell into crisis several years ago, has joined Weiss Peck & Greer, an investment firm involved in management buyouts and venture capital.
LEAD: In an afternoon free of upsets at the Player's Limited International, John McEnroe, Michael Chang, Tim Mayotte and Jay Berger advanced to the quarterfinal round today.

LEAD: The guitarist Kazuhito Yamashita is to perform his arrangements of Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition'' and Bach's Cello Suite No. 6 at 5:30 P.M. on Sunday at Caramoor, Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y. The program is also to include Toru Takemitsu's ''Folios I, II and III'' and Fernando Sor's ''Variations on a Theme by Mozart'' (Op.

LEAD: Only hours after North and South Korea signed an agreement on Thursday for a historic first meeting between their Prime Ministers, hopes for rapid progress were dimmed when negotiations over a brief opening of the border next month seemed to collapse.

LEAD: Coast Savings Financial Inc., the parent company of a Los Angeles-based savings and loan association, said today that it lost $28.7 million in the second quarter after adding to its loss reserves to reflect problems in several real estate markets. In the period a year earlier, Coast earned $5.8 million, or 41 cents a share.

LEAD: In a broad presentation of his fiscal policies if elected New York's governor, Pierre A. Rinfret says he would balance the state budget by freezing spending at its current level but would avoid sweeping cuts in state personnel and programs.

LEAD: The Boeing Company said its net income for the second quarter nearly doubled from a year ago because of continuing strong shipments of commercial airplanes. But the company said it continues to have problems in its military and space businesses, and it expects them to post a significant operating loss in 1990.
LEAD: A defense lawyer in the Central Park jogger case challenged the detective who handled his client's statement, accusing him of ''putting words'' in the youth's mouth.
LEAD: Short Stories in Song
LEAD: Investors are trying to determine the value of the new RJR Nabisco security that will be exchanged for some of the company's ''junk bonds.''
LEAD: Brian Washington has had a taste of the football world and a taste of the real world and right now, he thinks the football world is where he belongs. The Jets think he might be right.
LEAD: Three men were attacked early yesterday by a gang that shouted anti-homosexual slurs at them in Greenwich Village, the police said.
LEAD: The Rev. Angelo T. Acerra, Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese for the United States Military Services, died yesterday at his home in Alexandria, Va., at the age of 64.

LEAD: TENNIS U.S. Gains Federation Semifinals Zina Garrison and Gigi Fernandez broke Jana Novotna's serve in the ninth game of the second set yesterday, opening the way for the United States to score a 7-6, 6-4 doubles victory over Czechoslovakia and win their quarterfinal match of the Federation Cup by 2-1 in Norcross, Ga.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. said today that its profit dropped 29.6 percent in the second quarter and announced that it was restructuring its fertilizer business.

LEAD: Groups that favor giving workers unpaid leave to care for newborn babies and ailing relatives are preparing to lobby individual states for legislation to do what a Federal bill vetoed by President Bush would have done.

LEAD: Senator Warren Rudman of New Hampshire was asked the other day whether Judge David Souter especially admired any past members of the Supreme Court. Senator Rudman said he thought the Souter favorites were Justices Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. and John Marshall Harlan the younger.

LEAD: A committee of Times Square business and community leaders announced plans yesterday to create a special district that would provide everything from sanitation to security services for Times Square.

LEAD: Ordinarily, it might be difficult for many lawyers to get excited about the American Bar Association's annual meeting in Chicago next month, which will feature the typical round of seminars on legal issues, many boring and obscure.

LEAD: The Whirlpool Corporation said today that its second-quarter profit tumbled 26 percent despite a 4.3 percent increase in revenue. The company cited economic troubles affecting its Brazilian operations.

LEAD: Federal prosecutors have ended their investigation into Mayor David N. Dinkins's transfer of Inner City Broadcasting stock to his son without filing criminal charges, the United States Attorney in Brooklyn, Andrew J. Maloney, said yesterday.

LEAD: Two weeks ago, after a 12-year court fight, DR. ROBERT W. KEARNS won a $5.2 million verdict against the Ford Motor Company for infringement on his patents for the intermittent windshield wiper. Yesterday, the 63-year-old former engineering professor at Wayne State University, was in the Montgomery County Detention Center in Rockville, Md., for failure to honor a separation agreement with his wife, PHYLLIS KEAR
LEAD: Greg LeMond is back on his bicycle, but he's hurting after his third Tour de France victory.

LEAD: Al Paul, a member of the Columbia University athletic staff for 30 years and the senior athletic director in the Ivy League, announced yesterday that he would retire at the end of the next academic year, in June 1991.

LEAD: There have been many bill-signing ceremonies at the White House, but none quite like yesterday's. Under a hot summer sun on the South Lawn, more than 2,000 advocates for the disabled, many in wheelchairs, cheered mightily as President Bush signed a law that could bring 43 million handicapped people into society's mainstream.

LEAD: Since irony seems to be art's most important product lately, appreciating the hyper-romantic sensibility of Victorian-era British photography requires a suspension of disbelief. True, the sugary tableaux of Henry Peach Robinson and the allegorical portraits by Julia Margaret Cameron may be viewed as precursors of the overtly fabricated art photography of the 1980's.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Sheila Maria Boyd and Jerry Conner, both of Brooklyn, were married yesterday in Queens Borough Hall. Afterward, they celebrated at Cobblestone's Restaurant, a few blocks away at 117-18 Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills.

LEAD: ''Art in the Anchorage'' is a great way to beat the heat and feel it too. This seventh annual summer show of installation artworks, organized by Creative Time Inc., takes place in one of the city's greatest hidden interiors: the cavernous brick vaults of the Brooklyn Bridge's Anchorage (Brooklyn side), a space pleasantly immune to the waves of heat and humidity assaulting the

LEAD: Rehearsals are the private struggles by which public performance is made to seem effortless and trouble-free. There are those who would keep it that way. Symphonic music is theater too, they say. It employs its own artifices to bind listeners and music together; one is by hiding from the observer the intervening problems of learning and technique.

LEAD: The Mets split a doubleheader with the St. Louis Cardinals last night before 45,936 scoreboard-watching fans in Shea Stadium. But they still managed to reach a milestone when they sidestepped into a first-place tie in the National League East with the team they've been chasing all season, the Pittsburgh

LEAD: The United States Open, still looking for a more pristine alternative to its noisy, outgrown site at Flushing Meadows, is also looking for a new television contract because its $18 million agreement with CBS expires this year.

LEAD: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. and his lead defense lawyer charged today that the Federal Government had an ''assault force'' of law officers that traveled the country singling out black officials for undercover operations.

LEAD: In a speech marking the 37th anniversary of a guerrilla attack that began the Cuban revolution, President Fidel Castro bitterly criticized Spain today for the standoff involving refugees seeking asylum in its embassy here.

LEAD: Seeking to continue to pick up the kind of international experience members of the United States national team crave, Tab Ramos has signed a one-year professional contract with Figueres, a Second Division club in Spain. The announcement was made yesterday by the United States Soccer Federation.

LEAD: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge receipt of or return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

LEAD: Judge David H. Souter, President Bush's Supreme Court nominee, spent a second day on Capitol Hill today and was told by both Democratic and Republican senators to expect to answer questions about his judicial philosophy and his views on the Supreme Court's role.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A ranking United Nations official familiar with the U.N.-sponsored negotiations on Cyprus's future recently told me that, in his view, of all the world's intractable problems the Cyprus situation is one that is clearly solvable. He said that progress depended on outside pressure on Turkey, especially by the U.S., to remove its troops from the island nation, and on insuring that the Greek and Turkish Governments fully participate in any agreement on Cyprus's future political structure.

LEAD: A 25-year-old from Queens who was arrested on Wednesday in the theft of a bus for a joy ride has confessed to taking 13 of the 22 buses that have been stolen in the last year, the transit police said yesterday.

LEAD: Rock and jazz made incursions into chamber-music territory (or was it the other way around?) in ''Sonic Boom,'' Friday evening's installment of the Serious Fun series at Alice Tully Hall. The violinist Mary Rowell, the British keyboard sextet Piano Circus, the percussionist and vocalist David Moss and the Soldier String Quartet offered music that, for the most part, had a greater visceral than intellectual appeal.

LEAD: A service for Rabbi Wolfe Kelman, executive vice president of the Rabbinical Assembly for nearly 40 years, will be held at on Wednesday at 6 P.M. at the Park Avenue Synagogue at Madison Avenue and 87th Street. The participants will include Rabbis Arthur Hertzberg, professor of religion at Dartmouth College, and Alexander Schindler, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

LEAD: After reporting record earnings and revenues on Wednesday for its 15th year in business, the Microsoft Corporation cautioned today that its unusually strong profits were not likely to continue in the next fiscal year.

LEAD: CBS is having a promising run with original programming this summer. At 10 P.M. on Thursdays, the network is doing very nicely indeed with ''Northern Exposure,'' a show about a doctor from New York who moves to Alaska. And at 9:30 P.M. on Fridays, there is ''Wish You Were Here,'' the second episode of which can be seen this evening.
LEAD: The Giants' offensive backfield received a lift today when Rodney Hampton, this year's first-round draft choice, and Aaron Emanuel, the seventh-round choice, agreed to contracts.

LEAD: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, the world's second-largest tire producer, yesterday reported a second-quarter loss of $9.4 million, reflecting costs associated with belt-tightening and reorganization.

LEAD: A Sept. 5 trial date was set yesterday for the youth accused of setting fire to David Opont, the 12-year-old who was seriously burned on the morning of March 7 in Brooklyn. The name of the suspect, who was 13 at the time of the attack, has not been released because of his age. He has been held in a juvenile detention center since his arrest, the night after the attack.

LEAD: In the staid world of Japanese finance, the Orix Corporation is like a jazz musician. It can improvise across the spectrum of financial markets more freely than securities houses and insurance companies here because, as a leasing company, it operates under a separate and more liberal regulatory system.

LEAD: Nolan Ryan, in shorts and sneakers without socks, sat thoughtfully in front of his locker cubicle in the Texas Rangers' clubhouse before Wednesday night's game against the Yankees. ''Butterflies?'' someone asked him. ''Always got butterflies before I pitch,'' he said, in his easy, Texas drawl.
LEAD: An obituary on July 12 about Robert A. Roth, a New York lawyer, described his background incompletely.
LEAD: The track and field competition of the Goodwill Games ended tonight with the United States and the Soviet Union winning events in which they have long excelled.
LEAD: Two Cultures
LEAD: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column in Business Day on Wednesday misstated the price paid by the Saatchi & Saatchi Company to buy two advertising agencies in 1986.

LEAD: EACH year the outdoor sculpture season seems to have more to say about the art and life of New York City. With some artists seeking exposure, others trying to define for themselves the meanings of public art, still others trying to leave their stamp on a street or square, and with all the artists now trying to wrestle with urban dramas for which it seems no author or director exists, the outdoor sculpture season has become a way of gauging not only the state of the art world but also the state of the city.

LEAD: The Procter & Gamble Company said it had completed the purchase of the toiletries and fragrances portion of the American Cyanamid Company's Shulton Group, excluding the Pierre Cardin fragrance line. Under the agreement announced last month, Procter & Gamble acquired Shulton's Old Spice and Santa Fe men's toiletries and fragrances, and several other products.
LEAD: * Norwalk Furniture, Norwalk, Ohio, to W.B. Doner & Company.

LEAD: The indictment of Eastern Airlines on Wednesday on charges of ignoring maintenance and falsifying records could not have come at a more trying time for the carrier, industry analysts said yesterday. July is a peak travel season, and the airline has just begun an ambitious advertising campaign aimed at winning back business travelers and travel agents.
LEAD: Max Kamiel, a retired certified public accountant, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: For years, sponsors and the organizer have been selling the Goodwill Games as a major world sports event. ''Uniting the World's Best,'' says the Games' promotional slogan. After a week of competition, the promise has been largely fulfilled except in track and field.

LEAD: Robert Tammero, who has been president both of Bloomingdale's and of Abraham & Straus, the New York store divisions of Federated Department Stores, has been named president of the Plymouth Lamston Stores Corporation, which is owned by Tribeca Holding Corporation, a New York-based investment firm.
LEAD: Betty at the Ballroom

LEAD: David H. Souter, President Bush's nominee to the Supreme Court, failed a medical examination by his draft board while a student at Harvard Law School in 1966 because one leg was found to be an inch shorter than the other, a White House spokeswoman said today.

LEAD: The Bush Administration is close to agreeing to compromise legislation that would give the Securities and Exchange Commission far less than the broad new authority it had wanted to regulate stock index futures, Congressional aides said tonight.

LEAD: A Hunter College student was stabbed in the chest in the lobby of his dormitory early yesterday morning by a security guard on duty in the lobby, whom the student had complained about, the police said.
LEAD: Educators facing teacher shortages are working to mine a new source: the tens of thousands of soldiers due to be laid off as America's military forces shrink.

LEAD: Shows, Nature, Museums CENTRAL PARK ZOO, #10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday to Friday and until 8 P.M. on Tuesday and 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. on weekends; gift shop and cafeteria are open the same hours, at Fifth Avenue and 65th Street. Admission: children under 3, free; ages 3 to 12, 25 cents; over 65, 50 cents; others, $1.

LEAD: Scott Burrell, who is attempting careers in both pro baseball and college basketball, is happy with his debut as a minor league pitcher with the St. Catharines (Ontario) Blue Jays of the Class A New York-Penn League Wednesaday night.

LEAD: The road winds through green, heavily wooded hills and into a clearing, on the far side of which stands the theater made famous by Ted Shawn, who in 1933 founded the Jacob's Pillow summer dance festival and school. To the left stands a large, giddily striped tent that serves as a cafe and bar. Down the road, past the old farmhouse that has been turned into offices and the cabins that serve as dormitories and dance studios, an outdoor stage may be seen through the trees.

LEAD: * Amoco Chemical Co., Chicago, a petroleum and chemical company and a unit of Amoco Corp., said it would spend $200 million to expand olefins production at its Chocolate Bayou plant near Alvin, Tex.
LEAD: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that warning labels on cigarette packs and advertisements do not protect manufacturers against damage claims filed by smokers or their relatives.

LEAD: The cable television industry moved closer to some re-regulation yesterday with the endorsement by a House panel of a bill to limit rates for cable service and the release of a Federal Communications Commission report recommending that some cable program producers that also own cable systems be required to sell their products to rivals.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a brief article on the Media Business page on Wednesday about the Interpublic Group of Companies misstated the revenue effect of its exchange of an interest in Lowe Marschalk for more ownership of the Lowe Group. Since its completion in July last year, the transaction has reduced domestic revenue; it did not increase 1989 second-quarter earnings.

LEAD: Although 24-year-old Adrienne Shelly and 29-year-old Robert Burke are making their screen debuts in Hal Hartley's film ''The Unbelievable Truth,'' both actors seem to have known their characters inside out before even reading the script.
LEAD: His Story, Her Story
LEAD: One top-ranked team was ousted here Wednesday night in the Spingold Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, and another barely survived.

LEAD: New Yorkers have become justifiably cynical about restaurants owned by celebrities. Over the years many flimsy places have opened to much fanfare and briefly attracted voyeur diners, only to disappear like second-rate summer movies. TriBeCa Grill, the ''Ten Commandments'' of movie-star restaurants, has much more going for it than just a stellar marquee.

LEAD: It took some courage for the Senate formally to denounce Senator Dave Durenberger, but not much. Senator Durenberger's ethical violations were too blatant to escape the Senate's 96-to-0 judgment. What took courage - nerve is more like it - was the Senate's willingness to render ethical judgment on anyone.
LEAD: Wilbur S. Smith, a retired international transportation designer and developer, died on Wednesday at the Providence Hospital in Columbia, S.C. He was 78 years old and lived in Columbia.
LEAD: ''There is an overall attitude out there that life is cheap.

LEAD: Exquisite fabrics, intricate workmanship and plenty of jewel embroidery, the hallmarks of couture fashions, were the real stars of the last two major fall and winter showings. Hubert de Givenchy, now part of the LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton empire that controls Christian Dior and Christian Lacroix, appropriately dedicated his collection to ''luxury and quality.
LEAD: * Laura Eshbaugh has been named vice chairman of Whittle Communications.

LEAD: The story could be called ''Saturday the Rabbi Arrived Late,'' though just how late remains in dispute. Or, if you prefer something more musical, it could be ''Get Me to the Synagogue on Time.'' It's also listed as Adler v. Frank in the Broward County Circuit.

LEAD: After an emotional and often rancorous debate, the House of Representatives voted today to reprimand Representative Barney Frank for ethical breaches involving his relationship with a male prostitute.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in sluggish trading yesterday, as dealers watched the progress of budget negotiations in Washington and waited for a preliminary report this morning on how much the economy grew in the second quarter.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The price of ''junk bonds'' backing Donald J. Trump's casinos fell yesterday on news that the developer was considering offering holders of the high-yield securities equity ownership in his casinos in exchange for a cut in interest payments.

LEAD: New York State desperately needs 3,000 nursing home beds, mostly in New York City, for AIDS patients. It has received applications from various service agencies willing to sponsor 1,700. Among the sponsors is the Catholic Archdiocese of New York, which promises to provide 400 beds, half of them almost immediately.

LEAD: The Burger King Corporation, in cooperation with the French restaurant and hotel company Elitair, announced plans to open the first two fast-food restaurants at rest stops along France's national highway. One will be near Evry, southeast of Paris, on the A-6 highway. The other, a drive-through restaurant, will be near Bordeaux on the A-10 highway.
LEAD: Stumbling along on a course that could lead to a franchise record for losses, the Yankees face a series of decisions and deadlines that seem to have created an identity crisis.
LEAD: WHICH country has the strongest economy in the world?

LEAD: A member of a Federal jury was removed by the judge from deliberations in a six-month-old money-laundering trial today after a report that the juror had telephoned members of a Colombian drug ring for more information about the case.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from an interview with Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican candidate for governor. It was conducted on Tuesday at The New York Times. Mr. Rinfret was accompanied by his campaign manager, Assemblyman John Faso of Kinderhook. Q. Can you give us a scenario how you can win against a well-financed incumbent, particularly in view of the fact that your governmental experience - I went back as far as Al Smith - and no gubernatorial candidate has as little governmental experience as you, maybe since the beginning of the century?

LEAD: Negotiators representing the Senate and the House of Representatives today completed work on a compromise bill on oil spills, and lawmakers said final action on the measure was likely before the Congress takes its August recess.

LEAD: When Filomen D'Agostino Greenberg of Coney Island first arrived as a student at New York University Law School, she found five small, cramped rooms in a single building east of Washington Square Park. The year was 1917.

LEAD: Yesterday morning, Ellen Watson, who is 75, and her good friend Viola Walker were saying how lovely it was that the Governor and the Mayor were coming to dedicate the brand new Pathmark supermarket here.

LEAD: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts announced today that its 1990 honors will go to the jazz trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie, the actress Katharine Hepburn, the opera singer Rise Stevens, the composer Jule Styne and the film director and writer Billy Wilder.

LEAD: Charlie Hayes hit a two-run homer off Neal Heaton in Philadelphia's five-run first inning tonight, and Carmelo Martinez drove in three runs as the Phillies romped past the Pittsburgh Pirates, 12-4.
LEAD: The House on Thursday left intact funds for abortions in the District of Columbia but cut money for the city's university.

LEAD: Alvin S. Felzenberg, who was asked to leave his job as senior deputy chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts on May 25 by John E. Frohnmayer, chairman of the agency, has been named executive director of the President's Commission on the Federal Appointment Process, a spokesman for the White House said today.
LEAD: Arrogance By Joanna Scott 283 pages. Linden Press/Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

LEAD: The St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble is to play Telemann's Sonata in A, Prokofiev's ''Overture on Hebrew Themes'' and the Schubert Octet (D. 803) at 9 tonight in the Spanish Courtyard at Caramoor, Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y. Tickets are $20. Information and directions: (914) 232-1252.

LEAD: A Honduran drug trafficker was found guilty today of racketeering, kidnapping and conspiracy in the abduction and killing of a Federal drug agent, Enrique Camarena Salazar, and his pilot in Mexico.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Great American Bank, a troubled savings and loan in San Diego, reported a large loss for the second quarter because of the deterioration of its portfolio of Arizona real estate.

LEAD: A magician deliberately orchestrates his audience's suspicions as a means of concealing the real tricks of his trade. Scott Turow accomplished something very similar with ''Presumed Innocent,'' his spellbinding courtroom novel in which the narrator finds himself accused of having murdered a seductive co-worker.

LEAD: South Carolina's football program escaped sanctions today as the National Collegiate Athletic Association announced it had found no serious rule violations resulting from a steroid scandal that had led to prison terms for three former assistant coaches.

LEAD: COMPANIES G.E. agreed to pay one of the largest fines ever assessed for defrauding the Defense Department. It was convicted in February of overcharging the Army for a battlefield computer system. [Page A1.] The indictment of Eastern Airlines could not have come at a more trying time for the carrier, analysts said.

LEAD: The crowd of 30,000 at the Padres-Reds doubleheader in San Diego on Wednesday night were not amused when ROSEANNE BARR, unfamiliar with the sound system, gave a shrill rendition of ''The Star-Spangled Banner.'' When she finished, boos filled the stadium, and the comedian responded by reaching for her crotch and spitting on the ground.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company yesterday reported sharply lower second-quarter profits. Both auto makers cited difficult market conditions in North America, and both were hit by economic disruption in Brazil that virtually stopped vehicle production there.

LEAD: Prentice Hall and The New York Times will offer a program to help college students and professors use current events in studying major subjects, according to a joint announcement from the companies yesterday.
LEAD: Asian Gods in Stone

LEAD: In their first formal accord after a decade of civil war marked by brutality against civilians, negotiators for the Salvadoran Government and leftist guerrillas agreed today to international verification of human rights.

LEAD: Despite waging an unusual, provocative campaign that has broken many of the rules of politics and offended some women, blacks and the elderly, John R. Silber is running more strongly than expected in the Massachusetts race for governor and could be in position to win the Democratic nomination in September.

LEAD: He's a long, tall drink of water with the finesse of a small forward, a desire to play the power position, and according to the Knicks general manager, a probable future as an intimidating center.

LEAD: The ingredients were good in Brenda Daniels's new ''Irises,'' presented last Friday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. Ms. Daniels's dream of a dancer's body is long, slender and impressively lithe, with an amusingly blank, slightly insolent face topped by a spiky punk haircut. She has assembled a group of seven witty and able female dancers who occupy the stage with a teasing boldness.

LEAD: Paul B. Fireman, whose salary and bonus of $14.6 million last year as chairman and chief executive of Reebok International made him one of the highest-paid heads of a publicly held company, has agreed to take one of the biggest pay cuts ever, the company said yesterday.

LEAD: A Verdict in Camarena Case A Honduran was found guilty of three charges, but acquitted of murder, in the death of an American drug agent, Enrique Camarena. Page A14. Family Fight in New Forum A debate over unpaid leave for workers who need to care for family members is moving to the states after the veto of a Federal bill.

LEAD: Eric Dickerson was a no-show yesterday as veterans began arriving at the Indianapolis Colts' training camp. Dickerson, who has a $1.45 million contract this year and has said he wants to be traded, had told The Indianapolis News, ''Even if I was there, my heart and soul wouldn't be in it.''

LEAD: Calling the labor dispute at The Daily News an explosive situation that could harm the regional economy, New York State's Labor Commissioner announced yesterday that he had appointed a fact-finding panel to help the two sides reach an accord on new contracts.

LEAD: ''Would you still want to be my lover if I tested positive?'' Steven is still mourning his lover, who died of AIDS, when he asks Peter this tough, chilling question about the AIDS test. ''Men in Love'' would be a much better film if Peter, an exotic Hawaiian gardener, and Steven, a pale blond from San Francisco, had not fallen in love at first sight in a scene that features extreme close-ups of their star-struck eyes.

LEAD: Presidents Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia and Richard von Weizsacker of West Germany met with President Kurt Waldheim of Austria today, further eroding efforts over the last four years to isolate Mr. Waldheim diplomatically because of his war record.

LEAD: Les Aspin, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, says he will stop supporting the B-2, the nuclear bomber designed so cleverly that to enemy radar it's the size of a bird. He no longer sees a unique and compelling mission for the plane. Sam Nunn, his Senate counterpart, warns that the B-2 could fail in the Senate, too.
LEAD: Bartholomew J. Viviano, a lawyer who had been a college football star, died on Wednesday at his home in Sea Bright, N.J. He was 79 years old.
LEAD: Baseball
LEAD: Debt
LEAD: The owners of the Starrett City housing complex in southeast Brooklyn yesterday withdrew a plan to make apartments available to Soviet Jewish emigres.
LEAD: A House subcommittee chairman accused a top Federal scientist today of improperly aiding the paper industry's campaign to loosen restrictions on dioxin pollution in water.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has acknowledged that perestroika will not work without help from foreign friends, and Western economic analysts do not disagree. But they say they believe Mr. Gorbachev is putting the cart before the horse.

LEAD: The Governments of Ethiopia and Israel said today that the flow of Ethiopian Jews to Israel had returned to normal levels after a series of recent disruptions that had stranded thousands of Ethiopians in refugee camps.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: AFTER a series of highly publicized marketing missteps Burger King may have discovered an effective tool to use in challenging rival McDonald's - children.

LEAD: National Power P.L.C., a Government-owned British electric utility that is preparing for privatization, today posted a loss of $:605 million, or $1.1 billion, for the year and said it would cut 5,000 jobs over the next five years.

LEAD: The Bush Administration and senior Congressional Republicans have agreed on a budget proposal that would limit the amount of state and local income taxes that taxpayers could deduct on their Federal returns, Congressional officials said today.

LEAD: One of three Kenyan lawyers formally released from detention on Wednesday was arrested again and charged today with publication of a seditious magazine.

LEAD: Stock prices weakened yesterday in sluggish trading, with investors continuing to show nervousness over disappointing earnings.
LEAD: A fuel truck hit a hotel in eastern Lebanon today and burst into flames, starting a fire that killed 12 people and badly burned 25 others, the police said.

LEAD: Earle Palmer Brown, an agency with headquarters in Bethesda, Md., moved closer to its goal of becoming a major national agency yesterday by signing a letter of intent to acquire the San Diego agency Franklin & Associates Advertising and Public Relations.
LEAD: Hector Torres, a fashion designer, died July 7 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The Bush Administration has started a wide-ranging review of American policy toward Iraq and will consider new economic sanctions and export controls as a result of Iraq's threats against two oil-producing neighbors on the Persian Gulf, Administration officials said today.
LEAD: The difference between the two parties may have come down to this: a can of Mace.

LEAD: Justice Thurgood M. Marshall, in remarks that were unusually candid for a member of the Supreme Court, left the clear impression in an interview broadcast last night that he thinks someone other than David H. Souter should have been nominated for a seat on the Court.

LEAD: Carol Dickey, an interior designer in New York, and Earle I. Mack, the chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, were married last evening at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. H. Bert Mack, in Jamaica Estates, Queens. Rabbis Israel Mowshowitz and Moshe Pomerantz officiated.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 513 money market mutual funds increased $1.93 billion, to $391.84 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 160 institutional funds rose $366 million, to $95.18 billion. Those of the 251 general-purpose funds rose $1.21 billion, to $135.91 billion.

LEAD: As the Senate nears a debate on revising Federal campaign financing laws, Democrats today rejected a Republican offer to place some limits on the contributions that candidates for the Senate may raise.

LEAD: A bipartisan Federal advisory panel said today that it opposed Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut Social Security payroll taxes.

LEAD: James Barker Smith, a retired resort owner, died Thursday at a nursing home in Portsmouth, N.H. He was 82 years old and lived in New Castle, N.H. His daughter-in-law, Brenda Smith, said he died of lymphoma. Mr. Smith bought Wentworth by the Sea in New Castle in 1946, when it operated only in July and August.

LEAD: The former chairman and chief executive of Farah Inc. is trying to take back control of the ailing company that his parents founded 70 years ago, one of the nation's largest makers of men's slacks and casual clothing.

LEAD: More than a year after the skipper of the Exxon Valdez, Joseph J. Hazelwood, was publicly ridiculed as a drunk, a furor has erupted over whether a laboratory mishandled his alcohol test results.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The rare rebukes of Representative Barney Frank by the House of Representatives and Senator Dave Durenberger by the Senate this week revealed as much about the behavior of the institutions as that of the two lawmakers themselves.

LEAD: For the average Muscovite, the art of surviving with assorted strange families in a communal apartment is merely surreal on a good day, making do with noisome juxtapositions. But for Tatyana Kolodzei, who shares kitchen, toilet and corridors with an alcoholic in one bedroom and a transient day laborer in the other, the art is always avant-garde.

LEAD: Another major Soviet republic, Byelorussia, approved a strongly worded declaration of sovereignty today, adding to the challenge facing the Soviet Government to accede to a vastly decentralized system.

LEAD: ESPN, the cable sports network, will televise Nolan Ryan's second attempt at his 300th victory when Ryan pitches for the Texas Rangers on Tuesday night against the Brewers in Milwaukee. The game will begin at 8:30 P.M. Eastern time.(AP)

LEAD: In a sign of budget constraints and a cold war thaw, the Defense Department has stopped the round-the-clock flights of an airborne command post that for three decades has been a symbol of America's readiness to wage nuclear war.

LEAD: An investor group led by James M. Sweeney, a health-care industry executive, said today that it has agreed to acquire McGaw Laboratories for $210 million plus what it called ''other consideration.'' LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Canada announced today that it had bought a piece of land in an effort to help end a two-week armed standoff between the police and Mohawk Indians. But a Mohawk negotiator, Mavis Etienne, called the purchase ''a drop in the bucket.'' The standoff began after the village of Oka, Quebec, tried to expand a golf course on what the Indians call ancestral land.

We aren't all blessed with Wordsworth's sense of childhood as a romantic idyll, but even hack film makers who think a malevolent orphan is raw comic material might show more imagination than they do in ''Problem Child.'' Junior is a red-haired, freckle-faced 7-year-old, a ringer for Opie on television's ''Andy Griffith Show.'' Imagine what would have happened if Andy and Aunt Bea had abandoned Opie at birth, and the unloved boy had turned into a child who writes fan letters to a famous murderer. That is the totally unfulfilled concept behind the movie. Despite his strange attachment to a killer, Junior is mischievous in the way only derivative screenwriters and directors conditioned by sit-coms could possibly find amusing. So Junior is enough to try the patience of a nun? ''Problem Child'' shows him infuriating nuns at an orphanage, sometimes by calling them penguins. No one ever said he was original. When he is adopted by a middle-class family, he sets fire to his room and tosses the cat around. This behavior never seems dangerous, and it never seems funny.

LEAD: Since emigrating from his native Guyana 21 years ago, John Grant has built a thriving residential renovation business in Brooklyn while buying up empty lots in his Boerum Hill neighborhood and dreaming of the day when he could build homes from scratch.

LEAD: It is an early February morning at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument in southern Arizona. Several campers are sitting outside tents, listening to chirping desert birds, when a rumble begins to build and the ground starts to tremble. A few seconds later, two American fighter planes, perhaps 200 feet off the desert floor, tear over the campground with an earsplitting roar.

LEAD: The nation's capital is not exactly a spiritual city, but it has its spiritual corners. It even has a small but valuable history of people close to power struggling with spiritual questions. One of them was Henry Adams, whose extraordinary monument lies off one of the least beaten paths in Washington.

LEAD: Five big Japanese banks with New York City offices have contributed $20,000 each to Neighborhood Housing Services, a nonprofit housing group, to help it assist low-income homeowners throughout the city in maintaining their properties.

LEAD: Writing about Jasper Johns, it is often irresistible to quote, yet again, the artist's famous sketchbook note: ''Take an object. Do something to it. Do something else to it.'' Johns has built an influential career on these legendary instructions to himself and they illuminate the basic tenets of his art with increasing accuracy.

LEAD: Several years ago, Borden Inc. asked a dozen or so employees to devise a smoking policy for the company's Columbus, Ohio, headquarters. The group - comprised of smokers and nonsmokers, men and women, executives and secretaries, oldtimers and newcomers - set rules that were more restrictive than the smokers wanted but also stopped short of the total ban that many nonsmokers had been pushing.
LEAD: A 71-year-old Queens man wrested a sawed-off shotgun from a 26-year-old armed robber yesterday morning and then caused the intruder to shoot himself with his own pistol, the police said.

LEAD: Amy Caroline Cox, the daughter of Bernard S. Cox of Akron, Ohio, was married last evening to David Stuart Prall, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart E. Prall of Hewlett, L.I. Cantor David Benedict officiated at the Union League Club in New York.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Rewriting the (Post)modern: (Post)colonialism / Feminism / Late Capitalism'' read the brochure advertising a conference that I attended at the University of Utah in March. The program was full of fashionable academic jargon - phrases like ''reified theory,'' ''(post)structuralist tropics'' and ''the racial subject'' - all of it standard lexical fare in the arcane world of literary criticism.

LEAD: Oh, what is so rare as a sensible building that is not too sensible, a lively building that is not too lively, a comfortable building that is not - no, wait a minute. This building is just as comfortable as it ought to be, and pleasant to look at besides. It is the new Computer Sciences Building at Princeton University, a campus that is rapidly becoming one of the nation's most ambitious architecturally, and it was designed by the New York firm of Kliment & Halsband.

LEAD: CHARLES SEARLES and Oliver Johnson are American blacks, Robergeau Duverger is from Haiti and all three are showing their work at the Blue Hill Cultural Center. Unless a 1988 exhibition by contemporary Chinese artists can be counted, this is the first show based on ethnic identity that the center has staged in its seven-year career and one hopes it will be the last.

LEAD: The engagement of Laura Anne Gussoff to Douglas Adam Brown, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald S. Brown of Richmond, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arnold M. Gussoff of Rye Brook, N.Y. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: Viewers of the new television series ''Northern Exposure'' on CBS Thursday evening could hardly miss the striking scenery and the quirky mooseburger meals depicted in the saga of a young New York doctor acclimating to a rugged Alaskan town.
LEAD: Fred Lebow leaned forward and stared at the greenish, semifrozen liquid that had been placed in a cup on the corner of his desk.

LEAD: In Room 1510 at the Drake Hotel on Park Avenue, it is readily apparent that the current renovation is much more than cosmetic. An entire chunk of floor is gone, leaving a 8-by-9-foot hole through which one can easily glimpse Room 1410.
LEAD: FADO ALEXANDRINO By Antonio Lobo Antunes. Translated by Gregory Rabassa. 497 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $24.95.

LEAD: It's hard to follow sports when you can't see the players, but now those who are visually impaired are going to get a chance to participate in one of the hallmarks of fandom, through a line of Braille sports cards.

LEAD: Underground oil spills are difficult to photograph or visualize - no beaches covered with black goo, no sticky birds. Yet even though they haven't received as much attention as the more dramatic above-ground spills, the subterranean accumulations probably pose as much of a threat to human health and are even tougher to clean up, environmentalists and government officials say.

LEAD: Updated operas - those old theatrical bodies dressed up in modern clothes - seem to come in two sizes: large and small. Handel's ''Tamerlano,'' by the Measured Breaths Theater Company at the Cooper Square Theater on East Seventh Street, measures somewhere between small and medium. Rather than dragging the director into the present with its compelling relevance, this production assumes newness as a virtue in itself and then searches for ways to justify it.

LEAD: For those who were alarmed by the shaggy hair and radical politics on college campuses in the 1960's, the traveling musical troupe Up With People was a comforting reminder that some of America's youth, at least, had interests other than insurrection.

LEAD: On May 14, as a beloved broadcaster bade farewell to San Francisco, crestfallen viewers were taped vowing that they could not cope without him. During KRON-TV's lavish 13-minute salute to Mark Thompson, the rock-concert promoter Bill Graham gratefully solicited Mr. Thompson's advice about scheduling headliners, and San Francisco Giants slugger Will Clark begged him for hitting tips.

LEAD: The Bolshoi Ballet season at the New York State Theater this month was much better than expected, not quite as excellent as hoped. To say the company has been in transition is to say nothing new, as that has been the case for the last decade.

LEAD: For the first time since heavy fighting broke out in southern Lebanon two weeks ago, pro-Iranian fundamentalists lost ground today in fierce gun battles with a rival Shiite Muslim faction, security officials said. Sixteen people were reported killed and 50 others wounded.

LEAD: The pilot of an American Airlines jet liner carrying 127 passengers was forced to take evasive action on Thursday to avoid a small plane heading into its flight path, the authorities said today.

LEAD: The children are back from camp or soon will be, trailing worn or outgrown play wear behind them. Parents are not likely to invest in summer replacements, even if they could find them at this late date. But among the back-to-school inventory are a lot of bright, lightweight transitional clothes suitable for the hot days and increasingly cooler nights of August and
LEAD: KHRUSHCHEV ON KHRUSHCHEV An Inside Account of the Man and His Era. By Sergei Khrushchev. Edited and translated by William Taubman. Illustrated. 423 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

LEAD: Craig Shergold, a 10-year-old English boy ill with a brain tumor, remarked last fall that he would like to break the world record for receiving get-well cards. Nine million Americans have responded, answering messages sent through a loose network of facsimile machines, office memorandums, neighborhood conversations and community newspaper advertisements.

Lundgaard of Kennett Square, Pa. The Rev. John L. O'Hear, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the bride's parents' home.

LEAD: Sparky Anderson, the dean of major league managers, knows a pennant race when he sees one, but he's not sure what he sees when he looks at the American League East.

LEAD: Clinton, Conn. $209,900 5 Christopher Lane 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 10-year-old gambrel colonial; slate foyer, room over garage w/skylights, wooded lot, 1 acre; taxes $2,460. Southington, Conn. $132,000 33 Whitney Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 37-year-old ranch; fireplace, new deck, new addition with family room, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,266.

LEAD: Oleg D. Kalugin may be the spy who talked too much. Mr. Kalugin, a recently retired senior officer of the K.G.B., caused a sensation in June when he told a gathering of Communist Party insurgents in Moscow that the state security police hadn't changed its ways despite all of the recent efforts to change its image.

LEAD: When John Campbell recorded his 5,000th career victory at the Meadowlands on Friday night, he became only the seventh driver in the history of the sport to reach that milestone. The 35-year-old Campbell is a native of Ailsa Craig, Ontario, with career purse earnings of $85 million, a record. The career leader in victories is Herve Filion, with more than 12,000, and he is still driving.

LEAD: Constant readers will recall that I have a couple of old Cadillacs, a red '65 convertible and a black '66 Coupe deVille, both of which I love dearly. What they won't know is that like lots of car nuts, I have been under some pressure to get the family's fleet down to sensible size.

LEAD: A new state law that takes effect on Oct. 1 has broad implications for the acquisition of open space in Connecticut. It enables communities to charge developers a fee instead of requiring them to donate parcels of land for preservation.
LEAD: University of Texas officials have derailed plans to focus a first-year English composition course on civil rights and affirmative-action court cases.
LEAD: A pipe bomb exploded today on a crowded Tel Aviv beach, killing a 17-year-old Canadian tourist and wounding 19 people, officials said.

LEAD: TO the 222 million Americans who do not golf, the line that forms before dawn at the Tamarack Golf Course in East Brunswick, N.J., may seem eerie, perhaps even cult-like. But to many of the nation's 25 million golfers, such bleary-eyed rituals are par for the course.

LEAD: The sign at the rear of the Northside Bombers Boxing Club says ''In Harmony.'' When Charles Hamm, the 52-year-old plumber who has run the place since 1978, first saw the sign, he liked the sentiment so much that he made sure the lettered poster board ended up on that wall of his storefront gym.
LEAD: When shore fishing for striped bass in the Northeast slows down, as it always does in July and August, I begin thinking of using bait rather than lure or fly to woo those fish.

LEAD: A suit charging that chemicals from a University of Kansas radioactive waste dump have leached into the well water of a home bordering the dump was filed in Federal District Court in Kansas City, Kan., last week.

LEAD: Christina Joy Baker, a writing teacher at the University of Virginia, was married yesterday in Bangor, Me., to David Franklin Kline, an English teacher at the St. Albans School in Washington. The Rev. William S. Winston and the Rev. James Curtis officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church.
LEAD: If ever there was a flower for summertime, it has to be the daylily. If ever there was a place to see them in full bloom, it is at the New York Botanical Garden.

LEAD: In the old religion game, there is a saying that the most segregated hour in America is 11 o'clock on Sunday morning.

LEAD: A LONG-AWAITED decision by county legislators over acquisition of the Jay Property in Rye may face yet another delay, political leaders indicated last week, even though two proposals offering a choice of action are now officially before them.

LEAD: Il Piccolo Teatro dell'Opera will perform Benjamin Britten's opera ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' staged by Charles Jarden and conducted by Anton Coppola, at 8 o'clock tonight in the Prospect Park Band Shell in Brooklyn (Ninth Street and Prospect Park West entrance of the park, in the Park Slope section).

LEAD: What does early music have to do with history? In theory, everything. In fact, very little. At the beginning, the movement was frankly antiquarian - a matter of reviving forgotten repertories and, with them, forgotten instruments and performing practices. Nobody objected to that, nor did most musicians even pay much attention to it.

LEAD: Nicole Diane Bachmann, a daughter of Margot Bachmann and Eric R. Bachmann, both of New York, and Dr. Thomas Newman Fromson, a son of Marjorie Fromson of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late David Fromson, plan to marry in December. Miss Bachmann, 32 years old, graduated from the Dalton School and Hamilton College and has a master's degree in special education from Columbia University.
LEAD: A prominent Kenyan human rights lawyer has called on the United States to press for democratic changes in Kenya by imposing economic sanctions similar to those in effect against South Africa.

LEAD: AN AVAILABLE MAN. By Patric Kuh. (Available Press/Ballantine, Paper, $8.95.) From the moment this first novel opens, one has the impression of having fallen into the clutches of a natural storyteller, a writer whose love object, in the end, is the city of Paris - Paris in summer, to be precise, sweltering and sinister, ravished by pleasure-hungry visitors and busloads of tourists who move through the streets ''like sharks through a sunken city.

LEAD: Jennifer Ann Marron, the daughter of Donald B. Marron and Gloria Swope Marron, both of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas R. Eldridge, a son of Ann Eldridge Choate of Schenectady, N.Y., and the late Thomas S. Eldridge. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

LEAD: September wedding plans for Dr. Alyse Bryna Katz and Jay Evan Sicklick, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Elliot Sicklick of West Hartford, Conn., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Katz of New York. Dr. Katz, a resident in rehabilitation medicine at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, graduated magna cum laude from Boston University, where she also received a medical degree.

LEAD: Metal toys made between 1860 and 1940 - in painted cast iron, lithographed tin, enameled steel and die-cast metal - are among today's most popular collectibles. They are also increasingly expensive. This year prices skyrocketed for metal cars, trucks and steam engines at two record-breaking auctions in April and June held in New Hope,

LEAD: Hero-worship is not among the afflictions common to journalists; their profession leads more often to exposing clay feet than shining up halos. But as ''Edward R. Murrow: This Reporter'' confirms, when journalists do find a hero, particularly in their own ranks, they do not stint on homage. LEAD: The World Junior Team Championships for players no older than 25 are now played in odd-numbered years. The first two, in 1987 and 1989, were played in Europe, and European teams were victorious. The American teams that competed were unable to mount a serious challenge, but matters may be different next year.

LEAD: To the Editor: I suggest installing zippers on the inside pockets of jackets as a protection against pickpockets. If possible, the wallet should be placed in a pocket lengthwise, with the opening at the top; since this is usually a tight fit, one must hold on to the jacket when taking out the wallet, which makes it very difficult for a pickpocket to get it out even without a zipper.
LEAD: When Roger Timmons heard that the State of Maine planned to ban the conversion of summer homes into year-round dwellings in certain environmentally sensitive areas, he was plenty worried.

LEAD: WHILE professional theaters await, on tenterhooks, the announcement of grants by the New Jersey State Council on the Arts, the consequences of cutbacks in general are already being felt by a number of summer theaters during the current shortened, uneven season.
LEAD: For three weeks this summer, she was the first Soviet journalist to visit the American Dance Festival, in Durham, N.C. This essay, written for The Times, was translated by Lynn Visson.
LEAD: Rebel soldiers fought to within a mile of President Samuel K. Doe's fortified mansion today and battled pockets of Government troops for control of a hill overlooking the city center.

LEAD: When the ''City of Angels'' composer Cy Coleman accepted his Tony award for best score last month, he thanked his producer, his director, his cast, his designers, the ''most awesome music group that I've ever worked with, and the best band in a Broadway pit ever.''

LEAD: Iraq, with modern armed forces numbering a million and with a leader driven by dangerous ambitions, started a war with Iran, threatens Israel and has rattled its saber against tiny Kuwait. Its President, Saddam Hussein, may not stop at threats if he can complete plans to build weapons of mass destruction.
LEAD: Trying to rebound from a slight slump in the polls and insure another landslide victory, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has already started campaigning extensively throughout the state.

LEAD: It's a good thing the Metropolitan does not have to put on an opera Sunday evenings. On this past March 4, it would have had real trouble, because most of the roster was over at Alice Tully Hall. Without even trying to look, I saw Carol Vaness, Marilyn Horne, Neil Shicoff, Aprile Millo and several others; it was about the starriest crowd I can remember sitting in.

LEAD: ''O.K., where are we?'' said Lennie Okoskin, 10 feet from the dock. As captain for an hour of a 21-foot boat with a 200-horsepower engine, Mr. Okoskin was a bit tense. A few miles from the historic Montauk Lighthouse, he was making history of his own. He was piloting a boat for the first time.

LEAD: THE GREENPEACE BOOK OF THE NUCLEAR AGE: The Hidden History, The Human Cost. By John May. (Pantheon, Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $14.95.) Coal-mine collapses and oil spills are front-page stories; the world of nuclear weapons and power plants, writes John May, exists in secrecy. ''The Greenpeace Book of the Nuclear Age'' seeks to provide a compendium of 45 years of bad news.

LEAD: By the year 2000, tourism may well be the world's biggest industry. Since the monuments travelers want to see are pretty much fixed, tourists are paying more and more for the dubious pleasure of seeing one another. For the last year, Martin Parr, a British photographer with an eye for the ordinary, has been documenting the thundering herd as homo touristus spreads across Europe.

LEAD: In the late 1800's, a wanderer nicknamed Yonkel the Mahzik (Mischief) showed up at Ellis Island wearing the dark coat of an Orthodox Jew, long sideburns and cowboy boots. An immigration official jostled him and Yonkel slugged the man and swore at him in a Russian-Texan drawl. When it was discovered that this strange cowboy was a United States citizen who had fought in the Civil War, Yonkel was readmitted into the country.

LEAD: Theodore C. Morehouse of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Mrs. Fredric J. Klink of Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kirsten Morehouse to Matthew Alden Kenney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Kenney of Searsport, Me. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley E. Issokson of Hyannis, Mass., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Karen Lee Issokson and Marc Adam Silver, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Silver of Secaucus, N.J.
LEAD: The Bush Administration opened old political wounds this week when it proposed to limit the amount of state and local income taxes that taxpayers could deduct on their Federal returns.

LEAD: It is more than three months since anyone has seen Dogu Perincek in public, and his wife says he is prepared to remain one of Turkey's best-known fugitives indefinitely.

LEAD: For three days at the end of August last year a forest fire of epic force ravaged what must be the best-known natural totem of modern art - Mont Sainte-Victoire outside Aix-en-Provence, a site made familiar the world over by Paul Cezanne. The fire destroyed three villages, as well as some 12,000 acres of woods, moors and vineyards.

LEAD: There are some people - call them naive - who honestly believe that when someone greets them with ''how are you?'' that person is truly interested in the state of their health and fortune. This, of course, is rarely the case. How a once genuine inquiry has deteriorated into a rote phrase, generally uttered without feeling, meaning or caring, is a sad commentary on life today.
LEAD: Ours is a nation of law, and Rose's arrogance ignored the law, for which he should pay the same penalty as any citizen.
LEAD: It was in the Fall of 1986 that I first saw the devil on the streets of Detroit.

LEAD: Saying they are getting little help from Gov. Jim Florio, who started it all, Democratic legislators are fighting a rear-guard grass-roots battle against a growing tax rebellion, and there are signs that some lawmakers are ready to concede ground in the face of a protest that will not go away.
LEAD: An article in The Times Magazine on Jan. 28 about Russian nationalism mistranslated a comment from Valentin Rasputin, a Russian writer.

LEAD: House 1. Family Leave: Vote to override President Bush's veto of a bill requiring employers to grant workers time off without pay for births, adoptions or emergencies in the family. Failed, with 232 votes in favor and 195 opposed (53 votes short of the two-thirds needed), July 25. 2.

LEAD: Pete Rose might not be so worried about being elected to the Hall of Fame if he were a racing driver. His chances would be better for numerical reasons alone: while major league ballplayers have to limit their aspirations to Cooperstown, racers can aim for any of six different halls of fame.

LEAD: What is it in popular culture that so exalts X? The letter is becoming so popular as to invite confusion. Nexus used to mean a connection between individuals of a group or members of a series. Now, spelled Nexxus, it refers to a brand of hair-care products; and spelled Nexis, it's the name of the Mead Data Central

LEAD: When the weather turns sticky, women can always keep cool with unfussy, basic clothing. It's a timeless, well-groomed, smooth style - in some circles, the ''Greenwich look'' - that high humidity won't wilt.

LEAD: Bishop George Carey describes his career as ''rags to purple.'' The son of a hospital porter, he grew up in public housing in London and recalls sharing his brother's shoes. Last week, Dr. Carey, a bishop for less than three years, was named as the next Archbishop of Canterbury, the spiritual head of the Church of England and 70 million Anglicans around the world.

LEAD: The community-service sentence given to Rose was not fair. Rose was banned permanently from baseball. Yet part of his tax-felony sentence will be 1,000 hours of community service teaching baseball to deprived youth. The art of teaching implies transmitting values and ethical standards to students as well as skills of play.

LEAD: Sarah Catherine Miller and Christopher Mark Haun, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Haun of Harrington Park, N.J., are planning a September wedding. The prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Scott Miller of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement.
LEAD: A man suspected in a series of aggravated sexual assaults in this resort town has been arrested, the police said today.
LEAD: Judge David H. Souter, President Bush's nominee for the Supreme Court, unknown to the nation when Mr. Bush chose him on Monday, is known now as an earnest, erudite, diligent New Hampshire man.

LEAD: Every age gets the ghostly lovers it needs. At a decisive point in the 1947 film ''The Ghost and Mrs. Muir,'' the audience finds itself hoping that Gene Tierney will break her engagement to George Sanders - she's the last to know he's a cad - and run into Rex Harrison's arms. Now, it's true that the sea captain Harrison plays is a ghost, so technically he has no arms.

LEAD: Current events evoke the past: the unbundling of the Soviet-dominated Eastern Bloc intersects with the 50th anniversaries of the spread of Nazi domination in Eastern Europe.

LEAD: Goose barnacles, bane of boatmen and certainly among the most unsightly creatures of the sea, are for all appearances inedible or, at the very least, thoroughly unappetizing. From a pointy pearly white and hard-as-rock shell, percebes, as these barnacles are called in Spain, extend into blackened leathery necks.

LEAD: Bursts of charged particles from the Sun sporadically cause huge surges of electric current through power lines on Earth, destroying transformers or tripping protective devices to take power lines and other equipment out of service and raising the possibility of widespread blackouts, utility experts say.

LEAD: Darlington, S.C., is a normally peaceful town of white-frame houses with big porches on the front and azalea bushes in the yards. But every Labor Day, about 80,000 people show up on the outskirts to observe a Southern ritual called stock-car racing. I travel to Darlington several times a year myself, though no longer on Labor Day.

LEAD: Re: '' 'These People' Are Ruining Our Lives? by Warren Goldstein (July 1): It is appropriate that Mr. Goldstein's commentary appeared four days before July 4th, which is the celebration of our forefathers' signing of the Declaration of Independence, which declared the 13 Colonies independent of the oppressive rule of England's king.

LEAD: Hoping to capitalize on the success of a retail magnet that has been attracting shoppers from across the region, a Fishkill, N.Y., development concern is planning a 20-store shopping center at the entrance to Woodbury Common, a complex of factory outlets about an hour's drive north of New York City in Orange County.

LEAD: Susan Ferraro's fine article ''The Prime of Pat Schroeder'' (July 1) reports that the nine-term Representative from Colorado is known on the Hill as the ''lone wolf'' of Congress. From the listing of her many accomplishments and her obvious dedication to family issues and cutting of military waste, it would seem that we could use several hundred more such lone wolves in Washington.

LEAD: When a wealthy businessman said in 1986 he would donate $1.5 million to Princeton University, the school, as is usual for a nonprofit organization, decided not to show the revenues on its books until it had collected the money. It is a good thing, because the donor, Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street arbitrager, was subsequently arrested on insider trading charges, putting him in no position to follow through on his pledge.

LEAD: In English-speaking regions of Canada, many spy an enticing irony in the crisis currently gripping Quebec. In the midst of the French-speaking province's renewed debate over independence, it has found itself confronted by an angry minority of its own, Mohawk Indians. Just as Quebecers have claimed to be a ''distinct society'' within Canada, so too are we, the Mohawks have proclaimed from the armed camps they have established across two highways near Montreal.

Jones is not the type to let such heady attention affect her judicial demeanor.

LEAD: It wasn't one of those monster boxing promotions with a multimillion-dollar guarantee and a network contract, so chances are you missed Larry Holmes in his last bout, an exhibition in Binghamton, N.Y., on June 23.

LEAD: Saddam Hussein emerged from last week's OPEC meeting more than ever a figure feared and respected by his Arab brethren. The Iraqi President's threats against a tiny neighbor, Kuwait, expressed many things about him: his determination to lead the Arab world in what he sees as a just cause, his penchant for intimidating those who challenge him, and his willingness to carry a bluff to the edge of a precipice.

Christopher Hollyday and Courtney Pine, two saxophonists in their 20's who have steeped themselves in the music of the mid-60's, are sharing a bill through tonight at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street.

Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

LEAD: It's Friday morning at La Guardia Airport and the shuttle business is even slower than usual. Richard F. Cozzi, wrapping up his first week as president of the Trump Shuttle, glances about anxiously, as if hunting for more passengers. A holiday that week has thinned the weekend rush; only a few people straggle into the Trumpterminal, ready to board a Trumpjet, sink into leather Trumpchairs and enjoy Trumpsnacks.

LEAD: Sentry Bank, one of Cape Cod's largest investors in real estate, has acquired through foreclosure a $20 million 18-hole championship golf course and clubhouse. It also took possession of 122 residential lots laid out around the fairways as well as 10 unoccupied condominium units and permits to build 23 more.

LEAD: The Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., is testing a new ''off-road vehicle'' - designed for Mars. ''Robby,'' as it's called, has an articulated body, a variety of sensors and stereo television cameras. The unmanned craft is designed to travel several kilometers a day. Two navigation strategies are being tested.

LEAD: THE 10th anniversary of family life education in New Jersey schools has proved to be a quiet celebration, in stark contrast to the furor with which the program was introduced. Too quiet, say its advocates, who are urging education policy makers, teachers and parents to take another look at family life programs in the state to see if they can be improved.

LEAD: After decades of eerily quiet summers under the dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, Bucharest faces a long hot summer. Tens of thousands of university students have taken to the streets to demand the release of a leader charged with inciting disorder at protests in June. Huge lines for meat and cheese stretch from bare-shelved stores onto the scorching streets while consumers grumble about hefty price increases for gasoline and bottled drinking water.

LEAD: It is chilling to think that $80 for a 96-hour work week is considered a virtual bonanza in the less-developed world - and that people are made to feel grateful for the opportunity to be thus exploited (''The Border Boom: Hope and Heartbreak,'' by Sandy Tolan, July 1). Tolan's moving article reduces the complex and impersonal laws of the global economy to their proper dimension - the human one.

LEAD: ''I've been advising members, at a more accelerated rate, about how they ought to conduct themselves. I've said, 'I don't know how many more pictures I've got to paint for you. We've got rules and we've got rules. If you want to protect yourself, keep yourself well inside the parameters.' '' - Robert H.

LEAD: Six months of growing political tension have further tarnished the faltering reputation of Kenya as an African nation with democratic inclinations and an economic strength lacking elsewhere on the continent.
LEAD: Thirty members of the Ku Klux Klan and white racist youth groups marched here this morning in front of 1,000 spectators, journalists and police officers.

LEAD: The anti-Reagan forces will have to try harder. Extremes of income and wealth are a fact of capitalism, but one that is really beside Phillips's point. The Reagan era has brought the longest economic expansion in American history. What matters is whether the vast majority of Americans benefited from the expansion.

LEAD: Lurid reports of child sex abuse, drug trafficking, pornography and political intrigue that have held Omaha enthralled for nearly two years were a ''carefully crafted hoax,'' a county grand jury in Nebraska has concluded. But two other inquiries are continuing, and the Nebraska State Senator who heads one of them has raised questions about the grand jury's conclusions.
LEAD: With all the surprise of a late-night rerun, the Soviet Union's female gymnasts outclassed the field tonight at the Goodwill Games, taking the first two places in the all-around competition.

LEAD: Caroline Ann Knight was the assistant pastor at one of Harlem's major churches for nearly seven years when she began to look around for a church of her own, a path that many men before her had taken. But Ms. Knight found that none of the big Baptist churches in Harlem were willing to put a woman in the top job.

LEAD: The invitation is to a quiet little dinner in a restaurant or someone's home. It won't be formal, but a suit seems too businesslike and pants somehow too casual. What to wear? The answer, of course, is a dress. Nothing fussy or frilly, just a simple dress in a flattering color and a comfortable fabric.
LEAD: The popularity of fajitas is rising, though it is doubtful that those who first made them would recognize their modern permutations.
