A bidding war over stolen artifacts convinces the private eye Jacob Asch that museum directors and art collectors aren't necessarily such cultured people after all. ''Mr. Lyons has hit upon a subject worthy of his detective's intelligence in this art-is-hell caper,'' Marilyn Stasio said here last year.
LEAD: Turkey breast is usually cooked in such a way that diners don't recognize what it is. Sometimes it is mistaken for chicken, but most of the time it is mistaken for veal.

LEAD: Communism may be crumbling around the world, but in South Africa it is undergoing a curious renaissance. The South African Communist Party, which President F. W. de Klerk on Feb. 2 restored to legal status after 40 years as an banned organization, is launching itself as a full-fledged political party.

LEAD: ACOUSTICAL ceiling tiles, which are made of porous wood or mineral fibers, are commonly used both as new and replacement ceiling material. Although easy to install and excellent for absorbing sound, such tiles are also soft, easily broken and often hard to clean. Damaged or stained tiles generally must be replaced.

LEAD: All three of the world's international titles in golf - the Ryder Cup for professional men, the Walker Cup for amateur men and the Curtis Cup for amateur women - are held by Europeans, but the United States took a step toward regaining the Curtis Cup today.

And The Fire Island News scored even lower.

LEAD: To the Editor: Your review of security problems in tourist cities around the world was on target in describing the activities of the ''bag hustlers'' who surround midtown transportation terminals and harass people waiting for a taxi.

LEAD: A chart last Sunday with the Mutual Funds column, about closed-end funds, misstated the closing price of General American Investors on Dec. 29, 1989. It was 18 1/8, not 8 1/8.

LEAD: COMPANIES The Power of the Pencil at Eastern For an airline to boast of correcting vital maintenance and repair problems is hardly the path to recovery. Who on Madison Avenue could craft a campaign around a message like this? But claims of ''full corrective action'' were the essence of Eastern Airlines' response to an indictment last Wednesday on 60 counts of ignoring upkeep and falsifying records - ''pencil whipping,'' as it was called.
LEAD: The United States will not have a chance for revenge against the Soviet Union in the Goodwill Games basketball tournament, but Mike Krzyzewski is not complaining.
LEAD: The University of Oregon has opened its family housing to unmarried heterosexual and homosexual couples with children, but has kept it closed to such couples without children.

LEAD: The dollar moved into new territory last week. First, it hit a two-and-a-half-year low against the German mark on Monday as the stock market plunged. Then it fell further on Friday as the report on the American gross national product for the second quarter showed a very sluggish economy, one held above water only by the build-up of inventories.

LEAD: If the maquiladora industry were to triple its Mexican workers' salary (to a breathtaking $1.65 an hour), it would mean that the average savings per worker per year would be reduced from roughly $16,000 to $13,800. Would the investors who rely on the maquiladora industry settle for that? Or is it inherent in capitalism that the affluence of some requires that others live in misery?

Dame Lydia, a 50-year-old executive director of a British-run Hong Kong conglomerate, Swire Pacific Ltd., was honored on the Queen's birthday list in June with a life peerage, an honor held by only two other Hong Kong residents, both men.

LEAD: One big obstacle to a wider adoption of computers is the keyboard. ''I had not even touched a computer before I came here, because I never learned how to type,'' confessed a man recently hired as a senior marketing executive by a large computer company. He has now learned to type - and to use a computer.

LEAD: A new group drawn from the intellectual core of the Solidarity movement held its first national meeting today, a milestone in the division of Poland's once-united anti-Communist opposition into two competing political parties.

LEAD: A man who drank from a soft drink bottle containing dissolved cocaine is in a coma today, and Federal officials are investigating for links to Colombian drug smugglers. The officials said drug traffickers often smuggle cocaine by dissolving it in liquids.

The group, which last appeared at City Center in 1986, will present the New York premiere of ''Unetsu,'' by Ushio Amagatsu, a choreographer and a member of the troupe.

LEAD: It's a long way from the Arctic to the runways of Europe. But now the parka has re-emerged as a glamorous evening cover-up. Parisian and Milanese designers seem to have become enraptured with the parka's shape and have interpreted it in the most lavish of fabrics for their fall collections. It's an amusing idea - and also one that makes sense, since these new gussied-up versions are also warm and comfortable.

Her former skipper, Joseph Hazelwood, will remain beached for a while longer. Last week, an administrative law judge for the Coast Guard suspended his captain's license for nine months for his actions when the tanker ran aground off Alaska in 1989, causing the nation's worst oil spill.

The photos of unwanted, institutionalized children in Romania are testimony to the far greater inhumanity of bringing children into the world without parents willing or able to care for them.

LEAD: James Nachtwey's photo essay on ''Romania's Lost Children'' (text by Kathleen Hunt, June 24) was striking and very sad, but I hope no one fails to see the relevance of this situation to our own in the United States. To disallow a woman's right to abortion and to limit the availability of birth control can lead to tragedy, not just for the women forced to bear children or forced to undergo illegal and unsafe abortions, but also for the unwanted children.

LEAD: Morris Smith, the new steward of the $14.3 billion Fidelity Magellan Fund, fills his small boxy office like a whirling dervish. He watches three computer screens, confers with several people and riffles through a pile of papers. Speaking at a rapidfire pace, he gives orders to the three traders who work exclusively for him.

LEAD: Face it, our century's guiding spirit has become the comic strip. The argot of POW! and ZAP! is an Esperanto available to all levels of society in all countries. What Orfeo and Euridice were to older civilizations, Mickey and Minnie are to our culture. It is difficult to sympathize with the hermetic sexual problems of Tristan and Isolde when one considers the grander issues of war, peace and political corruption confronted daily and often on Sunday, too, by Superman and Lois, Batman and Robin, Tracy and Tess.

LEAD: Snake through the crowds on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn on any Saturday, past the Sno-Kone vendors selling winter's taste in summer flavors, past the stores that sell shorts and dresses and blouses at two for $5. Pass under a hand-painted sign and into a narrow three-story building so unprepossessing it gives no hint that you've arrived at the mecca of hair.

LEAD: The idyllic Forest of Arden, the setting of the pastoral part of ''As You Like It,'' has been variously assumed to be in England or between France and Belgium. But exactly where, Shakespeare did not say. Nor did he care, according to Isaac Asimov's ''Guide to Shakespeare.'' Why not, then, transpose the play's romantic entanglements to make-believe Irish woods and set its darker aspects in a nearby timeless town, instead of the 16th-century Usurper's Courts?

LEAD: Tennis U.S. and Soviet Union in Final: The United States, behind victories from Zina Garrison and Jennifer Capriati, advanced yesterday to the final of the Federation Cup in Norcross, Ga., but the anticipated rematch of last year's final against Spain will not take place. That is because Arantxa Sanchez Vicario twisted her left ankle in her singles match, defaulted to her opponent and opened the way for the Soviet Union to win the doubles against Spain and reach today's final against the Americans.

LEAD: The School of American Ballet's commendable New Choreography workshop, which presented its fourth annual program on Thursday afternoon at the Juilliard Theater, gives fledgling choreographers the opportunity to create ballets for young dancers enrolled in the school's summer session. The project also necessarily forces the choreographers selected each year to work under the kind of conditions that are typical today - giving them just under five weeks to create the ballet, using unfamiliar dancers, though with a full production at the end.

LEAD: There is a new breed of luggage on airport conveyor belts and on the backs of budget travelers in European streets. This is the ''travel pack'' or ''soft pack,'' which converts from a suitcase with a handle into a medium-sized backpack. The crucial difference between this luggage and a rucksack or big athletic bag with webbed handles is that travel packs have frames that distribute the load on your back.

LEAD: People The nation has a population of about 1.3 million, all but 45,000 on Trinidad. Most of the people are of African or East Indian origin. The two major folk traditions are Creole, a mixture of African elements influenced by Spanish, French and English culture, and East Indian.

LEAD: The wrecked supertanker Mega Borg has begun a two-month trip to Pakistan, where it will be broken into scrap. A tugboat towed the vessel from the Gulf of Mexico on Friday afternoon, the Coast Guard said. The Mega Borg rested about 57 miles offshore since it was rocked by an explosion on June 8. Four crew members were killed and a fire raged for several days aboard the ship, which spilled 3.9 million gallons of light crude oil into the gulf.

LEAD: Long after leaving, images of Africa take root in the memory. For me, some that linger are braking for goats on a dirt road; brush fires that smell like perpetual autumn; driving through towns made up of ubiquitous landmarks - a gas station, a superette, a tearoom and a ''supermodern'' nightclub. There is also the wonder David Livingstone called ''God's Highway'' - the Zambezi River.

LEAD: Blobby light-show shapes flicker and wobble on a screen. Musicians, scruffy in blue jeans or gaudy in flower-patterned shirts, play their instruments and shamble around the stage. Onstage and off, people flail the air in hippie dances. But amid all the appearances of a festive 1960's revival, the lyrics (if any) are often grim, while the beat is likely to be pumped out by a drum machine.

Some are standing on lines, chatting. Others are leaning against tables or sitting on the floor, reading newspapers or doing crossword puzzles.

LEAD: In her 20 years in Fresh Air Fund camps, Beverly McEntarfer has lived through a hurricane, a multitude of violent storms and a cabin fire. She has had to retrieve hundreds of lost children, not to mention a few runaways. And she has endured several broken bones, a nasty bout with a campwide epidemic of food poisoning and, she estimates, no less than 10,000 mosquito bites.

LEAD: Governors at their annual meeting approved a plan today to monitor the progress of national education goals, but only after they were assured that the monitoring committee would include more governors.

LEAD: A boat designer from Noank, Conn., has created a rowing shell that can be split into three pieces so it can be carried and easily stored. Robert Champlain, the shell's inventor, said his shell took about 10 minutes to put together. Fully assembled, it is 20 feet 3 inches long. When the three parts of the hull are put one inside the other, the unit is 7 feet long and 23 inches wide.

LEAD: The nation's governors, Democrats and Republicans alike, today attacked a proposal to limit the amount of state and local income taxes that could be deducted on Federal tax returns as yet another attempt by the Bush Administration to push more of the burden of closing the budget gap onto states.

LEAD: AMERICAN consumers rarely cause a recession. Even when their incomes are barely rising, which is the case today, they somehow manage to spend enough to keep the economy afloat. LEAD: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation yesterday priced $300 million of 8.75 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of 99.649 to yield 8.84 percent through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

LEAD: Mark Bavaro, the Pro Bowl tight end for the Giants who underwent serious surgery on his left knee in January, underwent another operation on that knee this morning. The latest surgery was minor, and Coach Bill Parcells said Bavaro should be ready to resume practice in a week to 10 days.

LEAD: Personal spending rose 1 percent in June, the strongest gain in five months, the Government said today. The Commerce Department report suggested that consumers have been keeping the nation's weak economy out of a recession.

LEAD: What's unsettling about standing in line is the all-too-real possibility that somebody's going to sneak in ahead of you. If what you're waiting for is a movie seat or a restaurant table, losing your place is only an annoyance. If it's a heart or kidney, losing your place is sometimes the difference between life and death.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A front-page picture caption on Saturday about bias at private golf clubs misidentified Hall W. Thompson in some copies. He is the founder, not the owner, of the Shoal Creek Country Club in Birmingham, Ala.

LEAD: In 1976, while David H. Souter was New Hampshire Attorney General, his office submitted a brief to a Federal appeals court arguing that the state should not provide Medicaid funds to pay for abortions, which the brief called ''the killing of the unborn.''

LEAD: The White House today condemned the massacre of Liberian war refugees as a ''senseless act of terror'' and repeated earlier appeals for all sides in the civil war to negotiate an end to the fighting.
LEAD: Jari Kurri, who helped the Edmonton Oilers win five Stanley Cups and became the most prolific scorer in the National Hockey League among European players, is off to Italy to play hockey.

LEAD: George Steinbrenner's reign of tyranny as the Yankees' principal owner was also a reign of propaganda. Whatever the problem, he shouted loud enough and long enough that it was always somebody else's fault. When the team stumbled, it had to be the fault of the dismissed manager, the dismissed pitching coach or the dismissed players.

LEAD: In the biggest expansion by a Japanese computer company into Europe, Fujitsu Ltd. will pay $1.29 billion for 80 percent of ICL P.L.C., Britain's only manufacturer of mainframe computers, the two companies announced today.
LEAD: The Ball Corporation announced today that it would spend more than $1 billion to make acquisitions that would nearly triple its sales.

LEAD: China's first full-fledged stock market since the Communist takeover will open in Shanghai in December, a newspaper report said today. A national securities exchange will open in a new building equipped with computer terminals linked to trading counters in the port city and around the country, the official Liberation Daily reported.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the case of Oliver L. North referred incorrectly to a July 20 decision by a Federal appeals court. The decision set aside Mr. North's conviction on three charges in the Iran-contra case and overturned one of the three charges, not an additional charge, outright.

LEAD: Three days after Senate Democrats proposed banning campaign contributions by political action committees, the party's leaders in the House today unveiled a proposal that would only limit such donations.

LEAD: Israel was created in response to savage inhumanity, and more than most countries it avows humane ideals. Perhaps understandably, then, any criticism of Israel for violating human rights touches sensitive feelings. Some supporters find denial easier than looking at the facts.

LEAD: John E. Frohnmayer, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, today acknowledged that both Congress and a substantial section of the American people have lost faith in his agency, but he insisted that new legislation or guidelines were not necessary to correct the situation.

LEAD: Revisions of municipal bond ratings in the first half of the year have affected more than $40 billion in debt, Moody's Investors Service said yesterday. The ratings on nearly $19.5 billion in debt from 102 issuers were upgraded, while those on almost $21 billion in debt of 84 issuers were downgraded.

LEAD: After slowing to a crawl for more than two years, the regional economy has shifted into reverse, shedding 8,000 jobs in private industry in New York City and 7,000 such jobs in northeastern New Jersey in the five months ended in May.

LEAD: WITH the lowering of another cold war barrier, American paleontologists have roamed the Gobi Desert of Mongolia for the first time in six decades, finding a new reptile species related to the Komodo dragon, identifying promising sites for future excavations and recapturing some of the exotic flavor of the most celebrated fossil-hunting expedition of this century.

LEAD: Jimmy DeSana, a photographer known for his witty and occasionally gently erotic color images, died on Friday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 40 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed. Mr. DeSana was born in Detroit on Nov. 12, 1949, and moved to New York City in 1973.
LEAD: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about convictions in a money-laundering case misstated the role of one defendant in some copies.

LEAD: Only nine local jurisdictions in the nation, all in the New York region, still dump sewage sludge in the ocean, and eight of them are on their way to complying with a Federal law that makes that illegal at the end of 1991. All except Nassau County. Every day that the county violates a compliance agreement it signed last year with the Environmental Protection Agency, it is fined $22,000.
LEAD: Commissioner Fay Vincent decided more than a week ago to permanently ban George Steinbrenner from running the Yankees. At 9 A.M. yesterday he unveiled his decision to the Yankees' owner.

LEAD: Rabbi Samuel Umen, a writer and teacher who held pulpits in Michigan and Maryland and at Temple Adath Yeshurun in Manchester, N.H., died Saturday at Elliott Hospital in Manchester, where he lived. He was 73 years old.
LEAD: The country's former Communist dictator, Todor Zhivkov, today indefinitely postponed his plans to appear this week before the national Parliament in an open televised session.
LEAD: ''Banned in Boston'' is a cliche with a long pedigree: It began with the Mayflower.

LEAD: The ''Vincent van Gogh Retrospective,'' an exhibition of nearly 140 works by the Dutch artist, drew a record 1.2 million visitors over four months, the show's organizers said today. LEAD: The Bolshoi Ballet did not perform ''Giselle'' during its recent season in New York. But the company from Moscow, which is touring the United States through September, gave balletomanes in the Washington area a glimpse of its current version of the venerable Romantic ballet over the weekend.
LEAD: Bobby Day, a singer and band leader who recorded ''Rockin' Robin'' ''Little Bitty Pretty One'' and other doo-wop hits of the 1950's, died on Friday. He was 60 years old.

LEAD: President Bush has decided to decide in 1993 whether to proceed with early deployment of space-based defenses. That puts him in the imprudent position of having to choose before the new Star Wars system is adequately tested.
LEAD: Mutual fund investors seem to have generally shrugged off last Monday's sharp break in the stock market, and cash continues to be drawn into stock funds, mutual fund executives said yesterday.

LEAD: Avco Financial Services Inc., a unit of Textron Inc., is offering $100 million in 8 7/8 percent notes due in 1995 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes are offered at a price of 99.75 to yield 8.95 percent, or about 85 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.
LEAD: Progress toward a peaceful settlement of a coup attempt by Muslim rebels was uncertain tonight after three days of tense negotiations mediated by a Anglican cleric.

LEAD: The brief, controversial and uncertain major league baseball career of Deion Sanders came to an abrupt halt yesterday when the Yankee organization ended contract negotiations that would have extended his commitment to baseball and could have led to a legal struggle.

LEAD: Explosion Is Feared In Atom Waste Tanks In the most pessimistic study to date, a Government panel warned that an explosion could rupture tanks of radioactive waste at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington.

LEAD: Sustained by conservation measures, the Indian brow-antlered deer, once thought to be extinct, is making a comeback in the humid marshes and unique wetlands of Keibul Lamjao, a small national park in the country's remote northeast.

LEAD: WINDOWS 3.0, the new Microsoft graphical interface, gives high-end MS-DOS computers much of the power and ease of use of the Macintosh. But what about those who don't use high-end computers? To rephrase an early Mac slogan, what about the rest of us? To find out, I installed Windows on a mid-level computer of the type still found in many homes and offices, and still selling in large, though decreasing, numbers: an AT-class machine (that is, one using the 80286 processor) with a 30-megabyte hard disk, V.G.A.

LEAD: Caribbean scholars and experts on Islam in the West Indies say the militant Muslim group that staged a coup attempt in Trinidad last week is one of many new religious movements that have emerged in the region in recent years, challenging governments and established religious organizations.

LEAD: MY barbecues this summer have featured much more pork than beef. Pork is a tender and mild meat that can be enhanced by all sorts of marinades.

LEAD: The outlook wasn't brilliant for the Yankee nine that day: They were anchored in last place, with less than half the season to play. LEAD: Interest rates declined modestly at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. It also marked the third consecutive week that the average rates have declined.

LEAD: Abortion rights groups are building major direct mail campaigns around the nomination of Judge David H. Souter to the Supreme Court, both to raise money and to encourage senators to press the abortion issue in confirmation hearings in September.

LEAD: Faced with a lawsuit filed by four major newspapers, John E. Frohnmayer, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts and its advisory body, the National Council on the Arts, today decided to open to the public the entire four-day meeting, beginning tomorrow, at which the council will review grant applications.

LEAD: George Brett of the Kansas City Royals, who was knocked down while covering first base during a play on Monday night in Cleveland, is expected to be out of action for several days, according to the Royals' trainer, Mickey Cobb. The 37-year-old infielder was bounced to the ground by Mitch Webster of the Indians, who was attempting to beat out an infield roller, and suffered a sprain and a bruise near his right collarbone.
LEAD: Dr. Norman Pleshette, an obstetrician and gynecologist in Manhattan for almost 60 years, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.
LEAD: * Steve Hayden, the chief creative officer of BBDO's Los Angeles and San Francisco offices, has taken on the additional role of chairman of the company's West Coast operations.

LEAD: Giving one of his bleakest forecasts to date, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that ever-weakening real estate markets and a near-record number of bank failures were likely to produce the third consecutive annual loss for the fund that insures deposits at commercial banks.
LEAD: In a contest between child care in France and the United States, American children are the losers.
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would shrink its computer equipment operations by up to 650 people through job transfers and possible layoffs.

LEAD: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States dropped last week by 26, to a total of 996, according to a widely watched index of drilling activity released on Monday by Baker Hughes Inc. The oil industry toolmaker said the total was still well above the 870 of a year ago. The count reflects the number of rotary rigs exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday.

LEAD: Imo Industries has grown so much in the three years since it was spun off from the Transamerica Corporation that it has created the posts of president and chief operating officer. It is bringing in Robert W. Womack to fill them.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation today reported a 47 percent decline in second-quarter profits, reflecting lower vehicle shipments and the increased cost of offering bigger incentives to car and truck buyers.
LEAD: The lead singer for the rock band Judas Priest testified today that he once recorded a phrase backwards, but he denied planting hidden messages in his music to promote suicide.

LEAD: The biggest problem with solar heating systems is that the sun shines most in the summer, when the heat is not needed, and least in the winter, when it is. But a team at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst has found a storage medium that will hold July's heat for February: the ground.
LEAD: Commissioner Fay Vincent wanted to suspend George Steinbrenner for two years, but Steinbrenner opted for life instead.
LEAD: Blinder, Robinson & Company, once the largest penny-stock brokerage in the world, has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws.
LEAD: Arab leaders will meet in Cairo in November in the first Arab summit talks to be held in Egypt in more than 13 years, Chedli Klibi, secretery general of the Arab League, said today.

LEAD: The University of Arkansas may be headed to the Southeastern Conference, but Athletic Director Frank Broyles wants to keep a few rivalries from ending.

LEAD: George E. Echols, who fought in France in World War I and was the nation's oldest known war veteran, died last Thursday at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center, the Department of Veterans Affairs reported. He was 105 years old.

LEAD: When Alfonso Perez Sanchez joined the Prado Museum in 1960, the young art historian was given the mundane title of head of the storeroom and the testing job of preparing an inventory of the institution's vast collection.

LEAD: The accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche has agreed to pay $19.75 million plus expenses to a former audit client, the Inter-Regional Financial Group, to settle a lawsuit that was in its 12th week of trial in state district court in Minneapolis, the two sides said yesterday.

LEAD: TENNIS Saved by the Rain Rain saved Horst Skoff of Austria from defeat and three West German players advanced at the Austrian Open tournament at Kitzbuhel, Austria. Skoff, one of the favorites, trailed Christian Saceanu of West Germany, 4-6, 4-5, when the match was interrupted by a thunderstorm.

LEAD: Bill Moyers and Studs Terkel come not to bury John Henry Faulk but to praise him. They were friends of the Texas performer, who died in April and who is best known for his victory over blacklisters in 1962. ''The Man Who Beat the Blacklist: John Henry Faulk'' may be seen at 9 tonight on Channel 13 and at 10 P.M.

LEAD: The crackling roar in Congress this week comes from yet another avalanche as billions more dollars go plunging into the savings and loan crevasse. But this could also be the week in which Congress sends a far more welcome reverberation. The Senate and House are each poised to vote on legislation that would deter such monumental scandals by breaking the connection between special interests and special treatment.

LEAD: The House of Representatives approved a bill late Monday night that would help ease overcrowding of the airwaves by transferring many radio frequencies from the Federal Government to private users and state and local governments. The House passed the bill on a voice vote without dissent.

LEAD: Donald L. Ranard, a longtime Foreign Service official who played a key role in uncovering the role of South Korean lobbyists in Washington in the mid-1970's, died on Saturday at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Centreville, Va., and Romney, W. Va. Mr. Ranard's family said he died of leukemia.
LEAD: The illusion of high society and the reality of superior horses will return to New York racing Wednesday when Saratoga Race Track opens for the 122d time.

LEAD: * Amoco Oil Co., Chicago, a subsidiary of Amoco Corp., named W. Douglas Ford vice president of operations planning and transportation. He replaces Rodger W. Murtaugh, who is on assignment for Amoco Production Co., another subsidiary.

LEAD: Weakened by a sluggish economy and the expectation of lower interest rates, the American dollar is tumbling, and many economists expect it to reach or come close to all-time lows against several leading currencies.

LEAD: Navy searchers using a remote-controlled deep-sea submarine have found what could be the cargo door that was torn off a United Airlines jumbo jet last year, hurling nine people to their death over the Pacific.

LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today rejected a bill aimed at keeping children out of foster care by providing housing subsidies to families without shelter. It was one of the few major bills that Mr. Cuomo had rejected in a year when he faces re-election.

LEAD: Liberian rebel forces seeking to oust President Samuel K. Doe today seized a key section of Monrovia that includes the American Embassy and other diplomatic missions, the State Department said today. But later press reports said Government forces had recaptured part of the area in a fierce counterattack.

LEAD: Interco Inc., a St. Louis-based shoe and furniture maker that has been burdened with debts incurred to avoid a hostile takeover in 1988, announced plans yesterday to reorganize its finances and avoid bankruptcy.

LEAD: The police continued their search last night for a man who attacked a young couple with a baseball bat -seriously injuring both - as they sat on a bench near Conservatory Pond in Central Park Monday night.

LEAD: George Steinbrenner's reign of tyranny as the Yankees' principal owner was also a reign of propaganda. Whatever the problem, he shouted loud enough and long enough that it was always somebody else's fault. When the team stumbled, it had to be the fault of the dismissed manager, the dismissed pitching coach or the dismissed players.
LEAD: For the first summer in 75 years, English will be officially spoken today on the Middlebury College campus. But it is for one day only.
LEAD: The Senate rejected an amendment late tonight that called for a voluntary system of public financing of Senate campaigns.

LEAD: In a blow to the Bush Administration, the House Armed Services Committee voted today to end production of the Stealth bomber and cut nearly $2 billion from the Pentagon's proposal for the ''Star Wars'' anti-missile program.

LEAD: Drinking by the ship's captain, a fatigued and overworked crew and inadequate traffic control by the Coast Guard all contributed to the enormous oil spill by the Exxon Valdez off the Alaskan coast last year, the National Transportation Safety Board ruled today.

LEAD: The Soviet Union and Albania have agreed to normalize relations, which were severed in 1961 during Moscow's rift with Beijing, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. The Albanians sided with China in the ideological dispute. The agreement was reached during talks in Bulgaria in June and in Tirana Monday, Tass said.
LEAD: The police arrested three men yesterday in the killing of a 9-month-old on Monday. The infant was shot through the door of his grandmother's apartment on the Grand Concourse in the South Bronx.
LEAD: A New York City man suffering from an AIDS infection won a court order yesterday requiring Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield to pay for a bone-marrow transplant from his identical twin.
LEAD: A Cincinnati Bengals cornerback, Lewis Billups, was sentenced in Cincinnati yesterday to serve 30 days in jail for pointing a gun at two undercover police officers.
LEAD: Now hatred is by far the longest pleasure; Men love in haste, but they detest at leisure. - Lord Byron $/

LEAD: Priscilla Lockwood Loomis, who received an award from Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1981 for 75 years of volunteer charity work, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Huntington, L.I. She was 99 years old and formerly lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, priced a total of $1.25 billion in new securities yesterday.
LEAD: The Cuban Government calls him a terrorist. A goodly number of Cuban exiles in Miami call him a patriot. And American officials have veered, at different times, between one view and the other.

LEAD: Investigators found a body of a man in the rubble of a gutted downtown block on Monday while looking for clues to the cause of a weekend explosion that destroyed at least eight busineses, a Federal agent said.

LEAD: Gunmen from a militant Muslim group released the wounded Prime Minister of this Caribbean island nation today, but they continue to hold other members of the Government who were taken hostage four days ago.

LEAD: Four privately-owned islands in Lake Champlain will be quarantined because of a mysterious disease that killed 4,000 to 5,000 ring-bellied sea gulls, a state official said today. The birds, almost all fledglings, died of a disease that seems to have subsided, said Bob Inslerman, a wildlife manager for the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

LEAD: ''Kid'' is the operative word in describing the ''Young Guns'' approach to the Billy the Kid legend, since these films regard Billy as more of a gun-toting cut-up than a true desperado. As played again by Emilio Estevez in ''Young Guns II,'' Billy tends to giggle at tense moments and, during important ones, to mumble.

LEAD: Senior Energy Department officials said today that the department had failed to deal appropriately with radioactive waste tanks at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington State despite more than a year of strenuous efforts by the Energy Secretary, James D. Watkins, to replace a culture of secrecy that had allowed safety problems to fester.

LEAD: An advertising executive was shot and killed Monday night while talking on a public telephone near his Greenwich Village apartment building, the police said. The executive, John Reisenbach, was using the pay phone because his home phone was disabled.

LEAD: Nearly a week later, Nolan Ryan was still disappointed that the party in Arlington, Tex., last Wednesday night, with friends and relatives from Alvin, Tex., to the West Coast present, had not ended with a 300th major-league victory.

LEAD: * Apple Computer Inc., Cupertino, Calif., said it reached an intellectual-property-rights agreement with Outbound Systems Inc. that will allow Outbound to continue to offer its products. Details were not disclosed.

LEAD: Body parts that washed up in a garbage bag at Seven Presidents Park beach have been identified as the remains of a New York jockey. Crews removing timber and other waste from beaches on Thursday discovered the bag, which contained a head, arms and legs. The Monmouth County authorities used fingerprints to identify the dead man as Pedro Ortega, 26 years old, of the Bronx, an apprentice jockey who rode at New York's Acqueduct and Belmont Park race tracks.
LEAD: THEY call this stark, spectacular crevice of Idaho the Magic Valley after a trick of nature that sends more than a million gallons of water a minute down its vast canyon walls.

LEAD: After Federal and local law-enforcement officials arrested Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington on drug charges in January, Cathy Hughes devoted a week of her morning radio talk show on WOL-AM to issues raised by the arrest.

LEAD: The killing of four children in nine days by gunfire intended for others has pierced New Yorkers' instinctive imperviousness to the violence that increasingly surrounds them in a city where 2,000 people are likely to be murdered this year.
LEAD: Michel Guy, a former Minister of Culture and director of the annual Autumn Festival in Paris, died on Monday after a long illness, associates said today. He was 63 years old.

LEAD: A small biotechnology company based in Seattle has taken the lead in the race to introduce a class of drugs that build up the body's defense against infections. Analysts say the drugs could prove the most important product of genetic engineering yet.

LEAD: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds eased yesterday in lackluster trading, causing rates to edge up. Dealers described the market's mood as indecisive. Some dealers said a pause was normal after two sessions of sharp advances, but others described the market as confused and contended that the recent price gains had left the market vulnerable to any determined selling.

LEAD: A chart in Business Day yesterday, headed ''The Favorite Stocks,'' misstated the performance of several stocks. LEAD: UAL's stock plunged $16.875 yesterday after sliding $6.125 on Monday, amid rumors that financial support for the $4.4 billion union-led buyout of the airline may be evaporating. The stock closed on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday at $140.

LEAD: The revolution in human gene therapy, so long ballyhooed and debated, began today in earnest as a Government panel approved experiments with two therapies designed to treat human disease by inserting new genes into cells.

LEAD: A GREEN sauce whets my appetite better than a sauce of a different color. White sauce sounds bland, brown sauce might be heavy, red sauce lacks delicacy and orange sauce is often too sweet.
LEAD: What's the difference, he was once asked, between owning race horses and owning a baseball team?

LEAD: Jose Rijo pitched, hit and ran well, and Hal Morris had two hits and scored twice as the Cincinnati Reds reawakened to beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5-2, tonight to snap an eight-game losing streak.

LEAD: The Communist Party won a majority in this country's first free legislative elections but will invite opposition groups to join the Government, the party chairman said today. The election was held Sunday.

LEAD: In their first week of training camp, the Giants were starved for defensive linemen. Today, they got help when Mike Fox, their second-round draft choice, signed and immediately became the starting left defensive end.

LEAD: Using market research to advertise their brand of ethically oriented education, Roman Catholic elementary and secondary schools have been waging a secular war against shrinking enrollment nationwide.

''Why would you want to stay manager and be second-guessed by me,'' he said, ''when you can be one of the second-guessers?

LEAD: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, is offering $300 million in notes through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The size of the issue was increased from a planned $250 million.

LEAD: With money for administrative expenses running short at the end of the fiscal year, the Social Security Administration has suspended hearings in September for people seeking disability benefits.

LEAD: Jill Esmond, a film and stage actress who was the first wife of Laurence Olivier, died on Saturday at her home in Wimbledon. She was 82 years old. No cause of death was given. Ms. Esmond, who appeared in Hollywood films including ''The White Cliffs of Dover'' and ''Random Harvest,'' studied at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London.

LEAD: Bowing to pressure from civil-rights leaders and an increasing number of corporate sponsors who have withdrawn television advertising from next week's P.G.A. Championship there, Shoal Creek Country Club agreed today to accept black members into its previously all-white membership. In return, the civil rights leaders agreed to call off picketing of the championship.

LEAD: After more than a year's delay, the Ashton-Tate Company today began shipping an updated version of its flagship product, a program that is considered a key to the company's return to profitability. Dubbed dBase IV Version 1.1, the new program seeks to correct flaws in the original dBase IV announced in October 1988.

LEAD: Seven members of a drug gang that authorities say committed at least three murders to protect its Elizabeth-based operations have been charged with racketeering and conspiracy in a 32-count Federal indictment released today.
LEAD: A jury today convicted Ruben Zuno Arce, a brother-in-law of a former Mexican president and the most important defendant in the 1985 torture and killing of an American drug agent in Mexico.

LEAD: Ned Rorem's ''Auden Poems,'' a song cycle that was given its world premiere on Sunday evening at the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival, is a study in esthetic schizophrenia. Mr. Rorem proves again and again in his setting of seven W. H. Auden texts of great musical potential that he is quite capable of writing richly expressive, eminently singable music.

LEAD: Roseanne Barr, purveyor of vulgar entertainment for the TV audience, ran afoul of President Bush last week. The President said he was offended by Miss Barr's singing of ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' at a professional baseball game in San Diego.

LEAD: The actions taken against George Steinbrenner by major league baseball on Monday have raised questions about his ability to remain as a vice president of the United States Olympic Committee, a position he cherishes and one in which he has worked hard.

LEAD: The Triton Energy Corporation announced plans to sell some assets to raise money to pay long-term debt and undertake new exploration. Triton said it expected to raise $150 million, most of which will go toward paying down $250 million in long-term debt.

LEAD: In an effort to make his proposal for a Social Security tax cut more attractive to his fellow Democrats, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan today offered a modified version that would stretch out the tax cut over five years instead of two.

LEAD: A judge's request that two United States officials testify in the investigation of the killings of six Jesuit priests last November has prompted a spirited debate between American officials here and in Washington.
LEAD: The executive editor and president of The Philadelphia Inquirer, Eugene L. Roberts Jr., announced unexpectedly yesterday that he would retire on Sept. 1.
LEAD: The South African military announced tonight that it had disbanded a clandestine unit held responsible by its adversaries for the assassination of political dissidents.
LEAD: The nation's governors today approved plans intended to give backbone to their national education policies, but the package was greeted with skepticism by some education groups.
LEAD: Sales of new homes surged 8 percent in June, the sharpest increase since November, the Government said today.

LEAD: Charles M. Mapes, a communications consultant and retired engineer with A. T. & T., died on Friday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 89 years old and lived in Suffern.

LEAD: Albert Rose, a research scientist whose work in converting optical images to electrical signals led to the development of the modern television picture tube, died on Thursday at the Princeton Medical Center in New Jersey. He was 80 years old and lived in Princeton.
LEAD: Bolton Sullivan, the founder and retired president of the Skil Corporation of Chicago, died Thursday at his home in Lake Forest, Ill. He was 94 years old.

LEAD: ERIC ONORE is a typical young American lawyer. He wears wing-tip shoes and pin-stripe suits. He specializes in civil law and divorce. Most days are as exciting as watching Wite-Out dry. ''I've evicted a family,'' he said, when asked about recent accomplishments.

LEAD: President Francois Mitterrand's decision to pardon a pro-Iranian terrorist who was serving a life sentence on murder charges has touched off a wave of protests in French jails, with prisoners complaining that they were not given similar treatment.

LEAD: SALADS are not the first thing that springs to mind when you're considering the capabilities of the microwave oven, but for the robust salads of summer, it can be an efficient, cool helper. For variety, vegetables can be cooked in one dish, rather than separately timed in a plethora of little pots of boiling water.

LEAD: East Germany's Interior Minister said today that the former Communist Government had released 33,000 political prisoners to West Germany from 1964 to 1989, against indirect payments from Bonn that started at the equivalent of $10,000 a head and ended up at about $60,000.

LEAD: A television review yesterday about ''Police Chiefs'' incompletely identified the role of Alan and Susan Raymond in an earlier program, ''An American Family.'' They did the photography; the program was produced and directed by Craig Gilbert.
LEAD: F.A.O. Schwarz, the 128-year-old toy store that has delighted generations of children, has been acquired by the Netherlands' leading department store chain for an undisclosed amount.
LEAD: The governing board of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. decided by voice vote today to remain neutral on the abortion issue but said it resented government intrusion into personal matters.

LEAD: An article on Monday about the Marlboro Music Festival in Marlboro, Vt., misstated the professional affiliation of a musician at the festival. The musician, Donald Weilerstein, was a founding member of the Cleveland Quartet but left the ensemble last year.
LEAD: One of three former Northwest Airlines pilots accused of flying while intoxicated had a higher tolerance for alcohol because he is an alcoholic, his lawyer said today.

LEAD: THE Broadway Barber Shop, between 103d and 104th Streets, and Kay Demetriou, its owner, have been Upper West Side fixtures for four decades. LEAD: IF you can't get the student to the classes, take the classes to the student. Some such philosophy was in the works when the Institute for Preventive Medicine at Methodist Hospital opened a satellite center on the second floor of the Rice Epicurean Market on San Felipe here in Houston.

LEAD: HELEN SAGLIN, a Chippewa, remembers childhood meals of wild rice, game, cornmeal soup and fry bread. Now, as a member of the Tekakwitha Club, a Roman Catholic women's organization on the Lac du Flambeau Reservation in north-central Wisconsin, Ms. Saglin is cooking similar meals for tourist groups interested in American Indian foods.
LEAD: Donald Trump has had a hard time lately keeping his financial empire afloat, but he has caught a few breaks in a boxing operation that for a while also appeared to be in trouble.

LEAD: The Pic 'N' Save Corporation, which has been under pressure from an investment group that has sought control of its board, announced a plan to repurchase as much as $150 million of its stock and scale back operations.

LEAD: Through the barred ground-floor windows of shabby workers' dormitories in a quarter of Bulgaria's capital known as Little Saigon, Vietnamese men sell scarce convenience store staples like Coca-Cola, instant coffee and cigarettes along with Canadian whisky and other hard liquor.

LEAD: In a move toward moderate cable re-regulation, the Senate Commerce Committee yesterday approved a compromise measure that would allow the phone companies to act as a delivery system for cable programming, but would not permit them to compete in the programming itself.
LEAD: THE Tokyo stock market, once again, is tumbling. And as in the 30 percent plunge from January to April, the villians are high interest rates, a weak yen and higher oil prices.

LEAD: Amid the layers on layers of defenses leading up to the edge of the demilitarized zone, it is easy to miss one more, added almost as an afterthought 12 years ago: a steep grassy slope, topped with barbed wire, that falls off into a 20-mile cliff of cement facing North Korea.

LEAD: An article in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday, about the events leading to Commissioner Fay Vincent's disciplinary action against George Steinbrenner, the New York Yankees' principal owner, incorrectly reported Mr. Vincent's initial decision. A baseball official has since said that Mr. Vincent intended to suspend Mr.
LEAD: Chris Chandler, the Indianapolis Colts' disgruntled quarterback, was traded to Tampa Bay yesterday, a week after suing the Colts for breach of contract.
LEAD: An article on Monday about a bombing in Israel misidentified the hometown of a Canadian tourist killed in the explosion. It is Willowdale, a suburb of Toronto.

LEAD: By the end of the week, Mark Leiter could be back in Columbus. There are no assurances, no guarantees that he will remain until the end of the season, when the Yankees finally play their last game in October and then go home.

LEAD: The pistols used in the four recent killings of children are members of a new generation of large-capacity semiautomatic weapons that have become standard among drug dealers and robbers, the police said.

LEAD: RUSTY STAUB is chatting with guests, a couple of young executive types, at his restaurant on Fifth Avenue at 47th Street. They are staring at him, wide-eyed. Could he be telling them about his first major-league homer, off Don Drysdale of the Dodgers, when he was 19 years old and playing for the old Houston Colt .45's?

LEAD: The House today overwhelmingly approved legislation that would strengthen criminal penalties for crimes involving savings and loan institutions and create a special national commission to study the causes of the savings and loan debacle.
LEAD: The prices farmers get for raw products were unchanged from June to July, but the overall commodity price index was still 2.7 percent above a year before, the Agriculture Department said today.
LEAD: Georges Conchon, a prize-winning novelist and screenwriter, died on Sunday in a Paris-area hospital after a sudden illness, his family said Monday. He was 65 years old.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: Lawn care is tedious and predictable. Lawns are seeded and fed. They grow. They get mowed. They grow again. But some lawns are more interesting than their owners would like. These homeowners face a bigger challenge than their flatland neighbors; they are the masters and caretakers of steep, almost vertical lawns.

LEAD: The new director of a Bulgarian arms-export concern long presumed in the West to have supplied weapons to terrorist organizations said today that his company was willing to share with Western governments information on arms that might have ended up in terrorist hands.
LEAD: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week ended yesterday.

LEAD: AFTER years of legal wrangling, the design field in New York state has taken a step toward professional legitimacy with the signing by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of a bill that provides for state certification of interior designers.

LEAD: Players waited and reporters waited and photographers waited, but there was no George Steinbrenner yesterday. Not at Yankee Stadium, where he was expected to appear and meet with the players in perhaps his final session with them as the principal owner.

LEAD: ''SO many people grow up with their parents saying 'Don't draw on the furniture,' '' said the painter Gary Komarin. Mr. Komarin and his wife, Sharon, a former nursery school teacher, aren't that way.

LEAD: For the first time, researchers have been able to cure patients with chronic hepatitis B, a devastating and often progressively debilitating liver disease that afflicts more than a million Americans and is the ninth leading cause of death worldwide.

LEAD: President Bush and Congressional negotiators are planning uninterrupted bargaining sessions at Camp David, Md., or a similarly isolated spot outside Washington in early September to work out a final compromise on the 1991 Federal budget, senior lawmakers in both parties said today.

LEAD: New medical evidence that a black teen-ager had his hands up when he was fatally shot in the back by a Teaneck police officer caused the New Jersey Attorney General to order a new investigation, people close to the case said yesterday.
LEAD: Bank stock prices fell yesterday after a televised allegation by a Stanford University economist that several of the nation's largest banks were ''very close to true insolvency.''
LEAD: Cracks in a Foundation
LEAD: The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases is setting up a program to help scientists design new drugs to treat the infections that kill people with AIDS.
LEAD: The National Basketball Association raised its team salary cap yesterday, and the teams immediately raised their trading intensity.

LEAD: In a move that could signal a break in their political stalemate, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has joined with his main rival, Boris N. Yeltsin, to create a commission to produce a program of economic change for the Soviet Union by Sept. 1.
LEAD: * BSN Corp., Dallas, a sporting goods company, said it would solicit offers for the company's assets.
LEAD: American Gardens, New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, Bedford Park, the Bronx; (212) 220-8747.

LEAD: The McDonald's Corporation, which has resisted efforts in some localities to ban its plastic packaging, has agreed to a conduct a joint study with the Environmental Defense Fund on the way it uses and disposes of its packaging and other solid waste.

LEAD: Joseph Volpe, who began 26 years ago as an apprentice carpenter backstage at the Metropolitan Opera, was appointed the company's chief administrative officer yesterday, effective immediately. He succeeds Hugh Southern, who was forced to resign in June after only seven months as general manager.

LEAD: In its 46-year history, the New York City Opera has had many mandates, sometimes conflicting ones. It has been a home for young American singers, a champion of American opera, a forum for innovative productions, a source of unusual repertory. But one of its humbler jobs has been to present solid, competent performances of standard-repertory operas in conventional productions at moderate prices.
LEAD: Childbirth, so often touted as a natural occurrence, can also be a daunting one for women who confront an array of modern technological procedures in large medical institutions.

LEAD: The New York City Correction Commissioner said yesterday that a ''high impact incarceration plan'' - similar in some ways to the state's boot-camp program for prisoners - would begin at Rikers Island in September.
LEAD: Seven members of UB40, the British reggae group, were deported from the Seychelles Islands yesterday after being arrested on suspicion of possessing marijuana.
LEAD: To The Home Section:

LEAD: Final arguments began today in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug and perjury trial, with the prosecution asserting that he was ''a general who joined the enemy'' in the war on drugs and the defense countering that the Government had used ''mustard gas'' tactics to apprehend a man who used drugs only occasionally.

LEAD: The longest and most expensive criminal proceeding in American history came to an official end today when a Superior Court judge dismissed all charges against Raymond Buckey, a central figure in the McMartin Pre-School child molestation case.
LEAD: Yusef Salaam repeatedly and emphatically denied yesterday that he had had any part in the rape and near-fatal beating of a jogger in Central Park.
LEAD: THE results of the 1990 ID Magazine Design Review are in.
LEAD: After a bewildering series of turnabouts, Bulgaria's Parliament today elected the leader of the main opposition political coalition to the national presidency.
LEAD: Paul J. Schierl, who has battled illness since arranging a management-led buyout of the Fort Howard Corporation two years ago, resigned today as chief executive after 16 years.
LEAD: * Hoya Museum Crystal to Atlas Citron Haligman & Bedecarre, San Francisco. The account had been with Cadwell Davis Partners, New York.

LEAD: FROM Manhattan to Berkeley, Calif., and from Atlanta to Newport, R.I., green thumbs and greenhorns are patronizing stores with names like the Potted Plant, the Elegant Earth, Victory Garden and Devonshire. Following in the path of mail-order businesses like Smith & Hawken and Gardener's Eden, which have already spread the word on the well-honed garden, this new breed of shop is bringing the sweet smell of earth (or at least the illusion of it) indoors.

LEAD: Following is the 77-to-23 roll-call vote by which the Senate voted today to prohibit its members from accepting speaking fees from special interest groups. A yes vote was a vote to prohibit such fees and a no vote was a vote to permit them. Voting yes were 53 Democrats and 24 Republicans. Voting no were 2 Democrats and 21 Republicans.

LEAD: George W. May, founder of Firecom Inc. of Woodside, Queens, a manufacturer and installer of alarms, died on Sunday at Glen Cove Community Hospital on Long Island. He was 64 years old and lived in Locust Valley, L.I.

LEAD: A group of prominent black legislators, clergy members and leaders of community groups asserted yesterday that District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan was systematically excluding blacks from policy-making roles in his office.

LEAD: Entertainment Marketing and Communications International Ltd. yesterday announced a sponsorship deal linking Pizza Hut Inc., a subsidiary of Pepsico, and the Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles cartoon characters. At the heart of Pizza Hut's agreement is the sponsorship of a 40-city rock-concert tour, with musicians appearing as singing turtles, scheduled to begin in September in New York.
LEAD: Japanese stock prices fell sharply today and the yen fluctuated wildly against the dollar after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Page D15.

LEAD: A former employee of the Arbitron Company attempted to give confidential information about the company's television ratings to its principal rival, the A. C. Nielsen Company, the Department of Justice charged yesterday.
LEAD: As George Steinbrenner continued to go quietly into the final days of his tenure as the Yankees' boss, his aides continued trying to practice the political art of damage control yesterday.

LEAD: TENNIS Sabatini and Capriati Gain Gabriela Sabatini and Jennifer Capriati led nine of the top 10 seeded players to victory at the Player's Challenge championships yesterday in Montreal. But second-round play was also marked by three retirements and one default because of injuries.
LEAD: Common Stock
LEAD: The Incidence of breast cancer is rising among American women. One woman in 10 will eventually get this disease, up from one in 11 just four years ago.

LEAD: George Napack, a chemical engineer and a retired vice president of the Hatco Chemical Corporation, died on Tuesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 65 years old and lived in Westfield, N.J.

LEAD: Last week ''Roseanne'' was the top-rated television show, with a 14.6 rating and a 26-point audience share, according to the Neilsen ratings. Also last week, ROSEANNE BARR, the show's star, sang the national anthem at a baseball game in San Diego, then grabbed her crotch and spat on the field.

LEAD: After a three-hour meeting today, President F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela indicated that they had overcome a crisis between them and would resume negotiations on the country's future as planned next Monday.
LEAD: President Joaquim A. Chissano has announced that for the first time in Mozambique's history, opposition parties will be allowed to compete for power. Mozambican rebels welcomed the move.
LEAD: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON DECOLONIZATION - 10 A.M.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Charles (Red) Barrett, who holds the major league record for the fewest pitches in a nine-inning game, died at his home Saturday after a long illness. He was 75 years old. While pitching for the Boston Braves in 1944, he faced 27 batters and threw only 58 pitches in a 2-0 victory over the Cincinnati

LEAD: In a sharp break with tradition, the directors of the leading oversight body of the accounting profession voted at their July meeting to allow accountants to organize their practices as corporations.

LEAD: Theodore M. Sabarese, an entrepreneur who built a computer company called the Ultimate Corporation into a $200 million business, hopes to do the same with the Digital Products Corporation in his new posts as president and chief executive.

LEAD: An article on the Company News page in Business Day yesterday about the Walt Disney Company's plans for a theme park in Long Beach, Calif., misstated the company's business relationship with two attractions on the site in some copies. Disney leases and operates the Queen Mary ocean liner and the Spruce Goose airplane; it does not own them.

LEAD: Hank Steinbrenner, designated by George Steinbrenner as the chosen successor to run the Yankees franchise, has cleared one of the three hurdles necessary to make his father's wish a reality and appears assured of clearing the second.
LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis today signed the $13.4 billion budget the Legislature sent to him on Saturday, ending seven months of bitter negotiations.

LEAD: At the entrance to ''Matisse in Morocco,'' on display at the Museum of Modern Art until Sept. 4, is a National Geographic magazine photograph of Tangier in 1906. The city is sun-baked, steamy and tired. Just beyond it is the Tangier painted by Matisse. Fertile, colorful, exuberant, the city is paradise.
LEAD: Leaders of two of the most prestigious all-white golf clubs in America said today that the events of Shoal Creek have made the search for black members at their clubs a major priority.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Arkansas jumped to the Southeastern Conference today, severing its 76-year ties to the troubled Southwest Conference and possibly starting a restructuring of college football leagues.

LEAD: Dr. Edward Frederick Landau, a retired research chemist and holder of six patents, died on Monday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived in West Orange.

LEAD: Eight to ten million people around the world are now infected with the virus that causes AIDS, and the incidence of the infection is rising dramatically in some parts of the world, the World Health Organization reports.

LEAD: The Daisy Systems Corporation, once a high-flying leader in the electronic automated design business, said the company and its Daisy/Cadnetix Inc. unit had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Daisy Systems, based in Mountainview, Calif., said it had liabilities substantially in excess of its tangible assets.

LEAD: To the surprise of hardly anyone, Joe Torre was named manager of the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday. The hiring ended a monthlong search for a successor to Whitey Herzog, who, in the middle of his 11th season as skipper, resigned on June 6 with the Cardinals in last place in the National League East.
LEAD: Jari Gronstand, a defenseman, and Bill Berg, a left wing, signed multiyear contracts with the Islanders yesterday.

LEAD: Travel Agent Magazine has been sold by Capital Cities Media Inc. to a partnership headed by Richard Friese, who will serve as the weekly's publisher. Friese's partnership also publishes Unique Homes Magazine.
LEAD: The most captivating news story in my home state last year concerned an attempted robbery of tragicomic proportions.

LEAD: The leaders of Italy, Czechoslovakia, Austria, Hungary and Yugoslavia, meeting for the first time as a new regional alliance, agreed today to step up political and economic cooperation to promote stability on the changing continent.

LEAD: A man convicted of killing a puppy with a butcher knife was sentenced Tuesday to three and a half years in prison under the state's recently toughened law on cruelty to animals. Everston Eugene Webb, 22 years old, was sentenced for aggravated cruelty. Testimony at his Circuit Court trial indicated he killed the dog on May 11 because it was tearing up his yard.
LEAD: Frederick Carl Gloeckner, a New York horticulturist, died on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: The Whirlpool Corporation and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company formed a venture to operate Whirlpool's 750-employee vacuum cleaner plant in Danville, Ky. Terms were not disclosed, but Whirlpool will retain a large minority interest in the venture. Whirlpool vacuum cleaners at the plant under the Kenmore name for Sears, Roebuck & Company.
LEAD: Construction spending, which fell for two straight months, was flat in June, the Government reported today.

LEAD: THE decorative arts of Africa are usually chronicled in books about masks, bronzes, jewelry, textiles and tools made by men. In ''African Canvas: Art of West African Women'' (Rizzoli, $60), the photographer and journalist Margaret Courtney-Clarke documents a lesser-known form: the art of rural dwellings.

LEAD: The decision by Shoal Creek Country Club to admit black members seems to have stemmed the flight of advertisers from the telecasts of next week's Professional Golfers' Association Championship, and one company, Spalding Sports Worldwide, said yesterday that it might reverse its position and buy commercials on the television broadcast of the tournament.
LEAD: Rival Palestinian guerrillas clashed with rockets and heavy machine guns in their largest district in Lebanon today, and the police said 10 people were killed and 50 wounded.

LEAD: Because of two missing words, and a law that puts a premium on the absurd, an insurgent candidate is working hard to invalidate scores of nominating petitions in the Bronx. The spectacle makes one more eloquent argument for reform of New York State's notoriously niggling Election Law.
LEAD: Dr. Edward Mahon Kline, an educator, cardiologist and retired medical director of the General Electric Company, died on Monday at his home in Southport, Conn. He was 81 years old.

LEAD: The Acura NSX sports car that will be roaring down American roads later in August has swooping lines, a heart-stopping 168-mile-an-hour top speed and a long list of other characteristics that the Honda Motor Company says a competitive ''super car'' should have.

LEAD: TERI SMITH looks forward to family reunions. They are times for her aunts, uncles, cousins, sisters and brothers to gather to talk of their new babies, travels, childhoods, deceased relatives and dreams. Ms. Smith will also learn more about families from a broader perspective at the six Black Family Reunion Celebrations being held in various cities around the country.
LEAD: The House approved a 1990 farm bill today that limits commodity subsidies, but not to the low levels sought by members criticizing agriculture spending.
