LEAD: An article on the Education page on July 25 about changes in leadership at several universities misstated Clark Kerr's tenure as chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley. He was chancellor of the Berkeley campus from 1952 to 1958, and president of the University of California system from 1958 to 1967.

LEAD: THE historic diamond deal announced last week by the Soviet Union and De Beers Centenary, a Swiss subsidiary of the huge South African mining group, took months of meetings and four sets of shuttle negotiations between London and Moscow.

LEAD: Charles H. Willard, a retired partner of Davis Polk & Wardwell, a Manhattan law firm, died on Monday at his home in Somers, N.Y. He was 85 years old. He died of pneumonia, his wife, Nancy, said. Mr. Willard, who specialized in practice relating to banking, joined the firm in 1930 and became a partner in 1950.

LEAD: The Pentagon has drafted a blueprint for United States military strategy in the 1990's with the assumption that once Soviet forces withdraw from Eastern Europe it would take Moscow up to two years to mobilize for a major invasion.

LEAD: Players from the New York metropolitan area were outstandingly successful in the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals in Boston last week, with at least a share in all the major titles.
LEAD: The most talked-about items in the last two issues of Paris Match magazine were the ones that did not appear in Britain.
LEAD: Stocks fell slightly yesterday, with bank shares giving ground amid fears that the industry could be facing difficult times.
LEAD: Stanley Brezenoff, the first deputy mayor in the Koch administration, has been designated to be the next executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission has approved the $1.25 billion merger of the MCI Communications Corporation and Telecom USA Inc. MCI said the merger to be completed before the end of the month, pending state regulatory approvals. MCI plans to acquire all of Telecom's outstanding common shares for $42 each, or about $1.25 billion.
LEAD: Ed Emshwiller, who created avant-garde films and videotapes, died on July 26 at the Henry Mayo Newhall Memorial Hospital in Valencia, Calif. He was 65 years old.

LEAD: Members of the council that advises the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts say they expect fireworks at a meeting here on Friday when they take up recommendations for new grants for two of the four sexually explicit performance artists who were denied grants in June.
LEAD: Jan Stussy, a West Coast artist with works in many museums and private collections, died on Tuesday at his home in West Los Angeles. He was 68 years old.
LEAD: International A3-9

LEAD: For Big Nurse in ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' it was a tool of terror, and in the public mind ''shock therapy'' has retained the tarnished image given it by Ken Kesey's novel: dangerous, inhumane and overused.

LEAD: ROGER CRAIG has thrown in the towel after posing in it for Macy's ads. The running back for the San Francisco 49ers, who posed earlier this summer for an ad for Calvin Klein underwear, said that his wife did not like his modeling career.

LEAD: In surprisingly quick action, the House today approved a bill overhauling Federal housing programs for the next fiscal year and approving $27.9 billion to pay for them. The spending would include $150 million to help people with AIDS.

LEAD: A front-page article yesterday about a Senate subcommittee hearing on the savings and loan crisis misidentified a lobbyist who used his Washington contacts to help buyers of insolvent savings and loan associations. He is Robert J. Thompson.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The American Legion, the largest veterans' group in the country, said today that it was bringing suit against the Government for failing to complete a study of the health of thousands of Vietnam War veterans exposed to the defoliant Agent Orange.

LEAD: The summer is still not over for Andy Hawkins. There are two months remaining, perhaps a dozen or so starts left for him to remove the memory of his strange season. He should want to forget the whole thing right now, but he doesn't.
LEAD: The brother of a 24-year-old man shot to death by a police officer outside a party in the Bronx has sued the city, claiming wrongful death.
LEAD: * John P. McLaughlin, a senior vice president and director of account management, has been promoted to executive vice president of Gray Kirk & Evans.

LEAD: Coast Guard officials said today that they were uncertain what had become of much of the estimated 500,000 gallons of oil that spilled four days ago when a tanker collided with two barges in the Houston Ship Channel.

LEAD: WHEN Tony Origlio and Kip Vanderbilt first saw their loft in 1985, it looked like a bowling alley with a dazzling view. Although the 70-foot-long loft had a 13th-floor view of the Hudson River and the skyscrapers of midtown Manhattan, it was just 12 feet wide.

LEAD: Following is the 77-to-23 roll-call vote by which the Senate voted today to prohibit its members from accepting speaking fees from special interest groups. A yes vote was a vote to prohibit such fees and a no vote was a vote to permit them. Voting yes were 53 Democrats and 24 Republicans. Voting no were 2 Democrats and 21 Republicans.
LEAD: An obituary yesterday about Dr. Norman Pleshette, a Manhattan obstetrician, omitted a survivor. She is his wife, Marjorie.

LEAD: As Afghan rebel leaders and Pakistani officials await the results of talks on Afghanistan between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, attention here and in Kabul is riveted on the sudden and mysterious trip to Moscow by the Afghan leader, Najibullah.

LEAD: The Mets turned into August tonight with the kind of desperate action reserved for pennant races. And, in three and a half hours of their ripest melodrama of the season, they survived when Tim Teufel had a pinch-hit home run for a tie with two down in the ninth inning, and then rose up to topple the Montreal

LEAD: * International Business Machines Corp., Armonk, N.Y., named Earl F. Wheeler, a general manager of programming systems, as senior vice president. I.B.M. also named Dr. James C. McGroddy, director of its research division, and Mary Lee Turner, director of corporate communications, as vice presidents.
LEAD: Chris Chandler, the disgruntled Indianapolis quarterback, was back at square one yesterday after the Colts announced the failure of a deal to trade him to Tampa Bay.

LEAD: Although the axiom that comedy is more difficult to perform than tragedy is a cliche of criticism, it might even be true. But like many an old saw, this one doesn't always cut deep. The fact is that unless we are talking about the heady level of ''Falstaff'' or ''The Marriage of Figaro,'' opera rarely demands more of singers than low comedy skills.

LEAD: The Senate tonight passed the first major campaign finance bill since the Watergate era, a comprehensive package that would bar political action committees from Federal campaigns, infuse public money into Congressional campaigns and offer candidates vouchers for television advertising.
LEAD: The Government announced plans today to sell 130 more failed savings institutions and about $50 billion in securities and real estate properties by the end of the year.

LEAD: Just after 10:30 yesterday morning, Yusef Salaam swept across the Manhattan courtroom, a tall, lean figure with a young man's face who was there to answer charges that he raped and tried to kill a young woman in Central Park one night.
LEAD: It's been said that only God can make a tree. But now mere mortals are stepping forward to argue about who owns a tree's image.

LEAD: The Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company said today that it would take part in the acquisition of the Oppenheimer Management Corporation from British and Commonwealth Holdings P.L.C. for about $150 million.
LEAD: Slipping a .38 revolver into the waistband of his blue jeans, Norberto Neves de Sousa led fellow environmental agents down a forest path to an Amazon gold-mining camp.
LEAD: Meadow Star, Fourstardave and 24,552 horseplayers were the biggest winners this afternoon on a nearly flawless 122d opening day at Saratoga Race Track.
LEAD: The nation's death rate from asthma has increased by more than 30 percent in seven years, and nearly 10 million Americans are now affected by the disease, Federal health officials say.
LEAD: A Natural History of the Senses By Diane Ackerman 331 pages. Random House. $19.95.

LEAD: Disability Hearings Rescued The Administration will free enough money to avert a disruption in Social Security hearings for people seeking disability benefits. Page A14. Barry Trial Nears End Summing up, the prosecution called Marion Barry a turncoat in the war on drugs, and the defense attacked ''mustard gas'' tactics.
LEAD: To The Home Section:

LEAD: Karsten (Cash) Mahlmann resigned today as chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade, the world's largest futures exchange, a day after Federal regulators charged an affiliate of his financially troubled commodities firm with misusing customer funds.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about Donald Trump and boxing misstated Bill Cayton's managerial relationship with Mike Tyson, the former heavyweight champion. Although estranged from Tyson, Cayton is still formally his manager.
LEAD: IRA GALLEN took a gulp of Naya Natural Spring Water from a Lone Ranger cup. ''Hi-yo, Silver,'' he toasted happily before answering his ringing Snoopy telephone.

LEAD: Imagine a couple rolling around a bathroom floor for 50 minutes. Then imagine that this ''floor'' is actually an upright wall in a theater, providing an audience with an aerial view as the performers move on the vertical plane by means of toeholds or harnesses.
LEAD: The Nynex Corporation plans to spend at least $100 million to build a second cellular telephone network in Manhattan by Christmas of next year, company officials said yesterday.
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that its earnings had risen nearly fivefold in the second quarter from results that were depressed by a large restructuring charge a year ago.

LEAD: Struggling to find a political response to the recent shootings of four children, the New York City Council yesterday proposed adding hundreds of officers to the police force. Hours later, Mayor David N. Dinkins rebuffed that plan as unrealistic and offered his own.

LEAD: The Government's main gauge for forecasting the direction of the economy did not budge in June, the Commerce Department said today in a report that analysts said was a sign of a listless economy in the months ahead.
LEAD: A Federal district judge today rejected the county's redistricting plan for electing county supervisors, calling the proposal ''a nonsensical distortion'' and insensitive to minority members.

LEAD: The hazards and delights of cultural interchange were on abundant display on Friday at Alice Tully Hall, where the Philip Glass Ensemble performed his score for a showing of the otherwise silent film ''Powaqqatsi.'' The title, a Hopi word, means ''an entity, a way of life, that consumes the life forces of other beings in order to further its own life.
LEAD: Florida officials today approved clemency for an 81-year-old man convicted of shooting his ailing wife in what he said was a mercy killing, and he is to be freed from prison on Thursday.
LEAD: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it was forming a sports marketing company called Time Warner Sports to expand the corporation's sports ventures and acquire a broad array of sports rights.

LEAD: Phil David Fine, a lawyer who played an important role in several major development projects in Massachusetts, died Tuesday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 64 years old and lived in Boston.

LEAD: THE death of a family pet may be a child's first experience with the loss of a person or animal he loves. In some ways it is more emotionally complex than coping with the death of a human being; for instance, the animal may be younger than the child, or may have been with the family since before the child was born.

LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about new-home sales in June misidentified an economist and, because of an editing error, misidentified the Congressionally chartered corporation for which he works. The economist is Mark Obrinsky; he is on the staff of the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, not the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac.

LEAD: A violent, five-day drama that saw the Prime Minister and half of the Cabinet taken hostage by heavily armed Muslim militants ended peacefully today when 112 gunmen and their religious leader laid down their weapons and freed their remaining 46 hostages.

LEAD: When Dave Zawatson went to grammar school in Cleveland, he was left-handed, but the teachers at St. Angela's Catholic School insisted that everybody do everything right-handed. That hard-learned lesson seems to be coming in handy for for the Jets' offensive lineman at training camp these days.

LEAD: Six sailors were drowned yesterday after their freighter, her lifeboats and rafts too poorly maintained to use, was pummeled by Hurricane Bertha's 90-mile-an-hour winds and broke up in the Atlantic about 400 miles east of New York.

LEAD: PAUL KARNER of Restoration and Design Studio said he would restore ''anything in metal,'' from knives and candlesticks to sterling silver hand mirrors. Mr. Karner also repairs many small items with sentimental value. ''But they say it was their grandmother's and they want it,'' he said. So he fixes it.

LEAD: Air traffic controllers took the unusual step Tuesday night of declaring a fuel emergency on an Avianca Airlines flight headed for Kennedy International Airport because of confusion over how much fuel it had left, one of the controllers and Federal aviation officials said last night.

LEAD: Robert C. Stempel, the new chairman of the General Motors Corporation, promised on his first day in office today that the auto maker would not pursue a strategy of reorganization like the one that caused turmoil in the world's biggest auto maker in the 1980's.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Governments of East and West Germany and their main political parties reached basic agreement today on holding a national election in a unified country on Dec. 2.

LEAD: The glare from all those bright lights that have followed Nolan Ryan and the Texas Rangers for the last two weeks will shine elsewhere for a while. The questions about his past and his future will not come so often, and from so many strangers.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: This column is an appeal for a special kind of help from Americans who do not live in the big cities - for those of us who do.

LEAD: Doug Jennings, a pinch-hitter, broke up a pitching duel with a run-scoring single in the 11th inning and Dave Stewart went the distance as the Oakland A's defeated the Seattle Mariners, 1-0, today.
LEAD: Interest rates resumed their decline yesterday as prices of Treasury securities rallied on new evidence of a weakening economy.
LEAD: ''As far as the Government is concerned, it's unconditional surrender.'' - Gregory Shaw, a Trinidadian spokesman. [A1:5.]

LEAD: In August, people come to Saratoga for more than the horses, or the waters (mineral). They come to soak up the romance of the track: Costume balls, tip sheets, barber shop quartets, racing forms, champagne breakfasts at the morning workout, sunshine and a glimpse of Mellons, Vanderbilts and Whitneys being put through their social paces.
LEAD: THE New Math is ''so simple, so very simple, that only a child can do it,'' the satirist Tom Lehrer sang in the 1960's.

LEAD: A monthly survey released yesterday by the National Association of Purchasing Management indicated a steep decline for the nation's manufacturing economy in July, reversing a three-month growth trend. Economists said the survey gave more credence to assessments that the economy is slowing, perhaps slipping into a recession.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation confirmed today that it would spin off its low-technology businesses - typewriters, keyboards and personal printers - into a new subsidiary. Clayton & Dubilier Inc., a New York leveraged buyout firm, is to become the primary owner of the new unit, the company said.

LEAD: The widely disputed exhibition of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe opened in Boston today without serious protest after a highly unusual broadcast of the show's most sexually explicit pictures on Tuesday night by the local affiliate of the Public Broadcasting Service.

LEAD: Richard G. Darman, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, has agreed to release $5 million to let the Social Security Administration hold hearings next month for people seeking disability benefits, White House officials said today.
LEAD: A French industrial group, Chargeurs S.A., today bought Pathe-Cinema S.A., the film company that the Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti tried to buy earlier this year.

LEAD: The Omnicom Group said second-quarter earnings rose 16 percent, to $17.4 million, or 67 cents a share, from $15.1 million, or 58 cents a share, in the period last year. Revenues rose 24 percent, to $298.5 million, from $241.7 million in the 1989 period.

LEAD: Executives of Ratners Group P.L.C., which is trying to acquire Kay Jewelers Inc. for about $410 million, met yesterday to reconsider the terms of its offer to Kay stockholders and bondholders. The company's plans were not disclosed, and no announcement about the offer was made last night.

LEAD: Eric Lansdown chisels grand visions down to manageable size. He builds fancy miniature houses endowed with architecturally correct details. The houses come complete with painted ivy and trees in front, stains and chipped bricks - in short, ''everything but cracked windows,'' he said.

LEAD: A former business associate of Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican candidate for governor, has filed a lawsuit charging that Mr. Rinfret went back on a promise to give him a share in his investment businesses.

LEAD: Sidney Brill, a civil engineer and the owner of a public-works construction company, died on Monday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Bay Shore, L.I. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan. He died of lung cancer, his family said.

LEAD: WHEN it comes to global bond investing, sometimes all that matters is getting the currency right. In July, the principal determinant of profit was investing in bonds denominated in almost any currency other than the dollar.
LEAD: Elderly people who own pets visit their physicians less often than those who do not have pets, and dog owners have the fewest visits of all, a study has found.
LEAD: Radio Free Europe began broadcasting directly from Prague today after 40 years of transmitting news to Czechoslovakia from abroad.

LEAD: The Daily News asked a Federal court yesterday to stop a State Board of Inquiry from examining negotiations between the paper and its unions.

LEAD: JULIA ROBERTS didn't exactly love Abbeville, S.C., where she worked on a film recently. In an interview in this month's Rolling Stone, the actress, who starred in the film ''Pretty Woman,'' called the town ''horribly racist'' and ''living hell.''

LEAD: LINING a closet with cedar paneling helps keep moths and insects away from woolen clothes. Cedar's aroma, which is pleasant to people, is a repellent to insects. Cedar is also safer than chemical repellents, like mothballs, which can be accidentally eaten by children.
LEAD: Four innocent children killed in nine days in New York City, by bullets fired from semiautomatic weapons but intended for someone else.
LEAD: Iraqi troops crossed the Kuwait border today and penetrated deeply into the country and into Kuwait's capital city, senior Administration officials said late Wednesday.

Grove. But by midnight E.S.T., one more name had joined Cy and Lefty on that rarified roster - L. Nolan Ryan.

LEAD: Even before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, America's energy situation was looking increasingly ominous. Fact one: Imports accounted for a record 50 percent of the oil consumed by the U.S. during the first half of 1990. Fact two: The oil cartel, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, this week raised its target price for oil by 17 percent.

LEAD: Commuters on the Staten Island ferry began paying a quarter more for the ride yesterday, prompting a few to grumble and groan but leaving most still satisfied that the fare, even raised to 50 cents a round trip, remained one of the best bargains in New York.

BRENNAN 3d, the retired Justice's son, who is a lawyer in New Jersey.

LEAD: The United States and the European Community renewed pressure today on Japan to import more foreign goods.

LEAD: Allianz A.G., Europe's largest insurance company, announced yesterday that it would buy the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, the American property and casualty insurer, for $3.3 billion in cash.

LEAD: When President Bush gathered with Congressional leaders in the Rose Garden last Aug. 9 for the signing of the savings and loan bailout bill, he triumphantly declared, ''This legislation will safeguard and stabilize America's financial system and put in place permanent reforms so these problems will never happen again.

LEAD: Does New York State's social studies curriculum fairly reflect the nation's racial and cultural diversity? The question has produced passionate political response. Sensibly, the State Board of Regents has now approved a committee of teachers, administrators and scholars who can offer a scholarly answer.

LEAD: Rumors swept through Wall Street today that two of the nation's largest general merchants -Sears, Roebuck & Company and Montgomery Ward & Company - had begun merger talks but had terminated them.

LEAD: One day after the Senate ended years of deadlock and approved a major bill to tighten campaign finance laws, the House of Representatives found itself mired today in a dispute among Democrats who feared that the House version could damage their re-election prospects.
LEAD: Friday RICHARD REDUX

LEAD: The recent resignation of the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Atlanta came about after he was confronted with evidence of an ''intimate relationship'' with a single 27-year-old Atlanta singer, church officials said today.

LEAD: Orders to factories for manufactured goods declined 1.5 percent in June, the Commerce Department said today. It was the third time this year that the monthly total of orders declined from the month before.

LEAD: Calling Health and Human Services Secretary Louis W. Sullivan ''a disgrace to his race,'' the chairman of a Congressional health committee harshly criticized Dr. Sullivan today for opposing proposals for Federally sponsored national health insurance.

LEAD: Midland Bank P.L.C. said it was cutting 4,000 jobs from its work force of 33,000 by the end of 1991 through attrition and voluntary departures. Midland also reported a profit of about $:22 million, or about $40.5 million, in the first half of the year. That compared with a net loss of $:383 million in the corresponding period in 1989, when the bank raised its provisions for bad loans to third world countries.

LEAD: R. H. Macy & Company, in a move dors about the retailer's financial strength, said yesterday that it had sold a 1 percent stake in the company for a price that values its equity at $1.5 billion - about four times what investors paid when the company was taken private four years ago.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Move over, Mario Cuomo. George Mitchell, the mild-mannered, sober-minded and rarely quotable Senate majority leader, is emerging as the Democrat the Republicans love to hate.
LEAD: Ed Cunningham is 6 feet 7 3/4 inches tall and weighs 296 pounds. He says he does not know his jacket size because he has to have his clothes made to order.

LEAD: A 15-year-old was shot and critically wounded early yesterday in the Bronx when a gunman opened fire on a group of friends with whom she was standing in a park on the Grand Concourse, the police said.

LEAD: DURING the last six years, New York City has been treated to several outstanding, and sometimes provocative, exhibitions of African art, thanks to the Museum of Modern Art, the Brooklyn Museum and especially the Center for African Art. Now the American Museum of Natural History is being heard from, and its ''African Reflections: Art From Northeastern Zaire'' is equal to the best of its predecessors.
LEAD: Many Hats, but Just One Jacket

LEAD: * Cigna Corp., Philadelphia, a holding company for insurance and health-care subsidiaries, named Dennis H. Ferro managing director of its international investment division. The company also named Nicholas Taylor managing director of its international investment advisers unit.

LEAD: Chauffeur-driven cars, drinks by the swimming pool, year-round tans and bottomless expense accounts may not be the happy fate of most American expatriates. But to a good many people back home at least, those are just some of the privileges they think are enjoyed by their fellow Americans abroad.

LEAD: Within the art world, there has been a tendency for some time to approach the art of other cultures in one of two ways. One way is based on an assumption that aspects of art are universal and that what one culture values in art is a standard by which the art of other cultures can be measured. Behind the second is a conviction that other cultures are so radically different from our own that no common ground exists and that any attempt to measure the art of those cultures in anything other than its own terms is unjust.

LEAD: THE revolutions in Eastern Europe have been driven by people's conviction that their standard of living rotted under Communism. You cannot find evidence of this decay in the official data. ''Under the Communist regimes, data have simply been faked in some cases, and collected on a very inadequate conceptual basis in other cases,'' according to David Lipton and Jeffrey Sachs, American economists who have been serving as economic advisers to Solidarity in Poland.
LEAD: Past Into Present

LEAD: When a Spanish photographer tried to snap a photo of MADONNA jogging in Barcelona, her chief bodyguard, MARCUS JOHNSON, got rough. But later he went to the newsroom of El Periodico de Cataluna to apologize in person to the photographer, JUAN VALGANON, the paper reported yesterday. Mr. Valganon was bruised in the encounter.
LEAD: Because of the Madison Avenue Street Fair, Madison Avenue will be closed on Sunday from 37th to 50th Streets from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.
LEAD: * Boeing Co., Seattle, received orders from Linhas Aereas de Mozambique, a Mozambique airline, for two jet transports valued at $117 million.
LEAD: Credit cards are now being tried in fast-food outlets, grocery stores, movie theaters and other places that have historically not accepted them. And that is music to Hatim A. Tyabji's ears.

LEAD: Eleo Pomare, a provocative choreographer on the New York dance scene for three decades, was honored last Friday evening at the Fiorello Festival of performances at the Fiorello H. LaGuardia High School of Music and the Arts.

LEAD: More than 50 percent of the nation's employees with health insurance provided by their employer now work for companies that design and insure their own health benefits, a sharp increase over the past 15 years, an insurance industry group reports.

LEAD: When hearings get under way next month on the nomination of Judge David Souter to the Supreme Court, it would be a relief if senators and others dropped from their vocabularies the weary slogans applied to judges in recent years. We have had enough of ''activist'' and ''originalist'' and the like.
LEAD: The Senate today unanimously approved legislation that is designed to prevent oil spills and to insure that oil companies and carriers pay for damage.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Rolling Stones will perform in Prague for the first time because PRESIDENT VACLAV HAVEL of Czechoslovakia wants to meet MICK JAGGER. The concert is scheduled for Aug. 18 as part of festivities marking the country's freedom from Communist rule.
LEAD: The Dinkins administration plans to provide more testing, treatment and housing for homeless people with AIDS under a broad new program to be announced today.

LEAD: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds tumbled yesterday, sending interest rates up, after Iraq invaded Kuwait. The invasion raised the specter of a resurgence of oil-fueled inflation, which would undermine the values of bonds and other fixed-income securities.

LEAD: Under an agreement announced yesterday by the Boston Celtics, Dino Radja of Yugoslavia will play for Il Messaggero Roma rather than the Celtics for the next two seasons, in return for an undisclosed amount of cash. The Italian team had announced earlier that the 6-foot-11-inch forward had signed a five-year agreement, for terms that the team did not disclose.

LEAD: ''Captains Courageous,'' a musical by Patrick Cook and Frederick Freyer from the novel by Rudyard Kipling, will be given the first of three readings, with music, at 8 P.M. tomorrow in the Rose Barns Theater at the O'Neill Theater Center, 305 Great Neck Road, Waterford, Conn.

LEAD: As with Gabriel Garcia Marquez's other novels, ''Chronicle of a Death Foretold'' (''Cronica de una Muerte Anunciada'') is suffused with sensuality and mysticism. Despite the absence of suspense, it is a compelling mystery with the author as investigator trying to understand an event that has become an obsession.
LEAD: This has always been a country with a cultivated eye for intrigue and conspiracy, where truth is rarely so careless as to lie on the surface and even the rain does not fall by chance.
LEAD: A NUMBER of analysts are recommending food stocks to investors, or in stock market parlance ''overweight'' their portfolios with those issues.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 521 money market mutual funds increased $800.1 million, to $395.42 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 168 institutional funds decreased by $100,000, to $97.97 billion. The assets of the 251 general purpose funds were up by $541.5 million, to $136.44 billion.

LEAD: Al Unser Sr. broke his right collarbone and right thigh and damaged some ribs yesterday in a crash while practicing for Sunday's Marlboro 500 at the Michigan International Speedway in Brooklyn, Mich. Unser was expected to have surgery later in the day.(AP)

LEAD: The Barnes Foundation of Merion, Pa., has named Richard H. Glanton as its new president. The foundation administers a major collection of 19th-and 20th-century Impressionist and post-Impressionist art.

LEAD: After months of denials from Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. that he had ever used illegal drugs before his arrest in January, his lawyer's acknowledgment to the jury on Wednesday that the Mayor had been an occasional cocaine user may have seemed a startling admission.
LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.'s food sector has put Peter M. Thompson in charge of its division that oversees Pillsbury International, Haagen-Dazs and Grand Met Foodservice U.S.A.
LEAD: O'Neal as Conscience

LEAD: Net Income Percent Apr.-June Change 1990 From '89 Bear Stearns Cos. $ 33,500,000 -29.6 Coastal Corp. 22,100,000 -37.4 Continental Airlines Inc. 96,800,000 +201.6 Halliburton Co. 47,100,100 +50.0 Horsham Corp. 19,500,000 +45.5 Jostens Inc. 34,100,000 +9.6 Meredith Corp.
LEAD: A 14-year-old from Queens was shot and killed on Wednesday night in an argument over a moped, the police said.

LEAD: The signs begin nearly 100 miles out, brightly painted billboards spaced at irregular intervals alongside Interstate 94 as it winds north from Illinois: ''Scenic Boat Tours.'' ''Tommy Barlett Thrill Shows.'' ''Visit Wis. Dells.''
LEAD: Voters in every Congressional district in America have reason to watch how their representatives vote on the campaign reform bill likely to come up in the House today.
LEAD: The Iraqi Invasion
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said that all telephone service between the United States and Kuwait was cut off without explanation yesterday at 6:37 P.M. Eastern daylight time.

LEAD: An investigation ordered by the Covenant House board of directors concludes that the Rev. Bruce Ritter, the charity's founder and longtime president, engaged in sexual misconduct with young men living at Covenant House shelters for runaway youths, according to people who have read the investigation's report.

LEAD: The civil war in El Salvador comes home with predictable violence in ''La Misma Sangre'' (''The Same Blood''), a play by Carlos Velis presented at the Public Theater as part of the Festival Latino.

LEAD: Mark Gubicza, the Kansas City Royals pitcher, had arthroscopic surgery yesterday to repair a tear in his right rotator cuff. The right-hander is expected to recover in time for spring training, said Steve Joyce, the team physician, who did the surgery.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: In freezing Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets in the United States, President Bush has fenced off an estimated $30 billion from President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Government analysts say.
LEAD: Communist rebels today released a kidnapped Peace Corps volunteer and a Japanese aid worker but warned the United States and Japan to stay out of the Philippine insurgency.
LEAD: This weekend brings a pop superstar, a song stylist and ''Beauty and the Beast,'' as well as Northern Ireland, Coney Island and Cambodia.

LEAD: The National Gallery of Art received nearly $3 million yesterday from funds established by the late LILA ACHESON WALLACE, co-founder of Reader's Digest. The money, $2.9 million, was given by GEORGE V. GRUNE, who is doubly involved with the gift as chairman of the Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund and chairman and chief executive of Reader's Digest.

LEAD: The United Nations Security Council voted overwhelmingly early this morning to condemn Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, demanding the immediate, unconditional withdrawal of all of Baghdad's forces from the tiny Persian Gulf nation, and threatening to invoke mandatory sanctions if it does not promptly comply.

LEAD: Presented with tons of documents every year and not enough room to store them, state court administrators are embracing computer technology that they hope will eliminate the need for case files.

LEAD: ''This is the first post-cold-war crisis in the economically dependent world. With the end of the East-West game, small countries can act with impunity to rearrange the neighborhood.'' - Judith Kipper, a Middle East specialist, on Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. [A8:3.]
LEAD: Calling Prime Minister V. P. Singh ''spineless,'' India's ousted Deputy Prime Minister today called on millions of his followers and farmers to pour into the capital in a show of strength.

LEAD: As the House of Representatives opened debate today on a major civil rights bill, Democratic leaders vowed to reject revisions that backers say would be the only way to avert a Presidential veto.

LEAD: Participants in the 15th Annual Convention of the National Association of Black Journalists spoke today of reaching out to break what they described as the profession's final barrier, to reach the top levels of management and media ownership.
LEAD: After a Senate hearing tonight, Wendy Lee Gramm, the chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, was expected to be reconfirmed for another five-year term.

LEAD: Lee Trevino will play in the P.G.A. Championship next week in Shoal Creek, Ala., but without wearing shirts bearing the Toyota name after the Toyota Motor Corporation pulled its commercials from the telecast in protest of exclusionary membership practices at the Shoal Creek Country Club, the tournament site.
LEAD: The House today overwhelmingly approved legislation that would let airports levy a new tax on airline tickets of up to $12 on a round trip to help pay for improving and expanding the airports.
LEAD: President Bush said today that the nation's armed forces could be cut by 25 percent over the next five years, as America adapts its military strategy to suit the new era of spreading democracy.

LEAD: Could country music stars like Willie Nelson or Waylon Jennings possibly be confused with Federal Judge Stephen Trott? Would Johnny Cash or Kris Kristofferson want to palm themselves off as Judge Trott? And will the real ''Highwaymen'' please stand up and sing?
LEAD: A study of 337 Louisiana families suggests that there is a genetic component to lung cancer, researchers say.

LEAD: When Bouley was first reviewed in 1987, shortly after it opened in TriBeCa, I noted that the restaurant had ''the potential for greatness.'' Overstriving and wobbly execution, though, resulted in too many near misses and a two-star rating. Today, though, Bouley displays remarkable poise and self-confidence.
LEAD: Theodore Birnbaum, a New York business executive, died on Wednesday at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 73 years old and lived in Ossining, N.Y.

LEAD: Dr. Margaret Brown, a former president of the Panzer College of Physical Education and Hygiene in East Orange, N.J., died on Monday at the Hospital Center at Orange. She was 98 years old and lived in Maplewood, N.J.
LEAD: For nearly 45 years, public television and radio broadcasting in West Berlin and East Germany followed the dictates of the cold war.

LEAD: Paula Robison will be the soloist in a program of Baroque flute and piccolo works in the Spanish Courtyard at Caramoor, Girdle Ridge Road in Katonah, N.Y., tonight at 9. The program includes four Vivaldi concertos, a Concerto in D by C. P. E. Bach, and Jacques Hotteterre's ''Echoes'' for solo flute.

LEAD: To understand the swift collapse of East German Communism, see Leipzig. There one can dine in the fine restaurant in the Gewandhaus symphony hall, facing what is still called Karl-Marx-Platz, the epicenter of the upheaval that ended four decades of Marxist rule.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: A Federal magistrate ordered three European banks today to provide records of Manuel Noriega's accounts believed to contain millions of dollars to his lawyers. The ousted Panamanian dictator says he needs the money for his legal defense on drug smuggling charges.

LEAD: Although art galleries will never replace confessionals, many contemporary artists have taken to using their personal experiences as the primary subject matter of their art. This can be seen as a reflection of what the historian Christopher Lasch has called the culture of narcissism, or else as a reaction to the sardonic emphasis on media experience in the art of the 1980's.
LEAD: The other day, West Germany's deputy chief delegate to the United Nations walked up to the front door of a forbidding gray mansion at 58 Park Avenue, rang the bell and was admitted.

LEAD: CPC International Inc., a big but relatively unfamiliar company behind a host of famous food brands, yesterday named its president, Charles R. Shoemate, to the top post of chief executive, as well.

LEAD: Israeli leaders publicly condemned the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait today and warned that it would contribute to a further destabilization of the Middle East, but they also appeared relieved by the move.

LEAD: MYRNA LOY became 85 years old yesterday and she celebrated among friends in Manhattan at what was billed as a Montana barbecue. The host was JAMES KOTSILIBAS-DAVIS, an old friend who was co-author of her biography.

LEAD: An article on July 26 about Soviet staff members of the United Nations Secretariat misstated the position of Gail Bindley-Taylor, vice president of the United Nations staff union. She said the status of the Soviet staff members was confused; she did not say they were ''secretive.''

LEAD: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait ushers in a new alignment in which Iraqis, Iranians and Palestinian hard-liners appear to share an interest in subduing the oil-rich monarchies of the region and challenging United States influence in the Arab world.

LEAD: Parades, music, eye-popping costumes, dancing in the streets: carnival celebrations are the unmistakable signature of African culture from Lagos to New Orleans to Rio de Janeiro. New York City's carnivals grew up more recently. In Brooklyn, the West Indian-American Carnival Association puts on an annual festival during Labor Day weekend, and since 1985 the Caribbean Cultural Center has presented a Pan-American carnival in

LEAD: SPIKE LEE is an exhilarating mix of brilliance and bravado, of artist, businessman and preacher. In his stylized visions of our racially tense society - the small-scale sexual comedy ''She's Gotta Have It,'' the inventive musical ''School Daze'' and the astounding political and moral drama ''Do the Right Thing'' - he dares viewers and the Hollywood establishent to keep up with his honesty and humor, his passion and visual flair.
LEAD: New Venture in Miami

LEAD: For more than a decade, anyone with doubts about who ran this country could lift his eyes to the Managua skyline, where giant letters on a hillside spelled ''F.S.L.N.,'' the initials in Spanish of the Sandinista National Liberation Front. Recently, however, the famous letters were altered to form a different message: ''Fin'' -or simply, ''The End.

LEAD: The tide of violence in New York City in the last two weeks - four children killed by stray gunfire, an advertising executive shot dead in the West Village, two cab drivers murdered, a young couple bludgeoned in Central Park - continued yesterday as officials struggled to respond to growing fears.

LEAD: A retired New York City policeman killed a suspected burglar early today before dying of stab wounds, the state police said. The retired officer, Alex Bodnar, 49 years old, died after interrupting what investigators believe was a botched burglary by Ronald Cummings, 29, of Newburgh.

LEAD: Joe Torre made his home debut as manager of the St. Louis Cardinals tonight and for a while outmaneuvered the Mets in a war of strategy. But just when he needed three outs to win, the Mets mounted a dramatic rally, scored three runs in the ninth inning off Lee Smith and snatched the game from Torre's
LEAD: A strong earthquake jolted the Iranian province of Khuzestan today, a little more than a month after an earthquake in the north killed 40,000 people.

LEAD: Faced with an undeclared ethnic war in her home province of Sind and a tense standoff with India over the disputed territory of Kashmir, Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto heads next week into a confrontation with her political opponents on Pakistan's most volatile issue: religion.

LEAD: In the Northeast, economic problems have led to a rash of residenatial mortgage foreclosures by commercial banks and other lenders. But conditions in New York and Boston are not typical of what is happening in some other parts of the nation, even though real-estate markets in most places continue to weaken and bank failures are at a near record.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''The violence in America is completely different: at home it's Catholic and Protestant, but here it's drug related,'' said Peter Evans, one of 450 children from Northern Ireland who ended their summers in New York yesterday.
LEAD: Justice Thurgood Marshall was admitted for observation to the Bethesda Naval Medical Center today after a fall in Chicago on Thursday.

LEAD: Put yourself back there, in that irretrievable New York of 55 summers ago. Kate Smith is on the radio. Lou Gehrig is at first base. Bob Hope plays the Palace. For $1.65 you can catch a movie, a newsreel and five vaudeville acts.
LEAD: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is known throughout Iraq and the Arab world by his first name, which means ''One Who Confronts.''

LEAD: At 34 years of age, Mark Smith calls himself something of a ''spiritual wanderer.'' Mr. Smith, who drives a delivery truck for New York Newsday, is a trained catechist in the Roman Catholic faith of his upbringing. He has also, he says, ''been in and out of Protestant churches.''
LEAD: At a time when the whole of Eastern Europe is changing, some political leaders in India continue to hold fast to socialist ideals.

LEAD: Kristine Parks MacDermott, a geologist, and Michael James Arena, a software engineer, were married yesterday at the Community Church of Mountain Lakes in Mountain Lakes, N.J., by the Rev. William Tolley, a Congregational minister.

LEAD: The chairman of a health subcommittee told the House today that he should not have called the Secretary of Health and Human Services ''a disgrace to his race'' when he criticized the Secretary's positions on Thursday.

LEAD: Manhattan prosecutors will impose tougher plea-bargaining procedures on defendants caught in a police drug crackdown in Washington Heights, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan said yesterday.
LEAD: Cars of domestically produced cars rose 8.4 percent in late July, helped by sharply higher sales for the General Motors Corporation, the industry leader.
LEAD: Sixteen people have been arrested on charges of selling hundreds of counterfeit state automobile inspection stickers to motorists.

LEAD: The House of Representatives approved a bill late tonight aimed at slowing the rapidly rising costs of Congressional campaigns after a rancorous debate in which some lawmakers questioned whether the legislation would do any good.

LEAD: Summer offers plums in staggering variety. Most are sweet and juicy, but some, notably the Santa Rosa, can be tart and astringent near the pit. Plums are ripe when the skin yields to pressure but is not soft. Clingstone varieties have pits that cling to the flesh; pits in freestone plums do not.
LEAD: For the economic policy makers in the Bush Administration, Congress and the Federal Reserve, Iraq's invasion of Kuwait creates a new storm in an already unsettled atmosphere.

LEAD: Of more than 100,000 votes cast on Thursday, only 158 separated the top two candidates today in a Republican primary race for the right to challenge Senator Al Gore in November's general election.

LEAD: * A&B Hawaii Inc., a subsidiary of Alexander & Baldwin Inc., Honolulu, an ocean transportation company, closed the purchases last week of four commercial properties for a total of almost $55.9 million.
LEAD: Tamil separatists stormed two mosques in eastern Sri Lanka and sprayed Muslim worshipers with machine gunfire, killing at least 93 people and wounding 70, military officials said today.
LEAD: President Bush today nominated Richard Y. Roberts, a former chief of staff of Senator Richard C. Shelby, Democrat of Alabama, to the vacant seat on the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a music review in Weekend yesterday about Monday's opening of the New York Philharmonic's season of free concerts in parks gave incorrect information for subsequent concerts.

LEAD: America has just passed a milestone. Unfortunately it's on the way downhill. Last year, for the first time, the United States invested less in plant and equipment than Japan did, even though Japan's economy is half the size. The disparity suggests how grossly America is neglecting its future.
LEAD: A 59-year-old dairy farmer in the central New York village of Munnsville was indicted today on a charge of suffocating his brother.
LEAD: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a bill that would authorize $875 million next year to provide health care to people with AIDS in cities and states hardest hit by the epidemic.

LEAD: Stotler Group Inc., a financially troubled commodity firm based in Chicago, announced last night that an involuntary Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition had been filed against it by three parties that say they are creditors.
LEAD: Following are excerpts from the Statement of the Oversight Committee of Covenant House:

LEAD: Thomas M. Macioce, a lawyer and former chairman and chief executive officer of the Allied Stores Corporation, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 71 years old and lived in Brookville, L.I.

LEAD: A majority of declarers, faced with a choice, will prefer a clear-cut line of play to a foggy one. In the diagramed deal from the New York Summer Regional in Manhattan on July 14, South opted for fog and was vindicated.

LEAD: J. RICHARD MUNRO and DR. JOSHUA LEDERBERG are new trustees of the National Museum of Health and Medicine Foundation Inc. Mr. Monro, former chairman and chief executive of Time Inc. and chairman of the executive committee of Time Warner Inc., and Dr. Lederberg, a Nobel laureate and exiting president of the Rockefeller University, joined the board of trustees last week.
LEAD: Thomas J. Ford, a dentist in Brookline, Mass., patented a device this week to protect whales and dolphins from becoming grounded in shallow water.

LEAD: Pushing to complete action on a $289 billion military programs bill, the Senate today rejected an amendment that would have overturned a virtual ban on abortions at American military hospitals overseas.

LEAD: Although it is too early to gauge the wisdom of the investors who made sudden market moves - trading for oil shares or dumping stocks - almost as soon as Iraq invaded Kuwait, such moves are generally a mistake for individuals. Patience is more likely to be rewarded, as it has been since the crash of October 1987.

LEAD: The advisory council to the National Endowment for the Arts voted overwhelmingly today to recommend the elimination of an anti-obscenity pledge that artists and arts institutions have been asked to sign before they can receive grants from the endowment.

LEAD: Lee Konitz, who has long been one of jazz's more idiosyncratic alto saxophonists, is also one of the least direct. At his first set on Wednesday night at Condon's, where he will be playing through tonight, Mr. Konitz did everything he could to avoid stating a complete melody; instead he hinted, placing tatters of a song against the bluster of the rhythm section.

LEAD: Responding to the recent controversy over membership practices at Shoal Creek Country Club in Alabama, site of the P.G.A. Championship next week, the PGA Tour today announced a new policy intended to insure that none of its 120 yearly tournaments will take place at private clubs that discriminate by race, religion or sex.

LEAD: The prosecutor in the Howard Spira extortion case asked baseball to postpone its investigation of George Steinbrenner because he did not want the inquiry to uncover any information ''helpful'' to Spira, the head of the investigation said yesterday.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson called on the Bush Administration today to move quickly, diplomatically and militarily if necessary, ''to secure an end to the military aggression by Iraq.'' In a telephone interview, Mr. Jackson assailed the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, and said, ''He must know he has pushed us over the line and that his insistence on the occupation of Kuwait and the threat against Saudi Arabia is an extreme act of provocation that would be met with force.
LEAD: Because of the Madison Avenue Street Fair, Madison Avenue will be closed tomorrow from 37th to 50th Streets from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

LEAD: Stocks took one of their biggest tumbles of the year yesterday amid widespread anxiety and uncertainty about the Middle East, but the close showed a solid recovery from the far lower levels earlier in the day.

LEAD: Bess Goodykoontz, an educator who served as Assistant United States Commissioner of Education in the 1930's and 40's, died Sunday at her daughter's home in South Newfane, Vt. She was 95 years old.
LEAD: Lava from Kilauea Volcano has closed the Kalapana Black Sand Beach, one of the island's most popular beaches.

LEAD: Minna Schrag and David Ira Goldblatt, partners in the New York law firm of Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn, were married yesterday by Judge Whitman Knapp of Federal District Court in his chambers in Manhattan.
LEAD: Government troops and guerrillas loyal to one of Liberia's two rival rebel leaders fired rockets and shells today in block-by-block fighting for the Liberian capital.

LEAD: Complaints about sexual contacts between the Rev. Bruce Ritter and residents at Covenant House were circulating for almost 20 years and were referred at least twice to senior staff members at the charity and the priest's Franciscan superiors, a report released yesterday said.

LEAD: Saddam Hussein of Iraq has answered with a roar the long, dithering argument over whether it was wiser to indulge him or try to isolate and block him. That is why his blitzkrieg invasion of Kuwait, proving his insatiable ambition, has led so many European commentators to remember Hitler. The same kind of argument went on through the 1930's, until it was too late.
LEAD: The Loral Corporation signed a definitive agreement yesterday for the purchase of the Ford Motor Company's aerospace unit for $715 million in cash.

LEAD: The Denver Nuggets yesterday acquired Orlando Woolridge, a forward, from the Los Angeles Lakers for Denver's No. 2 choices in the 1993 and 1995 National Basketball Association drafts, the Nuggets announced yesterday in Denver.

LEAD: Some members of the Federal Trade Commission have said that provisions of the five-year contract between the College Football Association and ABC Sports could violate Federal antitrust laws, The Dallas Morning News reported yesterday.

LEAD: International 2-7 Iraqi forces wheeled into position for a possible attack on Saudi Arabia, while the U.S. and its allies continued to search without success for a way to force Iraq to pull back from its rapid conquest of Kuwait. Page 1 Iraq has deployed armored brigades close to the Saudi border and poured reinforcements into occupied Kuwait, Pentagon officials said.

LEAD: Armando Huerta arrived here two months ago from Mexico and, like many of the illegal aliens who continue to come to Southern California, went almost immediately to a seedy part of Alvarado Street near downtown Los Angeles.
LEAD: The Soviet Union and the United States joined tonight in urging a worldwide halt of arms deliveries to Iraq after what they called ''the brutal and illegal invasion of Kuwait.''
LEAD: Milton C. Sapinsley, a retired manufacturing executive, died Wednesday at his home in Providence, R.I. He was 94 years old.
LEAD: Doug Drabek's bid for a no-hitter was broken up by Sil Campusano with two out in the ninth inning tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 11-0.

LEAD: New York City transit police officers will be allowed to carry a more powerful handgun that has long been resisted by officials here because of its possible danger to the public, transit police officials announced yesterday.

LEAD: Before 1914, workers in New York State who were disabled on the job faced a stark choice: Sue or starve. Then the Legislature devised a no-fault insurance plan that covered medical costs and two-thirds of lost pay. Albany closed its 1990 session by voting a deserved increase in worker benefits. It now needs to restore the compensation system to financial soundness.

LEAD: A team of researchers at the University of Virginia Medical School in Charlottesville, Va., obtained a patent this week for a system of producing three-dimensional images that delineate hardening of the arteries.

LEAD: Dr. John Honan Keating Jr., a retired specialist in internal medicine and cardiology, died on Thursday at the Riverview Medical Center in Red Bank, N.J. He was 70 years old and lived in Locust, N.J.

LEAD: Toward the Radical Center A Karel Capek Reader Edited by Peter Kussi Various translators. Foreword by Arthur Miller. 412 pages. A Garrigue Book/ Catbird Press. $23.95, cloth; $12.95, paper. Three Novels Hordubal, Meteor, An Ordinary Life By Karel Capek Translated by M. and R. Weatherall.

LEAD: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday after two patrol officers in a squad car saw that he was carrying a large object hidden under his coat, which turned out to be a 9-millimeter machine pistol with a fully loaded 24-shot magazine, the police said.

LEAD: American support for a new lending organization intended to be the main conduit for assistance to Eastern Europe could be cut off by a dispute between Washington and the organization's management, Bush Administration officials warned today.
LEAD: International
LEAD: A swap of park land to let the BASF Corporation build a regional headquarters in the International Trade Center in Mount Olive was approved yesterday by the State House Commission.
LEAD: Bombings in the two largest cities in southern Lebanon killed 11 people and wounded 80 others on Thursday night, the police said today.
LEAD: It is a pleasure to welcome a season at the New York City Opera that heralds a period of promise if not yet much excitement.
LEAD: An Avianca jet that was given emergency clearance to land on Tuesday night was not dangerously low on fuel, an official at the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday.
LEAD: Lou Guida, harness racing's most successful owner, will seek his third Hambletonian victory in four years today when he sends out Embassy Lobell at the Meadowlands.

LEAD: There was a time, only a few decades ago, when ''La Boheme'' could be successfully staged as a vehicle for great Italianate voices. Dramatic plausibility, if any, was a bonus. Operagoers did not mind, apparently, if the roistering bohemians were overage, overfed and as nimble as arthritic water buffaloes.

LEAD: Commissioner Fay Vincent said yesterday it was ''much ado about very little,'' but a letter that George Steinbrenner sent to the Yankees' limited partners earlier this week raised questions about Steinbrenner's intentions.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: No one has been charged yet in the death of a Suffolk County narcotics detective who was killed when his car exploded in February. But Robert Horan, the Nassau County police officer who was originally called the chief suspect, is still the focus of the investigation, law-enforcement officials said.

LEAD: A Federal district judge has sentenced a former president of the Indianapolis League of Women Voters to nine years in prison for her role in a drug-smuggling ring allegedly operated by her sons.

LEAD: Fourteen American oil workers are missing in Kuwait, and there are reports that at least some of them may have been taken into custody by invading Iraqi troops and moved across the border into Iraq, Bush Administration officials said today.

LEAD: When Mark Bavaro is healthy, he may be the best tight end in professional football. But he has not been healthy since he tore a knee ligament early last season, a situation that creates major problems for the Giants.

LEAD: About 400,000 gallons of jet fuel gushed from a ruptured pipeline as it was being pumped into a storage terminal here early yesterday but workers and a dike kept it from reaching the Arthur Kill, officials said.

LEAD: Inspired by origami, the Oriental art of folding paper into ornamental objects, a researcher at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories has patented a method for solving large computational problems.

LEAD: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds continued to crumble and interest rates continued to rise yesterday, as more investors feared that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait would fuel a resurgence of inflation that would undermine the value of fixed-income debt issues.
LEAD: Coach Jerry Peirson was dismissed by Miami University yesterday for giving one of his basketball players a false grade in a class.
LEAD: The price of a seat on the New York Stock Exchange has fallen to its lowest level in more than five years.

LEAD: A millionaire who was arrested last month for spray painting For Sale signs he thought cheapened this wealthy suburb now says he's willing to pay to replace metal highway signs with more attractive wooden ones.

LEAD: New York's summer of pointless violence wears on, prompting frustration, fear and demands for action. Police Commissioner Lee Brown responds with a bold plan to expand the new police strategy known as community patrol. He deserves the chance to make it work.

LEAD: As Congress moved closer to a monthlong recess, the House of Representatives today approved a major civil rights bill despite threats by President Bush to veto the measure, which he contends would lead to job quotas.

LEAD: The United States asked other members of the Security Council today to endorse its proposal for a worldwide economic boycott of Iraq and occupied Kuwait until Baghdad agrees to withdraw its military forces from Kuwait.

LEAD: Carl Ekern, a former linebacker with the Los Angeles Rams, died of head injuries on Wednesday when the Jeep he was driving ran off a highway near the Kern County town of Ridgecrest, the California Highway Patrol said.

LEAD: Reacting to recent comments by Britain's Foreign Minister about Islam and Salman Rushdie's novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' an Iranian ayatollah said today that Britain had ''almost met'' Iran's conditions for restoring diplomatic relations.
LEAD: Harry Macklowe has quietly opened his elegant hotel, which towers 38 stories over Times Square. He hopes his stature will soar with it.
LEAD: A book review on Wednesday about ''The Bomb,'' by Makoto Oda, misidentified another novel about the atomic bombing of Hiroshima. It is Masuji Ibuse's ''Black Rain,'' not ''Hard Rain.''
LEAD: A state judge has approved the settlement of a lawsuit filed on behalf of mental patients who said they were denied adequate medical care at the state's largest mental hospital.

LEAD: Jim Palmer and Joe Morgan, two highly deserving and relatively uncontroversial ballplayers, are to be inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame tomorrow, but the focus of attention for many remains the moral issues of the candidacy of Pete Rose and Shoeless Joe Jackson.

LEAD: The poet JOHN ASHBERY and the Nigerian novelist CHINUA ACHEBE will share Bard College's Charles P. Stevenson Jr. chair in literature. The two writers will teach for the two next semesters at the college in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. The chair was previously held by the American novelist MARY McCARTHY, who died last

LEAD: To Freedom remained undefeated but failed to live up to his out-of-town notices while barely holding off Fighting Affair to win the $87,900 Saratoga Special by a head today at Saratoga Race Track.
LEAD: ''Governments that engage in blatant aggression must know that the international community cannot and will not acquiesce in nor facilitate aggression.'' - An American-Soviet statement. [6:3.]
LEAD: The Senate Agriculture Committee, in a voice vote, today approved the nomination of Wendy Lee Gramm to a second term as the head of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

LEAD: In a mostly grim report that took many analysts by surprise, the Labor Department said today that the nation's unemployment rate climbed three-tenths of a point in July, to 5.5 percent, in the biggest increase since early 1986.
LEAD: After two days of frantic maneuvering, Arab leaders agreed tonight to hold a summit meeting in Saudi Arabia this weekend to deal with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
LEAD: Soviet rescuers today brought ashore 21 survivors of the wreck of a cargo ship, and the saved sailors said they felt ''very lucky'' to have lived through Hurricane Bertha.
LEAD: The Federal jury weighing the 14 drug and conspiracy charges against Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. met for five and a half hours today without reaching a verdict.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A student who led a 53-day anti-Government rally has been freed after six weeks' detention, and he denied charges today that he incited protesters to violence.
LEAD: Iraq has deployed armored brigades close to the Saudi Arabian border and poured reinforcements into occupied Kuwait, Pentagon officials said today.

LEAD: Allegheny International Inc. said a Federal bankruptcy court had approved an agreement giving a New York investment group control of the company, which makes Sunbeam and Oster appliances. The court approval will allow the investors, Japonica Partners, to take control of Allegheny on Aug. 15. The deal, announced on Thursday by committees representing the company's creditors and shareholders, is contingent on

LEAD: With Iraq having overrun Kuwait, the crisis in the Persian Gulf appears to be turning into a struggle between the United States and Iraq for influence over Saudi Arabia and its vast oil reserves. The Iraqi takeover of

LEAD: Using her powers under an obscure state law, Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan yesterday placed such tight restrictions on money to be used to build a biomedical laboratory on the site of the old Audubon Ballroom that New York City officials said the project was effectively doomed.
LEAD: On a street corner in Brooklyn an empty chair stands surrounded by flowers where a young man used to sit and drink beer, before he was killed by a gunman in a passing car.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the indictment of Representative Floyd H. Flake incorrectly described Jamaica, Queens. It has a mix of low- and middle-income residents.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Japan and the Soviet Union, in their most intense round of diplomatic activity in recent years, tried and failed this week to narrow their differences on a 45-year territorial dispute that has stood in the way of improved relations.

LEAD: Hans Paul Verhoef, a Dutch AIDS patient who was imprisoned in Minnesota last year because he did not declare that he had the disease when he entered the country, died in the Netherlands on July 23. He was 33 years old and had been hospitalized since May. In April 1989 Mr. Verhoef landed at

LEAD: Riding a hefty lead in fund raising and in the public opinion polls, Clayton Williams, the Republican candidate for governor of Texas, has begun a series of pre-emptive strikes against his Democratic rival, Ann Richards.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Leaders of the Governments in Bonn and East Berlin moved today to speed up the formal unification of Germany by seven weeks with national elections on Oct. 14.

LEAD: TENNESSEE ERNIE FORD and GEORGE JONES are among the five nominees for the Country Music Hall of Fame. Also nominated Thursday by the Country Music Association were DON GIBSON, THE LOUVIN BROTHERS and WEBB PIERCE. Only one of the performers will be inducted at the association's award show Oct. 8.

LEAD: Turn to the back of most supermarket tabloids and some beauty magazines and you will find them - outlandish ads for miracle diet pills and aids that promise quick weight loss without any exercise or hard work.

LEAD: Pierre A. Rinfret today reneged on a campaign promise to release eight years of tax returns, releasing instead only his return for 1989. They showed that he had an adjusted gross income of $438,286 and paid $128,237 in Federal, state and New York City taxes.

LEAD: Choctaw Securities L.P. has engaged the New York branch of Creditanstalt-Bankverein to consider providing financing for a possible effort to gain control of Justin Industries Inc. Choctaw, an investment partnership in Kansas City, Mo., now controls 11.6 percent of Justin's 8.5 million shares outstanding.
LEAD: A new vaccine to protect dogs against Lyme disease has been granted conditional approval by the Federal Government and is available to dog owners in 43 states.
LEAD: A Ewing Township man who is alleged to have tapped into the state's computer system and tried to infiltrate a Federal computer was arrested yesterday, the state police said.

LEAD: Contemplating the grand sweep of Subic Bay, recognized for hundreds of years as one of the best-protected natural harbors in Southeast Asia, it is easy to see why the United States Navy wants to keep its access to the huge naval base here.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The mezzo-soprano Tatiana Troyanos will appear with the Waterloo Festival Orchestra on Aug. 11 at 8:30 P.M for the last concert of the Waterloo Festival, in the tent at Waterloo Village, Waterloo Road, Stanhope, N.J. Miss Troyanos will appear in place of Marilyn Horne, who canceled because of a scheduling problem.

LEAD: ''Hey, guys, we made it through Megadance,'' an audience member said as she filed out of Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night after the concluding program in the Serious Fun festival. It was a long night, with eight commissioned dances that together ran for about two and a half hours. The accent was on light entertainment, though, with one charming piece taking the evening's honors.

LEAD: Americans in the besieged capital of Kuwait spoke yesterday of a modern city transformed overnight into a war zone of rattling gunfire and explosions by Iraqi invaders who seized Government buildings, commandeered police cars and chatted on street corners as residents cowered behind locked doors.

LEAD: The University of Nevada-Las Vegas has filed a formal appeal seeking to overturn a National Collegiate Athletic Association ban that would prevent the Runnin' Rebels from defending their national basketball championship.

LEAD: For the first time since its parent company filed for bankruptcy in February, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. lost its ability to exercise independent control of purchases and sales of securities in its portfolio.

LEAD: A music review on Thursday about a performance by the Philip Glass Ensemble on July 27 at Alice Tully Hall misidentified a children's choir whose recorded music was used in presenting Mr. Glass's score for the film ''Powaqqatsi.'' It is the Hispanic Young People's Chorus from Brooklyn, not a South American group.

LEAD: Powerful Iraqi forces wheeled into position for a possible attack on Saudi Arabia today, while the United States and its allies continued to search, without discernible success, for a way to force Iraq to pull back from its rapid conquest of Kuwait on Thursday.

LEAD: How can a television news operation cover a war that is over before it begins and to which cameras are not invited? LEAD: In an effort to offset rising fuel costs, Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it would add an $8 fuel surcharge each way on all of its domestic tickets.

LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 272 to 154 by which the House of Representatives today approved a civil rights bill to combat job discrimination. A yes vote was a vote to pass the bill. Voting yes were 240 Democrats and 32 Republicans. Voting no were 12 Democrats and 142 Republicans. X denotes those not voting.

LEAD: Florence King Weichsel, co-founder and former director of the Children's Studio in Rye, N.Y., a private art school for children that closed in 1972, died yesterday at a convalescent home in Albuquerque, N.M. She was 82 years old and had moved to Albuquerque from White Plains five months ago.
LEAD: Dale Murphy, the seven-time All-Star outfielder for the Atlanta Braves, was traded to the Philadelphia Phillies tonight for Jeff Parrett, a relief pitcher, and two players to be selected later.

LEAD: Oil prices rose again yesterday and the stock market fell sharply in unusually volatile trading as investors feared that higher energy prices brought on by the turmoil in the Middle East could push an already weak American economy into recession.
LEAD: Tom Candiotti's junk was precious. His knuckleball was doing its contortions on its way to the plate and its dirty dancing in front of and behind it.
LEAD: Lucy Goldschmidt Moses, a philanthropist, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 103 years old.

LEAD: It's summertime and the airlines are sweating. The normally prosperous travel season is proving a disappointment for the industry, and as a result the airlines are offering discount fares, although with many restrictions, that are unusual at this time of year.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: 2 Germanys Agree To Rush Unification
LEAD: An obituary on Tuesday about Jimmy DeSana, a photographer, omitted the name of his companion.

LEAD: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.84 percent this week, down from 9.98 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.38 percent, down from 8.41 percent last week.

LEAD: Humans need to hate a little. It's too bad, but so is their compulsion to uglify everything that's beautiful. We are a superb species, all right, just not quite perfect. Since we must hate, the sensible thing is to hate in moderation. For this reason, I have always hated the New York Yankees.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: GOLF Zahringer and Baldwin Gain George Zahringer 3d and John Baldwin, two of the New York metropolitan area's most successful amateur golfers, won at the Metropolitan Amateur Championship yesterday at the Piping Rock club in Locust Valley, L.I., and advanced to a semifinal showdown today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: FRANCESCO GALLO, director of international operations for the Fiat Group, had the proud and worried look of an expectant father as he paced through the half-finished $1.3 billion assembly plant that Fiat is helping build here amid southern Poland's fields of hay and corn.

LEAD: LAST year, William F. and Ann Powers of Setauket, L.I., and their teen-age daughter spent July in a home in Brittany, while the owners of the French house stayed in the Powers home in Setauket. LEAD: LAWYERS AND THIEVES By Roy Grutman and Bill Thomas. 224 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

LEAD: George Steinbrenner, addressing his Olympic position publicly for the first time, said he would resign as a vice president of the United States Olympic Committee if committee leaders thought it was appropriate because of his banishment from the daily operations of the Yankees.

LEAD: BEFORE the eruptions in the Middle East sent the theorists back to their computer keyboards on Thursday, the Dow Jones utilities had been enjoying a rare market rally, gaining nearly 5 percent over the past two weeks. The reasons were largely defensive, analysts said. With the fearsome gyrations of the Dow industrials and the damage inflicted on the Dow transports by the recent decline in United
LEAD: A GOOD Stephen King yarn, aficionados of the wildly successful and prolific writer say, can be scary, funny and moving, psychically probing, even meaningful beyond mere menace.

LEAD: Flying to Senegal from New York, some visitors get their first glimpse of West Africa even before the coastline comes into view. Still miles from the port of Dakar, Senegal's capital city, the careful observer can spot wooden fishing canoes in bright primary colors bobbing like toys in the Atlantic waves far below.

LEAD: There is some first-rate writing coming from those whose muse is stimulated by their going afield with rod or gun. John Gierach's ''Sex, Death, and Fly-Fishing'' (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, 238 pages, paperback $8.95, hardcover $17.95) is one such effort.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Soldiers have been accused of killing 19 members of a Muslim family, including six children, to avenge the death of two comrades who were gunned down by a member of the clan, a Government official and witnesses said today.

LEAD: In the seven weeks since he went public with allegations of K.G.B. abuses, Oleg D. Kalugin has been officially denounced, stripped of his major general's rank and pension and charged with the crime of disclosing state secrets.
LEAD: BOONE By Brooks Hansen and Nick Davis. 394 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

LEAD: More than 700 guests from East Hampton and Sag Harbor on Long Island trooped out to Dune Alpin Farm in East Hampton to dance under a large white tent and celebrate the 60th anniversary of Guild Hall in East Hampton and its venerable John Drew Theater.
