LEAD: Cynthia Leigh Franklin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John B. Franklin of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday at the Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford to Daniel Kevin Carpenter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Carpenter of Northville, Mich. The Rev. Carl Becker officiated. Mrs. Carpenter, 25 years old, graduated from Cornell University.
LEAD: A letter about the second baseman Louy Whitaker (Mailbox, July 29) incorrectly identified the writer. His name is Jim Grondin.

LEAD: Surely but not slowly, the Australian Ballet won the hearts of a supposedly jaded audience in New York during one brief and indisputably successful week at the Metropolitan Opera House last month.
LEAD: SEVENTH HEAVEN By Alice Hoffman. 256 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.
LEAD: The St. Louis Cardinals reached up from last place in the National League East today and did what no team had done in two months: They defeated Dwight Gooden.

LEAD: The chief preoccupations in this English-speaking nation of 1.3 million people are calypso, cricket and soccer. So the attempted coup against the Government, and the violence it spawned before its peaceful denouement on Wednesday, struck many Trinidadians as something alien.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: With Lawrence Taylor and Leonard Marshall still boycotting the Giants' training camp and five other starters missing while they negotiate new contracts, the team moved to bolster its defense yesterday by picking up a linebacker, Aaron Chubb, on waivers from the Green Bay Packers.
LEAD: The American Circus An Illustrated History
LEAD: WISH upon a star. Wish upon a hockey puck. Dreams come true on Long Island no matter what the stimulus. Take the recent feat of Mike Galligan of Floral Park.

LEAD: Imagine a luxury resort in the middle of a lava field. Imagine sod laid on top of the lava and mowed so low you could practically play pool on it. Imagine white sand on the shore, trucked in at hundreds of dollars per load and manicured as carefully as a wealthy woman's hands.

LEAD: ''Don't analyze music; love it,'' said Francis Poulenc. It was a characteristic remark. Celebrated for his wit and elegance (however loud his tweeds), Poulenc was not a graduate of the Paris Conservatory, but of the Sorbonne. Hence his academic foundation was not musical but literary, and his professional outlook was libertarian: ''For Poulenc composing was a game,'' wrote his fellow Frenchman, the composer and conductor Manuel Rosenthal.

LEAD: WASHINGTON Jolene Unsoeld, a freshman Democrat elected by just 618 votes in 1988, is running in a tough environment: the designation of the Northern spotted owl as a threatened species could eventually cut thousands of logging jobs in her district, the Third. Her opponent, former State Representative Bob Williams, advocates weakening the Endangered Species Act to permit continued logging.

LEAD: Siberian Tigers are the largest of all cats, weighing up to 700 pounds, and white Siberian tigers might be the rarest. First bred successfully four years ago by Robert Baudy at the Rare Feline Breeding Center in Florida, there are now six in the world. Five are with Baudy; the sixth, Kita, (above and right), lives in Westfield, Ind.
LEAD: What a coincidence when I found that informative article about New York City chefs on Long Island (July 15).

LEAD: MOTORISTS who suspect they have seen a driver on the road who may be under the influence of alcohol or drugs can now call a toll-free number to alert the nearest police officer, under a new program developed by the state police.

LEAD: Ben and Dorothy Lin left Bethesda, Md., at 8:15 A.M. yesterday and hoped to be in Tarrytown, N.Y., about five hours later. The Lins established this modest goal before they encountered the George Washington Bridge.
LEAD: More new immigrants moved to Israel last month than at any time since the first years after the nation's birth 42 years ago.

LEAD: There was no American among the top 11 players in the Interzonal Tournament that ended July 14 in Manila. This means that no American qualified for the elimination matches to pick a challenger for the world championship in 1993. The failure was not for lack of ambition, but things just did not go their way.
LEAD: Martin Victor, a former Mayor of Lattingtown, L.I., and a former vice president of Babcock & Wilcox, an engineering concern, died on Friday in his home in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 76 years old.

LEAD: THE Hudson River ferry sloop family is getting ready to produce another offspring. The 32-foot gaff-rigged sloop, tentatively named the Eleanor - after Eleanor Roosevelt - is being built on the grounds of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Veterans Administration Hospital in Montrose, a joint effort of the newly revitalized Riverlovers boat club of Crugers and of drug- and alcohol-abuse patients at the hospital.

LEAD: With their cobblestone streets and 18th-century brick town houses, the neighborhoods surrounding Georgetown University are a source of pride for residents. But many residents contend that the drunken behavior of students living off campus are creating slumlike conditions.

LEAD: Susan Melissa Tolson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Tolson of Rockville, Md., was married yesterday to Charles Hammerman Rivkin, a son of Mrs. John S. LEAD: MORE than half of all public libraries in the United States do not have any librarians on staff whose primary responsibility is attending to children, who are major users of public library resources and services. Four out of ten public libraries have fewer than two full-time employees, which means librarians must be generalists.

LEAD: LAST week, after years of debate about the scientific and ethical dimensions of inserting new genes directly into humans, the Recombinant DNA Advisory Committee of the National Institutes of Health approved gene therapy techniques to treat certain types of immune disorders and a lethal form of skin cancer.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: What is now the tiny Borough of Metuchen grew up as a way station serving coaches carrying passengers from New York City to Perth Amboy, New Brunswick, Newark and Trenton. Today, it is a commuter paradise, straddling Route 27 and within three miles of Route 1, Interstate 287, the Garden State Parkway and the New Jersey Turnpike.

LEAD: Many students at the University of Wisconsin have been surprised by the age of hundreds of their classmates at this year's summer session. These classmates are retirees, mostly from Florida, whose ages range from the early 60's to the early 80's.

LEAD: The quality of United States stamp production is excellent. Mistakes are seldom made, and when they are, stamps that come off the presses lacking perforations or some colors, or with part of the design upside down, are almost always found by postal inspectors and destroyed. That's almost always. There has been a mini-epidemic of errors in the production of the Lighthouse booklet, the strip of five 25-cent stamps.
LEAD: Florida A & M University is discovering that growth can bring pain along with benefits.

LEAD: At a time when not-for-profit housing and development groups have multiplied in New York City, it is hard to keep them straight. Who are the Green Guerrillas and the 52 People for Progress? How does one contact Good Old Lower East Side Inc., or the Neighborhood Action Coalition?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: As an experiment, hold the Masters at a public golf course in Altanta. The corporate jets, the TV hangers-on and the pampered players would find a lot of excuses not to attend that event. PEGGY EDSALL New York

LEAD: WITH the end of the cold war, the United States and the Soviet Union are forging a working alliance at the United Nations that offers the organization its first real chance in 45 years to function as it is supposed to.

LEAD: There are all sorts of aphorisms, maxims, adages, sayings - call them what you will - that are true, but so what?

LEAD: Genetic tests used to identify suspects in criminal cases are valid and reliable when properly performed, but strict standards must be set to assure confidence in the method, according to a Congressional study released today.

LEAD: One of the discomforts of monitoring new American composition is having to watch young composers steeped in the lore of Third Avenue or the Bronx as they escape into Buddist chant, Tibetan prayers or the everyday musical obeisances of Islam. There is romance in these flights of fancy, but the flight too often is from what one really knows and understands.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL Iraq Marches, Kuwait Crumbles and the Markets Convulse It's as if President Saddam Hussein of Iraq sat at a trading desk, with enough capital to suddenly, violently dump yen, unload Treasury bonds, buy oil, bid up the dollar, hoard gold, invest in Norwegian and Australian commodity stocks and sell shares almost everywhere else.

LEAD: THE thin line separating art from crafts is nearly erased when they are exhibited side by side. In the current exhibition at the New Jersey Center for Visual Arts, it is hard to tell the difference, even with a program.

LEAD: It was a cloudy, gray morning here at the Pro Football Hall of Fame, and throughout the ceremony on the steps outside the building, a downpour appeared likely. But the rain never fell on the seven inductees and a spirited, elbow-to-elbow crowd of nearly 16,000 spectators. And the celebration turned out to be a sparkling tribute to the diverse array of stars that increased to 155 the number honored inside with bronze busts.

LEAD: AMERICANS have been getting a healthy dose of lessons in civics and government lately, what with proposed constitutional amendments, suggested reforms of the Electoral College (remember the Electoral College?), attempts at taking a census and efforts to establish democracies from scratch.

LEAD: For people who notice such things, there has recently been an unaccustomed hush in nature. The wind sighed and other birds called, but nature's great conversationalist, the crow, was hardly uttering a caw. With young crows not long out of their nests, the parents were keeping quiet, lest predators discover their fledglings.

LEAD: After spending his entire 13-year career with the Atlanta Braves, Dale Murphy is going to have to learn a new city and familiarize himself with a new team. LEAD: AT LEAST a third of the undergraduates surveyed last year said they had been victims of a crime since their college enrollment. LEAD: FOR years now President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has been the bad boy of Arab politics, a classic bully who lived by the credo that crime pays and absolute crime pays absolutely. The Iraqi strongman was at it again last week, invading his neighbor Kuwait, holding up the whole country for its oil and gold, and then daring the world to do something about it.

LEAD: Following is the vote of 255 to 155 by which the House of Representatives on Friday approved legislation to place a limit of $715,000 on how much House candidates can spend on their election campaigns. Voting ''yes'' were 240 Democrats and 15 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 3 Democrats and 152 Republicans.

LEAD: RAMJETS don't have turbines, so they can't ''breathe'' and can't carry a plane aloft. But once in flight, these simple jets ''ram'' air into their engine compartments, where it is mixed with fuel and burned. At high speeds, ramjets are lighter and more efficient than conventional jet-turbine engines.

LEAD: Bent but not broken, the flagpole atop the Ferry Building was a powerful symbol of San Francisco's durability, its tensile strength, in the days after last October's earthquake.

LEAD: There is a Vermont we carry around in our imagination, and a Vermont that really exists, and it's in the hill towns of the state's back roads where vision and actuality coexist best. A white church steeple framed by sugarloaf hills of maple and birch; weathered red houses progressing backward into connected red barns; a stream bending around the village in a line of alders; freshly cut meadows rising up from the town's back; a general store selling insulated boots in August, sunflower seeds in March.

LEAD: THERE were 40,407,540 students enrolled in 83,165 public elementary and secondary schools in the United States during the school year 1988-89. California is home to the most public schools, 7,312 of them, while Delaware, with 168, has the fewest.

LEAD: Hosteling is a frame of mind, an alternative psychology of travel. As a hosteler you carry your house on your back: your bedroom is a soft white envelope of top sheet, bottom sheet and pillowcase sewn together and called a sheet sleeping sack; your kitchen is a water bottle, a blue enamel cup, a cheap stainless steel spoon and a Swiss army knife; your bathroom is a toiletries bag and a towel; your desk a notebook and several foreign stamps.
LEAD: For years, Justina Cardenas Gomez has known what happened to her brothers when they disappeared here in 1983. But she guarded the secret for fear of meeting the same fate.

LEAD: It's not that leggy fashions are exactly new - after all, the short skirt has been around so long that it's almost ancient. The eye-boggling bodysuit, or cat suit as it is sometimes called, is a style trend that has been taken up by designers and comes in every price range.

LEAD: As publishers of slick, adfat magazines go, Bill Regardie is regarded as a very gutsy fellow indeed. Certainly he seems to have tried to offend them, town house to White House and everything in between.

LEAD: In ''Prince Charming Comes Back'' (Hers, July 15), Daphne Merkin notes that men are bewildered or angry about the movie ''Pretty Woman.'' But she doesn't bother to examine why. We women, she writes, ''still need our myths, our amatory fictions; they help us endure.'' However, I doubt Merkin would be sympathetic to men who ''need'' to fantasize about physically beautiful, intellectually inferior, sexually submissive women to help them endure.

LEAD: The engagement of Robin Lynn Silverman to Harry Andrew Keates, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Keates of Villanova, Pa., has been announced by her parents, Susan Silverman and Henry Silverman, both of New York. The wedding is planned for next July.

LEAD: The first message transmitted by major oil companies to Vera Haskins's fax machine came Thursday, less than 24 hours after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait: Gasoline prices would immediately increase by 3.5 cents to 8.5 cents a gallon.

LEAD: THE United States will probably be importing 60 percent of its oil by the time today's first-graders get their driver's licenses; debate over whether to build new nuclear reactors seems likely to intensify as those youngsters grow up, and acid rain and the greenhouse effect promise to focus attention on energy use of all kinds for years.

LEAD: ''It's a tricky task,'' Arthur Laurents said one recent afternoon, discussing the job of bringing a new actor into a working production. Mr. Laurents, who wrote the book for ''Gypsy'' and directed its current Broadway revival, was in the midst of helping Linda Lavin prepare to replace Tyne Daly as Rose.

LEAD: As a starstruck 17-year-old, David Hampton feared he would never win stage fame on his own, so he latched onto someone else's. It began one night in 1983 when he simply had to get into Studio 54 and hit upon the ruse of posing as Sidney Poitier's son. It worked so well he used it again - for a free meal in a trendy restaurant - and again and again to gain access to the homes of some wealthy and well-known New Yorkers.
LEAD: Federal regulators will seek to make changes in some deals in which the Government sold nearly 100 insolvent savings institutions in 1988, and they may try to cancel some of the sales.
LEAD: ENCOUNTERS & REFLECTIONS Art in the Historical Present. By Arthur C. Danto. 356 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.
LEAD: Breaking the barbed-wire and cow-pasture monotony of the Belem-Brasilia highway, a large orange sign here proclaims, ''Welcome to Paragominas.'' The sponsor is Stihl, a maker of chain saws.

LEAD: MUCH as the creation of a women's studies major reflected a kind of consciousness-raising for students in the 1970's, so environmental studies may be a generational barometer for the 1990's, as colleges and universities increasingly create curriculums on the environment and grant their graduates degrees.

LEAD: KEEPING WATCH: A History of American Time. By Michael O'Malley. (Viking, $19.95.) In tracing the ways timekeeping has evolved in the United States, Michael O'Malley quotes Lewis Mumford's claim that ''the clock, not the steam engine, is the key machine of the modern industrial age.'' There were clocks in the American colonies as early as 1638; by 1700, roughly one white adult in 50 owned a clock and one in 32 a watch.

LEAD: This may be the baseball season, but California fans who haven't forgot basketball will get a chance tonight to see some top National Basketball Association stars in action. The event is the fifth annual Magic Johnson all-star game at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif.

LEAD: It shouldn't. The key word in this Shoal Creek matter is ''private.'' The club should be allowed to accept and reject whomever it chooses, based on whatever criteria the club establishes. It is private.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Not too many people take the trouble to visit the Loch, a section of upper Central Park just north of the 102d Street Cross Drive. It has no rowboats, no hot-dog vendors, no swings, no baseball field.
LEAD: Dr. Mortimer Jacob Blumenthal, a New York City psychiatrist and child psychoanalyst, died yesterday at his home. He was 68 years old and lived and practiced on the Upper East Side.

LEAD: CONNECTICUT gubernatorial races have generally been pretty straightforward affairs: two parties, two candidates; no muss, no fuss. Each side lined up, snarled a bit and retired to the voting booths, where Democrats usually voted Democratic, and Republicans lost.

LEAD: CLASSICAL Chopin: 24 Mazurkas Charles Rosen, piano. Globe CD GLO 5028. CD only. Chopin composed more than 50 mazurkas. On this disk Charles Rosen presents a cross-section from the very earliest to the last. The mazurkas are amazing works in which Chopin far transcends superficial nationalism.

LEAD: This hamlet in Orange County, N.Y., squeezes about 60 galleries and shops into one main street less than half a mile long. But there is no big billboard heralding that fact, and the galleries themselves, in 200-year-old houses, look like the long-time residences they are, except for their own tiny hand-painted signs, often camouflaged by overgrown trees.

LEAD: What Mr. Kessel didn't say in the article on Lilco (June 24) is that because of the shutdown of Shoreham, Long Island consumers will have the highest cost electricity in the United States. The installation of new gas turbine plants possibly may produce electricity at lower cost than Shoreham but only because the price of oil has fallen from $30 a barrel in the 70's.

LEAD: Lillian C. Gustilo and Roderick M. Hamar were married yesterday at the Good Shepherd Roman Catholic Church in Golden Valley, Minn., by the Rev. Theodore C. Campbell. The couple, both 26 years old, graduated from Brown University. The bride, who is keeping her name, is a law student at the University of Minnesota.
LEAD: SUMMER is the relative calm before students storm their local educational institutions, be those institutions public or private, geared to youngsters or adults.

LEAD: THE STATE of Texas, long considered a national bellwether in the selection of elementary and secondary school textbooks, is for the first time considering computer software, videodisks and CD-ROM disks as alternatives to conventional printed textbooks in some courses.

LEAD: THE main event now at Wadsworth Atheneum is ''Robert Longo.'' LEAD: From the insistence and intensity of their gestures, it is obvious that Sakina Williams and Brian Cosgrove are locked in a vigorous debate. Absent, however, are the strident voices that usually accompany an exchange between 7-year-olds.

LEAD: ALL the things an adolescent can be,'' laments Thomas S. Anthony, ''is reduced to a three-digit number'' - the Scholastic Aptitude Test score. Mr. Anthony, dean of admissions at Colgate University in Hamilton, N.Y., believes that students give too much weight to this number when gauging their chances of being accepted at a particular school.

LEAD: An article on July 22 about the Jasna Gora Monastery in Poland misidentified the Roman Catholic holy day celebrated on Aug. 15. It is the Feast of the Assumption, not Ascension Day.

LEAD: MONKEY BAY, by Elaine Ford. (Penguin, $7.95.) In a dreary little town on the coast of Maine, Hannah Pratt decides to take revenge for her desolate childhood by seducing her mother's boyfriend. Last year our reviewer, Howard Frank Mosher, said this is ''a realistic, often unexpectedly funny and invariably well-written novel.
LEAD: The article on hospitals struggling with a ban on smoking (July 15) cited the state requirements for clearcut smoking policies as a moving force in implementing such an action.

LEAD: Two police officers who were on plainclothes duty in Madison, Wis., the night of June 28 say things got pretty rough when they tried to subdue a man who they say was acting obscenely outside a tavern and his two companions intervened. Indeed, according to a series of civil damage suits the officers filed Friday, the three, Chris Chelios of the Chicago Blackhawks, Gary Suter of the Calgary Flames and David Lundeen, a former teammate of the two pros at the University of Wisconsin, ''showed a complete disdain and disregard'' of the officers' ''inherent dignity as human beings.

LEAD: To follow developments in the management of the Metropolitan Opera, it might help to have a libretto. Directors of the Met, which has been without a chief administrator since Hugh Southern was forced out as general manager in June, last week named John Volpe to the job. Sort of. Mr. Volpe, who arrived 26 years ago as an assistant carpenter, will be the Met's chief administrator, but he will be called general director instead of general manager and will have less power than his predecessors.

LEAD: The recent article ''A Man Who Doesn't Know His Son Is Married'' (Opinion page) brought back not too far-off memories of my own life with my father. My father had a close relationship with both of his children when they were young. Plagued by his own insecurities, as his children grew and matured, he felt threatened and left behind.

LEAD: ''As far as fairy tales go,'' writes Merkin, ''this one not only has a Prince Charming, but it also has an audacious, instinctive, principled heroine who reforms the Prince . . . the only one who has to do any real self-examination is the man!'' No wonder the film is so pleasing to many women: it perfectly captures the ethos of 1990-style feminism, which evidently holds that no woman need rue any action she has ever taken - least of all, a career in prostitution - as long as she faithfully obeys the dictates of her ''feelings.

LEAD: Ben Johnson said today that he would return to competitive racing in January.

LEAD: FEW diseases are as difficult to live with as Alzheimer's, a degenerative brain disorder that is both progressive and irreversible. For the families involved, the personality changes that the afflicted suffer on a day-to-day basis can be devastating.

LEAD: The deep division in the nation over public support of controversial art was reflected today at a clamorous meeting of the council that advises the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts.

LEAD: It's odd, this sensibility we're all plugged into, where colored lips seem normal and naked ones seem, well, naked - and most of us spend a lot of time making sure the latter never happens. Still, the idea of using lipstick treads an uneasy line between the real and the artificial. The fashion writer Kennedy Fraser once declared that ''the woman who replaces her lipstick at the end of a meal often does so with a desperation which suggests that her mouth itself has been obliterated by chewing and by conversation.

LEAD: IN the last three weeks President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has ushered in a frightening era in international commerce and relations. He has used blackmail and force to achieve his commercial and political ambitions. President Hussein, a desperate man facing failed domestic policies, must be stopped now, if necessary by force.

LEAD: There is something almost mythic about a farm: the sun setting on rolling green pastures, the swoop of barn swallows on their way to the nest, the new life (newborn calves, lambs, kittens, puppies) that seems to crowd the small corners of the cavernous barn. It is the place to view The Farmer - that embodiment of the work ethic - on the job, and to have a glimpse of the livelihood that, as Americans, seems somehow our birthright.
LEAD: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait is the most iron-fisted of a series of actions that it has taken against the emirate since Kuwait became independent in 1961.

LEAD: Sharon's reputation as a soldier rests primarily on his performance in the Six-Day War, which was outstanding. However, a man who spends 25 years in the army must be judged on his cumulative performance. A review of Sharon's military career reveals an uneven record and a persistent tendency to disobey orders, employ excessive force and remain indifferent to civilian casualties.

LEAD: Michelangelo Antonioni's first color film, ''Red Desert'' (1964), is to open a two-week run at the Public Theater on Aug. 31. One of the Italian director's stories of alienation, the film stars Monica Vitti and Richard Harris. The new print, struck from the negative, will be shown nightly except Mondays at 5:30, 7:40 and 9:50, with a Saturday and Sunday matinee at 3:15.

(population 4,775 and falling), to allow the Japanese film maker Hiroaki Yoshida to continue shooting his first American movie, ''Iron Maze,'' in some of the town's abandoned buildings.

LEAD: President Bush did the right thing on Liberia over the weekend, ordering in the Marines to evacuate threatened Americans and protect the U.S. Embassy. He also sends a useful signal about America's willingness to use appropriate military force in defense of clear national interests.
LEAD: John Baldwin today ended his streak of second-place finishes in major amateur events by capturing the Metropolitan Amateur Championship, a title he also won 23 years ago.
LEAD: The Times Mirror Company said on Thursday that it had agreed to purchase 50 percent of La Opinion, one of the nation's largest Spanish-language daily newspapers.
LEAD: Jack McDowell pitched a five-hitter and Lance Johnson drove in three runs today to lead the Chicago White Sox past the Milwaukee Brewers, 6-1, for a sweep of the teams' five-game series.

LEAD: Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister reportedly urged Turkey today not to take retaliatory action against Baghdad for the invasion of Kuwait. Officials here said he was told that there were no such plans at this time.
LEAD: An explosion and fire today at an electrical substation caused the second power outage in a week on the city's West Side, cutting off electricity to about 25,000 customers, officials said.

LEAD: In the face of stiff pressure to take action against rising crime in New York City, Mayor David N. Dinkins is to announce today that he will hire 1,058 new police officers by next spring to increase foot patrols in neighborhoods, a senior mayoral aide said last night.

LEAD: GOLF Kite Rolls In $6 Million: Tom Kite rolled in a 15-foot birdie putt on the first playoff hole yesterday to defeat John Cook in the St. Jude Classic in Memphis and become the PGA Tour's first $6 million man. Kite hit a fairway iron to the green on the 13th hole, the first of sudden death, while Cook's approach landed in a leftside bunker.

LEAD: Nine police officers were injured and nine people were arrested early yesterday when officers trying to quiet an impromptu street concert in Greenwich Village were pelted with bottles, the police said.

LEAD: If Israelis are hard on the outside and sweet on the inside, as local folk wisdom says, then a good part of their toughness probably comes from the constant struggle against a battered economy, where taxes are all-encompassing, prices are higher than in Manhattan, and meager salaries seldom stretch to the end of the month.

LEAD: The advisory council to the National Endowment for the Arts today refused to bar support for any project that ''advocates or promotes a particular political, ideological, religious or partisan point of view.''

LEAD: The Jim Dandy Stakes at Saratoga Race Track is supposed to be a prep for the richer Travers Stakes 13 days later, but none of the four colts who ran today will be back for the main event this year. After this Jim Dandy, no one had any illusions about the quality of the quartet who contested it.

LEAD: An Old Refrain Q. Back in 1957, when Walter O'Malley was threatening to move the Dodgers to Los Angeles, a song was recorded imploring them not to leave Brooklyn. What was the song and who sang it? A. The song, ''Let's Keep the Dodgers in Brooklyn,'' published by Famous Music Corporation, was made popular by Phil Foster, a comedian from Brooklyn who viewed O'Malley's intention as no laughing matter.

LEAD: At the age of 79, the sculptor Louise Bourgeois is finally being honored by her native France. LEAD: Soon, as a result of the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait, we may know the truth about Israel's chemical, biological and - the ultimate taboo - nuclear weapons capability.

LEAD: It was a leaky afternoon yesterday in this hamlet by the lake, just the kind of wet and gray day on which no one here would ever have considered inventing baseball. Umbrellas, yes. But not the national pastime.

LEAD: On a sticky summer evening 60 years ago tonight, a serious-looking man wearing an old-fashioned choker collar and a brown suit hailed a taxicab on West 45th Street. He said goodbye to two friends on the sidewalk and climbed into the cab, apparently heading for a theater a few blocks away.

LEAD: Maurice Braddell, an actor, author and art restorer, died July 28 in England. He was 89 years old.

LEAD: House Republicans went down to defeat on the civil rights bill last week with President Bush's slogans flying. ''Quota bill!'' they declaimed. ''Lawyers' bonanza!'' But 64 percent of the House ignored their watered-down alternative and voted instead for the proposed Civil Rights Act of 1990. It was a triumph for reasonableness as well as rights.

LEAD: Ruth M. Shattuck, a former member of the Board of Selectmen for Darien, Conn., died Friday at her home in Darien. She was 69 years old.

LEAD: THE Sporting News is generally acknowledged to have been the first newspaper primarily devoted to baseball since it made its debut March 17, 1886. But now it appears that a paper known as The Bat and Ball, published in Hartford, beat The Sporting News to the newstands by 20 years.

LEAD: THE path to running a triathlon is paved with tales of renewal and reward as recreational athletes discover the value of cross training and pursue peak performance in a wider spectrum of sports.
LEAD: In ''?De Donde?,'' Mary Gallagher has written an intelligent and instructive play about the illegal immigration of refugees to the United States from Central America.
LEAD: A Queens man has been charged with stealing 25 medallion taxis during the last month and using them to pick up fares to support his crack habit, the police said.
LEAD: Japan's trade surplus in the broadest measure rose 12.2 percent in June from the period a year earlier, ending two consecutive months of decline, the Finance Ministry said Friday.
LEAD: In magazines as in life, being known as someone's sister can be a badge of pride - or a real drag.

LEAD: Boarding the 9:30 Pan Am shuttle to Boston on Saturday morning was the moment of truth for Buffy Smith. Her hands were clammy, her heart was pounding and she had endured nightmares about being trapped on a plane the size of her bathroom. After months of preparation, Flight 526 was it - her first time off the ground.
LEAD: The Vermont Supreme Court has let stand a lower court ruling that the Abenaki Indians of northwestern Vermont have a right to fish in their ancestral homeland without licenses.

LEAD: Thousands of mentally ill patients and other people unable to care for themselves are being assigned by New York State authorities to live in unsanitary, dilapidated and poorly supervised adult group homes or halfway houses, inspections by a state monitoring agency have found.
LEAD: In reaction to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, marine underwriters in the Lloyd's of London insurance market have added a premium for ships traveling in the Persian Gulf.

LEAD: The United Nations Security Council is expected to approve a worldwide ban on oil purchases from Iraq and occupied Kuwait on Monday in retaliation for the Iraqi invasion and to prohibit all other trade and financial dealings with these countries, Council members said tonight.
LEAD: When he was 9 years old, DR. HENRY KAUFMAN fled Wenings, Germany, with his parents in advance of World War II. Today he is to become an honorary citizen of the town.

LEAD: Boris Hansen Klosson, a retired foreign service officer specializing in Soviet and Eastern European affairs, died Friday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 71 years old and lived in Chevy Chase.

LEAD: Three years ago, American Federal Savings and Loan Association was in deep financial trouble, and Federal regulators were threatening to seize it. To minimize the cost to taxpayers, the regulators proposed merging the institution with a more solvent Oregon savings and loan.
LEAD: Affirming reports of record levels of violent crimes in many cities, the Federal Bureau of Investigation says the rates for murder, robbery and aggravated assault have risen sharply since 1985.
LEAD: US West Inc., the Colorado-based telecommunications holding company, has named Richard D. McCormick as its chief executive to succeed Jack A. MacAllister.

LEAD: Together, they may be Britain's brainiest couple. And together they received honorary degrees from Sussex University recently. LADY ANTONIA FRASER was honored for her contributions to the writing of history. Her husband, HAROLD PINTER, was honored for his contributions to the university.

LEAD: Japan said last night that it would join its allies in halting all purchases of oil from Iraq and Kuwait, cutting off an eighth of the country's entire supply of oil.

LEAD: JEFF JARVIS, former managing editor of Entertainment Weekly, will become Sunday editor of The Daily News, the newspaper announced yesterday.

LEAD: Iraq's new proxy government in Kuwait threatened to take hostages or nationalize foreign property today in the face of international calls for sanctions in response to President Saddam Hussein's takeover of his oil-rich neighbor.
LEAD: Prices of some ''junk bonds'' of RJR Nabisco Inc. fell sharply on Friday as rumors swept the market that the company had completed a huge buyback of some of its bonds.
LEAD: A fire driven by high winds and temperatures close to 100 degrees engulfed about 3,300 acres of parched forest, jumped a 75-foot-wide river canyon and destroyed 28 houses by this afternoon.

LEAD: Early in the century, Supreme Court Justices were confirmed as a matter of course. Felix Frankfurter notes in his reminiscences that even he, once considered an ''execrated character'' by many lawyers because of his radicalism, was approved by the Senate without dissent.

LEAD: In the final hours before leaving for its summer recess, the Senate gave final approval late Saturday to legislation to provide more than $4 billion over the next five years to help cities deal with AIDS and to provide money to upgrade airports, mass transit systems and Amtrak.

LEAD: GEORGE SEIFERT stuck his hands into everything. He coached his players and he coached his coaches. He was not a good listener. His teams won 3 games and lost 15. He was fired. ''It was a learning experience, for sure,'' said Seifert, recalling his stint as Cornell's head coach in 1975 and 1976, a time when he possibly grew the most as a coach but was still nearly run out of town by alumni who were never in favor of his selection.

LEAD: With Japan joining the United States and Europe yesterday by agreeing to halt oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait, the industrialized world has begun an economic campaign against Baghdad that for the moment relies on an embargo but holds out the possible use of a naval blockade.
LEAD: John F. Fanning, the advertising makeup manager for The New York Times, died yesterday at Centrastate Medical Center in Freehold, N.J. He was 61 years old and lived in Howell, N.J.

LEAD: David and Ginger Twitchell, a Christian Science couple from Massachusetts who relied on prayer rather than on doctors as their young son lay dying from an obstructed bowel, were convicted of involuntary manslaughter last month. It was a stunning verdict, coming as it did in the very shadow of the Mother Church in Boston.
LEAD: The first iridescent posters greet visitors at the ticket office for the ferry to Martha's Vineyard from Cape Cod: ''The designated driver is the life of the party.''

LEAD: If there are those among the Yankees who miss Deion Sanders, Roberto Kelly isn't one of them. Not that Kelly disliked Sanders, the flamboyant football player and erstwhile baseball player; it's just that with Sanders gone, Kelly is the Yankees' center fielder again and Kelly likes being the Yankees' center fielder.
LEAD: A headline on Saturday about an unsuccessful attempt in the Senate to overturn a virtual ban on abortions at overseas military hospitals gave an incorrect vote tally in some copies.

LEAD: Treasury financings this week include today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, tomorrow's auction of three-year notes, Wednesday's auction of 10-year notes, and Thursday's auction of 30-year bonds and a 36-day cash management bill.

LEAD: After years of hostility, the Soviet Union has given the first clear signal that it wants to join the $120 billion International Monetary Fund, and officials both here and in Moscow say it may not be long before the Soviet Union formally asks to join.
LEAD: Investigating allegations of cheating on nuclear reactor safety inspections aboard the aircraft carrier Nimitz, the Navy has restricted four crew members aboard ship.

LEAD: In 1953, as a student at Columbia, I wrote a paper on the ''Grapes of Wrath'' for a literature course. Although I knew John Steinbeck only through his novels and stories, I mailed the critique to him. To my surprise and delight, I received a letter from him by return post. It was handwritten (so was the 200,000-word ''Grapes of Wrath'' manuscript) on a yellow tablet.
LEAD: Dr. Mortimer Jacob Blumenthal, a New York City psychiatrist and child psychoanalyst, died Saturday at his home. He was 68 years old and lived and practiced on the Upper East Side.

LEAD: A proposal to convert aging nuclear missiles into cheap rockets for launching satellites has presented the Government with a difficult choice between conflicting goals: cashing in on the peace dividend and promoting American competitiveness in high-technology industries.

LEAD: Rollerblade Inc., a tiny company based near Minneapolis that brought out a roller skate with a single row of wheels, has spawned a sport called blading that in the last three years has become something of a national craze.
LEAD: Home mortgage interest rates, which last week were hovering just above 10 percent, have increased quickly in recent days, following the yields on Treasury bonds onto higher ground.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a short article with a listing headed ''Movies This Week'' in the Television section on Sunday misidentified an actress in ''The Baker's Wife,'' which will be shown at 1 o'clock tonight on Bravo. The runaway young wife is played by Ginette Leclerc; Marlene Dietrich does not appear in the movie.

LEAD: The delegation of gypsies had come to the site of the Nazi concentration camp at Mauthausen to look for a part of their history, one that has been less examined and less lamented than the fate of other peoples in World War II.
LEAD: A Coast Guard inquiry yesterday blamed a declining standard of care throughout the maritime community for the 12 spills in the Arthur Kill and the Kill van Kull this year.
LEAD: The Firstar Corporation and Banks of Iowa Inc. said today that they had agreed to merge in a stock swap valued at about $200 million.

LEAD: BASEBALL COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE - Suspended Rick Leach, San Francisco Giants outfielder, for 60 days after he tested positive for drug use. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Placed Bryn Smith, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list. Moved John Morris, outfielder, from the 15-day disabled list to the 21-day list.

LEAD: The Mets bombed in St. Louis again tonight when they lost to Joe Torre's revived Cardinals for the third time in a row and to Joe Magrane for the second time in a week. And they flew home wondering why the hottest team in the big leagues in June had become a .500 team in August.

LEAD: Francis C. Symonds Jr., clinical professor of surgery at the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University, died on Saturday in Englewood Hospital in New Jersey. He was 63 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J., and Southold, L.I.

LEAD: The economic fallout from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has quickly filtered to the airline passenger, with higher oil prices already translating into higher air fares. Two airlines will add surcharges or raise fares on Thursday to offset their higher fuel costs, and several others are considering a similar move.

LEAD: President Bush has rallied the U.N. Security Council to vote a trade embargo against Iraq and Kuwait. This is the right response to Baghdad's heinous invasion, but it raises two troubling questions for the U.S.: Will the embargo block Iraqi oil exports? And will it throw the U.S. into a devastating recession?

LEAD: * Amdura Corporation, Denver, a hardware distributor, said it would sell its Amdura National Distribution Co. unit to Our Own Hardware Co., Minneapolis, a wholesale supplier of hardware, for undisclosed terms.

LEAD: The Lebanese investor Toufic Aboukhater has raised his stake in the Henley Group Inc. to 9.11 percent from 7.67 percent. He disclosed late last month that he had asked Government regulators for permission to increase his holdings in the Hampton, N.H., manufacturing concern to more than 15 percent.

LEAD: PEOPLE say they are seeing panthers in New England and neighboring areas of Canada. But do the sightings, even if authentic, mean the stealthy big cat is breeding again in the Northeast decades after its presumed extinction there? The question has split naturalists into fervent believers and skeptics demanding foolproof evidence.
LEAD: The San Francisco Giant outfielder Rick Leach was suspended for 60 days by the baseball commissioner, Fay Vincent, today after a positive drug test.
LEAD: An effort to stop cruising in Milwaukee and three of its suburbs has led the American Civil Liberties Union to sue on the behalf of teen-agers who say they have a right to free travel.

LEAD: The prospect of rain, what with the persistent clouds overhead indistinguishable from the black incinerator smoke that belched across the Bronx sky, was no doubt for more than a couple of Yankee fans as promising as it was threatening.

LEAD: After a decade in which Federal housing programs stagnated or starved, Congress has passed bills that pledge significant amounts of new housing money, both to strengthen current programs and to create new ones.

LEAD: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that motorists accused of drunken driving are not entitled to jury trials, even though those convicted for the third time can be jailed for six months, fined $1,000, pay thousands of dollars in insurance surcharges and lose their right to drive for 10 years.

LEAD: American and British officials said today they would be prepared to organize an international naval blockade of Iraq to insure enforcement of economic sanctions imposed on the country by the United Nations.

LEAD: Justice THURGOOD MARSHALL of the Supreme Court was released from a hospital yesterday. He had fallen in the lobby of his hotel when he was in Chicago on Thursday to address the annual convention of the American Bar Association.
LEAD: The dollar, a longtime haven for investors in times of military and political crisis, has been all but shunned since Iraq invaded Kuwait.

LEAD: After a yearlong study, a nonprofit advocacy group has concluded that many rural Americans suffer needlessly from poverty and pollution because Federal programs to help them are poorly financed and poorly run.

LEAD: After hearing James M. Fail acknowledge that he made incorrect disclosures to Federal regulators in 1988 when he purchased 15 insolvent savings and loans, members of a Senate panel said today that they were seriously troubled by the deal's inadequate disclosures and questionable finances.

LEAD: New Jersey's tax revolt, up to now a citizens' protest with no recourse in this non-election year, is reverberating in both the Legislature and the Governor's office, and Democrats now fear it could carry into next year's legislative elections.

LEAD: Neither the weather nor television fare has sizzled much this summer. But all the networks have offered a few new series for those inclined to spend the pleasant evenings in front of the tube. John O'Connor and Walter Goodman offer comments on some of the main shows. Northern Exposure CBS, 10 P.M.
LEAD: Conversations between a psychologist and two brothers after their parents were slain can be used as evidence in their murder case, a judge ruled today.
LEAD: Tripp Wommack, who has been buying and operating oil fields here for 10 years, scanned the buffet room at the Petroleum Club.
LEAD: Maybe George Bush really believed that the world was becoming kinder and gentler.

LEAD: The United States moved today to increase its naval forces in the Middle East for a possible blockade to enforce the United Nations trade sanctions against Iraq, and other Western officials indicated that they were prepared to join in such an action if it was necessary.

LEAD: Odor Flashbacks Q. Occasionally one smells an odor and then smells it again hours later. Are odor molecules still in the nose, or is it psychological? A. ''It could happen either way, but in most cases it is probably psychological,'' especially if it is a very bad odor, said Solomon H.
LEAD: Oil prices rose sharply again yesterday and financial markets around the world plummeted as the international embargo against oil from Iraq and Kuwait appeared to be taking hold.
LEAD: John A. Gronvall, former chief medical director of the Department of Veterans Affairs in Washington, died Aug. 2. He was 59 years old.

LEAD: The Government of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto was dismissed today by the President of Pakistan, who accused her administration of corruption, nepotism and other acts ''in contravention of the Constitution and the law.''

LEAD: Pittsburgh's Randy Tomlin pitched a five-hitter in his major-league debut tonight, but he didn't have time to enjoy it. While his arm was being wrapped in ice after the game, Tomlin started worrying whether he would go back to Harrisburg of the Class AA Eastern League or remain with the Pirates.
LEAD: The Senate has approved the renomination of Wendy Lee Gramm as the chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

LEAD: LEE ATWATER is back in the hospital. The Republican Party chairman became ill in March and the diagnosis was a benign brain tumor. He was visited at George Washington University Hospital yesterday by PRESIDENT BUSH.

LEAD: IN a race of muscle-powered watercraft on Saturday, a light hydrofoil built mostly of aluminum achieved a speed of 17.45 miles an hour, believed by race organizers to be a world record for its class.
LEAD: International A2-11
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Among the underlying causes of the East German Prime Minister's surprising call to move up all-German elections is a realization that reunification will cost far more than expected and that monetary union has not slowed East Germany's economic decline.
LEAD: In the Giants' minicamp in May, Coach Bill Parcells issued a challenge to his veteran wide receivers.

LEAD: ''Funny, but I don't have any regrets about not playing in the majors. They say that I was born too soon. I say the doors were opened too late.'' - James (Cool Papa) Bell Perhaps the saddest part about James Bell's baseball career was that he was a major leaguer in every sense but name, but never fully realized it.
LEAD: A Liberian rebel leader seized about a dozen foreigners, including an American, as hostages from a hotel outside Monrovia today, the State Department said.
LEAD: Residents chased from their homes by a forest fire that continued to burn today after consuming 20 houses returned to find the blaze had roasted meat inside freezers and melted bottles.
LEAD: The Internal Revenue Service is losing its battle to collect overdue taxes, which are growing faster than tax collections, Government auditors said last week.
LEAD: ''It takes a sense of humor and some talent,'' Edward C. Stanton 3d said yesterday about his new job as managing director of the mergers and acquisitions unit of Oppenheimer & Company.

LEAD: Responding to pressure from Congress and community groups, Federal regulators have withheld approval for some bank mergers in recent months until the companies agreed to improve service to poor neighborhoods.

LEAD: July 19, 1989 - Calling New York ''a city under siege,'' a campaigning David N. Dinkins says that over the next four years he wants to hire 1,300 more police officers for neighborhood foot patrols and for the subways. Jan. 1, 1990 - In his inaugural address, he reaffirms his vow to be ''the toughest Mayor on crime this city has ever seen.
LEAD: A Federal judge dismissed Peggy McMartin Buckey's $1 million civil suit for malicious prosecution today, saying that ''being very, very upset does not state a cause of action,''

LEAD: After three Administrations fought bitter battles in Congress to secure billions of dollars of military aid for Saudi Arabia, insisting that the Saudi Government was crucial to United States interests in the Middle East, the complex relationship between Washington and Riyadh has abruptly reached a crossroads.
LEAD: ''We have approached the surge in crime methodically, professionally and creatively.

LEAD: In one of the fastest and funniest sketches in ''Los Rayos Gamma in New York,'' the satirical musical revue that had weekend performances at the Public Theater, a young Puerto Rican minister soberly informs his father that he intends to go into politics.

LEAD: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation will provide technical assistance for a joint venture to produce its passenger cars in Venezuela beginning in September. A Mitsubishi spokesman, Kyoichi Shimada, said the joint venture, MMC Auto Motriz de Venezuela S.A., would produce 800 passenger cars this year primarily with parts shipped from Japan.

LEAD: It wasn't so long ago that Ballet Chicago was being hailed as an extremely promising new company. But the performance also suggested that Ballet
LEAD: The setting was unusual, but Jim Palmer and Joe Morgan finally got to make their speeches today as they were inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame.

LEAD: John T. Kolody, retired president of St. Barnabas Hospital, died on Saturday at St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains. He was 70 years old and lived in Whitestone, Queens.

When he brought his band to Kilimanjaro on Friday night, there was no resisting that imperative; Mr.
LEAD: Unless a small, determined band of residents have their way, this city of 29,000 people is about to become the site of the nation's largest incineration of dioxin.
LEAD: The United States should undertake a major effort to develop superconducting computers that can operate a million times faster than today's fastest machines, a national panel recommends.

LEAD: Salim B. (Sandy) Lewis, a former leading Wall Street trader, settled Federal civil anti-fraud charges today that he had manipulated the price of a stock in 1986. Mr. Lewis was also barred from the securities business.
LEAD: The police today defused a bomb they believe was planted by the Irish Republican Army in an attempt to kill a retired British official.

LEAD: * Hill & Knowlton Inc., New York, has formed a new unit, Hill & Knowlton International, for its operations outside the U.S. Thomas E. Eidson, president and chief operating officer of U.S. operations for the firm, was appointed president and chief executive of the new division. John D. Bergen, executive vice president of the parent company's Eastern region and general manager of its New York office, replaces Mr.

LEAD: Concerned about television's smaller audience this summer and a looming threat from the Fox Broadcasting Company, NBC announced a prime-time scheduling plan yesterday that will move up the premiere episodes of five new fall series to August. The new television season officially begins Sept. 17.
LEAD: Bruce Coslet finally put it in writing today.
LEAD: On the first day of a citywide amnesty program for people with illegal guns, only three weapons were turned in - all by the same person.

LEAD: Sparring partners, whether in boxing or chess, do not have an easy time of it. In fact, the boxing partner has the advantage because he gets to wear protective head gear. There is no analogue for the chess training partner who has to put up with one drubbing after another from his principal's slashing combinations.
LEAD: Mandela's Group Suspends Revolt The African National Congress has suspended the guerrilla campaign it began 30 years ago in its struggle to end apartheid in South Africa.

LEAD: The Tandy Corporation introduced a six-pound notebook computer equipped with hard-disk and floppy-disk drives priced at $1,999. The new machine will compete directly with similar models made by the Compaq Computer Corporation, the Zenith Electronics Corporation and the Toshiba Corporation.

LEAD: A party of 24 Soviet bridge experts is to arrive in New York City today and tomorrow for a visit that runs through Saturday. The danger that through a ticketing mix-up they would be stranded in Seattle, where they competed last week in the Goodwill Games, was averted by the combined efforts of the bridge community and T.W.A.
LEAD: The mother of a defendant in the Central Park jogger trial was ordered removed from the courtroom yesterday after she shouted ''Liar!'' at a prosecution witness.
LEAD: The General Dynamics Corporation announced today that it would consolidate two California military-related divisions that will result in 1,500 to 2,000 layoffs by the end of 1991.

LEAD: George Stavrinos, a graphic artist and illustrator who helped revive interest in finely drawn representational art, died Friday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan. He died of complications of pneumonia, his sister Lydia said. Mr. Stavrinos graduated from the Rhode Island School of Design in 1970, and his drawings and illustrations soon began to appear in The New York Times, Gentleman's Quarterly and Cosmopolitan.
LEAD: Iraqi soldiers rounded up hundreds of Westerners, including at least 28 American citizens, from hotels in Kuwait. It was not known what Iraq planned to do with them.

LEAD: Panicky officials at the U.S. Department of Agriculture are racing around to bank regulators to find Iraqi funds; unless they can seize and use offsetting assets, $2 billion in commodity credit guarantees will come out of taxpayers' pockets to pay for Mr. Bush's past appeasement of Saddam Hussein.

LEAD: Riverside Church in Manhattan, which has had difficulty in recent years in putting the inspirational message from its pulpit into social action, has hired a former union organizer as its No. 2 minister.
LEAD: * Eastern Airlines Inc., Miami, named Jack E. Robinson 3d vice president of corporate development and president and chief executive of Eastern Express, its commuter airline.
LEAD: Debt
LEAD: This summer, 74-year-old Geraldine Jones has been encouraged by the view from her 12th-floor terrace in the East Tremont neighborhood of the Bronx.

LEAD: The European Community's program to turn its 12 nations into a single market is creating a bonanza for makers of personal computers in general and for the Compaq Computer Corporation in particular. Analysts expect the Western European personal computer market to grow by as much as 25 percent this year - twice the pace of the more mature

LEAD: FOR the second stage of testing Windows 3.0, the new Microsoft graphical interface, with a modestly endowed AT-class computer, I loaded a selection of software that had not been written with Windows in mind. That is, each of the programs got its own little icon, or symbol, and could be run by putting the on-screen pointer on the icon and clicking the mouse button twice, even though they had not been designed for a graphical environment.

LEAD: The role of management recruiters, also known as ''headhunters'' and ''search consultants,'' seems to confuse many executives, especially those who have suddenly lost their jobs. In desperation, they deluge recruiting firms with resumes and telephone calls demanding interviews immediately.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Los Angeles Lakers yesterday announced they had signed Sam Perkins, an unrestricted free agent, to a multiyear contract reported to be worth as much as $3 million a year. Terms were not announced by the team. After being selected fourth over all in the 1984 draft, out of North Carolina, the 6-9 forward played six seasons for the Dallas Mavericks.
LEAD: The productivity of American workers improved for the first time in six quarters, climbing in the second quarter at an annual rate of 1.6 percent, the Labor Department said today.
LEAD: Salvage crews cleaned the tanks of a damaged oil barge today so it could be cut up and removed and the Houston ship channel fully reopened.

LEAD: The number of rigs exploring for oil and natural gas in the United States dropped by 30 last week, to a total of 966, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago the count stood at 874. The decline was attributed to weak gasoline prices in the last few months.

LEAD: The election of Alan Rothenberg as president of the United States Soccer Federation on Sunday has pleased the world governing body for soccer, which had supported his candidacy over those he defeated: Werner Fricker, the federation president for six years, and Paul Stiehl, the federation treasurer.
LEAD: Maurice A. Pollak, president of the Maurice Pollak Investment Office in West Long Branch, N.J., died on Sunday at his home in West Long Branch, N.J. He was 94 years old.
LEAD: States have increased taxes by $7.6 billion thus far in 1990 to meet rising costs of schools, prisons and health care, a study reported today.
LEAD: Eric Dickerson reported to the Indianapolis Colts' training camp in Anderson, Ind., yesterday but the star running back did so after failing a physical he took in Indianapolis.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Rabbi Jacob J. Hecht, an educator, writer and radio commentator, died on Sunday while visiting Camp Emunah, a summer camp he founded in Greenfield Park, N.Y. He was 66 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

LEAD: Advocates for people with AIDS are expressing concern that the public is growing weary of hearing about the disease and that a sense of alarm has given way to a resigned acceptance, making it harder to raise badly needed private funds.

LEAD: After a marathon 15-hour negotiating session with the white authorities, the African National Congress announced early today that it had ordered the immediate suspension of a guerrilla campaign begun 30 years ago in its struggle to end apartheid.
LEAD: The first formal talks on Cambodia between the United States and Vietnam were held yesterday in New York, and both sides called them useful, although they were evidently inconclusive.

LEAD: Prices of ''junk bonds'' dropped sharply yesterday as investors worried that many of the low-rated companies that have issued such high-yield securities would have trouble meeting their obligations if higher oil prices caused a recession.

LEAD: The Seattle Mariner pitcher Bill Swift, struck on the forehead by a line drive at the Kingdome while pitching against Minnesota on Sunday night, was released yesterday from a hospital after undergoing tests. Swift, who was sprawled on the mound for four minutes after being hit by a drive off the bat of Gary Gaetti, suffered only a bruise and was expected to make his next start on Saturday.
LEAD: An automotive trade journal reported today that the Honda Motor Company plans to enter the truck market and increase its United States sales by 50 percent by 1995, but Honda denied the report.
LEAD: The Smithsonian Institution has been uneasy in recent days about reports of an impending budget squeeze and a major shake-up in its managerial ranks.

LEAD: The Lotus Development Corporation has imposed a cost-cutting program that will result in the layoff of about 40 workers, mostly from the company's marketing department. The company, which employs 3,100, said that it was still hiring in some areas and that the net reduction in workers would be about 20 people.

LEAD: Until rains of biblical proportion turned Saratoga Race Track into a mudpit yesterday, the opening week of racing here was as invigorating as the cool Adirondack night air. After extended summer doldrums at Belmont Park, New York State once again is the capital of American racing this month, a place of champions.
LEAD: * Allen P. Adamson has been appointed senior vice president and group director at Ammirati & Puris.

LEAD: ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' is an opera about compromise, composed by a man of the theater who believed in the tactics of accommodation and who practiced them in his art and his life. During World War II Richard Strauss let himself be used by the Nazis in the belief that he was using them, with unhappy effects on his reputation.
LEAD: The police say they believe one gunman committed at least six felonies -three robberies, two rapes and a kidnapping - in less than two hours in Queens yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AQUATIC designers are creating giant water slides that are starting to mimic roller coasters and eight-foot-high artificial waves that can propel surfers and swimmers on long, pleasurable rides down the length of a pool.
LEAD: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 6 (AP) -

LEAD: David J. Melamed, a lawyer and former secretary of the Communications Satellite Corporation, died on Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

LEAD: There's an early scene in the first of the ''Robocop'' film series that provides a familiar nightmarish shock of technological recognition when a machine, a kind of latter-day Frankenstein's monster, runs amok with tragicomic results.

LEAD: ''This is where I come for business, 'cause this is where the bread and the jelly are at,'' explains the mugger, with a smirk. ''I see a ripe vic, I tell him, 'You can do it my way or you can do it your way, but do it your way and you'll get hurt.''

LEAD: HORSE RACING Majesty's Time Prevails Majesty's Time outfought favored Candid Cameron through the stretch to carry Jorge Chavez to a 2 1/4-length victory in the $85,200 Albany Handicap for horses 3 years old and up at Saratoga. Candid Cameron, with Dave Penna up, was easily second best in the five-horse field, finishing 15 1/2 lengths ahead of Applebred and Jean-Luc Samyn.
LEAD: THROUGHOUT the late spring and summer, Dr. Robert C. Gallo, one of America's most prominent AIDS researchers, has been feeling a withering heat that has nothing to do with the weather.
LEAD: * Crystal Brands Inc., New York, to Lewis, Gilman & Kynett, Philadelphia, for Izod Lacoste golf and tennis attire.

LEAD: ''HE was a scientist, but he was acting strangely,'' said Dr. Stuart Yudofsky, a psychiatrist who consulted on the man's case. ''At work, when something didn't go right, he would scream and threaten his co-workers. At home, if his 4-year-old spilled some food at the table, he'd get so mad at her, he'd punch holes in the walls with his fist.

LEAD: Pressured to respond to a recent string of alarming crimes in New York City, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he would hire 1,058 new police officers by next spring to increase neighborhood foot patrols and would pay for this by cutting a range of other services.
LEAD: A 27-year-old man was killed in a Brooklyn subway station, apparently after an argument over the use of a pay telephone, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: Gov. Mike Hayden has not lost an election since he first won a seat in the Kansas House of Representatives in 1972, but he faces a strong challenge from a political newcomer in Tuesday's Republican primary.
LEAD: Bridgeport has listed its 44th homicide this year, matching the record set in all of 1988.

LEAD: Surgeons have devised a procedure in which a tiny gold weight implanted in the eyelid restores the blinking ability to patients with facial paralysis, researchers say. The pull of gravity on the weight mimics nerve function and allows people who have a weakened or damaged facial nerve to close their eyes in an almost natural fashion.

LEAD: Van Gogh His Life and His Art By David Sweetman Illustrated. 391 pages. Crown Publishers. $30. Vincent van Gogh By Evert van Uitert, Louis van Tilborgh, Sjraar van Heugten, Johannes van der Wolk, Ronald Pickvance and E. B. F. Pey. Illustrated. Two volumes: paintings, 292 pages; drawings, 336 pages.

LEAD: Lieut. Gov. Zell Miller, whom many see as the heavy favorite in the runoff on Tuesday for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, campaigned Sunday among the clog dancers and fiddlers and more than 25,000 other people at the Georgia Mountain Fair in the rolling hill country where he grew up.

LEAD: Following his success in Pirandello's ''Henry IV'' in London, RICHARD HARRIS said yesterday that he planned to abandon films and now spend the rest of his career playing major Shakespearean roles. The Irish actor, who is 58 years old, said he would play King Lear, Richard III and Shylock in London's West

LEAD: NEW evidence from Sweden reveals that the average summer temperature in far northern Europe has fluctuated almost seven degrees over the last 1,400 years, illustrating how widely the earth's climate varies naturally and suggesting that in the northernmost parts of the world, the effects of any global warming will be hard to feel for a long time.
LEAD: Though the approaches to resort collections change dramatically from designer to designer, a strong theme pervades them all: practicality.

LEAD: A tribute to the alto saxophonist Jackie McLean on Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall really began two songs in, with the arrival of the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis. Mr. Marsalis and Mr. McLean seared the melody of Mr. McLean's ''Bird Lives,'' tearing through the tune with two impressively assured improvisations so bursting with ideas and momentum that the piece barely held them.

LEAD: James (Buster) Douglas, the undisputed heavyweight champion, brimmed with confidence yesterday at a news conference in Manhattan promoting his first title defense, which will be against Evander Holyfield on Oct. 25 at the Mirage hotel and casino in Las Vegas, Nev.
LEAD: Polo for Boys and Trees
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The stock market is undergoing a series of stresses with no direct parallels in the recent past. And all this comes as traders are trying to cope with a new rule that many do not fully understand.

LEAD: Indian troops captured the chief military commander of Kashmir's independence movement and 11 other militant leaders in Srinagar today as the Kashmiris met to discuss strategy, the authorities said.
LEAD: Harold E. Beste, an electronics researcher and engineer who helped develop television components and weapons systems, died on Friday at his home in Verona, N.J. He was 81 years old.

LEAD: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation, a construction and engineering company, said on Friday that its chairman and chief executive, William M. Agee, had been named to the additional post of president. Mr. Agee succeeds Frank M. Adams, who died on May 27 in an airplane crash.

LEAD: Nothing marked the euphoric and triumphant march of the Reagan Administration into Washington in 1981 more than two policies - a ''free market'' in oil (in lieu of energy independence) and a massive strategic weapons buildup. Last week, nine years and $1 trillion later, we found ourselves threatened by our dependence on Middle East oil and unable to mount a quick and effective military response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
LEAD: PATIENT trials of new treatments, long a crown jewel of American medical science, are increasingly being conducted overseas, a number of prominent researchers say.
LEAD: Lawyers at the American Bar Association's annual meeting called upon the group's policymaking body today to abandon its stance favoring abortion rights and return to neutrality on the issue.

LEAD: In an attempt to put pressure on the Manville Corporation, a Federal judge said yesterday that the company's senior executives had not been cooperative in helping to bail out the trust they created to assist victims of asbestos.

LEAD: The Federal jury in the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. worked throughout today weighing the evidence compiled in the case, but once again the panel recessed without reaching a verdict.
LEAD: A former Federal judge who was impeached by Congress after his perjury conviction was arrested today and charged with breaking parole by carrying a gun, the authorities said.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A 5 1/2-month-old boy was shot in the head yesterday in Manhattan when a bullet tore through an apartment wall as he lay sleeping in bed with his grandmother, the police said.
LEAD: CONCERN has been increasing over the possibility of adverse health effects from computer monitors.

LEAD: A headline on the front page of SportsMonday this week, referring to an article inside about the new head of the national governing body of soccer, misidentified the organization. It is the United States Soccer Federation.
LEAD: Paul V. Galloway, a retired bishop of the United Methodist Church, died Saturday at St. John Medical Center in Tulsa, Okla. He was 86 years old and lived in Tulsa.

LEAD: With the American economy seemingly headed for recession and the exploding cost of imported oil about to push it over the edge, analysts widely agree that cutting the budget deficit this year no longer makes sense. But by the same token, they argue, the case for making a credible deal now on future deficit reduction is more compelling than ever.

LEAD: Two Jewish teen-agers who disappeared on Saturday while hitchhiking through Arab East Jerusalem were found dead today in a valley between the city and a Palestinian village. They had been bound, gagged and repeatedly stabbed.

LEAD: JOSE RAFAEL MONEO, the Spanish architect and chairman of the architecture department at Harvard's Graduate School of Design, is designing his first building in the United States. It will be a museum and cultural center on the campus of Wellesley College, Wellesley, Mass., and is to house the school's permanent art collection, temporary exhibitions and a theater.

LEAD: O. B. Hardison Jr., a professor of English at Georgetown University and former director of the Folger Shakespeare Library, died Sunday at the Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 61 years old and lived in Washington.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: An article on Saturday about religion as a political issue in Pakistan misidentified a human rights lawyer.

LEAD: Apparently already feeling the effects of an American-orchestrated boycott, Iraq sharply reduced the flow of oil today through twin pipelines that cross southern Turkey and normally transport more than half its oil exports.

LEAD: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Atlanta says it will investigate whether church money went improperly to a woman whose intimate relationships with a priest and an archbishop led to their resignations.

LEAD: Stung by sharply lower earnings this year because of a weak paper market, the Boise Cascade Corporation announced plans today to scale back pulp and paper mill operations in the Northwest while continuing to upgrade its other paper and timber mills.

LEAD: A man trying to sell an automatic pistol at a gun show accidentally fired it into the crowd, injuring two people, the police said. A 27-year-old man was arrested for investigation of aggravated assault after the shooting on Sunday.

LEAD: A Federal jury in Los Angeles has convicted the last of a group of four defendants charged with a number of crimes that included the kidnapping and killing of a United States drug agent in Mexico.
LEAD: Stock prices plunged again yesterday as continuing tensions in the Middle East pushed up oil prices, leading to investor fears that inflation will heat up.
LEAD: Markets

LEAD: Within weeks of a declaration of sovereignty by the Yugoslav Republic of Croatia, leaders of the republic's Serbian minority are pressing for cultural and, in all likelihood, territorial autonomy that would further complicate an already intricate political map and could exacerbate already bitter ethnic rivalries.

LEAD: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds took their worst battering yesterday since the days just before the 1987 stock market crash, although bargain hunters prevented the interest rate on the benchmark 30-year bond from moving higher than its level of May.

LEAD: A Westchester County Court judge today dismissed a murder indictment against Carolyn Warmus, a 26-year-old teacher accused of killing her lover's wife, saying the District Attorney's office had manipulated the grand jury.
LEAD: Firefighters battled a ship blaze at Port Elizabeth from midnight to 6 A.M. today before a carbon-dioxide system smothered the fire, an executive of Maersk Inc., Ken Karahuta, said.

LEAD: AFTER a 15-month voyage from Earth, looping the Sun one and a half times, the Magellan spacecraft is approaching Venus. Scheduled to arrive Friday, it is primed to conduct the first detailed mapping survey of the planet's mysterious surface, which lies beneath a perpetual covering of dense, acrid clouds.

LEAD: Businessland Inc. stunned Wall Street today by posting losses for the fourth quarter and the year far in excess of analysts' estimates. The stock of the personal computer retailer lost more than half its value, plunging $4, to $2.875.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The players who captured the Curtis Cup for the United States late last month played the best golf in the first day of the 90th United States Women's Amateur Championship today at Canoe Brook Country Club.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has barred two executives of Jefferies & Company from the securities business for six months for their roles in events that led to the criminal conviction of two prominent Wall Street figures last year.
LEAD: Baseball caps used to be strictly for men. But this summer women have taken to wearing them with a passion.

LEAD: No policy to contain Saddam Hussein, let alone force Iraq to resume the status quo ante in Kuwait, can work without active support from Saudi Arabia. The question for U.S. policy makers and other world leaders is how to persuade King Fahd to take the necessary risks.

LEAD: The first dance program of the 1990 Central Park Summerstage festival got off to a varied start on Friday night at the pretty new outdoor performance space just east of the 72d Street Band Shell.
LEAD: The Board of Education offered yesterday to put back on the street more than 100 police officers now giving instruction in police work and crime-prevention to pupils in New York.

LEAD: Each workday morning, Ron Walker, 30 years old, a senior credit analyst for the Bank of Boston, drops off Elvi at day care by 8, then rushes for the 8:36 train to the city. Elvi seems to enjoy day care. Yesterday morning Mr. Walker pulled up to the curb and Elvi dashed from the car, leaving the door open.

LEAD: SUMMER is the kindest time of all to those who know they shouldn't have their cake, but keep eating it. Succulent melons, blushing nectarines, bright red strawberries, plump plums take the onus off desserts for anyone worrying about what makes most desserts taste so good: fat.

LEAD: Don Johnson, a co-star of the television show ''Miami Vice,'' who in his spare time won the 1988 world championship in the superboat division of powerboat racing, will lead a fleet of more than 40 high-powered motorboats on Aug. 18 when the New York Offshore Grand Prix is contested on the waters of the Hudson
LEAD: * Apple Bancorp., New York, said the Delaware Chancery Court had denied Stanley Stahl's motion seeking to compel Apple to hold its 1990 annual meeting by Sept. 14.

LEAD: A notebook kept behind the bulletproof glass where American consular officers talk to visa applicants is proof of the desperation created by Peru's deepening guerrilla violence and economic ruin.

LEAD: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq remained unrepentant in the face of growing pressure today, saying in a speech that ''Iraq will firmly confront any imperialist or Zionist attempt from any side that may stand against Kuwait's uprising or infringe on Arab dignity and land.''
LEAD: How much is a police officer worth to a taxpayer?

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday on Federal housing legislation misstated the difference in spending between the Senate proposal and the Bush Administration plan. According to estimates by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the $27.9 billion Senate version would provide $4.2 billion more than the White House version.

LEAD: Finding nothing so urgent that can't wait till September, Congress broke for its summer vacation right on schedule. The budget deficit? Manana. Curbs on campaign contributions? Clean air? Child care? Some other day. New taxes? Horrors.
