LEAD: * Eastman Kodak Co., Rochester, the photographic materials and chemicals company, appointed Dennis M. Peck chief executive of Interactive Systems Corp., a computer supplies and services unit.

LEAD: By allowing American troops to land on its territory and increasing its oil production, Saudi Arabia tonight proclaimed what it has been reluctant to say openly for decades: that its interests lie with the West.

LEAD: United States marines evacuated 21 more foreigners from Liberia today, including several Americans, as a rebel leader who seized more than a dozen hostages on Monday threatened to attack the 237 marines protecting the American Embassy in Monrovia.

LEAD: The Alvin Ailey Dance Theater Foundation will establish a second home, in Baltimore, it announced yesterday. The foundation, which is based in New York City, is the umbrella institution for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, a school and a junior dance company, the Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble.

LEAD: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about Congressional testimony by James M. Fail, an Arizona businessman who bought 15 insolvent savings and loan associations, misidentified Mr. Fail's lawyer. He is Ronald S. Liebman.

LEAD: Trade School Problems Critics of the nation's 4,000 private trade schools say many schools are more interested in getting Federal aid than in helping students. Page B6. Georgia Democrats Choose Lieut. Gov. Zell Miller swamped Andrew Young, the former Mayor of Atlanta, in a runoff to win the nomination for governor.

LEAD: CHRISTIAN BRANDO pleaded not guilty yesterday to murdering his pregnant half-sister's boyfriend during an argument at the home of his father, MARLON BRANDO. He also pleaded not guilty to possession of an illegal weapon, a machine pistol.

LEAD: Last fall, Gov. Ray Mabus proposed sweeping changes designed to rescue Mississippi's long-suffering schools. This spring, the Legislature first strengthened and then swiftly approved the package.
LEAD: I'M looking at Louie. Louie is looking back at me. Louie is a two-pound lobster with little black eyes.

LEAD: He had not pitched in two months, not since the June night in Baltimore when his right elbow suddenly gave out in the second inning. But tonight, three months after he was acquired in a controversial trade and 11 months since his last victory, Mike Witt finally won.
LEAD: ''There have been changes of a sort that cause us to believe there is a growing and continuous threat to Saudi Arabia.'' - Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. [A8:2.]

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on July 27 about laws requiring businesses to grant leave for workers who need to care for ill family members or newborn babies referred incorrectly to the status of legislation in New Jersey. New Jersey's family-leave law, among the broadest in the nation, went into effect in May, giving employees at businesses with at least 100 workers the right to take up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave every two years to care for a new baby or an ill family member.

LEAD: My plan was to wax wroth today about gasoline prices being raised at Biff's Exxon before Iraq's Wehrmacht had moved more than 10 yards into money-rich Kuwait. Luckily, while I was searching for the wax my gaze fell on a New York Times story that took the steam out of me.
LEAD: Oil turned Kuwait virtually overnight from a sleepy, mud-walled little fortress that sheltered pearl divers and traders into an air-conditioned Eden where wealth accumulated without work.

LEAD: Iraq has been jamming the Arabic-language broadcasts of Voice of America for three days, the radio network said today. The network, run by the United States Government, said it would try to beam its programs to Iraq through satellite television tonight. The jamming has affected much of Voice of America's broadcasting to the Middle East, including the Persian Gulf and Jordan, said the network's deputy director, Robert Coonrood.

LEAD: France's continuing addiction to the movies can be easily measured by the extraordinary variety of feature films broadcast at prime time, free of charge and without commercial breaks, every week on French television.
LEAD: The Upsala College basketball program was placed on five years' probation yesterday, banned from post-season play for three years and ordered to trim its 1990-91 schedule to 22 games from 26.

LEAD: The main article in Business Day yesterday about the performance of the stock market on Monday incorrectly characterized the drop in the Dow Jones industrial average in some copies. The decline, to 2,716.34, was the biggest one-day drop since Oct. 13, 1989; the close was the lowest since May 4, 1990, when it was 2,710.36.

LEAD: THE steam from four outdoor lobster pots rose toward the blue sky and danced like happy ghosts in a balsam-scented breeze over Mount Desert Island, Me. It was a perfect Maine day. LEAD: How high can oil prices go?

LEAD: The Intel Corporation won a round in its copyright suit against Advanced Micro Devices Inc. over its math coprocessor chip, the 80287. United States District Court Judge William A. Ingram issued a ruling blocking Advanced Micro from using the phrases ''genuine Intel equivalent,'' ''100 percent Intel compatible'' or their equivalents in advertising.
LEAD: The jury in the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. reached a verdict today on one misdemeanor count of cocaine possession, but in a suprising move it refused to disclose it.

LEAD: The stock market continued to react nervously to events in the Middle East yesterday but steadied after a steep three-day slide. Fears of higher oil prices and inflation were still very much on investors' minds, as the Dow Jones industrial average fluctuated within a 65-point range.

LEAD: TENNIS Graf Rolls Past Rehe Steffi Graf, whose chief rival, Martina Navratilova, dropped out earlier in the day, rolled to an easy 6-0, 6-3 victory over Stephanie Rehe yesterday in her first match at the $225,000 Great American tournament in San Diego. Navratilova, seeded second, was scheduled to play her first match last night.

LEAD: A Federal court in New Orleans denied a request yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board for a rehearing of a case testing the validity of the Fed's power to control the financial affairs of bank holding companies.

LEAD: The rise in oil prices on world markets slowed yesterday. And prices could steady or even fall, analysts and traders said, if Saudi Arabia raised its production and other exporting nations followed suit.
LEAD: A strike threatened by 80,000 California supermarket workers was put on hold early today so contract talks could continue.

LEAD: With oil from Iraq and Kuwait under embargo and the threat of war hanging over the Middle East, oil companies are preparing to redeploy their tanker fleets to pick up oil from alternative producers. And they are already paying a price for the region's instability in the form of higher insurance rates for ships and cargo.

LEAD: Scheduling a Maine vacation according to phases of the moon in August is not the easiest thing to do. To maintain proximate sanity, one cannot disclose the scheme; it's really easier to say that you have to check the schedule with the cat sitter or the closet organizer, then sneak a peek at the moon-phase calendar.

LEAD: Before its monthlong recess, Congress moved toward completing an unfinished legislative agenda of the 1980's by passing the first major bills in years on child care, housing, civil rights and the environment. But these ambitious proposals are threatened by legislative, financial and political obstacles.

LEAD: Coach Bruce Coslet made a startling admission today, four days before the Jets' opening preseason game: When he took over as head coach, he had virtually given up on Freeman McNeil. But McNeil will start at running back against the Philadelphia Eagles Saturday night.

LEAD: Airport Expansion - The House has authorized $17.7 billion in spending over the next two years to upgrade the nation's aviation system that includes letting airports levy a tax on roundtrip airline tickets of up to $12. The tax faces strong opposition in the Senate, which has not yet acted.

LEAD: American consumers are being ''ripped off on a massive scale,'' Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut said yesterday, voicing anger felt around the country. The anger is directed at gas stations and oil companies that jacked up prices even though the gasoline they were selling was imported long before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.
LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it had voted 3 to 2 to approve a long-awaited consent order that it expects will make the accounting profession more competitive.

LEAD: Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader, unexpectedly faced with a rapid and menacing global response to his invasion of Kuwait, increasingly is being backed into a corner from which his most likely options are to surrender or to lash out militarily, private and Government experts on the Middle East said today.
LEAD: Natural gas, long regarded by oil producers as the crab grass of fossil fuels, is getting new consideration because of the crisis in the Middle East.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Virginia Royall Inness-Brown, a proponent of the arts and former consultant to the State Department, died July 28 at Miles Memorial Hospital in Damariscotta, Me. She was 89 years old.
LEAD: By joining the worldwide sanctions against Iraq today Turkey moved more decisively than many cautious and even nervous people here had wished.

LEAD: Joe Slovo, a leading figure in both the African National Congress and the South African Communist Party, said today that the organizations' low-key guerrilla war, suspended in what many here took as a major breakthrough, could still be revived.

LEAD: Jay Bell's sacrifice fly after Jose Lind's leadoff double in the 12th inning gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 4-3 victory tonight over Montreal, the Expos' sixth consecutive loss, a season high.

Judge Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District Court performed the ceremony at the Federal Court House in New York.
LEAD: Customs officials today seized a shipload of Iraqi crude oil at Port Arthur saying it violated the United States trade embargo.

LEAD: While the powerful Japanese economy appears to be in a position to ride out the storm of higher oil prices and disrupted supplies relatively well, the country's weak link in an otherwise solid economic chain may be in the financial markets, economists and analysts say.

LEAD: THE old argument about French wine versus California wine goes on and on, but the wine enthusiasts who gathered here recently had no time for it. They were wine makers, French and American, some of the most highly regarded in their profession, and they were here to learn from each other, not compete.
LEAD: President Bush is to address the nation on the Persian Gulf crisis today at 9 A.M., the White House said late yesterday.

LEAD: MOST people think of salads as cold, but it's not necessarily so. I have been experimenting; warm salads are excellent appetizers or main courses any time of year.
LEAD: A 49-year-old Colombian immigrant who was a high-ranking official in the New York chapter of his country's Liberal Party was killed Monday night outside his house in Queens, the police said.
LEAD: Raw tomatoes may be the common link in a salmonella outbreak that has sickened more than 100 people in four Midwestern states in the past month, health officials say.

LEAD: Michael J. Fox and James Woods were rehearsing a fight scene under the domed rotunda of the Beacon Theater in Manhattan. Their director, John Badham, looked on for a while, then turned to the New York City police lieutenant standing next to him. ''Is that all right?'' he asked.
LEAD: Wall Street is offering varying, and in some cases contradictory, advice for individual investors seeking a safe harbor after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

LEAD: Like the cactuses that dot the desert, Arizonans pride themselves on being able to stand alone, no matter the heat.
LEAD: A company that made a faulty mechanical heart valve reversed itself yesterday and said it would try to find all of the 21,000 patients implanted with the device in the United States.

The deal in April ended the $1.64 billion bid made by BTR P.L.C., a British conglomerate.

LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins's decision to hire 1,058 more police officers is the latest in a long string of similar pledges by recent mayors and would-be mayors of New York City, maneuvers in a numbers game that has as much to do with political appearances as with fighting crime.

LEAD: Labor-contract negotiations between the Western Union Corporation and the Communications Workers of America continued yesterday after a previous contract between the company and the union expired at midnight Monday. The C.W.A. represents 2,500 of the 3,400 workers at the ailing financial services and telecommunications company.

LEAD: Justice John Paul Stevens said today that it was fruitless and inappropriate to use the coming Senate confirmation hearings of Judge David H. Souter to predict how he would decide cases as a member of the United States Supreme Court.

LEAD: Tanglewood's annual Festival of Contemporary Music is performed primarily by the youthful fellows and assorted faculty of the Tanglewood Music Center and takes place in the smaller theaters on the Tanglewood grounds. This year's festival is running from Saturday afternoon through Thursday night.
LEAD: Sweaters made of synthetic fibers in South Korea are being sold in the United States at less than fair market value, the Commerce Department said last week.

LEAD: She is golf's teen-age phenomenon, with numerous championships, including the United States Women's Amateur, to her credit, but Vicki Goetze is not a golf fanatic.

LEAD: An apparently deranged man who had been refused help by a Bronx legal aid agency opened fire from the sidewalk into the agency's Grand Concourse offices yesterday, injuring two employees, the police said.

LEAD: Saks Fifth Avenue, the nation's largest luxury retailer, which was recently bought by a Middle East investment group, named two vice chairmen this week, Arthur C. Martinez and Philip B. Miller.

LEAD: The value of farm land in the Midwest continues its climb in the second quarter of 1990, a new survey indicates. The survey of 420 agricultural bankers in Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Wisconsin and Michigan indicates that farmland values rose 1 percent in the April-to-June period. That means farmland values are up 33 percent from their lows more than three years ago, said Peter Heffernan, an analyst for the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about problems in raising funds to fight AIDS referred incorrectly to the status of a bill authorizing $875 million for AIDS-related health care. It has been passed by Congress and sent to President Bush.

LEAD: MEN'S fashions were center stage in New York last week as leading designers showed their spring 1991 lines. The dominant message was hang loose. The antidote to the french-cuffed, pin-collared, my-suit-wants-to-eat-you-for-breakfast 1980's seems to be a roomier, slouchier, less uptight Mr. Dude.
LEAD: Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd Jr., a former Commandant of the Marine Corps and a decorated veteran of both World Wars and the Korean War, died Monday at his home in San Diego. He was 94 years old.
LEAD: In the five days since Iraq occupied Kuwait, the Soviet Union and the United States have begun testing a new working relationship that is without precedent since the outset of the cold war.

LEAD: At this time of tens of thousands of teen-agers around the country are at summer camps, engaged in a wide variety of sporting and cultural activities. To that long list four camps have added bridge this season: Belvoir Terrace in Lenox, Mass.; Camp Emerson in Hinsdale, Mass.; Camp Laurel in Readfield, Me.; and Camp Merrimac, in Contoocook, N.H.

LEAD: Bush Administration officials said today that Washington was prepared to invite the Soviet Union into any international naval force assembled to enforce sanctions against Iraq. They added that they had no doubt that Moscow would want to take part.

LEAD: Sir Peter Hall has announced his resignation as artistic director of the Glyndebourne Festival Opera because, he said, he was not consulted about the director Peter Sellars's decision to delete all the spoken dialogue from his recent production of Mozart's ''Magic Flute.''
LEAD: Here in the Naugatuck Valley, long a bastion of the white working class, Gary Franks is an unlikely candidate for a seat in Congress. He is a black Republican.

LEAD: Because of a mechanical error, a news analysis article from Washington yesterday about President Bush's decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia appeared without a byline in some copies. The writer was Thomas L. Friedman.

LEAD: Joe Morris reads it in the newspapers and hears it on television and radio. He hears people say he is not the runner he was, that his job is in danger, that when the pro football season begins in less than five weeks he may no longer be a Giant.

LEAD: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that oil price shocks need not topple the economy into a recession, and he called on the Federal Reserve to stimulate growth with lower interest rates.

LEAD: Morris Ginsberg, a retired steamship company executive who helped buy ships to settle Jews in Palestine in the 40's, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

LEAD: ''A line has been drawn in the sand.'' - President Bush. [A1:6.]
LEAD: Golf's best players today sounded off on a topic they could be truly passionate about: the grass at Shoal Creek Country Club.

LEAD: In what shipping industry officials call the largest wage award in maritime history, a Federal district judge has ordered that 21 Filipino sailors be given $32 million to make up for a wage system in which some were paid only a fraction of what was reported by ship owners.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Sharper Image Corporation, a retailer of unusual high-technology products, announced today that it would cut its nationwide workforce by 10 percent. The layoffs of about 110 of the company's 1,100 workers include corporate and store employees. The layoffs come amid a sales slump for most types of retailers.

LEAD: When the Rev. Abraham Lincoln Woods speaks to visitors in the quiet of his cramped office at St. Joseph's Baptist Church, it is often with his eyelids nearly closed, his mind drawing on the hard lessons of 35 years on the battlefields of the civil rights movement.

LEAD: CEDAR closet lining, which repels moths without the need for chemicals, is not difficult to install as long as the surfaces are suitable. As noted last week, there are two types of lining; sheets are less expensive and easier to install, but many people find them less attractive than strips. Either kind can be fastened to flat, smooth walls, or to furring strips if the wall has bumps or hollows.

LEAD: Wade Omer Martin Jr., Louisiana Secretary of State for 32 years, died Monday at his home in Baton Rouge, La. He was 79 years old. The cause of death was not given. Mr. Martin, a lawyer, was elected Secretary of State in 1944 at the age of 33. He quit in 1976 to run for governor. After defeat in that race, he retired to private practice and served as a consultant to the Louisiana Elections Integrity Commission.

LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Bank is offering $275 million in system bonds due in 1995 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

LEAD: Rosemary Baker hummed to herself on the No. 5 train to the Bronx on her way to work at a construction site. She shrugged off fears of crime, even after the rash of violence in recent weeks that has left four children dead.

LEAD: Television news organizations, their camera crews and correspondents barred along with other journalists from Iraq and Kuwait, returned this week to what a senior network news executive described as the kind of reporting that radio did during World War II: broad based and, of course, picture-free.

LEAD: Iraq released an American child today and permitted United States officials to visit 38 other Americans confined to a Baghdad hotel, but it continued to hold them under armed guard, the State Department announced today.

LEAD: Eugene F. Black, a former Michigan Supreme Court justice, died Saturday at his home in Port Huron, Mich. He was 87 years old. The cause of death was not announced. Justice Black was a member of the State Supreme Court from 1955 until 1972, when he returned to private practice. He was Attorney General of Michigan from 1946 to 1948.

LEAD: British Airways P.L.C. said Tuesday that its first-quarter profits rose 79 percent despite a slower rise in sales. British Airways' profits for the three months that ended June 30 came to $:111 million, or about $194 million, up from $:62 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. The carrier's sales rose 14 percent, to $:1.33 billion, or about $2.3 billion, from $:1.17 billion.

LEAD: SKIING Roth Wins Opening Race Peter Roth of West Germany overcame 13 rivals with a sizzling second run and won the opening slalom race of the 1990-91 World Cup season by a hundredth of a second over Michael Tritscher of Austria yesterday in Mount Hutt, New Zealand. The victory was the 29-year-old Roth's first in 12 years on the World Cup circuit.

LEAD: Confronted with a tax protest that refuses to go away, Gov. Jim Florio announced today that he would go to the voters on television and in fireside chats to explain the record $2.8 billion tax increase he pushed through the Legislature six weeks ago.

LEAD: The tenor saxophonists Johnny Griffin and Von Freeman, both playing at the peak of their abilities, stormed through their concert at the Classical Jazz festival at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night, offering intense, complicated improvisations.

LEAD: Americans bought $629 million worth of United States savings bonds in July, up 4 percent from the period a year earlier and 2 percent from June, the Government reported on Tuesday. LEAD: Thousands of elite United States troops, the vanguard of a force that senior defense officials said may reach 50,000, took up positions in Saudi Arabia today as President Bush vowed to defend the Middle Eastern kingdom and its oil reserves, the richest in the world.

LEAD: Stocks advanced strongly in active trading yesterday, as oil prices turned downward following President Bush's morning address to the nation explaining the dispatch of United States troops to Saudi Arabia.

LEAD: Jacques Soustelle, an anthropologist and former Cabinet minister who was one of the leaders of an underground movement that fought against Algerian independence, died Tuesday in the Paris suburb of Neuilly-sur-Seine. He was 78 years old. The cause of death was not reported. Dr. Soustelle, who was named to the Academie Francaise in 1983, was one of Europe's foremost experts on pre-Colombian civilizations in Mexico, on which he wrote several authoritative studies.
LEAD: Two months after voting to deny unemployment benefits to thousands of temporary census workers, Congress has decided to reverse itself.

LEAD: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., the British-American health and household products company, said today that its second-quarter profit jumped 47.5 percent from the period a year ago because of continued sales growth, strong operating profits and large debt reduction.

LEAD: Until a couple of weeks ago, even the possibility would have been unthinkable. Now, however, the Yankees are within sight of sixth place and have a legitimate chance of escaping a last-place finish. They owe it all to the Milwaukee Brewers. The Yankees, who have been in last place for two and a half months, since late May, were nine and a half games from sixth as recently as July 26.

LEAD: In a management shake-up announced today, Edward A. Brennan, chairman and chief executive of Sears, Roebuck & Company, will take direct control of the company's troubled merchandise group. Mr. Brennan will assume the additional title of chief executive of that group.
LEAD: A 19-year-old Bronx man was arrested yesterday and charged in the slaying of a teen-ager who had danced on Broadway, the police said.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from a news conference at the Pentagon today by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription agency: OPENING STATEMENTS
LEAD: Tim Raines broke out of an 0-for-18 slump with two run-scoring doubles to back Dennis Martinez's six-hitter as the Montreal Expos beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-2, tonight.

LEAD: Pakistan's new caretaker Prime Minister, Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, who took office Monday after the abrupt dismissal of Benazir Bhutto's Government, pledged today to investigate and punish those responsible for what he called ''the worst corruption in Pakistan's history.''

LEAD: Paul Evantoff paid 5 cents a gallon more this morning to fill his gas tank at Fred's Chevron than it did last week, a development he attributed to the eagerness of the big oil companies to cash in on the turmoil in the Middle East. ''It's really greed with a capital 'G,' '' Mr. Evantoff said.
LEAD: The recent outbreak of a potentially fatal disease linked to L-tryptophan probably came from an impurity introduced by a change in how the dietary supplement was made, scientists say.

LEAD: TONIGHT at 8, Paul Panhuysen and Johan Goedhart, Dutch multi-media artists, will turn the Great Hall of the National Building Museum in Washington into a concert hall. The performance is called a Long String Installation.
LEAD: A caption in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday about the New York Jets training camp misidentified the coach shown. He was Bruce Coslet, the head coach.

LEAD: While the leaders of the oil-producing countries of the Persian Gulf region welcomed the arrival of American troops in Saudi Arabia and the commitment by President Bush to defend the kingdom, anxiety was evident at airline offices and banks.

LEAD: SCALI McCABE SLOVES, once one of the most talked-about agencies on Madison Avenue because of its innovative work for Perdue chicken and Volvo, is now getting the kind of critical attention most agency executives abhor.

LEAD: Better late than never, Lincoln Center commissioned its first jazz composition for the Classical Jazz concert on Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall. LEAD: Pete Rose arrived at the Federal work camp here today to begin serving a five-month sentence for cheating on his income-tax returns.

LEAD: Raphael Yavneh, retired president of the Forbes Investors Advisory Institute, an affiliate of Forbes Inc., the magazine publisher, died on Monday at New York Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Bud Harrelson, who had said he wasn't much of a preacher anyway, opted against holding any revival meeting. Still, as he sat in his office before yesterday's game against the Phillies, the manager of the Mets felt compelled to do some thing inspirational.

LEAD: FORGET about potted palms and intimate corners in which to rendezvous. There is no clock to meet under.

LEAD: The Rev. Arthur H. Tildesley, an Episcopal priest, died on Saturday at his home in Fair Haven, N.J. He was 58 years old.
LEAD: * Chris Dickens has been appointed worldwide media director at Young & Rubicam.

LEAD: Fleeing or forced from their homes by the stepped-up war in the Cambodian countryside, huddling against a torrid sun or stinging rain in crude shelters of thatch and plastic sheeting, they have the semivacant stare of refugees everywhere.

LEAD: Now it's up to other countries, particularly Arab countries. President Bush has drawn a line in the sand, committing U.S. forces to face down Saddam Hussein. The costs and risks are momentous, going well beyond U.S. military operations in Lebanon, Grenada and Panama.

LEAD: The jury weighing the Government's drug and perjury case against Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. took another look today at an 84-minute videotape that shows him smoking crack and being arrested in a room at the Vista Hotel here last January. But the Federal panel recessed without announcing any verdict.

LEAD: Scientists probing the depths of Lake Baikal in the Soviet Union have discovered heat escaping from cracks in the lake bottom to support rich communities of exotic life, much like those around hydrothermal vents in the midocean ridges. It is the first time such a phenomenon has been found in fresh water.

LEAD: Because of the Dominican Day Parade, Madison Avenue will be closed on Sunday from 37th to 56th Streets from noon to 4 P.M.

LEAD: In the past, Sandinista leaders reserved terms like ''coercion,'' ''authoritarianism'' and ''abuse of power'' to describe mortal enemies like the deposed Somoza dictatorship and the Reagan White House. Now, the Sandinistas have turned that language on a new target: themselves.

LEAD: When Shoal Creek Country Club of Alabama burst into the headlines as a symbol of restricted all-white golf clubs, Robert F. Carroll wasn't too surprised. ''There are Shoal Creeks all over,'' he said. ''There are Shoal Creeks a couple of minutes from here.''

LEAD: Only a few hours after Actors' Equity in New York announced its decision to bar Jonathan Pryce from acting in a Broadway production of ''Miss Saigon,'' Mr. Pryce was back on stage here, doing his job in the theater, giving an electrifying performance in the role of his career.

LEAD: In response to growing environmental concerns among consumers, the Lever Brothers Company said it was planning to use more recycled plastics in the bottles of its liquid soaps and other products. The New York-based company pledged to buy at least 10 million pounds of recycled high-density polyethylene a year.

LEAD: As American forces pour into Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf, there are signs that a military stalemate between Iraq and the United States is rapidly developing.

LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, will redeem on Sept. 10 all of its outstanding 9.25 percent fixed-rate notes due Sept. 10, 1992, which were issued in 1987. The notes will be redeemed at 100 percent of the principal amount, with interest accrued up to Sept. 10 of $46.25 per $1,000 principal amount.

LEAD: Shows, Nature, Museums CENTRAL PARK ZOO, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday to Friday (until 8 P.M. on Tuesday) and 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. on weekends; gift shop and cafeteria are open the same hours. LEAD: In a case that is likely to present some uncomfortable legal issues, an Oshkosh man is to stand trial next month on charges of sexually assaulting a 26-year-old acquaintance suffering from what has been diagnosed as multiple personality disorder.

LEAD: Andres Galarraga scored from second base in the 10th inning on Mike Fitzgerald's bad-hop grounder when Don Slaught did not cover home plate to give the Montreal Expos a 7-6 victory tonight over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

LEAD: Saying New York City's crime problems are not hopeless, a business-sponsored anti-crime group offered a formula yesterday that it said could turn back the clock a generation and restore the streets to forgotten levels of safety.

LEAD: All the uncertainty in the Persian Gulf has insured at least one thing at home: this fall's elections, which weeks ago seemed but a hodgepodge of races with little national focus, will now revolve heavily around the economy as it sags under the burden of rising oil prices.

LEAD: Federal District Judge Harold H. Greene today removed one of the lingering legal uncertainties in the proposed $2.4 billion acquisition of New Zealand's state-owned telephone company by the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the American Information Technologies Corporation, or Ameritech.

LEAD: The assets of the nation's 522 money market mutual funds increased by $6.03 billion, to $401.94 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 169 institutional funds increased by $1.39 billion, to $100.29 billion; 249 general-purpose funds were up by $3.7 billion, to $139.42 billion, and 104 broker-dealer funds increased by $946.9 million, to $162.24 billion, the institute said.

LEAD: A construction company owner who illegally demolished four buildings in Times Square in the middle of the night in 1985 was shot to death Wednesday in front of his house in Brooklyn in what the police described as a mob-style slaying.

LEAD: Zvee Aroni, a prominent cantor for Conservative Jewish congregations, died Tuesday at his daughter's home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 65 years old and lived in North Miami Beach.

LEAD: A New York State investigation into a major Colombian drug cartel has led to the indictments of five Queens residents on cocaine-trafficking charges and has shed light on what the authorities say is the structure of the cartel's New York operations.

LEAD: Vice President Dan Quayle warned Haitian leaders today that the United States would cut off economic aid to this Caribbean nation if general elections scheduled for November are not free and fair.

LEAD: The New York City police will no longer use one type of chemical spray to stun people, after a 14-year-old Brooklyn youth was seriously burned when officers used the chemical on him in conjunction with a stun device, Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown said last night.

LEAD: A group of companies controlled by the New York investor Mario J. Gabelli, the owner of Gabelli & Company, has acquired 5.08 percent of Paramount Communications Inc. for $225.8 million. In a Securites and Exchange Commission filing, the Gabelli group said it now controlled 6.04 million of the entertainment company's 118.9 million shares outstanding.

LEAD: FOR generations, hot dogs and beer have been as much a part of the baseball ritual as chewing tobacco and pudgy managers throwing tantrums at home plate. It was inevitable, though, that the food revolution sweeping across the land would scale the walls of the nation's ballparks, threatening to turn our ingenuous national pastime into a food event.

LEAD: On the heels of a warning by a Federal administrator that racketeers still control the Fulton Fish Market, New York City officials said yesterday that they have a plan for ''comprehensive reform.'' But they said they would withhold details of the plan for about 30 days.

LEAD: Howard O. McMahon, a scientist, inventor and former president of Arthur D. Little Inc., the international management and technology consulting concern, died Sunday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 75 years old and lived in Cambridge.

LEAD: A lawyer who played a major role in exposing corruption in New York City government by disclosing he had paid kickbacks on a city contract has been suspended from practicing law for five years for his part in the scheme.
LEAD: Consistent fare from the north of India, with some scorchers from elsewhere thrown in.
LEAD: Michael Robinson, a composer of electronic music who began his career in New York and moved to Hawaii last year, returned to present 11 of his works at St. Peter's Church on Tuesday evening.

LEAD: In Hollywood, Alec Baldwin, the blue-eyed star of ''The Hunt for Red October,'' is a major celebrity, the kind of person who attracts gawkers and swooning teen-agers whenever he steps outside. Here in East Hampton, he is just another homeowner who might not be allowed to build an addition to his house.

LEAD: Tonight's edition of ''20/20'' goes to Athens, Ga., for an account of the reconciliation of Dean Rusk, the former Secretary of State, and his son, Richard, after years of division over the elder Rusk's role in the Vietnam War. The program, at 10 o'clock on ABC, does not go deeply into the reconciliation, which began in 1985; the occasion for dealing with it now seems to be the recent publication of ''As I Saw It,'' which Dean

LEAD: The Department of Trade and Industry cleared Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C.'s $211 million acquisition of Source Perrier S.A.'s non-cola soft-drinks business. The purchase includes two plants in the Paris area and another in Marseilles for various brands of a Perrier unit that includes Oasis and Bali orange squashes, Pschitt sodas and Gini lemonade.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: The scandal over a country club's racially exclusionary membership policy will make corporations more cautious about paying to associate their names with athletic events, a $2 billion industry that until now has been growing explosively.
LEAD: From the days of Bull Connor's police dogs and fire hoses to the present, perhaps no American city has had to wrestle with the demons of race so conspicuously as Birmingham.

LEAD: The judge in the Central Park jogger trial told the jury yesterday that contrary to defense assertions, the law did not necessarily require parents to be present for the questioning of the three youthful defendants.

LEAD: Timothy F. Finley, a turnaround manager, has been named president and chief executive of Jos. A. Bank Clothiers Inc., which operates 40 retail clothing stores throughout the United States and is known for its American-made men's suits.

LEAD: On the official docket of the American Bar Association's annual meeting here this week, item No. 1 was abortion rights. But amid the tinkling piano bars in the hotel atriums, alongside the canapes and crudites at the receptions, another monomania prevailed: What in the Sam Hill happened to Stan Chauvin's cash?

LEAD: YOU will have to scramble a bit - the deadline for submitting an entry form is Monday - if you wish to take part in the River Project's annual instant boat contest. This year the contest will be Aug. 25-26, and even if you don't wish to participate, you might enjoy watching the zany event.
LEAD: Seventh Heaven By Alice Hoffman 256 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.
LEAD: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously today to declare Iraq's formal annexation of Kuwait null and void in international law.

LEAD: A Federal effort to reach drug addicts with programs born out of the AIDS epidemic has recorded success rates as high as 47 percent in getting them to quit, the Centers for Disease Control reported today.
LEAD: * Ritz Carlton Hotel, Chicago, to Zwiren Collins Karo Trusk & Ayer, Ayer's Chicago affiliate, with an estimated budget of $1 million. The account had been with Haddon Advertising Inc., Chicago.

LEAD: * Dean Scaros, the president of Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc., the United States division of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide, has been given the additional title of chief operating officer of the division. The promotion of Mr. Scaros fills the position left vacant since the retirement last year of G.

LEAD: 3 houses in London to sell rock memorabilia, including Presley's library card and first driver's license and much from the Beatles. Going by the collected wisdom of 1960's rock songs, summer is a time for surfing, romance, street-fighting or just getting gritty on the city streets. Songwriters seem not to have caught on yet, but in the last decade summer has also turned into a hot time for buying and selling rock-and-roll memorabilia.
LEAD: In one day, the Defense Minister was replaced and 143 officers retired. Such military changes take place peacefully here, but some Venezuelans wonder how long that will continue.

LEAD: JENNIFER CAPRIATI, the 14-year-old tennis player who turned professional only six months ago, is scheduled to play in the New York area for the first time since she charmed Wimbledon in July. Jennifer lost there to STEFFI GRAF, but is ranked 13th among women players.
LEAD: Dr. Earl R. Zack, a psychologist and an educator, died yesterday in Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Florida. He was 77 years old and lived in Sarasota.

LEAD: A dank, sunless morning. A distracted young woman with the features of a high-fashion model (Monica Vitti) walks along the bank of a ship canal. She holds the hand of her small son, pulling him along as if he were a wooden duck on wheels. She is distracted, but she looks terrific, her dark reddish-blond hair set off by the soft green of her cloth coat, which is, of course, couture.

LEAD: The Rev. Paul V. Callahan, a Jesuit priest and a teacher of classical languages for 33 years, died on Wednesday at St. Ignatius Loyola Residence in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 68 years old.

LEAD: New York State is exploring the sale of Aqueduct Race Track in Queens to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which would close the track and use the land to expand Kennedy International Airport, state officials said today.

LEAD: After all the witnesses are gone and all the arguments are finished, big court cases often hang on fragments - bits of jumbled facts and incomplete memories - that jurors fix on to test a theory or a witness's account as they try to decide what really happened.

LEAD: After 14 months of investigation, a House committee concluded today that the Reagan Administration had obstructed a $43 million Federal health study of Vietnam veterans exposed to the defoliant Agent Orange, causing the study's cancellation.

LEAD: In a match that will be remembered as one of the most exciting in the history of the United States Women's Amateur Championship, Pat Hurst defeated Vicki Goetze, the 17-year-old defending champion, 1-up, in the quarterfinals today.
LEAD: A spokesman for the Pakistani armed forces said today that there had been no request so far from Saudi Arabia for Pakistani troops to augment an international force facing the Iraqis.

LEAD: Alex English has agreed to a contract with the Dallas Mavericks, but he won't sign until he has a chance to meet with the team's owner, Donald Carter, The Dallas Morning News reported yesterday. (AP)

LEAD: Prices of long-term Treasury securities rebounded strongly yesterday after the Government's successful auction of $10.25 billion of 30-year bonds, the last of its record $32.25 billion quarterly refunding sales this week.

LEAD: While tensile-strength rough and Formica-firm greens made Shoal Creek an often infuriating test of composure today, a player who has been hardened by frustration emerged as the first-round leader of the 72d P.G.A. Championship.

LEAD: Dorothy Gillam Baker, a scholar and educator who researched patterns of development in world history, died on Aug. 3 at Albert Einstein Hospital in the Bronx. She was 84 years old and lived in the Bronx.

LEAD: William H. Donaldson, one of the three founding partners of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., was named chairman of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. He will replace John J. Phelan Jr., who will retire in January.

LEAD: Fifteen years after North Vietnamese tanks smashed into Saigon's Presidential Palace, there are still two Vietnams. The Republic of (South) Vietnam, that artificial creation of French colonialism and cold war politics, is no more. But commercial capitalism, the American presence and the Viet Cong-led insurrection pressed a distinctive subculture onto the South.

LEAD: The Procter & Gamble Company, one of the world's largest makers of consumer products, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings had surged 66.1 percent, to $284 million, or 78 cents a share.

LEAD: To Run for Canada Ben Johnson, who lost his Olympic gold medal and 100-meter world record after testing positive for steroids at the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, was given Government clearance yesterday to run again for Canada.

LEAD: Grey Advertising Inc., the New York-based agency, said its second-quarter earnings rose 4.5 percent, to $5.2 million, or $3.96 a share, from $4.9 million, or $3.73 a share, in the comparable period in 1989. Revenues rose 10.1 percent, to $117.6 million, from $106.8 million.
LEAD: War and Romance

LEAD: With almost every living jockey and trainer enshrined in racing's Hall of Fame looking on, two trainers, a jockey and four horses were inducted into the Hall this morning at the national Museum of Racing on Union Avenue.

LEAD: Two freight trains collided near this northwest Georgia town early today, killing two conductors and an engineer and injuring four other railroad employees. The authorities said one train was on the main Norfolk Southern track when it ran head-on into a train that had just moved off a side track shortly before 3:30 A.M.

LEAD: There is no innocence in the world of ''Flatliners'' - not in childhood memories, not in the motives of the medical students who push themselves beyond death and then return to life, not in the film's borrowings from classic horror movies. And all of that is to the good. ''Flatliners'' is a stylish, eerie psychological horror film laced with wit, a movie that thrives on its characters' guilty secrets and succeeds on the strength of the director Joel

LEAD: Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger's veto of a Columbia University plan to build on the site of the old Audubon Ballroom could hasten the decline of a deteriorating community and leave those who want to honor Malcolm X, murdered in the ballroom 25 years ago, with nothing but a building in ruins.
LEAD: Deliberations in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug and perjury trial were suspended today when one of the jurors was hospitalized for what her doctor called stress and depression.

LEAD: Joe Montana quickly negotiated one of the richest contracts in National Football League history today with Edward J. DeBartolo, the owner of the San Francisco 49ers. The 34-year-old quarterback agreed to a four-year deal reported to be worth $13 million.
LEAD: JAYNE TORVILL and CHRISTOPHER DEAN, the British Olympic ice-dancing champions, are engaged, but not to each other.
LEAD: Pascual Perez, the Yankee pitcher who signed a three-year, $5.7 million contract and then pitched just 14 innings this season, underwent surgery on his right shoulder today in Birmingham, Ala.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: In walking away from the tottering airline empire he created, Frank Lorenzo has arranged a far better deal for himself than is available to other shareholders.
LEAD: FRIDAY 3 BY BECKETT

LEAD: Janet Nevins Young, the executive director of the Van Hornesville (N.Y.) Community Corporation and a former insurance industry executive, died on Tuesday at her home in Van Hornesville. She was 61 years old. She died of cancer, a nephew said. Mrs. Young was a personnel manager for the Equitable Life Assurance Society and for the Mutual of New York Insurance Company for 20 years.
LEAD: A great leader, a new Saladin, is known for the enemies he makes. I now have the enemies I need.
LEAD: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said today that its profit fell 44.3 percent in the second quarter and the British Petroleum Company reported a drop of 88.9 percent.

LEAD: It's often said that every picture tells a story, but, in fact, so do many objects, especially when similar ones are grouped in an orderly profusion. ''Splash: A History of Swim Wear,'' a sometimes surrealistic exhibition at the Fashion Institute of Technology, deploys just such order and profusion in behalf of that essential modern invention, the swimming suit.
LEAD: With oil markets still jittery today, the industrial world's senior energy officials sought to reassure the industry and investors that there were sufficient oil supplies worldwide.

LEAD: Stocks advanced yesterday for the second consecutive session, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 24.01 points to 2,758.91. Favorable results of the Treasury's 30-year bond auction produced a late rally after stocks had drifted in light trading most of the day.
LEAD: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co., New York, appointed Richard S. Bodman senior vice president of strategic planning and corporate development.

LEAD: A front-page caption yesterday about Americans' reactions to the Persian Gulf crisis misidentified the man shown. He was Bruce Kennedy of Plattsburg, Mo., not Bruce Wilkinson, who was quoted in the caption.

LEAD: Frank J. Jiral, a Texas oil man, and five other Americans piled into two cars at 4 A.M. Wednesday and headed south out of Baghdad across the scorching desert, bound for the Iraqi-Jordanian border.

LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he was ''reaching out to Actors' Equity'' to see if he could help in the dispute that has led to the cancellation of the planned Broadway production of the London hit musical ''Miss Saigon.''
LEAD: There was blood, both bad and real. There were bruises, to egos as well as to arms and legs.

LEAD: At the Walterscheid home in the tiny town of Jacksboro, Tex., the trees are festooned with yellow ribbons. Family members give directions to the house by telling visitors to turn left at the trees with the big yellow bows.
LEAD: When Aaron Emanuel was in high school, he was such a good running back that he seemed ready to skip college and the pros and head right for the Pro Football Hall of Fame.
LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc., helped by strong sales of its low-priced computer work stations, reported sharply improved results for its fourth quarter and 1990 fiscal year.
LEAD: Spider-Man Project

LEAD: Vivaldi's unassuming ''Four Seasons'' has become the very emblem of crass commercialization in classical music. In listener polls, broadcasters report, the concerto cycle ranks second only to Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, and since it is handily separable into bite-size units, it constitutes the cornerstone of ever smaller, safer ''play lists.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Richard A. Styskal, deputy director of the Center for Labor-Management Policy Studies at the City University of New York, died on Sunday. He was 53 years old and lived in Mountainside, N.J.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Grolier Club is the latest of the cushy, homey semiprivate restaurants and nightspots to open in Manhattan - it also has some of the best food. The magnificent Romanesque four-story stone building at 29 East 32d Street has a baronial dining room on the ground floor with mahogany walls, leather and wood booths, scattered palms and soft jazz.

LEAD: The Justice Department filed a lawsuit today challenging Georgia's election system, which requires candidates to participate in a runoff if none receive 50 percent of the vote in primary elections.

LEAD: BASKETBALL United States Beats South Korea The United States routed South Korea, 146-67, yesterday in a game that was a far cry from the harried overtime victory over Greece on Wednesday in the opening game of the world championships in Buenos Aires. Alonzo Mourning scored 29 points in less than 19 minutes to lead the United States, which shot 73 percent from the field and outrebounded the South Koreans, 54-17.(AP)

LEAD: The centerpiece of the wonderful hodgepodge that is the summer show at the Salander-O'Reilly Galleries is a surprise. This gallery, which specializes in 20th-century art, has put on display ''Christ on the Cross'' by Francisco de Zurbaran, the 17th-century Spanish painter whose finely cut, firmly modeled, sculptural figures, bathed in bright light and black darkness, have appealed to a host of modern artists.

LEAD: Kenneth Eaglespeaker looked out over the plains that run eastward from the Rocky Mountains to the horizon, past clusters of visitors intent on learning about his ancestors, the Blackfoot Indians who hunted these plains for at least 6,000 years.
LEAD: Two gunmen disguised as policemen killed the Government's chief witness in the assassination of the presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan, the police said today.
LEAD: Sun Ra Celebrates
LEAD: Brian Holloway, the former Pro Bowl offensive lineman, has come out of retirement and signed a contract with the Buffalo Bills, the team announced yesterday.

LEAD: Several major oil companies cut or froze their wholesale gasoline prices yesterday. Others said that any price increases would be reasonable. And all the companies that made statements vigorously defended their pricing practices, which have come under strong criticism from consumers, who have faced sharp price rises at gasoline pumps in the last week.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it would offer four-year loans at 4.8 percent on selected car lines and $1,000 cash rebates on others. The low financing and rebates end on Sept. 26, the date of the official introduction of Ford's 1991 models. The 1991 Escort and the Ford Explorer are in showrooms and are exempt.

LEAD: Asked several months ago about the position of Hun Sen, the young and highly visible Cambodian Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, a Cambodian official smiled broadly. ''Don't forget Hun Sen is only No. 3 in the party,'' he said. ''Chea Sim is No. 2.''

Two corporations of which he was president, the BATO Company and Riviere du Loup Newsprint Ltd., pleaded guilty to willfully filing false tax returns, a felony.

LEAD: Bryan Holme, an author and retired publisher of photographic and art books, died Wednesday at his summer home in Round Pond, Me. He was 78 years old and also lived in Vero Beach, Fla. His son, Christopher, said his father had died of kidney failure. Mr. Holme had been the head of Studio Books, a subsidiary of Viking Press based in Manhattan.

LEAD: Lisbeth Ann Murray, a psychology student, and Dr. Theodore Max Miller, a psychiatrist, were married yesterday at the Bedford Village Inn in Bedford, N.H. The Rev. Ann Chamberlain, a minister of the Universal Life Church, officiated at the nondenominational ceremony.

LEAD: Frustrated by the wave of costly and slowly resolved asbestos cases, 10 Federal district judges with the heaviest caseloads agreed today on how to consolidate tens of thousands of cases clogging dockets around the nation.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The first stages of rehabilitation have begun on Connecticut's newest national historic landmark, the 209-year-old homestead of Oliver Ellsworth in Windsor, eight miles north of Hartford.

LEAD: Preserved first by benign neglect and now by design, the red-brick company town of Pullman, Ill., on the outskirts of Chicago, offers the visitor a revealing course in late-19th-century industrial paternalism. Though this is textbook social history, Pullman today is very much alive, a real place where people live - people proud of their community's past.

LEAD: THE biotechnology industry welcomed the California Supreme Court ruling last month that a man was not entitled to share in the profits from a drug developed from tissues removed from his body. But the case raised questions about the property status of tissues, genes and other biological materials, issues that are not likely to go away.
LEAD: Whenever Diane Gardner hears the squeal of tires outside her bedroom window, she picks up the telephone and dials 911.

LEAD: WHEN Actors' Equity voted on Tuesday to bar the English actor Jonathan Pryce from re-creating his prize-winning portrayal of a Eurasian pimp in a Broadway production of the London hit musical ''Miss Saigon,'' a lot more was potentially at issue than the future of the $10 million show, or its record $25 million advance sale, or whether the union even had a legal basis for taking such action.
LEAD: John G. Briggs Jr., a music critic who once served as Arturo Toscanini's press agent, died on Friday at the Cooper River Convalescent Center in Pennsauken, N.J.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: BY using plastic plumbing pipe instead of metal, amateurs can perform many home repairs and improvements that otherwise might require hiring a plumber.

LEAD: A woman wary of trees, the father of a creature who seems part baby and part worm, a trashy-chic punk heroine and a deadpan Hungarian woman on the road to Cleveland: some movie heroes are deeply weird, in the best sense of the word. Such socially misfit, funny and appealing characters are most likely to escape from film makers' imaginations at the start of their careers.

Rugged pioneers and their prairie schooners rank up there with the people on the Mayflower as historical archetypes. But even those who can manage a glib discourse on Manifest Destiny or identify the year when the Great
LEAD: Gloomy trade figures aside, at least one American product, the Harley-Davidson motorcycle, is outmaneuvering its competitors abroad.

LEAD: Last week it was what didn't happen that made the news. Despite the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the sending of American forces to Saudi Arabia, the dollar did not rise sharply. In the past, most traders would have expected the dollar to move much higher because it was considered a safe haven. But at the end of last week, the dollar was only a quarter of a pfennig stronger against the German mark than it had been before the Aug.

LEAD: For a short time last spring, it looked as if the Baylor University students of 1990 would be allowed to do something none of their predecessors had been allowed to do in the school's 145-year history - dance on campus.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Things were just fine for Hall Thompson and his Shoal Creek Country Club near Birmingham, Ala., in the weeks leading up to the P.G.A. Championship there last week. Then Mr. Thompson uttered some words that the Rev. Abraham Lincoln Woods thought he should eat. In an interview, Mr. Hall said that Shoal Creek discriminated against blacks and would not be pressured into changing.

LEAD: Kalen Leigh Donaldson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Whitney Donaldson of San Rafael, Calif., was married yesterday at Incline Village on Lake Tahoe in Nevada, to Stephen Rudd Best, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Best of Weston, Conn. The Rev. James F. Thompson performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Episcopal Church.

LEAD: The thought police are busy this year. With all the best intentions in the world - because aren't their intentions always honorable, from preserving the sanctity of the family to promoting racial equality? - they have proferred petitions, organized boycotts, brought lawsuits. Last week they even had the capacity to surprise us.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: This spring's breeding populations of wild ducks in North America were much the same as in 1989, approximately 22 percent below the 1955-1989 average, according to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.
LEAD: In Fashion, in Public

LEAD: WHILE most people look at a garden and see flowers, Sydney Eddison, of Newtown, also sees people. There are Viki Ferreniea, who gave her peonies, and Jim York, from whom she got her thread-leaf Japanese maple. ''And then there's Helen Gill,'' Mrs. Eddison said as she pointed out the soft border of lamb's ears and the tall stands of irises.

LEAD: LOCUST VALLEY'S Basil Leaf Cafe sings a summery tune. Its namesake herb, now burgeoning in Long Island gardens, is used with abandon, perfuming the air and adding pizazz to salads, pastas and pizzas.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Media Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is experimenting with holograms using a video image. Holograms, images created on flat surfaces by laser light that appear to be three-dimensional, are now frequently seen as decorative art, on credit cards among other things. Video hologram technology, when perfected, might offer architects the ability to draw a house on a computer screen and then examine its three-dimensional appearance or it could become the basis of three-dimensional television.

LEAD: The engagement of Deborah S. Wilner to Dr. Richard M. Hoffman has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Milton Wilner of Long Island City, Queens. A September wedding is planned.

LEAD: The TV View article on July 29, about Edward R. Murrow, misstated his age at his death in 1965. He was 57 years old.

LEAD: IN New York City, summers mean Mostly Mozart; but 90 miles away at the new Bard Music Festival, the focus will be on Rediscovering Brahms. The 600-acre Bard College campus is in Annandale-on-Hudson, just north of Rhinebeck, in the heart of the Hudson River Valley.

Cantor Nathaniel Benjamin assisted Rabbi Bruce Block in performing the ceremony at the Loews Glenpointe Hotel in Teaneck, N.J.
LEAD: Linda Abbey, a fifth-grade teacher at the Spalding Drive Elementary School in Atlanta, has heard the same complaints about mathematics for the last five years.

LEAD: Dr. William Bosworth Castle, an eminent hematologist who discovered the cause of pernicious anemia, died Thursday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 92 years old and lived in Brookline, Mass.

LEAD: Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam Vietnam's Communist leaders now have the long-awaited chance to open their country to a brighter economic future. But that will require them to move away from dogmatic foreign policy positions of the past. Thanks to Vietnam's withdrawal of its occupation army from Cambodia and Secretary of State Baker's new diplomatic initiative to prevent a Khmer Rouge victory there, direct talks are now under way.

LEAD: Ruby and white were the colors for the 40th anniversary celebration of the Saratoga National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame on Monday. Most of the women wore red or white, matching the decor in the tent on the museum lawn. The 550 guests danced and dined under 12 crystal chandeliers.

LEAD: The engagement of Kara Shannon Donahue to Alec Stephen Berman has been announced by the parents of the bride-to-be, Julia Halleran Donahue of Cambridge, Mass., and Dr. Robert M. Donahue of Concord, Mass.

LEAD: I was always an offensive groupie until a strong Giant defense, led by Lawrence Taylor, gave me an appreciation for the beauty of the defensive game. It makes my adrenaline flow to chant ''L. T.!'' during a game, to watch him - like an animal of prey ready to attack. What are the Giants waiting for?

LEAD: The issue underlying President Bush's moves in the Persian Gulf is not Kuwait or Saudi Arabia or even oil. It is Saddam Hussein, the Noriega of the Middle East. Like his Panamanian counterpart, he has to go. He ought to be disposed of now before his power and opportunity for doing greater damage grows.

LEAD: As Egyptian and Moroccan troops began landing in Saudi Arabia to guard against the threat of an Iraqi invasion, President Bush made it plain today that it would please him if President Saddam Hussein of Iraq were to be overthrown.
LEAD: Far from the crowds at Shea Stadium and a cellar season in the Bronx, professional baseball is on display in a quieter and perhaps purer form at minor league parks.

LEAD: As members of the Civitan Club bowed their heads in prayer, a minister reminded them of their good fortune ''in this time of crisis'' to have Representative Howard Coble as their luncheon speaker.
LEAD: After this year's Indianapolis 500, which wiped out the race's speed record at the expense of several blistered tires, it looked as if the Indy car drivers could not come up with an encore.
LEAD: Q. Our bathroom has an imitation marble sink that has developed small black slits. Is there any way to clean or repair these slits?

LEAD: October wedding plans for Wendy Ellen Light and Danal Frederic Abrams, a son of Lynn E. Abrams and Dr. Martin Abrams, both of Great Neck, L.I., have been made known by the prospective bride's father, Gerald Light of Floral Park, Queens.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Sarit Rozycki is one of a handful of young New York City developers who have been bidding up prices for prime midtown Manhattan real estate parcels recently. In her case the goal is to put up a 50-story office tower with retail space that she expects to become the first American home of Harrod's, London's swank department store.

LEAD: Paris in the Fall: Hotel Rooms Hard to Find

LEAD: It has been three years since Gov. Mario Cuomo proclaimed this to be the Decade of the Child. How is he doing? When measured against his own promises, the Decade of the Child remains a modest but worthy effort that is not yet the major initiative the Governor pledged it would be.

LEAD: I think L. T. should get a raise because if you look at the salaries of other football players who are not nearly as good as he is, you see that they earn as much as or more than he does. The Giants wouldn't be nearly as good without him. A lot of people go to the games just to see him sack the quarterback.

LEAD: THE way Judy Godino sees it, getting the family food through a cooperative buying club only looks like trouble. Granted, it entails planning weeks in advance, ordering in bulk, making sure someone can take time off from work to unload the delivery truck and separating everyone's order once it all arrives.

LEAD: Tennis Edberg Breezes: Although he is ranked as the No. 1 player in the world, yesterday was just another day at the office for Stefan Edberg as he defeated Andres Gomez, 7-5, 6-3, to advance to the final of the Association of Tennis Professionals Championship in Mason, Ohio. Edberg passed Ivan Lendl into the top spot on the A.T.P.

Jamison of Georgetown, Md., and the late William W. Jamison. Rabbi Moshe Edelman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I.

LEAD: When Browning said that a museum's reach must exceed its grasp -all right, I know he didn't quite say that, but it is hard not to wish he had after seeing the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art's major summer exhibition, ''Visionary San Francisco.'' For this is one of the most ambitious, and admirable, efforts to address the realm of architecture and cities that any museum in the country has mounted in the last decade.

LEAD: The jury in the Central Park jogger trial deliberated for a third day in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday without reaching a verdict.
LEAD: In the haste to find new sources of income in slow times, Alex. Brown & Sons seems to have forgotten that on Wall Street, you are what you take public.

LEAD: James Gleick's article ''The Census: Why We Can't Count'' (July 15) gets to the heart of our diminished capacity to collect accurate data on a large scale. The Census Bureau has (admirably, I believe) carried out the census it planned. However, the size, diversity and mobility of our society have rendered time-honored cenus methods imprecise, at best.

LEAD: The Long Island Power Authority is the wrong agency, at the wrong time, doing the wrong job in an ineffectual and inefficient manner. The threat of taking over Lilco is no longer credible, and we certainly don't need the Long Island Power Authority to decommission Shoreham.

LEAD: ''Richard III,'' Shakespeare's first enduring drama, is an extraordinary rendition of the price exacted when what is considered appropriate to manly behavior shades first into violence and finally into acts of ultimate brutality.

LEAD: Less than a week after the abrupt dismissal of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, Pakistanis seem to be in sorrowful agreement that this Western-educated ''Daughter of the East'' had let her country down at its most hopeful moment.

LEAD: Two advocates of the protection of dolphins say they were intentionally run over by Navy boats on Friday when they tried to demonstrate against a test involving explosives earlier in the day off Key West.

LEAD: Daniel Levy never edited a book before last year, and at 32 he is too young to have been involved in the tumult of the 1960's. But today the Los Angeles native is the editor of Citadel Underground and edits books about the counterculture.

LEAD: Like wines, antiques of a particular region have a taste of their own. Although many city shops specialize in country antiques, the collector learns more by regular shopping close to the source - an experience enhanced by local scenic and architectural pleasures. On the Maine coast, one area rich in antiques of regional interest is along the roads of the peninsulas extending out from this 200-year-old town on Blue Hill Bay, just across the water from Acadia National Park.
LEAD: Margaret Norris Perry was married yesterday to Donald John Allard Jr. at the Annisquam (Mass.) Village Church by the Rev. Harold B. Sedgwick, an Episcopal priest.

LEAD: No company likes to be knocked off the mountaintop by competitors, but the experience is especially galling if that mountain bears the company's name. Consider the case of the Formica Corporation, whose name is to laminated plastic countertops what Xerox is to copiers and Polaroid to instant photography.
LEAD: As an armed soldier stood guard, Carlos Gomez struggled to keep up with spinning numbers on a gas-pump meter. A gallon of premium had jumped from 41,800 intis to 1,200,000 intis.

LEAD: THAT PLACE IN MINNESOTA: Changing Lives, Saving Lives. By Ed Fitzgerald. (Viking, $18.95.) Take an executive at the pinnacle of his profession in an industry that associates creativity with alcohol. Mix in an exhilarating career full of deals sealed at three-martini lunches. Add forced retirement at the age of 65 and you have created circumstances, at least for Ed Fitzgerald, as explosive as a Molotov cocktail.

The agreement, whose terms were not disclosed, ends eight months of talks between Jerry Krause, the Bulls' vice president; Jerry Reinsdorf, the owner of the Bulls, and Grant's representatives, Kyle Rote Jr.

LEAD: The most intriguing drama of the Jets' summer of change emerged in the first half of their preseason opener tonight: Although the Jets led by only 3-0 at halftime, their offense had lifted noticeably after Tony Eason replaced his good friend Ken O'Brien at quarterback in the second quarter.

LEAD: An announcement has been made by Eben W. Pyne of Old Westbury, L.I., of the engagement of his daughter Mary Alison Pyne to Donald Bruce McNaughton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce McNaughton of Setauket, L.I. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: Robert W. Cleveland, a road builder and heavy-equipment supplier, died on Thursday at the United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y. His family said he died of lymphoma. The company that bears his name was the contractor for road work at several major projects in the 1930's and 1940's, including the New York World's Fair of 1939-40 and the Pentagon in World War II.

LEAD: As soon as i'd gotten the improbable call inviting me to Chicago to play in the Fifth Annual Equitable Old-Timers All-Star Game, my baseball dream merchant appeared. My vision was pure, uncomplicated: the brick and ivy of Wrigley Field, patriarchal, antediluvian, the baseball acropolis where Babe Ruth called his shot.

LEAD: I read Barbara Warsaw's ''The Other Side of the Welfare Debate'' (May 27) with resentment. Once again it seems someone is commenting on poverty, morality and indigence from a middle class armchair. I don't have any answers for American poverty. But I get so tired of hearing people suggesting the victims are to blame.

LEAD: Gleick is not convincing in arguing that a statistical sample would produce an improvement over the actual census count. The imperfect art of sampling, and the inevitably political selection of the ''right'' adjustment formula, would add entirely new sources of distortion to the census results. Gleick seems to forget that we are not talking about stars or fish.

LEAD: A map on April 1 with an article about Glacier National Park included an incorrect highway symbol and misspelled a nearby town. As a reader wrote recently to point out, the highway is U.S. 89, not Interstate 89, and the town is Kalispell.

LEAD: Never mind the people who get hysterical over nothing, the disorganized, the dillydalliers and shillyshalliers. It's only to be expected that these types would be prone to panic. But what about the middle-of-the-roaders, the average Jill and Joe? And what about the calm, cool and collected, the logical, the organized, the ''nothing fazes me'' types?

LEAD: If life is unfair now, it is about to become even more so for some sectors of American business and industry as the sudden rise in oil prices plays out through the economy. All companies will be affected to some degree by the fallout from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. For some, the impact may range from negligible to potentially catastrophic.

LEAD: Just as Washington was preparing to lower its profile in Europe in the new post-cold war era, the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has abruptly reminded Western Europe that it still looks to the United States to defend its vital security interests.

LEAD: STATE SENATOR Mary B. Goodhue, a popular Republican-Conservative representing northern Westchester and Putnam Counties, coasted through the 1988 election without a Democratic opponent. This year, however, promises to be different.

LEAD: For This Week: Keep up with transplanting perennials, shrubs, especially conifers, but water everything well so the roots become established. Mail orders for hardy bulbs that will be planted in the early fall months. Cut off the stalks of early-blooming hostas and daylilies; carefully remove seed pods from other perennials.

LEAD: SINCE Iraq invaded Kuwait, some investors have been prowling for ways to benefit from the turmoil in the Middle East. One ''Iraq play'' that has been spotted involves Erly Industries Inc., a Los Angeles-based food processor whose 2.8 million shares are trading at $7.125 over the counter. Like other thinly capitalized stocks, the shares have fallen modestly since the invasion, but speculative investors think they will drop further because of a disclosure in the company's annual report that one short seller described as ''too good to be true.
LEAD: Forty-six years after the Navy convicted 50 black sailors of mutiny for refusing to load ammunition on ships after an explosion killed 320 men, an effort has begun to exonerate them.

LEAD: Danny Deaver adjusted the ornate golden candelabrum on the black Baldwin grand, smiled and glided into his Chopin medley. A polonaise or two later, he peered down from his perch on the restaurant's balcony to acknowledge the applause of the diners below. Their tables were bedecked with fresh flowers, which also blossom in the men's and ladies' rooms.

LEAD: Harry (Cookie) Lavagetto, the popular Dodger infielder best recalled for his ninth-inning double that spoiled a no-hitter for the Yankee pitcher Bill Bevens in the 1947 World Series, died in his sleep Friday morning at his home in Orinda, Calif.

LEAD: In Kharkov, a city in the Ukraine, Alexander Kisler could depend on the government to provide his water. In Pittsburgh, Mr. Kisler had to depend on a legal counseling service to keep his water free.

LEAD: It could be argued that the room shown in the photograph above, at the Steinway & Sons factory in Queens, is where a piano actually begins to be a piano. Known as the belly department, it is where the innards of the instrument - the metal plate and soundboard - are fitted and set in place. After all, before it gets there, the piano is something less than musical.

LEAD: On Normannenstrasse in East Berlin, in the heart of an ordinary middle-class neighborhood, stands a massive office complex: 41 concrete buildings as grimly functional as the apartment towers that surround them. Nine months ago it was the headquarters of East Germany's Ministry for State Security - the Staatsicherheit - or Stasi, perhaps the most sophisticated and far-reaching espionage organization ever created.

LEAD: AS unappealing as the thought of baking might be on a hot summer's day, the abundance of fruit in the market makes it compelling. Dessert planning is often resolved by filling pastry or topping cake with peaches, plums, nectarines or berries.
