LEAD: Katherine Gardner Crispell, an executive assistant at the Avatar Investors Associates Corporation, investment advisers in New York, was married yesterday in Sacramento, Calif., to Michael Ross Shumway, a product manager at Timeplex Inc., a telecommunications company in Woodcliff Lake, N.J. The bride, 27 years old, is a daughter of Mr.
LEAD: Additional titles of interest:
LEAD: The political map of the Arab world has been remade, or perhaps erased, overnight.

LEAD: The list of drug traffickers in the war on drugs includes a lot of unscrupulous villains: the Colombian drug lords, gangs like the Bloods and the Crips and some U.S. pharmaceutical manufacturers.

LEAD: Consumer Credit June May April Percent change, annual rate 0.8 6.1 0.6 Producer Price Index July June May Monthly percent change -0.1 0.2 0.3 Labor Productivity II Q'90 I Q'90 IV Q'89 Percent change, annual rate 1.6 -1.9 -2.2 Unit Labor Costs (non-farm) II Q'90 I Q'90 IV Q'89 Percent change, annual rate 3.9 7.0 5.2 Electric Power Aug.

LEAD: SITTING on a hill in a modest neighborhood in this town of 4,000 year-round residents is a house the locals call the Castle on Mill Street. It belongs to William King, an architectural draftsman and graphic designer who has been building the 5,000-square-foot dwelling himself, cinderblock by cinderblock, for 18 years.

LEAD: The jurors in Marion S. Barry Jr.'s drug and perjury trial said they vowed not to discuss details of how they voted on the 12 counts on which they deadlocked, providing little help to prosecutors considering whether to retry the case.

LEAD: OIL AND THE MIDDLE EAST Prices at the Pump Gas station owners seemed to react to the oil crisis with the quickened reflexes of commodities traders last week. Retail prices soared an average of 12 cents a gallon by Wednesday, with analysts blaming psychological factors, motorists blaming gas station owners, gas station owners blaming Arabs and oil companies.

LEAD: THE show, a $2 million musical extravaganza, was in trouble. The director-choreographer had fallen ill, the production was falling apart and the producer was on the warpath. After a five-week tryout at the Kennedy Center in Washington (where the reviews were bad, but business was good), a Broadway premiere was expected.

LEAD: Linked by geography, Biarritz and St. Jean-de-Luz lie 10 minutes apart along the southernmost Atlantic coast of France. Yet the two cities are as unlike as tea and cocoa: the former elegant, reserved and with a slight English air; the latter cozy and high-spirited.

LEAD: Twilight seems to be near for the gaudy, raunchy, blazingly public pornographic emporiums in and around Times Square, many of which - by a curious circumstance - are now tenants of the New York State Urban Development Corporation.

LEAD: While American universities and corporations worry about a future shortfall of research scientists and engineers, Victor Vigdorchik, a theoretical physicist and mathematician from the Ukraine, works as a home attendant in Brooklyn.
LEAD: THE threat by Iraq to the economy of the United States is once more demonstrating that the United States is an energy giant of the undesirable kind.

LEAD: On the wall of the Fresh Air Fund office in midtown Manhattan hangs a patchwork quilt decorated with names and designs representing some of the 13 states and countless communities that are the destinations of thousands of poor city children for two weeks in the summer.

LEAD: Harry W. Faeber, a designer of printing presses and a consultant to printing concerns around the world, died at Brookhaven (L.I.) Hospital on Thursday. He was 95 years old and lived on Shelter Island. His family said he died of pneumonia.

LEAD: From Yehudi Menuhin to Stevie Wonder, American music has a long tradition of Wunderkinds, though few if any have demonstrated the range of talents commanded by Harry Connick Jr. In the last three years, the 22-year-old entertainer from New Orleans has released no less than five albums. This week three of them - a number matched only by New Kids on the Block - are listed on Billboard's pop album chart.

LEAD: When Willie Randolph sits in the dugout this weekend and looks across the field, the faces he sees are young, unfamiliar and full of uncertainty. The Yankees are no longer the team Randolph spent 13 years playing for; they are not even a facsimile.

LEAD: Until this summer, said Kory T. Morrow, a 16-year-old high school student here, he never even considered opening his own business. But with the guidance of the Minority Youth Entrepreneurship Program at the John M. Olin School of Business at Washington University in St. Louis, he and four other youths wrote detailed plans to open a mail-order software company.
LEAD: Peter Chermayeff was flying home from Japan two and a half years ago when he looked out at the Pacific and saw the answer to his problem.
LEAD: TO ALL APPEARANCES A LADY By Marilyn Bowering. 336 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

LEAD: The nicest discovery that a world champion can make about a training match is that it was unnecessary. And that is the conclusion that Gary Kasparov can draw from his recent six-game practice series with Lev Psakhis at the La Manga Chess Club in Murcia, Spain.

LEAD: Cynthia Louise Tavs, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Tavs of Miami, was married last evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York to Marko Cyril Remec, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter P. Remec of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Kevin V. Madigan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

LEAD: The traveler heading north on Water Street in Sandwich, Mass., will encounter a scene that conjures up the archetypal New England village. As the road winds toward the center of Cape Cod's first settled town (1637), it passes several 17th- and 18th-century buildings on the shores of tranquil, wooded Shawme

LEAD: The cheers of 500 supporters washing over him, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. asked the people of the nation's capital for forgiveness today and urged citizens and Federal prosecutors to help bind the wounds left by his 10-week drug and perjury trial.

LEAD: What do you wear with leggings, cat suits, ski pants or micro-miniskirts? Boots. Or at the very least, shoes that look like boots. That's the big news in fall footwear. Even regular shoes are cut high on the vamp for what fashion people call a ''choked up'' look.

LEAD: Since January, Doron Ilai, a 31-year-old graduate student in clinical psychology at the University of Texas, has helped 60 undergraduate volunteers confront one of their worst fears: claustrophobia.

LEAD: Kathleen Mary Cozzarelli, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James D. Cozzarelli of Chalfont, Pa., was married there yesterday to Michael Brian McCann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. McCann of Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. James W. Devlin performed the ceremony at St. Jude Roman Catholic Church.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The nation, it seems fair to say, has never been in quite the same kind of economic bind it is in now.

LEAD: THE HOME GIRLS. By Olga Masters. (Norton, $18.95.) The women in Olga Masters' stories do not triumph. They rarely smile and are often mean. Most simply endure. Yet they are powerful, somehow positive characters. Like most of the works of Masters, an Australian who died in 1986, the stories in ''The Home Girls'' tell of poverty, sadness, dreams and lost opportunities, often seen through the eyes of children forced to grow up too soon or women bowed by a relentlessly patriarchal society.

LEAD: Is this a trick question? Just total the starting defensive unit's salary and divide by two. That's what L. T. is worth. He is the ''G'' in Giants. Lawrence Taylor is the Ultimate Wrecking Machine. JOHN SHITEMI Brooklyn

LEAD: IN the state's public colleges, tuition will be higher. At Division of Motor Vehicles offices, lines will be longer. And on state highways, potholes will deepen before they are filled, more litter will accumulate before it is removed, and more time will pass before the deer accidentally killed by a truck or a car disappears from the side of the road.
LEAD: FACT: A lot of Americans have hit their mid-40's - the age at which, traditionally, bright people step onto the lower rungs of the upper management ladder.
LEAD: Teaching the Easy

LEAD: Macy's has announced it will open a store in downtown Providence, which has no major department store. It will be an anchor of Providence Place, a $300 million mall, office and hotel project to be built not far from the State House lawn.

LEAD: The latest spat over the accuracy of television ratings should not be dismissed as just another round of posturing among symbiotic elements of the advertising industry. The rift marks no less than the collapse of the ''social contract'' that for decades bound the networks, advertisers, agencies and, ex officio, the viewers they buy and sell.

LEAD: With state subsidies in place, plans are advancing for a 14-unit condominium in White Plains for buyers with modest incomes. A one-bedroom apartment would cost $95,991 and a two-bedroom $112,181, said Jane Henderson, executive director of the White Plains Housing Information Service, the not-for-profit developer.

LEAD: A 22-year-old man was charged in the shotgun slaying of his father in their Islip, L.I., home yesterday after they argued about the father's throwing the son's electric fan into the garbage, the police said.
LEAD: To the Editor: Congratuations to Craig R. Whitney on his article ''Heady Days in Prague'' (Travel, March 18). A classic.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Rebels are advancing on the capital in an attempt to depose President Samuel K. Doe before a five-nation West African peacekeeping force arrives to impose a cease-fire and set up elections.
LEAD: Camela Irene Smyke and David Scott Moskin were married yesterday at the Meeting House in New Marlborough, Mass., by the Rev. William A. Johnson, an Episcopal priest.

LEAD: WAVES By Bei Dao. Edited by Bonnie S. McDougall. Translated by Bonnie S. McDougall and Susette Ternent Cooke. 208 pp. New York: New Directions. Cloth, $22.95. Paper, $10.95. THE AUGUST SLEEPWALKER By Bei Dao. Translated by Bonnie S. McDougall. 140 pp. New York: New Directions.

LEAD: SICK-BUILDING SYNDROME, a disorder that medical and environmental professionals say is widespread, but largely unregulated, refers to vague illnesses reported by people who work in large office buildings where the windows are inoperable.
LEAD: MUSICAL IN THE MAKING

LEAD: Slid in among video's new releases this summer are documentaries worth noting. One is ''Common Threads: Stories From the Quilt,'' the 1990 Academy Award winner, to be released next month by HBO. Broadcast by HBO-TV last year, the tape presents five profiles from the AIDS Memorial Quilt, begun in 1987 by the Names Project in San Francisco.
LEAD: If Valley Hospital's cardiac surgery unit is closed, lives will be lost (''Cardiac Surgery Unit Fights for Its Life,'' July 15).

LEAD: For 40 years, Louis L. Friedman has cursed the darkness and lit a few candles. As a New York State Senator from Brooklyn in the early 50's, he sponsored a bill requiring landlords to put lights in front of apartment buildings. He believed this would deter muggers and make it less perilous to navigate stairways at night.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The engagement of Joanne Sydney Lessner to Joshua David Rosenblum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray H. Rosenblum of Pittsburgh, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alford H. Lessner of Newburgh, N.Y. An October wedding is planned.

LEAD: CLYDE LYNDS is an artist who combines the talents of a sculptor, a painter, an engineer and a magician. He casts monumental sculptures in stone; like slow silent fireworks, patterns drawn with points of light seem to move across their surfaces. Although the lights move as subtly as the hands of a clock, their mesmerizing quality compels the viewer to experience the work in time as well as space.

LEAD: The staff at Danbury Hospital in Connecticut has grown accustomed to a strange machine trundling through the corridors. It is a robot called HelpMate that is being tested as a courier by its developer, Transitions Research Corporation of Danbury, to fetch things, like a late meal tray.

LEAD: When Cindy Benson was growing up she wanted to be a tap-dancer: someone, as she recalls in her cabaret act, like ''Shirley Temple and Agnes de Mille rolled into one.'' The singer goes on to declare mischievously that she finally got her wish. In the current Broadway production of ''Cats,'' she portrays a 200-pound tap-dancing feline named Gumbie.
LEAD: Pauline Lichtenstein, former director of research and planning at Hofstra University, died August 4 at home in Manhattan. She was 65 years old.
LEAD: Maria Shriver did not have a baby in order to get into prime time; it only worked out that way.

LEAD: On a stage at Pinewood Studios, surrounded by the gilded trappings of British privilege and power, the American actor John Goodman plays a common man - actually a piano player from Las Vegas - who becomes the King of England.

LEAD: Worldwide orders for new ships have begun to recover after one of the industry's longest slumps. Yet the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, for one, has recently disbanded a team of managers, designers and engineers capable of building new ships at the company's yard here.
LEAD: Wayne Grady, perhaps golf's most accomplished runner-up, will try to fight off the man who used to hold that dubious distinction in the final round of the P.G.A. Championship on Sunday.

LEAD: In June, just before the start of the Little League playoffs, which lead to the World Series in Williamsport, Pa., the South Shore team from Staten Island heard words that championship franchises dread: ''Break them up.''
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ''I've never put anything on that looked so great,'' Teresa Shapiro said, pirouetting in a black crepe dress with a white satin peplum. She had come to Bergdorf Goodman to see the clothes Anthony Muto had designed for Joan Raines.

LEAD: Neckties, you may have noticed, are loosening up a little. Gone with the wind are those lockstep power ties that turned gray suits into Wall Street uniforms. In their place are wider, splashier, more individualistic ties that put zip into any suit, regardless of its color. Most of these ties trace their roots to Italy, or more specifically, Florence, and their designs, roughly, to the school of Pop Art.

LEAD: Joanna Louise Fowler, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Howland Auchincloss Fowler of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Eric Carl Jonsson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan R. Jonsson of Honolulu. The Rev. D. Worth Carson performed the ceremony at the National Presbyterian Church in Washington. Mrs. Jonsson, 27 years old, will begin work in September as an investment analyst for the Capital Research Company in San Francisco.
LEAD: How can investors in mutual funds maneuver safely through the choppy waters of the current stock market?

LEAD: The excellent article about the jeopardy to the Valley Hospital's cardiac surgery-coronary angioplasty program raised many valid points. However, there are a few items that require additional clarification.

LEAD: The lifetime ban of Ben Johnson has proved to be short-lived. Canadian officials announced last week that Mr. Johnson would once again be allowed to compete for his country. The West Indian born Toronto sprinter was told he could never again run for Canada after he forfeited a gold medal in the 1988 Olympics for using steroids.
LEAD: The Soviet Union has evacuated all but 700 of its 8,000 citizens living in Iraq, Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis of Italy said today.

LEAD: An article on July 22 about an increase in the number of women on corporate boards misstated the age of Catalyst, a research and advisory organization for women in the business world. Catalyst is 28 years old; its Corporate Board Resource service, which helps place women on boards, is 13 years old.

LEAD: The human race may owe its rise to the survival of the foulest. Our hominid forebears, said Louis S. B. Leakey, the anthropologist, smelled so rank that hungry predators recoiled, allowing our unappetizing species to flourish and invent civilization. Brains and an opposable thumb helped, too.
LEAD: Q. Our bathroom has an imitation marble sink that has developed small black slits. Is there any way to clean or repair these slits?

LEAD: The rents that the Santa Fe Trail tore through the earth of Missouri, Kansas, Oklahoma and New Mexico serve as one great metaphor for travel. Now they are followed ''in pursuit of an experience that is never quite brought to completion.'' (The words are those of the trail historian Marc Simmons.) Traveling the Santa Fe Trail from Kansas City to Santa Fe is addictive, hallucinogenic, for without the forgotten fears of Indian attack or thirst or childbirth to dispel the boredom, finding the historical remains of the trail in the empty prairies becomes a desperate necessity.
LEAD: THE army did it.

LEAD: THE David Smith nudes at the Montclair Art Museum come directly from Knoedler & Company, the Manhattan gallery that administers the artist's estate. As art money gets tighter, there will doubtless be more such liaisons, but this one has - or had - a small snag built in.
LEAD: LARRY RIVERS By Sam Hunter. Illustrated. 358 pp. New York: Rizzoli. $75.

LEAD: THE Summer Music series in Waterford will close on Saturday with the traditional pops concert. The program, at 8:30 P.M., will feature ''great Gershwin, Hollywood gems, Grucci fireworks and other treats for the entire family.'' The Gershwin is the Piano Concerto in F, with Jon Klibonoff as soloist.

LEAD: I was recently an angioplasty patient at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood. I live and work in nearby Wyckoff. The fact that the procedure was performed at Valley Hospital insured that a network of physicians who know me personally were available for consultation.
LEAD: Less beer and more restrictions on it are on tap for Eagles fans at Veterans Stadium this fall as the main parts of a plan to reduce drunken rowdiness in the stands during football games.

LEAD: ''Ancient forests: Rage Over Trees,'' a National Audubon Society special, tonight at 8 on the Public Broadcasting Service, was shown on the Turner Broadcasting cable system last September - and therein lies a tale. About three weeks before the original presentation of the hourlong documentary on the controversy over logging in the Pacific Northwest, the Stroh Brewing Company, which had planned to give $600,000 toward the
LEAD: Want a major league expansion team? If so, you had better be ready to answer questions on everything from parking to population and lighting to luxury boxes.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Because of the Dominican Day Parade, Madison Avenue will be closed today from 37th to 56th Streets from noon to 4 P.M.

LEAD: GENOME The Story of the Most Astonishing Scientific Adventure of Our Time - The Attempt to Map All the Genes in the Human Body. By Jerry E. Bishop and Michael Waldholz. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

LEAD: The new director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said last week that he would keep the Authority's $6-billion plans to renovate bridges, tunnels, airports, marine terminals and the PATH system moving forward.

LEAD: Ever since its invention a shade more than 150 years ago, photography has been seen as a medium of truth and unassailable accuracy. Photographs have been used by scientists to map the planets and identify subatomic particles, by police and prosecutors to solve crimes and convince juries, by newspaper and magazine editors to document events around the world - and few think twice about it.

LEAD: The commitment of American forces to the Arabian Peninsula is altering the debate over the military budget, promising to slow the momentum for deep spending cuts and to hasten a shift in military planning from superpower standoffs to regional conflicts.
LEAD: Sherif S. Byrd was only 10 years old when he was struck down by a drug dealer's bullet as he played in the spray from a fire hydrant two summers ago on Jesup Place.

LEAD: The Giants added another missing body today when Gary Reasons, a seventh-year inside linebacker, signed a two-year contract for more than a million dollars. Coach Bill Parcells said Reasons might play Monday night against the Bills in Orchard Park, N.Y., in the Giants' first preseason game.
LEAD: Patrick Halpin probably thought the mausoleum he built 125 years ago would be his family's final resting place.

LEAD: Collectors of United States proof sets may be in for a nice surprise - cents in some of the sets lack a San Francisco Mint mark and this is making such sets valuable. Within one week of the discovery, proof sets lacking the mint mark on the cent are being bought for $600.
LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Ministry today praised the Arab leaders who condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and agreed to send Arab troops to Saudi Arabia.

LEAD: To the Editor: Joan Gould writes of Ravenna: ''Nothing of tourist interest was added from the completion of the mosaics'' (in the sixth century) ''to the opening of Benetton.'' Apparently she is unaware of the Tomb of Dante, a building erected in 1780 to enshrine the older tomb by Pietro Lombardo (1483).

LEAD: In his statement to the nation on Wednesday explaining the decision to send American troops to the Arabian Peninsula, President Bush said that the defense of Saudi Arabia was of ''vital interest'' to the United States. But Mr. Bush and his top aides have not clearly defined just how the Iraqi invasion and annexation of Kuwait touches the lives of Americans or affects their future.

LEAD: About all Prokofiev's ''War and Peace'' and Mozart's ''Cosi fan tutte'' have in common, it might be plausibly argued, is that both play in two long acts. Forget for the moment that Mozart sustains lengths more skillfully than anybody, let alone Prokofiev. Such gross differences are easy to point out.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: They were the legal profession's gilded generation, an army of lawyers without limits. As law students, they were wined and dined and wooed by the most prestigious law firms in New York. Once hired, they began settling into a frantic but fantastically lucrative life. It was a life of glamour, prestige and, they assumed, stability.

LEAD: A PANEL of Bush Administration officials who investigated infant mortality recommended 18 steps to reduce infant deaths in the United States. Half the recommendations were marked ''high priority'' because they could have a ''direct and immediate effect.''

LEAD: Young, gifted and doomed - that's the prognosis for jazz musicians in the movies. On screen, jazz is a siren call, an obsession, an addiction that disrupts the lives it touches and consumes anyone under its sway. The musicians are pure souls, verging on idiot savants, who are so wrapped up in the music that they invariably mess up both business and romance.

LEAD: To the fulminant debate on future television standards - which concerns the introduction of high definition television (HDTV) and its impact on existing broadcast technology - some calm but cutting observations have recently been added by James C. Davies, an executive of Barco Inc., a company that makes video projectors in Kennesaw, Ga.

LEAD: Closings in the week ended July 28 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill $490,000 4 East 95th Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,500-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, maid's room, windowed kitchen, three exposures; maintenance $1,077, 33% tax-deductible (Broker: Carnegie Hill Properties)

LEAD: While gentrification has brought changes to the Park Slope section of Brooklyn over the last decade, the transformation has involved mostly restoring and modernizing the neighborhood's picturesque rowhouses and stately mansions.

LEAD: Thirty-five years ago, a 6-year-old named Eloise first stampeded through the corridors of the Plaza Hotel, and children are still enchanted by her kinetic escapades. So what better way to celebrate the anniversary of Kay Thompson's story, with illustrations by Hilary Knight, than to return to the scene of Eloise's crimes.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Laidlaw of Chappaqua, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Margaret Elizabeth Laidlaw to John M. Nebens, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lewis M. Nebens of Millwood, N.Y.

LEAD: Betty Burnham Hinckley, president of the real-estate firm of Wood Associates of Greenwich, Conn., died on Thursday at Greenwich Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived in the Riverside section of Greenwich. Her family said she died of renal cancer.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: THE FIVE OF HEARTS An Intimate Portrait of Henry Adams and His Friends, 1880-1918. By Patricia O'Toole. Illustrated. 459 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter. $25.

LEAD: I am baffled by Barbara S. Cuiffo's article about her children (''College Is Out and the Brood's Back Home,'' Opinion Page, July 22). What was the point of it? Were we supposed to find her grown children cute or charming in their incredible self-absorption? Were we supposed to feel sorry for her because of the extra work they caused her?

LEAD: A review of ''Time of Change: An Insider's View of Russia's Transformation'' in The Times Book Review today misidentifies the reviewer, Abraham Brumberg. He is the editor, not the author, of ''Chronicle of a Revolution: A Western-Soviet Inquiry Into Perestroika.''

LEAD: Fat, crude, surly Superintendent Andy Dalziel literally plays God in BONES AND SILENCE (Delacorte, $17.95), the 10th entry in Reginald Hill's outstanding procedural series featuring the bluff Yorkshire detective and his sensitive and contemplative associate, Inspector Peter Pascoe. The role of the Deity, which Dalziel assumes for a pageant of medieval mystery plays in his cathedral city, suits the Old Testament personality of the detective, who has achieved local fame as ''a man who walked through brick walls as he headed for the truth.

LEAD: THE families of the victims of Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, bound together by the tragedy of the crash, have been split by a debate over legislation that in large part arose from their anger, grief and determination to prevent future terrorist bombings.

LEAD: Throughout the commissioner's investigation of George Steinbrenner's association with Howard Spira, the Yankee owner argued that baseball should also look into the connection between Spira and Dave Winfield. Spira, Steinbrenner contended, became involved on the periphery of baseball through Winfield.

LEAD: SINCE Nelson Mandela walked to freedom in February, South Africa has witnessed a peculiar and often troubled courtship between those who stand for the competing nationalisms that have vied for the nation throughout its modern history. Mr. Mandela and President F. W. de Klerk must now be wondering how long the coziness will last.
LEAD: FATAL VOYAGE The Sinking of the USS Indianapolis. By Dan Kurzman. Illustrated. 331 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.

LEAD: Hector Camacho retained his World Boxing Organization junior welterweight title here tonight when he won a unanimous 12-round decision over Tony Baltazar at the outdoor stadium of Caesars Tahoe hotel and casino.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: George Whiteley, a teacher, author, sailor and marine biologist, died Wednesday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 81 years old and lived in West Chester, Pa.
LEAD: American English is not what it used to be.
LEAD: BITTER HARVEST Gordon Kahl and the Posse Comitatus: Murder in the Heartland. By James Corcoran. Illustrated. 274 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

LEAD: Very little seafood reaches the table in New York City without passing through hands of criminals, according to Frank H. Wohl. Mr. Wohl, who was appointed by a Federal court in 1988 to oversee the Fulton Fish Market with an eye to curbing the racketeering that has long been rampant there, said in a report last week that an ''atmosphere of lawlessness'' persisted.
LEAD: Paige Power and Scott Andrew Metzger were married yesterday at the Chapel of the Snows in Stratton, Vt., by the Rev. John T. Scully, a Roman Catholic priest.
LEAD: THE county's Board of Elections, which has drawn Albany's attention for the inability of its two commissioners to work together, may have new leadership after this year's elections.

LEAD: THE Endresens, father and son, are good at making new money by exporting products to the Old World. They are so good at it that Jan Endresen, the son and president of the family-owned company, Aerotech World Trade Corporation of White Plains, recently received a special Presidential citation. It was the same award his father received in 1975 when he headed the business.
LEAD: Choreographers choreograph dances. Dancers dance dances. Ballet dancers dance ballets.
LEAD: The alliance between the United States and Western Europe will face a clear but so far unspoken danger in the Middle East. It is important to face it in advance.

LEAD: The ever-popular headband has acquired a new versatility and softness. In most cases, this means a wide band of fabric pulled on like a ski band and adjusted in a variety of ways to the wearer's liking.

LEAD: To the Editor: A wonderful part of air travel used to be the ''open ticket,'' which meant passengers could use their prepunched airline tickets whenever they wished. Open tickets still exist, but they cost an arm and a leg. Most nonbusiness budget travelers are locked into nonrefundable, nonchangeable flights.

LEAD: Time and the seven-figure auction prices have proven them right, these men and women who first collected and commissioned Impressionist art. Their taste has meant enough to history and the marketplace to warrant several books. IMPRESSIONISM: The First Collectors (Abrams, $75), however, isn't one of them.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Kristin Lynne Powers, a banking executive, and Kevin T. Rover, a lawyer, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Minikahda Club in Minneapolis by the Rev. Dr. Harold G. S. King, a minister of the United Church of Christ.
LEAD: An illustration with the About Men column in The Times Magazine on March 19, 1989, about a veteran's return to a Korean War battlefield, appeared with an incomplete credit.

LEAD: Charlie Hough won his third straight decision and the Texas Rangers escaped jams in the seventh and eighth innings today to beat Chicago, 7-5, and drop the White Sox four and a half games behind Oakland in the American League West. The White Sox stranded 14 runners and could not overcome an early 6-0 deficit.
LEAD: Although a Dartmouth College student might spend years preparing for a Wall Street career, a group of executives is reversing the process, going from the board room to the classroom.

LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration will test the nation's honey because some produced by a large supplier in Massachusetts was found with 22 times the legal limit of a pesticide. The investigation, first reported Friday by The Boston Herald, involves apparent misuse of fluvalinate, a pesticide that the Environmental Protection Agency describes as ''low to moderately toxic.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Carolyn Kangleon Roska, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jose C. Roska of Bloomsburg, Pa., was married yesterday to Erik Helge Weiner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Erik Weiner of Falkoping, Sweden. The Rev. Joseph H. Fennessy performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Berwick, Pa.
LEAD: The United Nations embargo on trade with Iraq and Kuwait appears to be throttling shipments of food, military spare parts and other essential goods into the area.

LEAD: Is it possible to get too much of a good thing when it comes to color films? It is if you can't figure out which one to use. In recent years film manufacturers have bombarded photographers with so many new and improved emulsions that for many choosing one has become something of a guessing game.

LEAD: Abby Brown Westervelt, a candidate for a doctorate in classics at Harvard University, and Hayden Newhall Pelliccia, a professor of classics at Cornell University, were married yesterday at the summer home of the bride's parents in Warwick, R.I. The Rev. Frank H. Geer, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. James P. Maguire of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Melissa Maguire to William James Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy F. Sullivan of Dumont, N.J. A September wedding is planned.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: WESTCHESTER'S mail service received a dubious distinction recently when the Postmaster General of the United States, Anthony M. Frank, called it ''the worst in the nation.''

The Rev. Frank H. Geer, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

LEAD: To the Editor: Joan Gould's otherwise lovely article on the mosaics of Ravenna (Travel, June 10) misstated the Arian heresy. The point at issue between the Arians and the Orthodox in the fourth to sixth centuries was not whether Jesus was fully human or a god who merely appeared to be human. Both sides in the controversy condsidered Him fully human and our fellow sufferer; the idea that he only appeared to be human was a characteristic of several other heretical groups, Gnostics, Apollinarians and Monophysites, each in their own way.

LEAD: Bob Tewksbury pitched a six-hitter and Todd Zeile had a homer and double as the St. Louis Cardinals got a season-high 17 hits and beat the slumping Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-0, today for a three-game sweep.

LEAD: If you are defending with a A-10 holding that surrounds an honor on your right, it might seem obvious to cover if that card is led. But honors should not be covered routinely, and it may be right to play low even if, as in the diagramed deal, everyone knows that the other defender has nothing in the suit.

LEAD: Emily Johannah-Marie Taravella, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Taravella of Queens, was married yesterday to Mark Andrew DiTaranto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent DiTaranto of the Bronx. The Rev. John C. Mulqueen performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth's Catholic Church in Ozone Park, Queens.

LEAD: Sitting on a hotel balcony with the soaring peaks of the Caucasus Mountains at his back and two hawk-eyed bodyguards watching him from below, Zviad Gamsa khurdia recently offered his view on the cut-throat world of Georgian politics.

LEAD: Julie K. Rubin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Rubin of Merrick, L.I., was married yesterday to Paul J. Goldberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Goldberg, also of Merrick, at the Lyman Estate in Waltham, Mass. Rabbi Henry Zoob officiated. The bride graduated from the University of Massachusetts and received a master's degree in audiology from Purdue University.
LEAD: Government troops reported killing 24 people in a raid on Friday on two villages in the Kashmir valley in search of Muslim separatists who had ambushed an army convoy.

LEAD: Frank Wilson was one of the last speakers a few weeks ago when more than 350 people gathered in a library meeting room to protest the construction of a $3 million shelter for the homeless in this small river city.

LEAD: As the title character in ''Death Takes a Holiday,'' Christopher Reeve has another role commensurate with his larger-than-life presence. Replacing his bright Superman cape with a cloak of spectral darkness, he is a not-so-Grim Reaper. More than anything, it is the actor's drollness that helps invigorate this creaky vehicle, revived at the Williamstown Theater Festival.

LEAD: Peter Warzel has been named president and chief executive of the newly created office of the president at United Artists Theater Circuit Inc., the theater exhibition subsidiary of the United Artists Entertainment Company, the cable and movie theater company that is based in Denver.

LEAD: ON the tennis court, his terms remain totalitarian. He stalks his stage like a maestro, and before issuing the inimitable strokes that trill forth from his racquet like music, he wants to hear a pin drop.

LEAD: The bearded trucker finishing his pancakes at the Hillview Cafe called himself Big Dog, his call-sign on the citizen's band radio as he takes oil pipes, produce and other loads from Texas, Oklahoma and California into Canada.

LEAD: Treasury financings this week are confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. By late Friday the rate was 7.40 percent on the three-month bill and 7.29 percent for a six-month bill.

LEAD: Zerline L. Goodman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Goodman of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Andrew Rothenberg, a son of Dr. Eleanore Dubin Rothenberg and Stanley Rothenberg, both of New York. Rabbi Charles Feinberg performed the ceremony at the Vassar College Chapel.

LEAD: Hitless More Than Once Q. There have been seven no-hitters in the major leagues this season, with a different team the victim each time: Seattle, Detroit, Oakland, Toronto, St. Louis, the Chicago White Sox and the Yankees. Has a team ever been no-hit more than once in a season? A. In this century, it's happened 10 times - seven times in the American League and thrice in the National - but no team has ever suffered the embarrassment of being held hitless in a game more than twice in a season.
LEAD: Helen Drees Ruttencutter, a musician and a writer for The New Yorker magazine, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan at the age of 63. Her family said she died of a brain tumor.

LEAD: The freeze on Iraqi and Kuwaiti investments and bank deposits announced by President Bush and officials of other Western countries last week is not likely to be costly to American banks, according to Government data and bankers' estimates.

LEAD: Cookie Lavagetto, who died at age 77 in his sleep Friday morning at his home in Orinda, Calif., was famous for one thing: He was the Brooklyn Dodger who struck a celebrated pinch-hit in the 1947 World Series. Thoughts of Lavagetto the ballplayer led to the notion here that great moments in sports don't last as long as they used to.

LEAD: Sara Seegar, an actress who appeared on and off Broadway, in films and on television, died yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital in Langhorne, Pa. She was 76 years old and lived at Stone Meadows, Newtown, Pa., with her husband, the actor Ezra Stone, who said she died of a cerebral hemorrhage.
LEAD: * Lifeline Systems Inc., Watertown, Mass., a provider of computerized health-care services, to Cabot Advertising, Boston, with a budget of $1.5 million.

LEAD: As head of a command once viewed as something of a misfit in the Pentagon's organizational charts, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf finds himself playing a pivotal role in the largest United States military operation since Vietnam.

LEAD: David Norman Dinkins is a man of moods, and eight months into his term as Mayor of New York City, his aides have learned to judge them by the satiny warm-up jackets he works in. If he appears in his favorites -gifts from the pop singer Janet Jackson or the Grammy Awards organization - the day is fine.

LEAD: While the United States national soccer team played the consolation match of the Marlboro Cup of New York tournament at Giants Stadium today, some people in the stands were focusing on the question of who will be coaching the team in future competitions, including the 1994 World Cup.

LEAD: Los Angeles and New York lie far apart in many ways, but they draw closer for two days next month. About 100 Angelenos are flying east to hear ANDRE PREVIN lead the Los Angeles Philarmonic at the benefit opening on Sept. 26 of Carnegie Hall's centenary season.
LEAD: The $5.95 paperback - a mainstay of bookstores and airports - is going the way of the 2-cents plain, the 25-cent candy bar and, in New York, the $6 movie ticket and the $1 subway token.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: CAL RIPKEN JR. hasn't missed a day's work in more than eight years, an impressive enough achievement for a bus driver, a college professor or a stockbroker. It is all the more remarkable in that Ripken is the Baltimore Orioles' shortstop.
LEAD: Pat Hurst of San Leandro, Calif., rallied from three holes down to capture the 90th United States Women's Amateur Championship today in 37 holes over Stephanie Davis of Bainbridge Island, Wash.

LEAD: Dr. George M. Parks, dean of Pace University's Lubin Schools of Business, died on Saturday while scuba diving in Bermuda, the university said yesterday. He was 56 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

LEAD: The Mets want you to know they are not in a swoon, a slump or even a sinking spell. Not even after losing 6 of their last 10 games and 2 straight to the Chicago Cubs. And don't waste your time fretting over Frank Viola just because he has been kayoed the last two times out and won only twice in his last seven starts.

LEAD: The jump in oil prices and drop in supplies stemming from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait will do far less damage to the world's economy than did the 1973 and 1979 oil shocks, economists and energy experts say.

LEAD: Who's to Pay, who just before the race didn't have a rider, collared Steinlen, who nobody thought could lose, to score a two-length upset victory today in the $88,200 Bernard Baruch Handicap at Saratoga Race Track.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The fragile alliance forged last week by 10 Federal judges trying to coordinate and resolve quickly tens of thousands of asbestos personal injury disputes will complicate settlement talks in many large cases, making their immediate resolution much more difficult, lawyers and judges said yesterday.

LEAD: GIVEN the squabble over who would represent the United States Equestrian Team in show jumping at the 1990 World Equestrian Games, which wound up in Stockholm last week, you would have thought it was the riders who did the jumping and the horses who hung on for dear life rather than the other way around.

LEAD: Dr. Audrey Michelle Weissman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Weissman of Old Westbury, L.I., was married yesterday to Adam Davis Goodfarb, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman R. Goodfarb of Ardsley, N.Y. Rabbi Solomon Goldman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I.

LEAD: In 1976, when the cold war was cold indeed, Lazar Berman appeared virtually unannounced from behind the Iron Curtain and provided the West with an exotic glimpse of a secretive Soviet musical life. On his first United States tour, Mr. Berman made an overwhelming impression as a pianist of great physical power - a performer who did more than just overcome technical problems; he seemed to crush them into insignificance.

LEAD: Time seems to have stopped for almost everyone involved in the Central Park jogger trial as the jury deciding the fate of three defendants charged with the rape and attempted murder of a jogger deliberated for a fourth day yesterday without reaching a verdict.

LEAD: CURT WARNER, the Seattle Seahawks' leading career rusher, remembers standing on the sideline at the Kingdome last season while Steve Largent was honored as a Seahawk for all seasons. Largent's No. 80 jersey was retired and Largent received tribute after tribute for his dedication, loyalty and production as one of the finest receivers in pro football history.

LEAD: Newspapers blow across the dusty, threadbare Great Lawn of Central Park. Abandoned cars block a running path in Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx. Citywide, trees that were once regularly pruned and meadows that were once regularly sodded now receive infrequent care.
LEAD: Marty Barrett hit a tie-breaking two-run double in the ninth inning today that sent the Boston Red Sox past the Seattle Mariners, 7-2.

LEAD: In northwest Connecticut, there is a celebrity tennis tournament of a distinctly different sort. The public is not invited, the players are discreet if not sheepish when talking about it and trophies are given for the worst players.
LEAD: A Las Vegas showman was awarded $4.2 million on Saturday in his defamation lawsuit against an animal rights group that made public a videotape of his striking his orangutans.

LEAD: Behind a tiny American flag on his office desk, Cliff Wilson, the state commander of the American Legion, talks of Pentagon cutbacks, glasnost and the current Middle East crisis with cool detachment.

LEAD: IT used to be that the only crowd anybody ever noticed on the Missouri River was a tower of tricos, a gray cloud of flies 30 feet high at the water's edge an hour or two after sunrise. A welcome crowd, for when the flies mated and fell to the water in midmorning a frantic hour or two of trout feeding and trout fishing followed.

LEAD: Susan M. Levin, a daughter of Charlotte S. Levin of Wilmington, Del., and the late Dr. Jules S. Levin, was married yesterday to Dr. David A. Liebergall, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon S. Liebergall of Suffern, N.Y. Rabbis David Wolpe and Leonard Gerwirtz co-officiated at Temple Har Zion in Philadelphia.

LEAD: Soul II Soul's concert at the Palladium on Friday night sputtered along amiably, a sort of pleasant variety show. The group, which looked as if it were going to dictate the future of pop and dance music with its ''Keep On Movin' '' album from last year, has a new record plummeting down the charts; the
LEAD: Jan Carlzon, the president and chief executive of Scandinavian Airlines System, does not suffer from delusions of grandeur.

LEAD: * Allstate Insurance Co., Northbrook, Ill., a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Co., promoted Rita P. Wilson, a vice president, to senior vice president of corporate relations, effective Sept. 1. She replaces Lawrence H. Williford, who is retiring.

LEAD: Madge O'Boyle stood in front of the apartment building in Woodside, Queens, where she has lived for three decades, since shortly after the Irish native arrived in the United States, and chatted with neighbors on the sun-baked steps.
LEAD: For a man long known for his caution, President Hosni Mubarak has put himself in a hot seat, at the center of a storm he himself warned could be ''horrifying.''

LEAD: In a duel between two players battling their own histories as much as each other, Wayne Grady transcended a career of near misses today while Fred Couples remained a prisoner of his past in the final round of the 72d P.G.A. Championship.

LEAD: ''Thomas, do you care if your peanut butter sandwiches are squished?'' Nancy Inglis called to her 9-year-old, racing to get him ready for day camp. The humidity was so bad that the white bread had swollen. ''Oh, well,'' she said, smooshing in two sandwiches. The stove said 7:07.

LEAD: Vornado Inc., the New Jersey real estate developer, said yesterday that it intends to acquire at least $15 million worth of the stock of Alexander's Inc. and perhaps as much as 25 percent of the company's common shares outstanding.

LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that the pace at which it distributed its new A.T.&T. Universal card, a combination calling card and general purpose credit card, had accelerated sharply this summer.
LEAD: Is widespread legal sports betting inevitable or preventable?

LEAD: A survey on the views of American business leaders was released last week, and the findings indicated a ''guarded optimism'' about the economy. Because of the Middle East crisis, an update was quickly made to get the executives' reaction. They supported President Bush's stand.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Old MacDonald, presumably, had a rooster to wake up to (45 decibels from across the barnyard). In New York City, he could not hear the crowing for the noise.
LEAD: The GTE Corporation has named Terry S. Parker president of its new Telecommunications Products and Services Group.

LEAD: In a move that was both technical and political, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. left the Democratic Party today and declared himself an independent, a position that allows him to seek re-election as Mayor or a seat on the District of Columbia City Council.

LEAD: Oil prices moved up more than $1 a barrel on world markets yesterday as traders reacted to the American blockade of Iraqi oil and the Saudi decision to turn away an Iraqi tanker that had sought to load at a pipeline terminus.
LEAD: A pilot whose plane crashed mysteriously off the Bahamas last year, was among four men charged today in connection with an investments plan prosecutors said was fraudulent.
LEAD: One of the Magellan spacecraft's backup computers rejected commands when a memory chip failed, but the problem is not expected to hinder the $744 million exploration of Venus, engineers say.

LEAD: Despite objections from the nation's tiny Protestant minority and qualms among senior Government officials, Poland's public schools will begin voluntary classes in religious education this fall.

LEAD: Sears, Roebuck & Company categorically denied a report that its chairman, Edward A. Brennan, had been given an ultimatum by its board of directors last week to shape up the company's sagging retail operations or leave. Crain's Chicago Business reported today that Mr. Brennan had been told at a directors meeting last Wednesday that he had six months to achieve marked improvement in retail profits.

LEAD: * Allen Group., Melville, L.I., an automotive products manufacturer, completed two separate acquisitions: the purchase of a 50 percent interest in a new-partnership joint venture with Metropolitan Air Research Testing Authority, Nashville, and the purchase of 80 percent of the stock outstanding of Grayson Electronics Co., Lynchburg, Va.

LEAD: King Hussein of Jordan, whose position in the gulf crisis has been equivocal, accused the United States in a speech published today of creating an ''explosive situation'' that threatens the entire Middle East.

LEAD: Words: After all the aggression, alarm, councils of state, hostages and troop movements, the controversy of the instant in the Iraq-Kuwait crisis is merely semantic. Should President Bush's orders to U.S. forces to halt shipments of Iraqi oil be termed a blockade, a quarantine, an interdiction or a barricade?

LEAD: The American Express Company, the nation's largest financial-services concern, is aggressively challenging the Western Union Corporation at a business it pioneered and has long dominated: wiring money.

LEAD: For years, law enforcement, policy-makers and the media have been preoccupied with the menace of cocaine and crack. In the meantime - partly as a result of our single-minded focus on cocaine - heroin has quietly and quickly extended its reach in this country.

LEAD: Andre Danesh, the president of the Allied Financial Corporation, said today that he was in talks to raise funds to acquire control of the Southmark Corporation, the Dallas-based real estate and financial services concern that emerged on Friday from Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

LEAD: In Georgia, a runoff election is required if no candidate receives 50 percent of the vote in a primary. The Justice Department says that's a form of racial discrimination, not a prudent exercise of democracy. The department's lawsuit is a new and welcome sign of sensitivity to civil rights by the Bush

LEAD: APPLE Computer Inc. has given its blessing to a small Colorado company that makes a nine-pound Macintosh-compatible portable. The rival portable machine, called the Outbound Laptop System, is made by Outbound Systems Inc. of Boulder. It is smaller, lighter and - if you already own a Macintosh Plus or SE - less expensive than Apple's own Mac Portable.

LEAD: Higher crude oil prices are starting to affect prices in the chemical industry, a leading consumer of petroleum products, executives of chemical companies say. And because products derived from crude oil are used to make many of the basic materials that go into a host of other products, notably plastics, consumers will soon feel the pinch.
LEAD: In a bid to bolster United States-Soviet trade, President Bush today raised a longstanding ceiling on the number of Soviet business people permitted to live and work in the United States.

LEAD: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu on Monday abruptly put off his plans to travel to the Middle East amid indications that his advisers were divided and uncertain about how to promote Japan's interests there.

LEAD: Hedley Donovan, a former editor in chief of Time Inc. who is credited with greatly enhancing the journalistic stature of Time magazine, died yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan and Sands Point, L.I.

LEAD: The Bush Administration's announcement that American warships are enforcing United Nations trade sanctions against Iraq left the United States largely isolated today at the Security Council, with most of the 15 members saying a new Council decision would be needed before military force could be used.

LEAD: Lawyers for George Steinbrenner were prepared last week to accuse Commissioner Fay Vincent of severely damaging Steinbrenner's reputation and business by misrepresenting their agreement that will end the owner's management of the Yankees next Monday.

LEAD: The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation today reached a tentative agreement that could end a parts plant strike that has forced eight other plants to close or curtail operations, a company spokesman said.
LEAD: Prices of precious metals continued to advance yesterday, fueled by the Middle East crisis. Gold jumped to more than $400 an ounce for the first time in five months.
LEAD: The jury in the Central Park jogger trial, in its fifth day of deliberations, asked for photographs of the victim and the testimony of a police detective who questioned one of the defendants.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday blocked enforcement of a law that would have prevented telephone customers in New York from reaching ''dial a porn'' numbers without first requesting access to the services.

LEAD: When the Giants chose Rodney Hampton in the first round of the National Football League draft last April, some people wondered what they would do with another running back. They found out tonight when Hampton, on his first carry in a professional game, ran 89 yards for a touchdown.

LEAD: Bruce Coslet, the Jets' head coach, called for improvement by his quarterbacks yesterday and reaffirmed that Tony Eason would be the starter when the team plays its second preseason game, against the Chiefs in Kansas City, Mo., on Saturday night.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today issued a sweeping decree to restore the rights of unrehabilitated victims of Stalinist repression, saying thousands of innocent people still bore a ''stain of injustice.''
LEAD: College football, already beset by whirlwind changes, is faced this week with a new legal challenge to its authority.

LEAD: The World Is Burning By Alex Shoumatoff 377 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $19.95 The Burning Season The Murder of Chico Mendes and the Fight for the Amazon Rain Forest By Andrew Revkin 317 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $19.95.

LEAD: The feud is over now, but it is still not behind Dave Winfield. Even though he is separated from George Steinbrenner by several months and thousands of miles, Winfield acknowledged today that he remains bound to him, and to the Yankees.
LEAD: Events in the Middle East have revived concern on Wall Street about the prospect of a securities transfer tax - something the financial community is dead set against.
LEAD: Indian soldiers tried to capture a mountain outpost, starting a firefight with Pakistani soldiers along the cease-fire line dividing the disputed region of Kashmir, Pakistan said today.

LEAD: THE power of subliminal messages is taken as an article of faith by many people. Critics of advertising often take for granted the power of ''hidden persuaders.'' Many parents stand convinced that messages buried in rock music are poisoning their children's minds. And for vendors of audio tapes, the power of the imperceptible exhortation to strengthen memory or take off pounds is more than an article of faith - it is a profit center.
LEAD: The fire in Consolidated Edison's electrical substation yesterday brought some important parts of Wall Street's business to a halt, closing several exchanges and slowing trading.
LEAD: Pakistan agreed today to join an international force deployed to defend Saudi Arabia against Iraq.

LEAD: Dr. Phillip Frost, a physician who is chairman of the IVAX Corporation, a pharmaceutical concern based in Miami, has acquired a 7.7 percent stake in Ferro Corporation. Mr. Frost said he received permission in March 1989 from Government antitrust regulators to raise his stake in Ferro, a Cleveland-based chemical concern, to as high as 15 percent.

LEAD: A fire early today in a Dallas boardinghouse killed four residents, and a fifth, Margaret Ann Wright, 46 years old, was charged with arson, the authorities said. Nine people, some of them clients of the Dallas County Mental Health-Mental Retardation Center, lived at the house, they said, but they could not confirm whether Ms.

LEAD: FOR most people, a computer - like a VCR, an automatic teller machine, or perhaps even an automobile - is a ''black box.'' You do something to it, it does something in return, and what happens in between, within the box, is a mystery.
LEAD: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has sharply scaled back the Navy's Seawolf attack submarine program and has trimmed the service's purchase of new destroyers, the Pentagon said today.

LEAD: ANTIBIOTIC-resistant bacteria seem to be more prevalent in certain parts of the world, particularly in developing countries, suggesting that such bacteria could become a serious public health threat, according to a new study.
LEAD: Hundreds of correction officers, protesting the assault and robbery of another officer by inmates last week, blocked the entrance to Rikers Island yesterday.
LEAD: Jay Rubin, president emeritus of the New York Hotel and Motel Trades Council, A.F.L.-C.I.O., died on Sunday at his home in Newtown, Conn. He was 86 years old.

LEAD: A four-alarm fire in an electrical substation knocked out power to the skyscrapers of lower Manhattan yesterday, disrupting financial markets, darkening trading floors, trapping hundreds of people in elevators and forcing thousands of others to walk down endless shadowy flights of stairs lighted by emergency beacons.
LEAD: France's growing network of high-speed trains may be the envy of many Europeans, but plans to extend it to the country's southern Provence region are stirring more protests than pride.

LEAD: The deployment of American forces to Saudi Arabia, the largest United States military operation since the Vietnam War, has severely strained the ability of the Pentagon to move thousands of troops and tons of weapons and equipment quickly over great distances.
LEAD: Because of the Feast of the Assumption, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City tomorrow.

LEAD: Tonight, at 10 P.M., NBC brings on the latest entry in the 1990 prime-time network news magazine glamour stakes. ''Cutting Edge With Maria Shriver'' follows close upon NBC's ''Real Life With Jane Pauley'' and CBS's ''Face to Face With Connie Chung,'' which have made fast starts from the post. If ''Cutting Edge'' does as well in the ratings, Ms.
LEAD: Resort Comes Into Its Own

LEAD: Navy Cuts Seawolf Plan In a move expected to save $7 billion in military spending through 1994, the Pentagon plans to cut in half the program of building new Seawolf attack submarines and to reduce the purchase of destroyers. Page A14. The Growing Gap in Wages There are several new theories that explain the gap between the incomes of the wealthiest and poorest Americans, which is now the widest since World War II, even after adjusting for inflation.
LEAD: Dr. Simon Grolnick, a psychoanalyst and a teacher, died on Sunday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset L.I. He was 60 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I., and East Hampton, L.I.

LEAD: Practically ever since the debate on the National Endowment for the Arts began to rage last year, the issue that has divided the agency's detractors and supporters has been whether the endowment has financed pornography and blasphemy or whether it has acted to protect the right of American artists to express themselves freely.

LEAD: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States rose last week for the first time in three weeks, jumping by 26, to a total of 992, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year earlier, the count was 858. Ike Kerridge, a vice president of Baker Hughes, said the increase might be related to the Iraqi oil embargo.
LEAD: The Persian Gulf crisis is recasting the United States' relations with two of its oldest Middle East allies, Israel and Jordan. Upset by the support
LEAD: The 20th century has chipped away at an idyllic tract of land that surrounds Walden Pond, where Henry David Thoreau used as a retreat to ponder the natural order.

LEAD: Eight years after it developed a genetically engineered rabies vaccine, a Philadelphia research institution gained final approval today to conduct the first outdoor field trial of the vaccine in the United States.

LEAD: With the aircraft carrier Saratoga expected to reach the Mediterranean Sea by today, the United States will have about 10,000 ground troops in Saudi Arabia and about 20,000 sailors and airmen on more than 30 ships in the Mediterranean, the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf region.

LEAD: Iraq has transferred between $3 billion and $4 billion in gold bullion, foreign currencies and goods seized from Kuwaiti financial and commercial institutions to Baghdad, Arab bankers in London and the Persian Gulf region said today.

LEAD: Just a year after L. Douglas Wilder made history in Virginia by becoming the first black elected Governor of a state, national attention has been focused on the chances of new breakthroughs by black candidates for governor in Georgia and South Carolina and for the Senate in North Carolina. But when
LEAD: Bondholders in the financially troubled Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. of Australia have failed to agree to the sale of the company's brewing assets, a company director said last week.

LEAD: As President Saddam Hussein of Iraq confronts the United States and its allies on the Saudi border, he must also watch his back against potential military enemies at home, intelligence analysts say.

LEAD: IN at least two cases, the rare northern spotted owl has bred with the more common barred owl, but scientists say it is too soon to tell whether the crossbreeds are isolated quirks of nature or the progenitors of a new owl species.
LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has begun landing tests of a drag parachute system to be installed in the space shuttles to help slow them down after they touch down.
LEAD: * BBS of America, Spring Valley,N.Y., an importer of German road and race wheels, appointed Percy Herrmann vice president of sales and marketing.
LEAD: The stock market recovered from an opening slump to finish sharply higher yesterday, showing resiliency in the face of uncertainty over Middle East developments.

LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc. said it planned to offer 5.9 million new shares of common stock together with about 1.1 million shares to be offered by individual stockholders. Of the shares to be sold, 5.6 million will be offered in the United States by Goldman, Sachs & Company, Salomon Brothers Inc. and Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

LEAD: Abductors in Lebanon have freed a Swiss hostage, Elio Erriquez, after 10 months of captivity, turning him over to Syrians, who took him to Damascus and released him early today to the Swiss ambassador.

LEAD: B. D. WONG, the actor who was an initiator of the ''Miss Saigon'' dispute, met yesterday at City Hall with Deputy Mayor BARBARA FIFE and DENNIS DELEON, who heads the Mayor's Commission on Human Rights.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the Florida Democratic primary for governor misstated the home town of Representative Bill Nelson, one of the contenders. He lives in Melbourne, not Miami.

LEAD: The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the support given to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq by the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, has created a deep rift within the organization's leadership.

LEAD: Pat Cash, continuing his long journey back after severing an Achilles' tendon 16 months ago, recovered tonight to beat Mats Wilander, 1-6, 7-5, 6-3, in the opening round of the Volvo International tennis tournament.

LEAD: While labor unions are still actively campaigning for a greater Government role in health insurance, a growing number of them have agreed to participate in discount health-care plans. With no immediate prospects for a national system, union officials say the discount plans can help stretch the limited dollars available for wages and other benefits as health costs keep rising.
LEAD: A 3-week-old Bronx boy was shot to death in his crib Sunday night when a gun his father was cleaning discharged, the police said.
LEAD: Two airlines said yesterday that they had lowered some domestic air fares for a short time. Other airlines have raised most ticket prices to account for higher fuel prices.

LEAD: Horace Grant, a 6-foot-10-inch forward who averaged 13.4 points and 7.9 rebounds as a starter for the Chicago Bulls last season, has signed a $6 million three-year contract extension, The Chicago Tribune reported yesterday. The agreement would make Grant, 25 years old, the second-highest-paid Bull after Michael Jordan, and one of the highest-paid forwards in the National Basketball Association.

LEAD: Deion Sanders showed up at the Atlanta Falcons' training camp in Suwanee, Ga., yesterday minus a $37,000 chunk of his $4.4 million salary and bonuses. After going through a physical examination in the morning, Sanders suited up and practiced at cornerback for the Falcons in an afternoon scrimmage.

LEAD: The Cincinnati Reds, making good on Manager Lou Piniella's brash victory prediction, pushed their lead in the National League West back to a comfortable six and a half games tonight by rallying from a four-run deficit to beat the San Francisco Giants, 6-5.

LEAD: The Mets, still waiting for penalties to fall on three of their star players for participation in the free-for-all with the Philadelphia Phillies last week, said yesterday that they expected hefty fines but would appeal any suspensions.

LEAD: Denise Grace Caspler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy S. Caspler of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married Sunday at her parents' home to Masaaki Tahara, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Susumu Tahara of Takamatsu, Japan. Rabbi Joel Goor officiated.
LEAD: THOUSANDS of surgeons are learning a new technique for removing gallbladders that could greatly simplify the operations now performed on some 500,000 Americans each year.

LEAD: SCIENTISTS have known for years that nitrogen, the gas that makes up 78 percent of the Earth's atmosphere, is pumped into the air by microbes that convert nitrates in the soil into nitrogen gas. Now scientists in Germany have suggested that there is another way the gas is released into the atmosphere: through the burning of trees, plants and grass by humans.

LEAD: An entry in the Bank Earnings listing in Business Day on Thursday misidentified a company that had a loss of $2.9 million in the quarter ended June 30. It was the Homestead Holding Corporation, a Middletown, Pa., savings and loan holding company, not the Homestead Financial Corporation, a savings and loan and real estate development company based in Millbrae, Calif.

LEAD: TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc., a multinational food products company operated by the financier Reginald F. Lewis, reported yesterday that its second-quarter net income doubled, to $17.5 million, from $8.8 million in the corresponding period last year. The company's revenue increased 26 percent for the quarter, to $403.7 million, from $320.5 million in the period last year.

LEAD: Rusty Staub and Joe Morgan were teammates and friends with the Houston Astros in the mid-1960's and shared an interest not only in doubles and double plays, but in drivers and divots, too. So Staub, a member of a nearby country club, had naturally taken Morgan as his guest to play golf at this club a few times.

LEAD: Because of a power failure caused by a fire yesterday at a Consolidated Edison plant in New York, trading was halted around 1:15 P.M. on the American Stock Exchange and the five New York futures exchanges - the New York Mercantile Exchange; the Commodity Exchange; the New York Cotton Exchange; the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, and the New York Futures Exchange.

LEAD: With some success, prison systems in New York and a few other states have established ''boot camps'' to ease crowding and provide a more constructive routine for young prisoners. Allyn Sielaff, New York City's new corrections commissioner, proposes such a system for the city's jails; he makes a good case.
LEAD: Japan's trade surplus shrank 10.3 percent in July from the period a year earlier, largely because of increased imports, the Finance Ministry said last week.

LEAD: The international embargo on Iraqi trade tightened noticeably today when an Iraqi tanker sailed away from a Red Sea port without taking on crude oil, and two or three other ships, according to the White House, failed to land Iraqi-bound cargoes in the Middle East.
LEAD: Debt
LEAD: An American jury sent a stern message to the Attorney General the other day: The Government of the United States should never stoop to acting like a pimp.
LEAD: At least 500 Americans who were trapped in Kuwait by the Iraqi invasion have been able to leave the country and more are expected to depart, the State Department said today.

LEAD: Ellis Island, the 24-acre pile of landfill in New York Harbor that was the first stop for millions of immigrants hoping to enter the United States between 1892 and 1924, is again poised for the surge of crowds. This time the visitors will be coming to see a $156 million restoration of the island's ornate Beaux-Arts main building, which is to reopen Sept.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: PRINCESS ANNE, the daughter of QUEEN ELIZABETH II of Britain, will be 40 years old tomorrow. The Queen's sister, PRINCESS MARGARET, will turn 60 on Tuesday. There are no official plans to celebrate either birthday, but The Daily Mail has reported that ''a bash at Balmoral'' - Balmoral Castle in the highlands of Scotland - is planned for Princess Margaret's birthday.

LEAD: Gillian Williams stands at the front of Room 20 of the San Gabriel Avenue Elementary School. She directs 30 second-graders making their family trees. ''Who goes with you to Disneyland? Who goes with you on picnics?'' That her voice lacks authority is understandable; she is an unusual student teacher who only recently took over the class.
LEAD: Chip orders declined in July as the American semiconductor industry's leading indicator continued the downward slide it began in June, a trade group said today. The Semiconductor Industry

LEAD: Ethyl Eichelberger, a flamboyant presence on the New York theatrical scene for the last 15 years as an actor, performance artist, clown and playwright, died over the weekend at his home on Staten Island. Black-Eyed Susan, an actress who was a frequent leading lady in his plays, said that he had AIDS and had committed suicide by slashing his wrists.

LEAD: SATELLITE monitoring shows that Antarctica has shed more than 11,000 of its 5 million square miles of ice since the 1970's, and scientists say further study is needed to determine whether the findings indicate that global warming is melting polar ice.

LEAD: A ''rogue computer'' used by New York City's Parking Violations Bureau is responsible for $19 million worth of tickets issued annually to people who do not own cars, people whose cars have been stolen and people who have paid their fines, City Council President Andrew J. Stein charged yesterday.

LEAD: Designers think clearly about the resort season. Their shows, presented without elaborate fanfare, are concise; the clothes are not obscured by special effects. So it is easy to catch the message.

LEAD: The actress ESTHER ROLLE, known for her 1970's role as an iron-willed matriarch in the television series ''Good Times'' and more recently for her portrayal of the housekeeper in the film ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' was injured in a one-car highway accident on Sunday afternoon in Nevada. The driver was killed and two other passengers were injured.
LEAD: Donald J. Trump will use the First Boston Corporation rather than Merrill Lynch & Company to reorganize some of his casino debt, people involved in the negotiations said yesterday.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Oil Jolt
LEAD: Curtis Mayfield, the musician, was seriously injured last night when part of the stage collapsed during a windstorm at a free concert in Brooklyn.
LEAD: Every 10 minutes or so, another plane lands in the Saudi desert with American troops and equipment.

LEAD: The United States securities industry has ''substantial overcapacity'' that is similar to the overcapacity in the banking industry, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said here today.

LEAD: ''The homosexuals are in a battle against American values,'' the speaker says. ''Their ultimate aim is to have the American people accept the proposition that their perverted 'life style' is as worthy of protection as race, creed and religion. I do not buy that. I say to them, 'Bosh and nausea.' ''

LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency gave permission last week for Allied-Signal Inc. to begin marketing a substitute for chlorofluorocarbons, a chemicial that has been found to cause damage to the earth's ozone layer. The new substance, called HCFC 141b, can replace chlorofluorocarbons, or CFC's, in solvents and foam insulation, said William M.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: In isolated pockets of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains, it is possible to gaze for miles and lose track of the century.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A2-11 The embargo on Iraq tightened noticeably when an Iraqi tanker sailed away from a Red Sea port without taking on any crude oil, and two or three other ships failed to land Iraqi-bound cargoes in the Middle East, the White House said. Page A1

LEAD: Throughout the country, groups are organizing counter-celebrations of the quincentennial of the year 1492. They are preparing to counteract the official celebrations of the 500th anniversary of Columbus's landing in the Americas. A New York group, tentatively called Columbus In Context, had its first meeting last month.
LEAD: Dave Winfield faced the Yankees for the first time since he was traded last May and had a good laugh about it.

LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steelmaker. said it planned to sell its railroad freight car division as part of an effort to divest itself of assets unrelated to its basic steelmaking operations.

LEAD: Despite its serious optical flaws, the Hubble Space Telescope has provided scientists with a detailed look into a prolific star-forming area, clearly showing 60 stars in an area once thought to have only 27 stars.

LEAD: A strike against the United Parcel Service of America Inc., the world's largest package shipper, was averted today when drivers and handlers rejected the recommendation of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' leadership and narrowly ratified a new three-year contract.
LEAD: A former Chinese journalist says security forces killed more than 450 Tibetans in the capital of Lhasa in 1989, the Observer newspaper has reported.
LEAD: ''The foreign power's aim to re-gain control of this Arab land and those who live on it.'' - King Hussein. [A9:5.]
LEAD: Perched on the gunwale of a skiff here, Juarez Cristiano Gomes chuckled to himself as he watched a trail of small bubbles rising to the surface of Tucurui Lake.
LEAD: More than 200 Roman Catholic bishops holding secretive meetings here will get their first glimpse on Tuesday of a new anti-abortion campaign put together by a public relations company.

LEAD: A huge screen in Central Park will mark the setting tonight and tomorrow of ''The Video Drive-In,'' a free event that will hark back, more or less, to the era of drive-in movies, when families and lovers watched the latest Hollywood romance or adventure from the relative privacy of their cars.

LEAD: Near the start of the Soviet writer Sofiya Prokofyeva's two-character drama ''Sin Testigos'' (''Without Witnesses'') the wife in a marriage that came apart nine years earlier declares in a soliloquy that the submergence of her personality in her husband's became a kind of death. Now she feels nothing.

LEAD: President Bush is returning to Washington on Tuesday, a day earlier than scheduled, and plans to hold a budget meeting and a news conference where aides said he would prod the Democrats to come to a ''reasonable'' agreement on the budget.

LEAD: A Federal judge in Brooklyn took the first steps yesterday toward carrying out a national plan for resolving asbestos personal injury cases. Federal District Judge Jack B. Weinstein said that he had appointed Marvin E. Frankel, a former Federal judge, as a special master to conduct hearings on part of the plan.
LEAD: The fire at a Consolidated Edison plant yesterday showed just how fragile - and resilient -the nation's trading systems are.
LEAD: Maybe it's just another manifestation of the current casual attitude toward clothing, but bare tanned legs are this summer's in-the-city look. It's a touch of the country come to town.

LEAD: An article on Saturday about a dispute between the Federal Government and New York State over an $80 million Westway grant incorrectly characterized a state application to avoid repaying the grant. The application dealt with potential development between the Hudson River bulkhead and the ends of the river piers, not the area between the bulkhead and the West Side Highway.

LEAD: Huge, super-efficient drift nets of the kind that ignited a storm of international protest in the Pacific Ocean have been spotted for the first time in the Atlantic near the Caribbean, raising fears that Atlantic marine life could be threatened and that commercial and sport fisheries important to the eastern United States could be devastated.
LEAD: President Hashemi Rafsanjani has declared the readiness of Iran to restore security to the Persian Gulf area and he called for the army to be put in readiness.

LEAD: It often happens that an apparently trivial spot card assumes crucial importance in the late stages of the play. Keep your eye on the heart six on the diagramed deal, played in the final round of the Regional Swiss Team Championship in Cherry Hill, N.J., in mid-June.

LEAD: The New Jersey Devils yesterday completed payment for the acquisition of Peter Stastny, the 33-year-old center, in a trade with the Quebec Nordiques last March 6.
