Yesterday, they named Randy Velischek, a 28-year-old defenseman, who played in 62 games last season for the

LEAD: B. Kliban, an art-school dropout whose cartoons of hordes of round-eyed, striped cats became a multi-million-dollar craze, died Sunday at the University of California Medical Center in San Francisco, two weeks after undergoing heart surgery. He was 55 years old and lived in Corte Madera, Calif.

LEAD: Men and women, jackets off and ties askew, streamed out of the emergency exit doors of the World Financial Center by the hundreds, and Marjorie Greenberg, a 22-year-old recruiter for American Express, was leading the pack. She vaulted onto the West Side Highway just after 2:30 and hailed the only visible taxi leaving the downtown maw, looking as elated and thankful as an American serviceman hauling himself onto the last chopper out of the American Embassy compound in

LEAD: Pierre A Rinfret, the Republican gubernatorial nominee, said today that he would solve the perennial problem of finding sites for landfills and garbage incinerators by forcing local governments to bid for the right not to build them.

LEAD: BASKETBALL U.S. Holds Off Argentina Kenny Anderson scored 32 points and the United States, which squandered most of a 22-point second half lead, held off Argentina, 104-100, last night in the quarterfinal round of the World Basketball Championships in Buenos Aires. The United States, which went 3-0 in the qualifying round, will face Australia on Tuesday as quarterfinal-round play continues.
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about the National Veterans Golden Age Games, on the On Your Own page of SportsMonday, misidentified the man at left. He was Frank Jones.
LEAD: Shaeri Reinsilber left her husband at home in Toronto and drove eight hours with a girlfriend to the Catskills resort region here for one thing and one thing only: the food.
LEAD: In a move that could signal a break in Liberia's military stalemate, a rebel leader agreed today to hold cease-fire talks with a group of West African leaders.

LEAD: When the wind blows, as it does in these days of squall and bluster at the Cape of Good Hope, the black plastic roof of Mongezi Sonqwelo's home flaps like a loud and loosened sail so that he has to pause in a winter's tale that has much to do with both the weather and South Africa's future.

LEAD: On hearing of the Franco-Polish grandmaster Savielly Tartakover's pronouncement, ''Sacrifices only prove that someone has blundered,'' you might be inclined to put it down as just one of the witticisms for which he was always ready to sacrifice the truth. It's not entirely invalid, although it is an exaggeration to claim that beautiful games must take their start in gross errors.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The 72d P.G.A. Championship was an amalgam of social revolution, overly severe course conditions, unexpected fades by top players and just-as-unexpected contenders.
LEAD: The Safety-Kleen Corporation has announced the retirement of its chairman of the board and changes in several top management positions.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Q How much carbon dioxide does the average person exhale into the atmosphere each year? Could this make a significant contribution to the burden of greenhouse gases?

LEAD: With George Steinbrenner having to surrender day-to-day control of the Yankees next Monday, there are signs that the succession process is in disarray. The Yankee owner's 18 limited partners are scrambling for solutions even as they prepare to gather in Cleveland tomorrow to select a new general partner.
LEAD: THE ultimate goals of medicine are to prevent illness and to promote public health, and thus many would expect them to be a prime focus of medical education.

LEAD: People who work in the same field and are of similar age and education are finding that their wages, once very close, now extend across a much wider range, new studies of Labor Department data show.
LEAD: Several N.B.A. players yesterday challenged the league's new pre-pension benefit plan, saying that a lowering of the salary cap as a result of the plan will hurt free agency.

LEAD: Kuwait's London-based overseas marketing and refining company said today that it was negotiating with Saudi Arabia to supply some of the 400,000 barrels of crude oil and refined products that it had received from Kuwait each day before the Iraqi invasion.

LEAD: The team that will represent the United States against Austria in the Davis Cup semifinal round next month in Vienna will be Andre Agassi and Michael Chang in singles, and Rick Leach and Jim Pugh in doubles, the United States Tennis Association said yesterday.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in a session that effectively ended shortly after 1 P.M. yesterday, after a fire in lower Manhattan led to a widespread loss of electrical power.

LEAD: The day's experiment had gone up in smoke. The evening's artless triumph had been followed by the late night's crushing loss. First place in the National League East had been yielded and second place once more occupied.

LEAD: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo told the country's leading state court judges today that the Federal courts had increasingly ceded the task of protecting basic liberties to the state courts and in the process had abandoned their obligation to address a number of national problems.
LEAD: Bow Valley Industries on Monday said that Jerry R. Wright would join the Canadian oil and gas company as president and chief operating officer.

LEAD: A Georgia O'Keeffe painting has been formally declared lost by the Art Institute of Chicago, 20 years after a search for the misplaced painting began. JAMES WOODS, director of the museum, said on Monday that its staff had hoped that the work, ''East River from the Shelton,'' would turn up. But a recent inventory of 1,500 pieces in the museum's department of 20th-century paintings and sculpture made it clear the painting was nowhere to be found.

LEAD: * Avis Inc., Garden City, L.I., named Robert D. Cardillo vice president of sales and marketing.

LEAD: There is a water shortage in much of France this summer thanks to a three-year drought, but in Paris it seems that only Badoit is affected. Badoit is a popular mineral water and since the recent spell of record-breaking heat here, there just has not been enough of it to go around.
LEAD: A car bomb exploded next to the government palace as Peru's new President, Alberto Fujimori, was meeting with advisers, injuring four passersby, the police said today.

LEAD: Basketball U.S. Team Closes In on Semifinal The United States overcame a 13-point deficit with seven minutes to play and beat Australia by 79-78 yesterday at the World Championships at Buenos Aires. The victory virtually assured the United States of a semifinal berth. The team would advance to Friday's semifinals if Puerto Rico beat Argentina later last night, or if the Americans beat Puerto Rico today in the last quarterfinal game.
LEAD: Just two weeks after the Shoal Creek Country Club in Alabama granted its first black membership, a club in Westchester County has begun a drive to enroll its first black members.

LEAD: A map of the Middle East that appeared Monday and Tuesday incorrectly located the United States aircraft carrier group headed by the Saratoga. The group arrived in the Mediterranean Sea only yesterday.

LEAD: If you like farce you had to love the outcome of the Government's case against Marion Barry, Washington's most famous film star (a.k.a. ''the Mayor'') and leading contender for the title of Playboy of the Western World.

LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation moved today to raise the premiums banks pay for deposit insurance by $1.1 billion, or 30 percent, next year. The action reflects increased concerns about the safety of the deposit insurance system and about the effects of depressed real estate prices on commercial banks and the overall economy.

LEAD: Scali, McCabe, Sloves, the New York agency that has been hit hard by account losses in the last year, lost another yesterday when the Procter & Gamble Company switched its Old Spice and Santa Fe men's toiletries and fragrances to Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago.

LEAD: The New York State Dormitory Authority yesterday offered $229 million worth of tax-exempt bonds through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities. The bulk of the securities offered in the negotiated sale were three term bonds maturing in 2010, 2018 and 2020.

LEAD: The Texaco Corporation announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement with the Soviet Union's Ministry of Geology to study the feasibility of joint oil production in Arctic oilfields south of the Barents Sea. Texaco officials said the Soviets had identified reserves of at least five billion barrels of oil in the region.

LEAD: Last month, a six-member team of American high school students placed third in the 54-nation International Mathematical Olympiad in Beijing. Only China and the Soviet Union scored ahead of the Americans.

LEAD: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association, whose financial troubles have been related primarily to the plummeting value of its ''junk bond'' portfolio, reported a loss in the second quarter because of other factors, including problem real estate, the institution said today.
LEAD: The Bush Administration is considering the partial mobilization of reserve forces to help deter an attack on Saudi Arabia by Iraq, Pentagon officials said today.

LEAD: To The Living Section:

LEAD: Calvin Klein has updated the erotic and often surreal advertising for his Obsession fragrance by using the quirky romantic touch of David Lynch, the creator of the provocative television series ''Twin Peaks.''

LEAD: Two months ahead of schedule, ''Trump: Surviving at the Top'' goes on sale today in bookstores across the United States. In his new book, Mr. Trump says that his financial and personal troubles have been compounded by his own mistakes, by a softening economy and by unfair and sensationalized news reports.

LEAD: A dying institution of government will conduct its own last rites in a marathon session to start tomorrow. In the process, New York City's Board of Estimate can improve - or obstruct - the life of the city it has managed for 92 years. Dozens of items are on the agenda for its last meeting; four in particular will determine how the board, and its members, are remembered.
